HEADLINE: Top Arkansas Lawyer Helped Hillary Clinton Turn Big Profit

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Dean Baquet, Jeff Gerth and Stephen Labaton and was written by Mr. Gerth.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Starting just before Bill Clinton was elected Governor of Arkansas, Hillary Rodham Clinton made about $100,000 in one year in the commodities market with the help and advice of a friend who was the top lawyer for one of the state's most powerful and heavily regulated companies.
The investments, made in a commodities trading account that was opened three weeks before Mr. Clinton was elected Governor in 1978, substantially altered the finances of the Clintons. At the time, Mr. Clinton was Attorney General. He and his wife were rising stars in Little Rock whose salaries were modest by the standards of their peers. 
 The proceeds helped them to buy a home, to invest in securities and real estate and eventually to provide a nest egg for their young daughter, according to the couple's associates and a review of the family's financial records.
 
Tyson's Fortunes
 But the trades, which came to light during a two-month examination of the Clintons' finances by The New York Times, also left them in the position of having relied significantly on the help of one of the state's premier powerbrokers, James B. Blair, a Clinton confidant who at the time was the primary outside lawyer for Tyson Foods Inc., of Springdale, Ark., the nation's biggest poultry company.
During Mr. Clinton's tenure in Arkansas, Tyson benefited from a variety of state actions, including $9 million in government loans, the placement of company executives on important state boards and favorable decisions on environmental issues. Even today, critics in Congress and elsewhere have complained that the Clinton Administration is too close to Tyson and the poultry industry it dominates, sparing it from some of the tougher Federal inspection guidelines enacted against the meat industry.
 
Her Money, Her Risk
 In a written statement, the Clintons' personal lawyer, David Kendall, said today that Mrs. Clinton had traded in commodities futures "with her own funds and assumed the full risk of loss."
"She did so through two different trading accounts in her own name in Little Rock and Springdale, Ark.," he said. "Mrs. Clinton reported gains and losses on her tax returns as appropriate."
Mr. Blair, in telephone interviews on Wednesday and today, confirmed that he had encouraged Mrs. Clinton to invest in the normally risky commodity markets and to open an account at a Springdale brokerage, and that he then used his investing skills to help guide her through a series of lucrative trades.
Mr. Blair and Administration officials designated to discuss the matter -- but who would speak only on condition of anonymity -- said Mrs. Clinton had put up the stake with which she began trading. The officials would not say how much money Mrs. Clinton had put at risk.
Lisa Caputo, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary, said in a statement tonight: "Mrs. Clinton consulted with numerous people, and she did her own research. This was her own risk; the commodity investments were her own responsibility."
The Administration officials said that Mrs. Clinton also studied financial data, including some in The Wall Street Journal.
John Podesta, a White House spokesman, said tonight: "Hillary and Jim were friends. He gave her advice. There was no impropriety. The only appearance is being created by The New York Times."
Mr. Blair, who himself made several million dollars trading commodities, said he saw no conflict of interest; he said he had helped Mrs. Clinton as a close friend, not because of the position held by her husband.
Speaking of the Clintons, he said: "Do they have to go weed their friends out and say they can only have friends who are sweeping the streets? They have friends who are high-powered lawyers. They have friends who write books, who write poetry."
Mr. Blair and the Administration officials estimated Mrs. Clinton's profits at $100,000. The officials said she opened her trading account in mid-October 1978, three weeks before Mr. Clinton was elected with 63 percent of the vote. She got out of the market on Oct. 17, 1979, just as the rising market in cattle futures from which she had profited was collapsing.
 
Protecting State Jobs
 As Governor and as a candidate for President in 1992, Mr. Clinton was forthright in defending the assistance that the state government gave to Tyson, which is among Arkansas's largest employers, saying that it was good for the state's economy.
Archie Schaffer, director of media, public and government affairs for Tyson, denied that Mr. Clinton had done any special favors for the company or the Arkansas poultry industry.
"I can tell you that I disagree totally with any suggestion that the Clinton gubernatorial administration gave the poultry industry or Tyson any breaks," he said. "That's just nonsense." Mr. Schaffer said he knew nothing of the commodity trading.
The history of the commodities trades casts a new light on the Clintons' personal finances and on their relationship to the poultry industry and to Mr. Blair, who remains a powerful figure where politics and business intersect in Arkansas.
 
Source of Down Payment
 The trades have never been publicly disclosed. During the 1992 Presidential campaign, the Clintons and their aides gave conflicting accounts when asked to explain where the couple got the money to make a $60,000 down payment on a house in 1980. During the campaign, aides declined to release the Clintons' tax returns for the late 1970's and did so again today.
When the question of the down payment first arose, the campaign said it had come from an investment by Mrs. Clinton, one that the officials declined to describe. At another point, the officials released a statement in Mrs. Clinton's name that said the money had come from "our savings and a gift from my parents."
Today, the Administration officials said that the down payment had come from savings, including the proceeds of the successful commodities trade.
 
The Clintons and Blair
Low-Paid Stars, Longtime Power

Bill Clinton came from a family of modest means, and for all his political prominence, neither he nor his wife, Hillary Rodham, had ever made much money.
Mr. Clinton was elected State Attorney General in 1976, at the age of 30. His annual salary then was $26,500. Two years later, on becoming the nation's youngest governor, his salary rose to $35,000, leaving him one of the nation's lowest-paid governors.
Mrs. Clinton, like her husband a Yale Law School graduate, had joined him in teaching law at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville in the mid-1970's. For the nine-month 1975-76 school year, each was paid $18,090, a university spokeswoman said. When Mr. Clinton's election as Attorney General took them to Little Rock in 1977, she joined the Rose Law Firm there as an associate. Her starting salary is not public, but within a year after making partner in 1980 it was $46,000.
Mr. Blair, 11 years older than Mr. Clinton, was already established in the world of business and politics in Arkansas. By the late 1970's, he had become one of the state's most successful trial lawyers.
His firm, Crouch, Blair, Cypert & Waters, was in Springdale, the center of Arkansas's booming poultry industry. In addition to advising some of the state's biggest poultry companies, it represented big trucking companies and the local utility. Mr. Blair was also a force in statewide political circles. In 1974, he ran the final, doomed re-election campaign of Senator J. William Fulbright, Mr. Clinton's political mentor.
While a partner at Crouch, Blair, Mr. Blair became general counsel to Tyson, which was founded in 1936, when John Tyson began hauling live chickens from Arkansas to Chicago. Mr. Blair eventually left the law firm and went to work directly for the founder's son, Donald J. Tyson, now chairman and chief executive. Over the years Mr. Blair has served as a director of more than 20 Tyson-controlled companies across the country.
 
The Trades
Exquisite Timing In a Risky Game
 Mr. Blair said in the interview that he first ventured into the stock market in 1956, when he was 20 years old. Through the 50's and 60's, he said, he made more money in stocks than he did practicing law. In the 1970's, he began trading commodity futures.
Mr. Blair's timing was impeccable. In the tiny Springdale office of Refco Inc., a trading firm based in Chicago, a rag-tag group of brokers, some of whom had been small-town liquor salesmen and clerks, was making millions of dollars, capitalizing on a stunning boom in futures contracts prices. The office's founder, a professional poker player named Robert Bone, was a 13-year Tyson executive who had turned a knack for gauging odds into a small fortune.
Mr. Blair said Mrs. Clinton had got into the commodities market at his suggestion.
"I recommended to her that she open an account at the Refco office," he said. "I was on a streak, on a streak that I thought was very successful, and I wanted to share this with my close friends, as I did with my fiancee, as I did with my law firm, as I did with my children, as I did with my fiancee's children and as I did with the person who was the best person at my marriage, which was Hillary, a tennis partner and friend."
Mr. Blair advised Mrs. Clinton to get into the cattle futures market because, he said, "I specifically was trading the cattle futures, and thought I knew what I was doing." He added, "I'm damn good at it."
 
On Blair's Advice
 Mr. Blair, a close friend and lawyer for Mr. Bone, who was known as Red, said Mrs. Clinton had started with a small stake. Mr. Kendall declined to say today how much money she had put up.
According to trading records examined by The New York Times and people familiar with the trades, she opened her account in the Refco office, using Mr. Bone as her broker. The account was opened in mid-October 1978, when Mr. Clinton was described in Arkansas newspapers as the favorite in the governor's race.
Mr. Blair said he had helped guide Mrs. Clinton's trades. "We discussed whether she ought to be long or short" in her trades, Mr. Blair recalled, referring to betting whether prices would rise or fall. "It was done in consultation," he said. "I gave her my best advice."
Mr. Blair said that while he would make specific trading recommendations, Mrs. Clinton "determined the size of the trade."
Around the time of Mr. Clinton's 1978 election, Mrs. Clinton opened another commodity trading account, this one with Stephens Inc., a large brokerage firm in Little Rock, Administration officials said. But they said that the bulk of her trading profits had come from the Refco account.
Mr. Blair said he had nothing to do with the decision to trade from the Stephens account.
People familiar with Mrs. Clinton's trading said she had profited from most but not all of the trades.
In commodities trading, a speculator essentially bets on the future value of a commodity, like cattle or pork. Trading in such futures contracts is among the riskiest and most volatile of investments. By some estimates, more than three-quarters of all investors lose money. But a sophisticated trader, or one with special knowledge of a market, can turn a small stake into millions of dollars.
According to records and people familiar with the trades, Mrs. Clinton made most of the $100,000 in proceeds trading in cattle futures.
But after several go-go years, the cattle futures market collapsed in the fall of 1979, shattering the Refco office, leading to huge losses and lengthy litigation and sending some of the traders, including Mr. Bone, into bankruptcy.
The Administration officials said Mrs. Clinton closed her Refco account in mid-October 1979 and her Stephens account in early 1980.
Administration officials said she had got out of the market because after she became pregnant with her daughter, Chelsea, she did not have the time to keep up with developments and found the investments too nerve-wracking.
Mr. Bone does not recall how much money Mr. Blair made during the boom or lost during the bust. But he remembers that when Mr. Blair departed from the markets, "He left happy."
 
The Benefits
Proceeds Gave Clintons Nest Egg
 Other than a brief reference to $449 in commodities trading losses on their 1980 tax return, there is no evidence that the Clintons ever returned to the highly volatile commodities markets.
But their brief involvement substantially improved their fortunes. Based on the tax returns they have released, the commodity trades were by far their most successful investment.
In mid-1978, in seeking a loan from a bank in Flippin, Ark., that financed the real estate venture called Whitewater, the Clintons reported having few assets, executives of the bank have said. The main reason they got the loan, the bankers added, was the creditworthiness of the Clintons' partner in Whitewater, James B. McDougal, who at the time was a developer.
But in November 1979, shortly after Mrs. Clinton closed her Refco account, the Clintons were able to acquire $55,463 in bonds, according to their 1980 tax return. And in December 1980, after Mr. Clinton was voted out of the governor's office, the Clintons were able to make the house down payment.
Mr. McDougal has also said that in 1980, Mrs. Clinton approached him for advice about putting money in tax shelters. Mr. McDougal, who made his remarks in a 1992 interview with the Times, recalled Mrs. Clinton saying that she needed to shelter large profits that Mr. Blair had helped her make in the commodities market.
The personal ties between Mr. Blair and the Clintons have remained strong. On some visits to Arkansas, the Clintons stay at the waterfront vacation home of Mr. Blair and his wife, Diane. The Wall Street Journal has reported that on the President's inauguration night, the Blairs spent the night at the White House.
During the 1980's, Mr. Blair was appointed to the board of the University of Arkansas, where he served as chairman. Mrs. Blair, a political science professor at the university, was appointed last year to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which helps channel Federal funds to the nation's public broadcast stations.
Mr. Blair has also remained a behind-the-scenes adviser to Mr. Clinton since his first days in public office. For example, during the 1992 campaign -- and after the election -- Mr. Blair helped devise strategies for blunting criticism about the Clintons' involvement with Mr. McDougal and Whitewater, said Mr. McDougal and Susan Thomases, a campaign aide.
 
The Growth of Tyson
Company Thrived In Clinton Years
 The ties between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Blair's client remained strong as well. Mr. Clinton's record of support for the poultry industry and Tyson in particular has been a subject of debate for years in Little Rock, and it became an issue during the 1992 Presidential campaign. Even today, critics in Congress and others have accused the Clinton Administration of not being tough enough on the industry, particularly in inspecting chickens. Today, a spokeswoman for the Agriculture Department defended its record and said the department was moving to tighten inspections after years of neglect.
The criticism of Tyson's connection to the White House goes beyond its poultry interests. The company owns Arctic Alaska Fisheries, a large fish-trawling business based in Seattle. Last April, small fishing outfits in the Northwest complained that Tyson's relationship with the Clinton Administration was one reason the Government reversed course and instituted rules that would allow Arctic Alaska and other big trawlers to dominate the nation's $100 million whiting catch. The Commerce Department, which wrote the rules, denies the accusation.
Mr. Podesta, the White House spokesman, said: "The President and Jim Blair have never discussed Blair's clients' business with the Federal Government. During the Clinton Administration, we know of no instance of his ever lobbying a Clinton White House official or discussing matters of concern between his client and the Federal Government."
Throughout the 1970's and 1980's, Governor Clinton and his administration made several significant decisions that helped Tyson become one of the world's biggest poultry companies. In campaigns for Governor and President, when questioned about his support of the company, Mr. Clinton said he had fought for the industry because it was one of the biggest employers in a depressed state.
As Attorney General in 1978, Mr. Clinton intervened in a lawsuit that eventually loosened Federal regulations so that Tyson and other Arkansas poultry processors could vastly increase their productivity.
As Governor, Mr. Clinton reappointed a Tyson veterinarian to the Livestock and Poultry Commission, a regulatory body often criticized as being too close to the industry.
 
'Clinton Understands'
 Mr. Tyson, in turn, has been a major fund raiser for Mr. Clinton and has praised him for creating a friendly environment for the growth of the poultry industry.
Last year, three days after Mr. Clinton's inauguration, Mr. Tyson was asked what influence he hoped to have with the new President.
"I would be irresponsible to my company and my industry if I didn't have any input," Mr. Tyson said after a speech in Anchorage. "Clinton understands the needs of business. There were several times in our company's growth that we could have taken opportunities outside of the state, but we chose to stay in Arkansas because he understands the balance between economic development and environmental issues."
Mr. Schaffer, the Tyson spokesman, said the company received no special treatment on environmental questions. The company has spent "tens, if not hundreds of millions of dollars" upgrading its plants to avoid pollution problems, he said.
But environmentalists and many Arkansas residents have complained that the balance was often tilted toward industry. The instance they cite most frequently was a long legal battle that followed the discovery that a Tyson plant in Green Forest, a town of 1,600 in northwest Arkansas, had been leaking waste into Dry Creek.
 
After Delay, Disaster
 In 1977, the state pollution control agency reissued the license for Tyson's Green Forest plant on the condition that the company meet with city officials to work out a plan for treating its wastes. But the state never enforced the order, and in May 1983 the waste from the plant seeped into the town's drinking water. Residents became ill, and 15 months later Governor Clinton declared the town a disaster area.
In a lawsuit in 1989, some residents contended that the company was responsible for a pattern of pollution around the state, abetted by a state government that refused to do anything about it.
"The various regulatory authorities legally charged with protecting the water, land and people of Arkansas from this well-known pollution have failed to take any meaningful enforcement action," the Green Forest residents said in their lawsuit. The lawsuit produced evidence that Mr. Clinton was personally briefed on the pollution problems at Green Forest, and it contended that his administration had failed to take significant action. State officials and the company denied any wrongdoing.
As one example, the residents cited the state Pollution Control and Ecology Commission, which levied an $11,000 fine when Tyson's was found to have dumped waste from its plant in nearby Berryville onto private property. Mr. Blair took part in negotiating that settlement, according to court papers.
 
Dropping Clinton's Name
 The lawsuit also revealed one instance in which Mr. Blair threatened to go to the Governor's office when the state's top health officials tried in 1987 to get the company to stop dumping sludge into Green Forest's drinking water supply.
On May 19, 1987, in response to a letter from Dr. Ben N. Saltzman, director of the state Department of Health, Mr. Blair wrote that the Pollution Commission had given the company permission to dump sludge. Tyson, he wrote, was caught in a turf battle between warring agencies.
"It seems to me it is time to have a major meeting in the Governor's office with the Governor's staff and get the turf problems ironed out," he wrote.
The meeting never took place.
The Green Forest case was recently settled out of court. The terms were sealed.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1994

 CORRECTION:
 An article on March 18 about Hillary Rodham Clinton's commodity trades misstated benefits that the Tyson Foods company received from the state of Arkansas. Tyson did not receive $9 million in loans from the state; the comp. did benefit from at least $7 million in state tax credits, according to a Tyson spokesman. (The error was also reflected in an article on March 19 about President Clinton's defense of his wife's investments in an interview with news agency reporters; in an article on March 30 about the White House's disclosure of how much Mrs. Clinton had invested in 1978 in the commodities trades, and in and editorial on March 31.)

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tyson Foods Inc., one of Arkansas' most powerful companies, benefited from a variety of government actions under Gov. Bill Clinton. Donald J. Tyson, the chairman and chief executive, at the Springdale, Ark., headquarters, standing before a picture of his father, John, who founded what became the nation's biggest poultry company. (Arkansas Business Newspaper); James B. Blair was a top lawyer for Tyson Foods Inc. in the late 1970's when he advised Hillary Rodham Clinton on commodity investments. (Tom Ewart for The New York Times) (pg. A20)
 
Charts: "Commodies Trading: A Primer"
 OVERVIEW -- The original purpose of the commodities market was to allow farmers and food companies to protect themselves from the vagaries of weather and consumer demand that can make supply, demand and prices swing wildly through the course of a year.
 Today most of the trading is done by people who never take possession of the actual commodity, but who seek to profit by being on the right side of such a swing.
 The Commodity Futures Trading Commission estimates that 75 percent of all of its investors lose money.
 REWARDS -- Profits can be great because an investor puts down only a fraction of the total cost upon buying or selling the futures contract.
 RISKS -- If prices go the wrong way, an investor can lose several times the original investment and also must come up with additional cash, sometimes within hours or days.
 If the investor is unable to do so, the commodity will be sold at whatever the current market price is and the investor will have to make up the difference.
 HOW IT WORKS
 1. Buyer agrees to purchase a certain amount of a commodity (like cattle or soybeans) at some date in the future, for a preset price.
 2. If the market price for the commodity then DROPS, the buyer is still obligated to pay the prearranged price, and loses money.
 3. If the market price for the commodity the RISES, the seller is obligated to honor the prearranged price, and the buyer makes a profit. (pg. A20)

HEADLINE: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS MISLED EXAMINERS, ALBANY CONCLUDES

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

 BODY:
Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield repeatedly obstructed state insurance examiners and tried to mislead them about the company's operations and finances, according to a report made public yesterday by the New York State Insurance Department.
Attempts at obstruction were frequent and caused significant delays in the Insurance Department's effort to unravel the finances of the troubled insurance giant, the report said. 
 The report, a review of the activities of the state's largest health insurer since 1988, makes sweeping criticisms of virtually every aspect of the company's operations during a period when its finances sank to near-insolvency.
 
'Frequent Runarounds'
 Empire employees, including some high-ranking managers, denied the existence of two sets of books, withheld profit and loss information, misled examiners about the existence of a memorandum detailing failures in fraud detection, and understated by $20 million the cost of a computer contract awarded to a dentist who had been on an Empire board, the report said.
"In short, the examiner experienced frequent runarounds trying to get necessary information and data as well as what were sometimes very basic explanations of the material supplied," the report said.
"Taken together," the report concluded, the actions violate state insurance law "and cast serious doubt upon the trustworthiness of Empire's management as it was then constituted."
 
New Management Team
 Much of the obfuscation occurred last spring and summer as revelations about management mistakes and the use of false financial data put Empire in the most tumultuous period of its 60-year history.
Under a new team of managers installed last summer and a reconstituted board of directors, the obstruction has largely ended, Salvatore R. Curiale, the New York State Insurance Superintendent, said yesterday.
The 154-page report is the first examination of Empire released by the Insurance Department since 1991. The document draws a portrait of an embattled company whose board of directors took little interest in important issues and whose managers, content to keep the board uninformed, bridled at scrutiny from state regulators.
The report, which was completed last November, made 52 recommendations for changes and reforms that Mr. Curiale said would be necessary to keep Empire afloat. They include clearly defining business strategies, tightening anti-fraud measures, abandoning the practice of lavishing expensive gifts and perquisites on board members and employees, requiring that the directors approve major contracts, toughening conflict-of-interest rules and altering some accounting procedures.
John Calagna, a spokesman for the Insurance Department, said legal action against Empire itself was unlikely because most of those responsible for obstructing the examiners had left the company or been dismissed.
Empire officials, who received a draft of the report last fall, declined to discuss it yesterday. In a written statement, the company said it "does not agree with all of the audit findings, particularly the conclusion that some employees of the company failed to cooperate fully with the department's examiners."
The company has "addressed many of the recommendations in the report and others will be implemented as soon as feasible," it said.
 
A Hidden Black Book
 Last year the examiners were repeatedly told by some Empire officials that certain internal financial reports did not exist. But they later learned that the reports, known as the Black Book, did exist and had been obtained by The New York Times.
Empire officials acknowledged last summer that figures in the Black Book, which included profit and loss data for certain types of accounts, differed significantly from the inaccurate figures that Empire gave the Insurance Department. The inaccurate figures were used by Empire to bolster its lobbying campaign for a major change in state insurance law.
The financial condition of Empire, the largest nonprofit insurer in the nation, has improved somewhat since its reserves plunged to $40 million at the end of 1992, far below the $500 million considered safe by insurance regulators and by the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
The company ended 1993 with $235 million in reserves, largely because of an unexpected slowing in medical cost inflation, Mr. Curiale said. He added that he was unlikely to grant Empire's pending request for rate increases that average 8 to 9 percent.
 
No More Cheerleading
 The report is very different in tone from previous Insurance Department examinations of Empire, which are made every three or four years. In the past, Empire and its regulators have been cordial and supporting, a relationship that some critics say led to Empire's financial decline.
Last summer in Washington, investigators for a Senate subcommittee said the Insurance Department had abdicated its responsibility for monitoring Empire and had taken the company at its word when it blamed all its problems on "unfair competition" from profit-making insurers. The investigators described the Insurance Department as "more a cheerleader for Empire's cause" than "an aggressive regulator."
In its report yesterday the Insurance Department said unfair "cherry-picking" of healthy customers by Empire's competitors was a major reason for the company's financial problems, but added that management mistakes were also to blame.
The report strongly criticized Empire's directors for apparently taking little interest in operations but accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of gifts, meals and trips for themselves and their spouses as well as free medical insurance.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bonuses Triple for Chrysler Officials

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 17

 BODY:
After a year of soaring sales, stock prices and spirits at the Chrysler Corporation, the company more than tripled bonuses for its top executives, according to a proxy statement made public today.
Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, received a bonus of $1.9 million in 1993, up from $575,000 in 1992. For the year, he earned $6.79 million in salary, bonus, stock awards and stock options. In addition, Mr. Eaton exercised stock options in the company worth another $4.47 million. 
 Yet Mr. Eaton, who left the General Motors Corporation two years ago to join Chrysler, has repeatedly refused to take credit for the recent sales success of the nation's No. 3 auto maker. He joined the company after many of the models that have attracted new buyers -- from the LH sedan to the Dodge Ram pickup to the Jeep Grand Cherokee -- were already being developed.
 
Criticism From Union
 Chrysler's president, Robert A. Lutz, who is widely credited with developing the new vehicles, received a bonus of $1,500,000 last year, up from $450,000 in 1992. His total compensation for 1993 was $4.86 million. Mr. Lutz exercised stock options worth another $5.96 million. The other three top officers at the company also saw their bonuses more than triple.
The generous pay packages drew criticism from the United Automobile Workers. "This kind of conspicuous, excessive compensation helps nothing worth helping in our society," Stan Marshall, a union vice president, said in a written statement. "It's too much for too little. It sends the wrong message to workers and especially to young people about what is really worthwhile and what essentially makes our economy work."
Because of an expanding car and truck market -- and because of the strong yen, which drove up prices of many Japanese vehicles -- all three major domestic auto makers improved their performance in 1993.
With demand rising for its vehicles, Chrysler was also able to increase its profit margins in 1993 by cutting rebates from an average of $1,020 per vehicle in the fourth quarter of 1992 to $650 by the end of 1993.
As a result, Chrysler posted record earnings of $777 million in the fourth quarter. For the year, however, Chrysler lost $2.55 billion because of a $4.68 billion charge to cover the health benefits of its future retirees.
Chrysler's shareholders and some workers have already benefited from the company's strong year. The company announced in January that it would pay record profit-sharing checks, averaging $4,300, to 65,000 unionized employees.
Shares in Chrysler ended the year at $53.25 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up 63 percent from $32.625 at the beginning of the year. Today, Chrysler closed at $58.875, down $1, in active trading.
The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation have not yet released their proxy statements. While Ford is expected to pay bonuses, G.M. is not expected to give bonuses to executives in its North American operations.
In determining bonuses, Chrysler said it paid special attention to improvements in vehicle quality, the area where critics still raise the most doubts about its cars and trucks.
Bonuses were only part of the total compensation packages. Mr. Eaton, for example, also received $928,750 in salary, up 56 percent from $597,000 in 1992. He also received 33,500 shares of stock, valued at $1.8 million, as a reward for corporate performance between 1991 and 1993. He was promised another 11,100 shares tied to performance from 1993 to 1995.
And Mr. Eaton received 140,000 options to buy stock in Chrysler at $46.25 cents a share before July 2003. Using a popular economic model for valuing options, Chrysler in its proxy statement priced those options at $2 million.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Senate Panel Snips Piece of the Budget

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The Senate Budget Committee surprised Democratic leaders by voting 13 to 8 today to cut an extra $23 billion from Mr. Clinton's proposed five-year, $8.5 trillion spending package.
Although $23 billion is a lot of money, today's vote was every bit as symbolic as substantive. The budgets are so huge, and the economy so unpredictable, that the impact of the latest cuts, if they survive the remainder of the legislative process, is tough to forecast. 
 The nine Republicans and four Democrats who pushed the reductions through the committee could not muster a majority to approve cuts in any specific programs, and instead told Congress's appropriations committees to make the decisions -- and anger constituents -- on their behalf.
The measure would cut a bare $1.6 billion from the $1.5 trillion budget that President Clinton has proposed for the 1995 fiscal year. But that is deceptive; the panel exempted popular benefit programs, like Medicare and food stamps, which comprise about two-thirds of all Federal spending. That means the cuts would fall on the military and on discretionary programs like education and road-building.
The Budget Committee's version still must survive a full Senate vote and a conference with the House, which passed its Mr. Clinton's package last week virtually intact. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: Brick Scavenger Is Killed When a Wall Collapses

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
One of four men who were scavenging bricks -- at 15 cents apiece -- from an abandoned building in the Bronx was killed yesterday when a wall collapsed and crushed him.
The police said that the four men were being paid by a construction company. It is common in the poorest areas of the city, officials said, for the bricks of abandoned and partially destroyed buildings to be taken for recycling into patios in the suburbs or decorator fireplaces in the city's more expensive neighborhoods. 
 Although police officials declined to estimate the extent of the scavenging, one officer at the scene of the collapse at 1123 Nelson Avenue, in the High Bridge section, said taking bricks from abandoned buildings in the area is "a common, everyday thing -- part of the neighborhood economy."
Captain Tom Purtell of the 44th Precinct said the three surviving scavengers were not being charged. "We don't think there's any criminality involved here," he said, "But we are not overlooking that possibility." The victim was not immediately identified.
 
15 a Brick
 One neighborhood resident, Freddie Rodriguez, said he had been offered 15 cents a brick to help the four others. He said he turned down the offer, which he said came from a local company that hired the four others.
Police officials said last night that they did not know who owned the abandoned building -- which was burned out and already partially collapsed -- or if the construction company had permission to remove the bricks.
Neighbors said the company, called American, had an office in a building two doors away. But when reporters rang the bell there was no answer.
The neighborhood, where many buildings are abandoned, and some of them gutted, is a half mile south of the abandoned building where Police Officer Sean McDonald was posted when he was shot to death trying to stop a robbery Tuesday night.
According to an executive of a large brick company not involved in the case, the New York area offers a highly lucrative market for old bricks because of the desirability of their antique patina. Emil Puswald, an official of the Long Island City Building Building & Mason Supply Company, said he was attempting to fill two orders of 8,000 bricks each for decorating two Manhattan apartments.
He said such bricks sold for from 25 to 30 cents a piece.
While one brick company official said old bricks were banned in some areas for new construction, many contractors, decorators, apartment and home owners used them for sidewalks, patios, and interior redecorating.
"There's quite a market for them," Mr. Puswald said. "People want that look."
According to the police, the three-story building was destroyed by a fire 18 months ago. Last week, they said, parts of the building collapsed and that it was amid the rubbled inside that the four men were working in yesterday afternoon, chipping bricks, one by one, from the rear wall, much of which was still standing.
At 3:40 P.M., however, the wall fell inward, crushing one of the workmen, who was removed about two hours later and pronounced dead.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance on Good Inflation News

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
When the stock market got a third day of good economic news yesterday, traders fought their tendency to ferret out the specter of inflation in even the cheeriest reports. Instead, they bid up all the leading stock indexes, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index set a record.
Economically sensitive stocks like Caterpillar and Alcoa, as well as oil and chemical companies like Exxon and Du Pont, rose. Technology stocks like Tele-Communications, Oracle and Lotus, helped lift the Nasdaq index. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 16.99 points, to 3,865.14, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 1.48 points, to 470.90. The Nasdaq index rose 4.86 points, to 803.85, up from its previous record of 800.47 on Jan. 31.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite Index rose 0.77 point, to 261.11, on moderate volume of 304 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues by 1,149 to 1,015. The American Stock Exchange Market Value Index rose 0.81 point, to 470.63.
 
 
Bonds Slip
 The stock market gained, even though the bond market did not. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Government bond reached 6.82 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. When prices fall, yields rise.
Bond traders failed to believe inflation was in check, despite a Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia survey yesterday showing that an index of prices paid by manufacturers had fallen sharply, indicating a possible slowing in inflation.
When the same survey last month showed the index rising, indicating a possible increase in inflation, bond traders believed it and bid bond prices down.
Earlier this week, both the Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index indicated scant inflation.
For much of the session, two of the three popular stock indexes tracked the price of the 30-year Government bond. The exception was the Nasdaq index, which rose strongly at 9:30 A.M. and continued to do so for the entire session. Around 2 P.M., both the Dow industrials and the S.& P. 500 parted company with the bond market and rose steadily.
Hanson P.L.C.'s American depository receipts were the most actively traded issue on the Big Board yesterday, with 7.9 million shares changing hands. Hanson rose 1/4, to 21 1/8. One A.D.R. represents five ordinary shares.
There was no discernible news to spur the activity, but the A.D.R.'s for Hanson, a British consumer-products company, often trade heavily around its ex-dividend date, which was Monday. When a stock trades ex-dividend, current purchasers are not entitled to a dividend until the next payment is declared.
 
 
Intel Gains
 Intel, the dominant maker of computer chips, rose 3/8, to 72 1/4.
Analysts have raised their assessments of the stock despite inroads by Intel rivals. Apple Computer recently introduced a new Macintosh that uses the PowerPC chip that will compete with Intel's new Pentium microprocessor. Also, the rival Advanced Micro Devices recently won an important copyright infringement case against Intel.
Acclaim Entertainment, a maker of home video games, saw its stock fall for a second day because of concern that a key vendor, WMS Industries, may not renew a licensing contract due to expire next year. Acclaim, whose shares fell 3/4, to 22 1/4, said it did not know whether WMS had reached a decision.

HEADLINE: For 2 Slaying Suspects, Quiet Lives, Odd Hours

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
The two young men charged yesterday with the murder of Police Officer Sean McDonald migrated to New York City from the Caribbean not long ago in search of opportunity, and they ended up in the perilous streets of Washington Heights, where drugs and guns are as common as the throbbing beat of salsa.
Interviews yesterday with acquaintances and landlords indicated that the suspects, Rodolfo Rodriguez, 20, and Javier Miranda, 27, both came from the Dominican Republic, but neither was known to have relatives in the city, and they rented cheap rooms in buildings about five blocks apart. 
 Acquaintances said the two men lived quietly, sleeping late and hanging out in a neighborhood just across the Harlem River from High Bridge in the Bronx, where the officer was shot to death Tuesday night as he interrupted a robbery in a clothing shop.
 
Drug Connections
 Law-enforcement officials said there were no indications that Mr. Miranda had been in trouble before. But they said Mr. Rodriguez, who arrived from the Dominican Republic last fall, had become a small-time drug dealer and was arrested in Washington Heights for selling crack cocaine to undercover police officers on Jan. 10.
While the charge against him was a class B felony carrying a maximum penalty of 8 1/3 to 25 years in prison and a prosecutor asked for $1,500 bail, a judge released him without bail the day after his arrest because he had no record, and two other judges affirmed that decision in his later court appearances.
Betty Reyes, 25, who said she had been Mr. Rodriguez's girlfriend for about three months, said he was unemployed but had formerly worked for a neighborhood supermarket. She called him "very sweet and nice," and said he had denied any involvement in the slaying of the police officer. "He said he didn't do it," Ms. Reyes said. "I know him. He wouldn't do it."
Franckline Jean, the owner of a four-story tenement at 558 West 173d Street, said he had rented Apartment 3A -- one room in the back of the building -- to Mr. Rodriguez last fall, and that the young man had lived there quietly, paid his $300 a month rent in cash and rarely had visitors.
"I never saw any of his friends," said Mr. Jean, who owns the building and occupies the first floor. He said Mr. Rodriguez told him he worked at night, but did not explain what he did for a living. He said he kept odd hours, slept until early afternoon and stayed out late at night. He said he never detected any signs that his tenant was involved with drugs or possessed a gun.
 
'A Nice Person'
 Other neighbors said they did not know and had never seen Mr. Rodriguez, but several teen-agers outside said they knew him. "He was a nice person," said Jenina Benitez, 16. "He would let us chill in his house and watch TV. If he was a criminal, he would not have turned himself in."
Natalia Encarnacion, 15, also expressed skepticism about the charges. "I didn't believe it," she said. "He wouldn't do it."
A spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney's office, Wayne Brison, said Mr. Rodriguez was arrested at 3:10 P.M. Jan. 10 at 156th Street and Edgecombe Avenue after selling two vials of crack cocaine to undercover officers of a police Tactical Narcotics Team.
Charged with criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, he was arraigned the next day in Criminal Court before Judge Laura Safer Espinoza. Assistant District Attorney Cheryl Blackman asked for bail, noting that he had given two addresses and said he had come from Miami and had lived in New York only two months, a background that suggested he might be a bail risk.
But a Legal Aid lawyer said it was Mr. Rodriguez's first arrest, and the judge ordered him released in his own recognizance. He was indicted by a grand jury three days later, and pleaded not guilty at his next court appearance, on Feb. 15, before Acting Justice Herbert J. Adlerberg of State Supreme Court, who left his bail status unchanged.
Mr. Rodriguez appeared next on March 10 before Acting Justice Herbert I. Altman of State Supreme Court, who also continued his bail status and set a hearing for April 8 to hear pretrial motions in the case. Legal experts said it was not unusual for judges to release a defendant without a criminal record on no bail. The case is still pending.
Less was known yesterday about Mr. Miranda. Gloria Almanzar, 59, who occupies a sixth-floor apartment at 2201 Amsterdam Avenue, at 169th Street, said she rented a room -- actually a cubicle fabricated of plywood within a bedroom -- to Mr. Miranda for $75 a week about two weeks ago.
He had answered a notice she had posted on neighborhood streets seeking a roomer, she said, and had identified himself only as David. She said she learned the name Javier Miranda only when the police came to her door Wednesday night in search of him.
She said her Spanish-speaking roomer was quiet, though he sometimes entertained a woman in his room and kept erratic hours. But she said there had been no signs of drugs or guns in his life. "He said he worked in a bodega," she said.
 
Teddy Bear and Cigars
 While he told her little about himself, she said he did mention that his father was Dominican and his mother Puerto Rican and that, while he had come originally from the Dominican Republic, he had arrived in New York recently from Puerto Rico.
In his cubicle, a mattress without sheets had been set up beside two dressers, one with a mirror leaning against the wall. There were rumpled clothes and other personal effects lying about, a radio, a yellow toothbrush, a small white teddy bear, a box of cigars and a box of aloe candy.
But there was no picture in the frame on the dresser -- no photos anywhere in the room, in fact -- and no obvious clues to his recent past or the crime of which he stands accused.

HEADLINE: In the Humble Ashes Of a Lone Incinerator, The Makings of Law

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 11

 BODY:
Every day, like enormous worker bees tending a hive, an endless procession of trucks haul 1,300 tons of garbage to Chicago's trash incinerator and carry away 400 tons of resulting ash to a modern, plastic-lined landfill in the nearby town of Elwood, Ill.
The ash is the end product of 14 percent of all the garbage that Chicagoans toss out, and it is tainted with two toxic elements: lead and cadmium. Whether the city is disposing of it safely is a question in dispute. Whether it is doing so legally is a question for the United States Supreme Court, which is due to decide before the current term ends in three months. 
 A lot is at stake. The city argues that an adverse decision, requiring that the ash be dumped at specially designed hazardous-waste sites, would increase the ash disposal expenses of Chicago -- and those of dozens of other incinerator-operating municipalities across the country -- perhaps tenfold.
And that starkly higher cost, the city says, could well force a shutdown of much of a new generation of waste management tools: the nation's 125 trash-to-energy incinerators, which consume almost a fifth of all of America's garbage. These new plants, which became popular during the 1980's and can cost as much as $400 million apiece to build, not only burn away 90 percent of the volume of trash that is fed to them but in the process also produce modest amounts of steam and electricity. (Chicago's incinerator generated energy worth $1.5 million last year.)
 
Many Allies for Chicago
 Few decisions of the Court have been so eagerly awaited by cash-short states and cities. Already burdened by the cost of complying with environmental mandates, many of which they view as the work of idealists who have never had to balance a municipal budget, other local governments have rallied to Chicago's side as its six-year-old legal battle against the Environmental Defense Fund moves toward climax.
"The Chicago incinerator case is a classic example of the central problem cities have identified with environmental policy," said Michael Pompili, Assistant Health Commissioner of Columbus, Ohio, which also operates a waste-to-energy incinerator and, like Chicago, dumps the ash in an ordinary plastic-lined landfill that it considers perfectly safe. "There is just not an unlimited amount of economic resources available. When it comes to the environment, we have to be smarter and set priorities."
Naturally the Environmental Defense Fund sees the issue differently, and not without reason.
Whatever the merits of plastic-lined landfills -- and the fund views them as insufficient to handle toxic ash -- the fact is that many cities that operate incinerators dispose of ash in dumps that have only clay liners, or no liners at all. Richard Denison, a senior scientist with the fund, says there has been one documented case, in Washington State, in which groundwater beneath a clay-lined ash dump was contaminated by leaking cadmium. Two states -- Florida and Alabama -- even permit incinerator ash to be used as fill in road construction.
Lead, one element of incinerator ash, is considered by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention the chief toxic threat to children. Children are particularly susceptible to neurological damage and other ill effects if lead invades the body at substantial levels. The toxic effects of cadmium, another ash element, are also well documented.
Lead and cadmium are present in all manner of debris hauled daily to Chicago's incinerator -- in cans, in light bulbs, in batteries. But the toxins are not present in proportions high enough to be deemed hazardous under the nation's waste disposal law, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976. The problem, however, is that these toxins do not themselves burn, and so they concentrate in the incinerator ash at levels that tend to exceed the law's thresholds of hazard: for lead, five parts per million when measured in testing solution; for cadmium, one part per million.
 
Expensive Protection
 To provide special protection against toxic leaching into the water table, the law requires that hazardous waste be dumped not in ordinary landfills, like the one Chicago nontheless uses to dispose of its ash, but instead at licensed hazardous-waste sites. These dumps are built with a double lining of plastic (instead of the single lining that characterizes the ordinary modern fill) and have two collection systems -- one inside each lining -- to capture any toxin that nears escape.
All this sounds expensive, and it is. For equivalent volumes of waste, hazardous-dump operators charge municipalities as much as 1,000 percent more than do ordinary landfills. By Chicago's own reckoning, its ash-disposal expenses would be about $50 million a year if it used a hazardous-waste dump, as against the current outlay of $4.5 million.
 
One Law, Differing Views
 Still, since the concentrations of lead and cadmium in Chicago's ash are hazardous by Federal definition, the city would seem to have little choice: either pay up or shut down the incinerator.
But maybe not.
At issue before the Supreme Court are the two sides' differing interpretations of a 1984 amendment to the waste disposal law. The amendment, aimed at encouraging the development of technology to deal with the nation's mountains of garbage, says that as long as trash incinerators that produce energy are burning only household waste or nonhazardous commercial waste, they "shall not be deemed to be treating, storing, disposing of, or otherwise managing hazardous wastes."
What does that mean?
By Chicago's reading, it means that the ash hauled from the city's incinerator enjoys an exemption that allows it to be dumped in an ordinary landfill, a conclusion shared by the Clinton Administration, which has filed a brief with the Court in support of Chicago's position.
By the reading of the Environmental Defense Fund, though, the "plain language" of the exemption makes clear that it applies only to the collection of garbage and the incineration of that garbage itself. What about the ash? "We say an exemption does not exist," said Karen Florini, a lawyer in the Washington office of the New York-based fund. "And if the Supreme Court strictly interprets the law, they will agree."
 
Split at Appellate Level
 A Federal appeals court has already agreed. Last year the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, reversed a Federal district judge and found in favor of the Environmental Defense Fund.
Noting that hazardous-waste dumps had been created as a result of the very waste-disposal law now at issue, the appeals court said it seemed "unlikely," if not "absurd," that "Congress, in an express effort to promote the proper disposal of dangerous substances that otherwise would seep into the ground and water table, would sanction the dumping of massive amounts of hazardous waste in the form of ash into ordinary landfills."
But a similar challenge in New York by the Environmental Defense Fund went just the other way, with victories at both the district and circuit levels for the operator of an incinerator in the Westchester County town of Peekskill. Faced with a conflict in decisions issued by the Seventh Circuit and the Second, the Supreme Court agreed last year to take up the Chicago case. The Justices heard arguments in January.
 
Big Stake for Connecticut
 Chicago has attracted no dearth of allies. Briefs supporting the city's position have been filed not only by the Administration but also by New York State, the National League of Cities, the National Governors Association, the United States Conference of Mayors and 29 cities and counties that operate waste-to-energy incinerators in 17 states.
None of those states have more at stake in the Court's decision than Connecticut, where six incinerators burn 6,000 tons of garbage a day. That is 62 percent of all the state's trash, by far the highest proportion in the country, according to the National Solid Wastes Management Association. New York State has 14 such incinerators, which burn 15,000 tons daily, or 20 percent. The figures for New Jersey: six incinerators, 4,600 tons daily, 9 percent.
 
The Threat of Landfills
 The fund's lawsuit against Chicago was filed in 1988, after years in which the city disposed of its ash by dumping it at an old quarry where gusts of wind often sent clouds of it billowing into a neighborhood nearby.
Now, at a time when Chicago has long since cleaned up that act, largely as a result of the fund's efforts, the city portrays the suit as not only errant but indeed self-defeating -- not a plus for the environment, but a minus. The reasoning is this:
In the absence of quick Congressional action to reverse a Court decision favoring the fund, most incinerators would have to shut down, the city says. As a consequence, it maintains, there would be a need to build vast new landfills to handle volumes of garbage that would otherwise be burned away.
The trend in landfill construction has been to build enormous regional dumps, each covering hundreds of acres. Most are being built in previously untouched forests and fields of rural America, bringing deterioration of natural landscapes held most dear by environmentalists.
Chicago's defeat would only accelerate that process, the city contends. "If people take a careful look," said Lawrence E. Rosenthal, deputy Chicago corporation counsel, "they'll be surprised by which way the environmental issues cut in this case."
To Ms. Florini, the Environmental Defense Fund lawyer, all this is just so much overstatement. Chicago and other cities, she says, can escape the steep rise in ash disposal costs -- and so keep their incinerators running -- simply by doing a better job of trash management. For instance, by separating from incinerator-bound waste any products that contain heavy metals, the cities could keep cadmium and lead out of incinerator ash, or at least keep concentrations of them below hazardous levels. And that would allow continued disposal of the ash in ordinary landfills.
Chicago's response: Easier said -- and far less expensively -- than done, given the sheer volume of garbage destined for the city's incinerator.
Each side continues to claim environmental correctness as its own, and that is not likely to end. By the time the Supreme Court's term concludes in June, though, everyone should know at least on which side the law comes down.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers vs. Mark And Registers Slight Gain

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar posted a marginal gain against the German mark yesterday, rebounding from an early selloff that was touched off by news that the Bundesbank, the German central bank, had left two key interest rates unchanged.
The dollar fell more than a pfennig in Europe and in early New York trading after the German central bank said it was holding its discount rate steady at 5.25 percent and the Lombard lending rate at 6.75 percent. 
 Although almost no one had expected the Bundesbank to trim the discount rate, some traders had thought that the central bank would cut the Lombard rate as a symbolic gesture to show that it remained committed to lower rates.
 "A lot of people expected the Lombard rate to come down as low as 6.25 percent," said Robert Mograbi, senior vice president at NatWest Bank P.L.C.
The Bundesbank's failure to act left the dollar mired near 1.6780 marks for most of the morning. But market speculation that the Federal Reserve Board may move to increase interest rates in the United States next week averted heavier losses, dealers said.
"The threat that U.S. rates could go higher will keep the dollar from getting annihilated," said the Bank of Boston's chief foreign exchange trader, Paul Wong.
Later, reports that the German Finance Minister had hinted that rates in Germany need not remain low simply because the bank failed to act contributed to the dollar's recovery.
Dealers also noted a flurry of mark selling against both the dollar and the British pound late in the afternoon, which cut into the mark's gains.
In the end, the dollar rose to 1.6882 German marks in late New York trading from 1.6881 marks on Wednesday.
With attention focused on American and European interest rates, the dollar drifted between 105.50 and 105.95 yen. It ended in New York at 105.78 Japanese yen, down from 106.05 yen.
Meanwhile, the Bank of Canada was seen intervening, buying Canadian dollars in an attempt to halt a slide that has sent the currency repeatedly to seven-year lows against the United States dollar. The United States dollar ended in New York at $1.3685 (Canadian), up from $1.3638 (Canadian).
Meanwhile, the British pound fell to $1.4925 in late New York trading from $1.4950 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Falls on Oversupply; Good News Hurts Metals

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices tumbled the daily limit for the second day yesterday as abundant supplies continued to depress the market.
Lumber for delivery in May fell $10 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, to $416.70 for each 1,000 board feet. 
 The price of lumber has been depressed as the result of bad weather in recent weeks that delayed housing starts. "The weather has caused people to hold inventories," said Bud Merrill, an analyst with Smith Barney Shearson in Eugene, Ore. "The hope was the weather was going to clear up and there would be a lot of pent-up demand, but we just haven't seen that so far."
On Wednesday, the Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose 4.1 percent last month, but lumber-futures traders were dissatisfied with the gain, which followed a 22 percent drop in January.
Traders also appeared concerned about rising mortgage rates as the spring building season approaches.
On other commodity markets, platinum futures continued to fall, leading a decline in precious metals in recent days. Reports of low American inflation and strong economic growth is the sort of news that makes metals traders unhappy, as is the relative calm in some of the world's hot spots. Investors tend to buy the metals as a hedge against inflation and during times of turmoil abroad.
Platinum for April delivery sank $4.90, to $398.50 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, April gold lost $2.60, to $383 an ounce, and May silver fell 2.5 cents, to $5.377 an ounce.
Nina Lipton, vice president of the Platinum Guild International in New York, contended that the recent price slide did not indicate a long-term trend. "There's basic underlying strength to all the metals," she said, "and you're just going to have choppiness coming day to day until we get some new news."
Energy futures prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude oil prices rose and then dropped sharply in the last hour on technical trading. The price of light sweet crude oil for April delivery settled 24 cents lower at $14.82 a barrel.
In other energy contracts, April home heating oil fell 0.23 cent, to 44.24 cents a gallon; April unleaded gasoline dropped 0.56 cent, to 45.99 cents, and April natural gas fell 0.39 cent, to $2.124 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain futures prices ended mixed, and soybean futures finished lower on the Chicago Board of Trade in sluggish trading. Wheat for March delivery settled 1.25 cents higher at $3.375 a bushel; March corn was unchanged at $2.80 a bushel; March oats were 2.75 cents higher at $1.295 a bushel, and March soybeans were 1.75 cents lower at $6.9025 a bushel.

HEADLINE: 2 Banks Raise Prime Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Harris Trust and Savings Bank said yesterday that they would raise their prime lending rates today to 6 percent, a move that brings both banks in line with the rest of the industry.
The prime rate has been at 6 percent since July 2, 1992. But Harris and Morgan broke ranks with other large banks last fall, cutting their rates in a bid to bring in new business and turn up the heat on competitors. 
 No other major banks moved yesterday to raise their prime lending rates, an important benchmark for many types of fixed- and adjustable- rate loans, including credit cards.
"I wouldn't take what Morgan and Harris are doing as an indication of what the rest of the industry would do," said Michael Foley, senior analyst at Moody's Investors Service. "They're just coming in line with the rest of the market."
The Chicago-based Harris lowered its prime to 5 3/4 percent on Sept. 17 and to 5 1/2 percent on Oct. 18. Harris eased the rate back to 5 3/4 percent on Feb. 4.

HEADLINE: U.S. Approach to Japan: 'Economic Acupuncture'

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 17

 BODY:
Having succeeded in its efforts to pressure Japan to open its most lucrative cellular phone market to Motorola Inc., the Clinton Administration plans to keep up the pressure on Tokyo to unilaterally open other markets with a strategy that some disdainfully call "managed trade," but that might best be thought of as "economic acupuncture."
That policy seeks to bring down Japan's trade barriers not with a single, big blow that would destabilize the whole United States-Japan relationship, but instead through a series of carefully targeted pressure points aimed at loosening some of Japan's other tightly constricted markets. 
 Critics charge that this approach constitutes managed trade, which inevitably requires more regulation, benefits certain companies over others, and undercuts arguments for free trade elsewhere. Despite such criticisms, however, the Clinton Administration's targeted policy seems to be producing results for the United States, and officials say it is actually reversing managed trade practices that already exist.
No sooner had President Clinton brandished the possibility of sanctions under the Super 301 trade law, than Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa promised Washington that by the end of March he would produce a package of unilateral Japanese initiatives to open the other closed markets to which the United States has spent the last eight months fruitlessly trying to negotiate access: autos, medical equipment, insurance and telecommunications.
This issue will no doubt be a topic of discussion between Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Japanese economic officials attending the meetings here this weekend of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, known as APEC.
For all the Administration's tough rhetoric, though, it is proceeding very cautiously with Tokyo, so as not to derail other aspects of the relationship or ignite a tit-for-tat trade war. For now, American officials seem satisfied that their speak-loudly-and-carry-a-small-needle strategy is working.
"Any time you maintain a strong and consistent position with the Japanese, it is helpful," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said.
President Clinton's approach to Japan, Mr. Kantor added, is very much colored by the fact that he was a governor, who accompanied Arkansas businessmen on trade missions to Japan in an effort to win them access. He looks at Japan as much through the narrow lens of a typical American exporter as he does through the wide-angle lens of a global strategist worried about cooperation with Japan on issues like Korea and Russia.
The American public, Mr. Kantor said, "wants a realistic trade policy grounded in practical experience, not in theory."
But if the public is pleased with the results, economists still contend that the absence of sound theoretical grounding will ultimately undo the pragmatic Clinton approach.
 
 
Trade Balance
 One of the economists' complaints is that the President and his aides often hold up the $60 billion trade surplus of Japan with the United States as proof that it is closing its markets to American goods. That $60 billion figure may make a nice emotional banner to gather under, economists say, but as any student of Economics 101 knows, the trade balance is not a measure of how open markets are between countries. Rather, it is a reflection of how much a country is saving and investing.
If the United States spends too much, instead of saving, it must make up the difference by getting capital from abroad. The United States buys lots of Japanese cars and the Japanese then lend the dollars they earn back to the United States Treasury.
"The Administration has lost the analytical high ground by couching the problem with Japan as a trade deficit," Robert Z. Lawrence, a trade economist at Harvard University, said. "Trade balances tell you about a nation's spending patterns, not whether its markets are open or closed."
The United States should be demanding that Japan lower its trade barriers because they exist and are unfair -- not because this would eliminate its trade surplus, Mr. Lawrence said.
 
 
Japanese Recession
 The real thing that the Administration should be focusing its energies and public attention on, Mr. Lawrence said, is the spending and investing habits of Japan -- the fact that it is in a recession and its Government is not spending enough, or lowering taxes enough, to stimulate Japanese consumer demand for imports from the rest of the world.
Barry Bosworth, a former top economic adviser in the Carter Administration, said: "If we really want to start to change the trade balance, we have to encourage Japan, as the world's second-largest economy, to adopt a more aggressive fiscal expansion, so it will import more of everything. The Japanese are very adept at resisting the important changes and then, at the last minute, giving in on the high-visibility trivial items."
Administration officials concede that at times their declarations on Japan put too much emphasis on the trade balance for public relations reasons. But, they argue, if people looked at the substance of their approach, they would see that it is precisely what the economists are demanding: asking Japan to stimulate domestic demand with tax cuts and Government spending programs and compelling the Japanese Government to lower trade barriers in those markets that it regulates, such as Government procurement.
 
 
'Rhetorical Issues'
 "Some of my friends have picked on some rhetorical issues and failed to recognize the substance of the Administration's policy," said Lawrence Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs.
While, of course, it is true that the trade balance is determined by savings minus investment, said Mr. Summers, a former Harvard economics professor, that does not mean that working to open Japanese markets is a useless exercise.
"As a rough estimate, the impact of each billion dollars in extra demand for American products that we generate -- which leads to a stronger dollar and makes American imports cheaper -- translates into about a billion dollars in extra real income for Americans," Mr. Summers said. "So market opening, even if it does not reduce the trade balance, has important benefits for American workers and producers."
As for accusations that the Administration's approach constitutes managed trade, that might be true, Mr. Summers said, if the United States were asking Japan for special deals only for itself that would close off the rest of the world. But the fact is, he said, the whole thrust of American policy is to open those Japanese markets for the world where market forces do not now operate because of managed trade practices by Japanese companies or the Japanese Government.
That is important for American companies, he added, because if they have access to this huge market, they benefit from economies of scale by exporting more and because the tougher competition hones them up to better compete with Japan elsewhere around the world.
While this strategy may require certain hardball tactics to carry out in the real world, Mr. Summers noted, "Pure economic theory needs to be leavened at times with a little political theory."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Off in Week

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
New claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week, the Labor Department said today.
The department said 342,000 people signed up for first-time jobless benefits, down from a revised 350,000 in the week that ended on March 5. Wall Street economists had expected 343,000 new applications for state benefits. 
 "It would suggest that labor market conditions have improved," said Michelle Laughlin, economist with Sanwa BKG.
The department said its four-week average tally of benefits claims slipped to 345,250 in the week that ended last Saturday from a revised 349,250 the previous week. The average, considered a more reliable measure than the more volatile weekly figure, has been steadily declining.
A total of 2,749,000 people received state jobless benefits in the week that ended on March 5, the latest period for which the data were available. That compared with 2,778,000 recipients a week earlier.
The department said 18 states and one territory reported increases in claims of more than 1,000 in the week ended March 5, the latest period for which the data were available. The largest were California, with 9,493 and New York, with 6,598.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
On Another List: Scholars Saved From the Nazis

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG 

 BODY:
In the United States and elsewhere, there were daring "Schindlers" who also kept lists. In different ways, far-sighted Americans rescued thousands of victims of the Third Reich's assault on the minds of people in every profession. Although few of these Americans risked their lives, they were often maligned by their own countrymen. On the eve of World War II, their humanitarian efforts met surprising resistance in the State Department and even in some universities.
The Johnson list was probably the most valuable. Alvin Johnson, the intrepid director of the New School for Social Research in Manhattan, saved nearly 200 European scholars from the Nazis. Many of these refugees later became indispensable Americans. Some of their activities have been touched upon before in biographies and documentary films, but what "Intellectuals in Exile" usefully provides is historical perspective from the German as well as the American side of the story. 
 That the author of this outspoken book is a German scholar, Claus-Dieter Krohn, professor of modern history at the University of Luneburg near Hamburg, adds another level of interest. For instance, Professor Krohn, who was born in 1941, is unafraid to declare that during the Hitler years anti-Semitism existed among the professoriate in some American as well as German universities.
The book briefly describes the origins of the New School, which was founded in 1919 by a group of liberals, including Thorstein Veblen, John Dewey, Charles Beard and Johnson. Until 1933 it was only a small experimental institution for adult education.
With the rise of Nazism, various committees were formed to aid threatened scholars and artists. They had to be: American immigration quotas were not relaxed even after the defeat of France in 1940. Among the most important of these groups was the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars in the United States, to which the Rockefeller Foundation made a strong financial contribution. (Unfortunately, as Arthur D. Morse pointed out in his seminal work, "While Six Million Died," no such special committees could save the vast numbers of anti-Nazis and nonscholars of Jewish origin who wanted to reach freedom's shores.)
Johnson founded a "University in Exile" at the New School in 1933, beginning with a list of 12 social scientists who became known as the Mayflower group. Among these "dismissed or furloughed" German professors were Emil Lederer, Frieda Wunderlich and Karl Brandt. Max Ascoli (who established the liberal magazine The Reporter after the war) became the first Italian political scientist on the faculty that year. When the "University in Exile" opened in October 1933, it was officially renamed the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science.
After the defeat of France, the New School became the last refuge for endangered German and other European scholars. Professor Krohn writes: "Quite clearly, too, the New School served as an alibi for the inaction at a number of universities. This is especially true of Harvard University, whose faculty recommended many of the most highly qualified scholars to the New School but did not itself accept any immigrants."
The author adds that some of the professors themselves caused problems: "The New School people had to deal not only with vexing placement policies but also with the indifference of many German scholars who had found teaching jobs and showed little interest in helping their less privileged colleagues."
The main resistance to rescuing the professors on Johnson's list, Professor Krohn documents, came from the State Department. While President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Eleanor Roosevelt encouraged granting visas to political refugees, State Department officials threw up roadblocks. The author writes that even as the German occupation forces were closing all exits out of France, the State Department's bureaucratic visa division refused all entry applications from Johnson and specifically denounced the New School as an un-American institution:
"Representatives of the State Department asked some scholars who had just come to New York from France if they knew that the place where they were going to work was headed by Communists. These machinations did not stop until Johnson threatened to request a public hearing on these attempts at sabotage."
Between 1933 and 1945, the New School managed to help hundreds of European scholars and artists, including such familiar names as Mario Einaudi, Claude Levi-Strauss, Wilhelm Reich and Gaetano Salvemini, in the social sciences and history, and Herbert Berghof, Fritz Eichenberg, Erwin Piscator and George Szell in the arts.
"Intellectuals in Exile," which is smoothly translated by Rita and Robert Kimber, can be faulted for one heavy-going section, on the influence of the New School's European economists in exile. Professor Krohn tries to show that their theoretical concepts were instrumental in the New Deal, but in this respect, he gives credit where it is not due. The Roosevelt Administration had its own economic idealists and reform programs to pull the country out of the Depression and create new regulatory and public-assistance agencies. America's New Dealers did not have to rely on the exiled European intellectuals for inspiration.
The author also discusses the New School scholars in relation to postwar Germany. He notes that there was no concerted effort to offer the exiled faculty members their former professorships in their old universities. Some of the Americanized professors criticized the United States for its role in the cold war and also for failing to change Germany's postwar political structure, "including the totally inadequate denazification," writes Professor Krohn, who leaves the strong impression that the Bonn Government should have made better use of its own well-kept lists of possible war criminals.
It is such freewheeling interpretations that make "Intellectuals in Exile" a challenging as well as informative book.
