HEADLINE: The Broadway Ticket Game: Bargain-Hunters Can Play

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
THE complaint is heard so often it's mundane. You've even made it yourself: tickets for Broadway shows are too expensive. But it's only three months until your anniversary, so you decide to bite the bullet. A couple of seats for a big musical would be a great way to celebrate.
You can't go to midtown Manhattan, so you call one of the ticketing services, order the seats -- not bad, 20th row center -- and pay $65 apiece, plus $4.50 or $5 each for a service charge, and maybe a handling charge, too. Finally, the big evening arrives. You go to the theater and sit down. Just as the curtain goes up, the seats next to you are filled by another couple, who are gushing about what a great deal this is. 
 "Two tickets for the price of one," they are clucking to themselves. "And we just walked up and got 'em!" Or maybe: "Hey, a third off! How about that! And right in the center of the orchestra!"
What's going on here? Well, a myth and an enigma. The myth is that Broadway tickets are hard to come by. Its corollary is the basic tenet of discounting, whose murky illogic can be simply summarized: make some tickets cheaper, but don't tell people how to get them.
Underlying it all is the reigning paradox of the Broadway theater business: the same high ticket prices that producers say are needed to pay the bills also keep a lot of people out of the theater. It frustrates producers; it frustrates audiences. Nobody has any effective solutions, and not many theater people are even willing to discuss the issue openly.
"I am thoroughly convinced that people in the business are totally aware of the truth, and the truth is, nobody in the business would ever pay that much to go to the theater," said one producer with several Broadway shows to his credit. "The reason people won't talk about it is that it's very difficult to have to start lying immediately. If you say it's not worth it to come and see what we're offering at this price, what happens to the already jaded theatergoing public when they read this? What happens when an investor reads this? Sometimes I'll sit in a room and feel guilty myself."
 
Affordable Seating
 Sixty-five bucks for a musical? Fifty for a play? And prices are on their way up?
The theater experience is singular, the argument for higher ticket prices goes. But if you're willing to forgo any of the privileges of a full-price-ticket buyer -- performance selection, for example, or seat selection -- you can have that singular experience for less.
In the theater business, this is actually a bit of a dirty little secret. Although no producer would deny the existence, or the usefulness, of lower-priced seats, most aren't terribly enthusiastic about publicizing ways to get them. And many of those interviewed echoed the words of one, who spoke on condition of anonymity, for obvious reasons.
"Great," he said with a groan. "You're going to tell people all the ways they can avoid paying full price."
In fact, this is so. Limited numbers of regularly priced cheap seats, binoculars not included, are available for many shows. You can see "Miss Saigon" or "Les Miserables" for $15; "Angels in America" has $10 seats for some performances. In addition, producers employ a variety of discounting programs to seduce theatergoers into the orchestra. The best-known of these, responsible for between 10 and 15 percent of Broadway ticket sales, are the TKTS booths, operated by the Theater Development Fund in Times Square and at the World Trade Center. At the booths, if you're willing to stand in line and take potluck as to what shows are available, tickets for that day's performances are on sale for half or, sometimes, three-quarters of their face value.
There are also group sales programs, twofers (the bookmark-shaped coupons distributed in various locations for some shows, redeemable at the box office for discounted tickets) and other means of getting in for less.
"The most expensive tickets in a theater often do sell at the big price," said James B. Freydberg, a producer whose latest Broadway show was "Fool Moon" last season. "But only the people who can afford the big price have to pay the big price."
 
A Broadway Paradox
 The reason producers are wary of discounting has to do with another Broadway paradox. It's a Marxist idea -- Groucho Marx, that is: Everyone wants to go to a show that he can't get into, and nobody wants to go to one that anyone can get into. In other words, the idea that Broadway provides an elitist form of entertainment is one of the things that make it attractive, and producers go out of their way to keep up the fiction that it's a cool, hopping place.
Why else is the pure myth that Broadway is a tough ticket so widely believed? The first week in March, for instance, not a single one of Broadway's 18 shows sold out every performance. Most had tickets available anytime; 12 shows had less than 70 percent attendance, and many perceived hits were truly hurting. "Crazy for You" and "Tommy" drew less than 60 percent of capacity, "The Sisters Rosensweig" and "Laughter on the 23d Floor" less than 50 percent. Last year's Tony Award winner for best play, "Angels in America," was less than three-quarters full, and the Tony winner for best musical, "Kiss of the Spider Woman," sold only 56 percent of its seats.
Discounting, producers say, sends the message that the show is not popular enough for people to buy tickets at full price. Theatergoers expect Broadway prices to be exorbitant, the argument goes, and when this isn't so, they suspect damaged goods. It's common knowledge among producers that the highest-priced seats sell fastest, then the lowest-priced sell. Quality first, economy next. The seats priced in the middle are the toughest to get rid of.
"There are more buyers for a $65 seat seat than for a seat almost as good for $20 less," said Michael David, whose company, Dodger Productions, is responsible for "Guys and Dolls" and "Tommy," among others.
Such is the mindset that has undermined the Broadway Alliance, producers say. The three-year-old alliance, a consortium of producers, craft unions and theater owners who have forged an agreement to curb their own costs to bring lower-priced drama to Broadway, has yet to produce a successful show.
And such is the mindset that persuades some producers to leave seats unsold rather than make them available at the TKTS booth. In that same March week, the producers of four shows -- "Tommy," with 43 percent of its seats empty; "The Phantom of the Opera" (10 percent empty), "Les Miserables" (25 percent), and "Angels in America" (26 percent) -- declined to make half-price day-of-performance seats available.
"We'd rather go dead with a limited number of tickets than have people say, 'Oh, it's at the booth now,' " said Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns five Broadway theaters and produces many shows, including "Angels" and "Tommy." "There comes a point even in the run of hits where the show goes to the booth, and at that point people begin to think the show is running down. We want to keep the perception that it's a hard-to-get ticket."
"There's a Zen proverb," Mr. Landesman concluded. "It says you can always have what you don't want." He paused, then added his own Groucho-style postscript to make it appropriate for the theater business. "Or vice versa."
 
Doing the Math
 There are no laws governing ticket pricing. Producers are responsible for setting the tariffs for their own shows (with the approval of the theater owners) and generally tailor prices to the demands of the particular shows. That is, the prices depend on things like the number and configuration of seats in the theater and the show's weekly operating budget.
"You price according to need," said Philip J. Smith, executive vice-president of the Shubert Organization, which owns 16 Broadway houses. "In theory, you price a show so that you break even at 50 percent capacity."
But producers also tend to watch one another to avoid seeming either greedy or foolhardy.
"We try to create a price scale not aberrational according to what everybody else is doing," said Michael David.
Some shows do come to Broadway with the aura of extenuating circumstances and can get away with prices above the norm: the limited-run, eight-and-a-half-hour "Nicholas Nickleby," say or "Miss Saigon," with its functioning helicopter onstage, which commanded $100 for an orchestra seat. (For "Miss Saigon," the $100 price tag was for only 200 seats a performance, and it lasted only until the capitalization was recouped.) But most shows hover in the same region and bump their heads on a tacitly agreed-upon ceiling. When prices go up, they tend to do so collectively, and only after one show has tested the waters.
For two seasons, the top price for a Broadway seat -- which also means the price of most seats, since the whole orchestra and at least half the mezzanine are priced the same for most shows -- has been $65 for most musicals and $50 for most plays. ("Angels" is now $65, a record for a play.) But in the fall, the $75 ticket will arrive on Broadway, borne in by a revival of "Show Boat," and "Sunset Boulevard" tickets will go for $70.
While nobody disputes that that's a lot to pay for an evening's entertainment (not to mention eating dinner out, paying the baby-sitter and parking the car), producers say prices are justified, at least from a simple business standpoint. Labor and advertising costs have driven up budgets alarmingly, they say. And singing, dancing, costumes and special effects, not to mention the presence of a star, are what it takes to draw people out from in front of a movie or television screen these days; for the mass audience, live theater has become synonymous with extravaganza.
It's a bit of a circular argument -- the helicopter helps persuade a mass audience to part with big bucks, which is what pays for the helicopter -- and of course, one wonders whether, say, a revival of "Show Boat" really needs to be so extravagant that it couldn't survive with a $65 ticket. But in any case, all of this has helped turn the business of putting on a show into a high-risk, low-reward enterprise.
"You can do the arithmetic as well as I can," said Garth Drabinsky, the producer of "Show Boat." With a cast of 71, a 30-piece orchestra and more than 500 costumes, "Show Boat" will cost $8 million to stage and $600,000 to run every week. Even with the higher ticket prices, the show will need to run nearly a year to break even, and a good deal longer than that for the investors to see a significant return. If Broadway is going to flourish, producers say, investors need to be encouraged. Otherwise, there will be no Broadway at all.
That's the usual argument. Indeed, Mr. Landesman is fond of saying that a ticket regularly priced at $100 or more would be justified, strictly on the basis of economics.
"If we could get away with it, we'd charge $125," Mr. Landesman said. "But the public would go nuts."
 
Strategic Pricing
 If this all sounds a little hardheaded and archaic, it is. Virtually everyone interviewed for this article admitted that the theater business has lagged in marketing ideas. But in general, because producers are rarely willing to risk the fortunes of any particular show on any new idea, innovations have been few. And the fact is, in contrast with the airline business, producers have only begun to exploit the idea of ticket pricing as a marketing tool.
"The industry sees discounting as panic liquidation of inventory," said Susan Lee, the director of marketing for the League of American Theaters and Producers. "What we never do is look at what kind of customers buy at what price point, and how to keep them coming."
 
Reluctant Experiments
 As a result, experiments to create greater blocs of lower-priced seats have languished. There's no reason, for example, that instead of pricing all orchestra seats at $65, a producer could not offer the first 10 rows at a premium price and reduce the price a similar amount on the rear 10. The revenue would be the same. This technique has occasionally been tried, with varying degrees of success; it isn't in operation everywhere because producers believe the public won't understand it.
"The problem is, you create a great perception that this is being handled in an elitist way," Mr. Landesman said, "and that a select few, who are not the general public, are getting select seats."
When "Miss Saigon," in the first nine months of its run, offered about 200 tickets for each performance at $100 each, many customers assumed the worst.
"We began to encounter market research that said people believed that $100 was the price for all seats usually sold for the top price," said Alan Wasser, the show's general manager.
(There are also plans that would raise prices to certain shows that have languished as well. Producers have often discussed a system that lets the demand for tickets determine the price. This would combat scalping but might put a show like "Phantom" out of reach of all but the very affluent until months into its run.)
In the end, of course, all the explanations and rationalizations still leave many would-be theatergoers at home. In a recent letter to The New York Times, Beatrice S. Daly, a librarian at the Queens Public Library, echoed the frustration of many. "What I'd really like to know is how a person of finite resources can attend the theater," she wrote. "Do producers want to empty theaters?"
Of course, they say no. But when you bring up to them the case of a Ms. Daly, someone who wants to visit Broadway but can't afford it, or even a hypothetical case -- a Brooklyn couple, say, who have cut their regular theatergoing from six times a year to twice -- the response is pure chagrin.
"It's not like we're rubbing our hands together thinking about all the money we're going to make," Michael David said. "I don't know how to fix the situation for the couple from Brooklyn who want to go six times a year. To give them six shows they want to see at the prices they can afford? I don't know how to do it."
 
 
How to Order, With or Without a Discount
 Here are some ways to buy discount tickets for Broadway shows, along with information on telephone ticket services and ticket brokers:
 
TKTS BOOTHS. The two booths are at Duffy Square, 47th Street and Broadway, open daily, and on the mezzanine of 2 World Trade Center, open daily except Sunday. Tickets for selected shows are sold on the day of performance, with availability posted at the front of the booth. Tickets cost 50 or 75 percent of box-office prices, as determined by the producers, plus a $2.50 service charge per ticket. Information: (212) 768-1818.
 
THEATER DEVELOPMENT FUND MAILING LIST. The same organization that runs the TKTS booths has a mail-order service, selling tickets to members at $14 plus $1.50 mailing charge. Students, teachers, union members, retired people, performing-arts professionals, members of the clergy and armed forces personnel all qualify for membership. To apply, send a request, with a self-addressed stamped envelope to T.D.F., 1501 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10036.
 
TWOFERS. The Hit Show Club distributes discount coupons in stores throughout the New York metropolitan area and also keeps a mailing list. The coupons, redeemable at the box office or by mail, offer discounts of 25 to 50 percent to selected shows. To join the club, send a stamped, self-addressed envelope for the first mailing to the Hit Show Club, 630 Ninth Avenue, Room 808, New York, N.Y. 10036. Recorded information: (212) 581-4211.
 
SCHOOL THEATER TICKET PROGRAM. This program distributes discount coupons to teachers, librarians and counselors at schools in the New York City area, who are to make them available to students. Prices range from $35 to $50. Saturday night performances are not available for most shows. Information: Sheila Berkowsky, (212) 354-4722.
 
MAILING LISTS. If you are a season subscriber to a nonprofit theater, like Lincoln Center Theater or Manhattan Theater Club, you may receive letters offering discounts on Broadway or Off Broadway productions. Most are for previews or the first few weeks after openings.
 
GROUP SALES. Many shows offer discounts, usually 10 to 20 percent, on the purchase of 20 or more tickets. The Shubert and Nederlander organizations have their own group-sales offices, and several independent businesses handle group sales. The telephone numbers are generally included in newspaper advertisements. The amount of the discount and when it is offered are determined by the producers, so it is possible for a group to pay less for "Show Boat" (which is offering a 10 percent discount on $75 tickets ordered before May 1) than for "Sunset Boulevard" (which is offering no discount at all on its $70 tickets).
 
WHEELCHAIR TICKETS. All three Broadway theater owners offer special discounts to theatergoers in wheelchairs, and to their companions or attendants. The Shubert Organization, which owns 16 theaters, offers tickets for $7.50. The Nederlander Organization, with nine theaters, sells tickets for $15. Tickets to shows in the five houses owned by Jujamcyn Theaters are half price. The number of available seats at a particular theater is limited by space and fire laws.
 
TELEPHONE ORDERS. Broadway tickets may be ordered by phone through Telecharge (for shows in Jujamcyn or Shubert theaters) or Ticketmaster (for Nederlander theaters), but theatergoers pay for the convenience. Telecharge, (212) 239-6200, adds $4.75 a ticket. Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4100, adds $5 a ticket plus a $2.50 handling charge for the order.
 
TICKET BROKERS. Brokers who operate in New York State or advertise in New York-based media are allowed to charge 10 percent or $5 more than the face value of a ticket, whichever is more, plus credit card charges. That, however, does not curtail abuses: recent calls to brokers advertising in New York newspapers turned up Broadway tickets for as much as $225. In a pinch, the concierges at many New York hotels have been known to find a ticket or two for hotel guests who just didn't plan well enough and are willing to pay for their forgetfulness.
 
 
Economics 101: Why 'Show Boat' Costs $75
 Tickets to "Show Boat," which is to open at the Gershwin Theater on Oct. 2, are now on sale for a top price of $75, a new high for a regularly priced ticket for an open-ended Broadway run. Here is why:
The show's producer, Garth Drabinsky, said the production would cost $8 million to open. Beyond that, he said, it will cost about $600,000 a week to run, by far the highest operating budget on Broadway.
The Gershwin, with about 1,900 seats, is Broadway's largest. With eight performances a week, that's 15,200 tickets, and if all sold for $75, that would be a potential gross of $1,140,000.
Not all the seats will be $75 seats, however; about two-thirds will be. Mr. Drabinsky said about 100 seats a night would be held as complimentary house seats.
"Then after you deduct discounts for group sales and credit-card commissions, the gross at capacity is around $900,000," Mr. Drabinsky said. "Some weeks you'll do capacity, some not. You know that when it snows in New York, you'll do less. You assume you'll do 85 percent to 90 percent capacity. That's a safe number. The show breaks even at approximately 63 percent capacity."
If the show will gross $900,000 at capacity, then at 85 percent capacity the weekly gross is about $765,000. That's a weekly profit of $165,000, which means the $8 million original investment will be recouped in 48 weeks.
If the top tickets to "Show Boat" were $65, the weekly gross at 85 percent capacity would be about $680,000, an $80,000 profit, which would mean the show would need 100 weeks, nearly two years, to break even.
"I knew we'd have to do this before I opened the show in Toronto," Mr. Drabinsky said of the ticket price. "So far the public has been respectful of what we're trying to do, and there hasn't been negative feedback on it. But it's always difficult to be the first." BRUCE WEBER

HEADLINE: Fairer Schooling for Michigan

 BODY:
This week citizens of Michigan voted courageously to toss out decades of tradition in public school financing. It is the first statewide, voluntary shift away from property taxes, as a rising national chorus of disgruntled homeowners and civil rights activists seek more equitable ways to provide one of society's most basic services.
Education in America has traditionally been seen as a local concern. Hence the reliance on property taxes, which are also less vulnerable to economic fluctuations, to finance school systems. 
 But property assessments within and among states diverge wildly. Across the country, the amounts of money spent on schools based on the taxes derived from those assessments are unconscionably unequal. In Michigan, for example, the poorest districts spend about $3,200 per pupil, while the richest spend $10,000. In New York, the bottom 10 percent of districts spend an average of $5,670 per pupil, while the top 10 percent average $11,265.
Legal efforts to challenge such disparities have rebounded from 1973, when the Supreme Court rejected such an attack from Texas and refused to declare education a fundamental right. Now 28 states are involved in lawsuits, many based on state constitutional promises of fairness, that seek to redistribute school aid.
Older voters in many communities have refused to tolerate rising property taxes to pay for schools. And many middle-class parents in cities, who send their children to private schools, have less of a stake in public schools that increasingly serve minority and poor students.
At the same time, the education reform movement of the last decade has elevated good schooling to a matter of statewide and even national concern. During that time, states and localities have reversed their stake in school financing. On average, the proportion of school aid coming from states has gradually increased from about 40 percent to 50 percent, while the proportion of aid coming from localities has dropped from 50 to 40.
Michigan will now go much further. Under a new financing plan pushed by Gov. John Engler, a conservative Republican, the state sales tax will jump from 4 to 6 percent. The increase is expected to raise about $2 billion, which would replace the same amount in property taxes. An increase in the cigarette tax will generate an additional $350 million.
Under the new plan, less than 10 percent of school funds will come from property taxes. In a state ranked eighth nationwide in property tax burden, that was surely a motivating factor for the 70 percent of voters who supported the plan. It also seeks to reduce disparities by setting a minimum of $4,200 per pupil for each district and capping spending increases by wealthier districts.
It is not yet clear if the sales tax will be a reliable source of school funds over the long term. But the status quo is unacceptable. Throughout most of the U.S., children in wealthier school districts continue to benefit from superior education while those who live in poorer districts -- and who need more resources, not fewer -- continue to be deprived.
The public schools have given generations of Americans a chance to fight their way up from poverty. If America is to live up to its promise of equal opportunity, this glaring inequity in education must be addressed. The fact that Michigan voters have voluntarily, and so overwhelmingly, tried to make school financing fairer should make other states sit up and take notice.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
A Friend Differs

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia

 BODY:
"I think the United States has wrong-footed itself unnecessarily in its argument with Japan," Prime Minister Paul Keating said.
"If it argues that Japan should open its markets to the rest of the world, having secured so much itself in the multilateral trading system, it cannot lose that argument. But if it then argues that the way to do it is through managed trade and quotas imposed on a market economy, it's bound to lose the argument." 
 Why? I asked. His answer was that managed trade would not work:
"What American President, what Australian prime minister, what German chancellor, what Japanese prime minister can deliver on behalf of their manufacturing or service industries great chunks of market share? I suggest: None."
Mr. Keating did not direct his criticism at President Clinton. After Mr. Clinton's efforts on Nafta and the GATT negotiations, he said, "the multilateralist in him is pretty obvious." But he suggested that the President was feeling pressure for "bilateral solutions."
"Because of a slowness in reconstructing its economy in the 1980's," he said, America has had "a loss of confidence in its capacity to trade profitably in these new burgeoning markets" in Asia.
But in fact, he said, "the United States is making very large productivity changes, changes to its business culture. Look at the car industry. In quality and price you can actually win a legitimate market battle. You don't need to be tricky about that."
Americans may find it a bit surprising to have the leader of an Australian Labor Government talking in those tough market terms. But Mr. Keating has moved the Labor Party to the center on economic and other issues, and the policy has been a remarkable political success.
He became Prime Minister in 1991 by carrying out a party coup against the man who had the job, Bob Hawke. A year ago this week he faced an election that all the experts said was "unwinnable" -- and won.
On China, too, the Keating Government differs from Clinton policy. The United States is right to put its views on human rights to China strongly, Mr. Keating said -- as he has done. "But to go the next point and say, well, if you don't accept that view, we will then rupture the relationship is not an ideal solution in a less than ideal world.
"The problem in all these things is, if you put a hook in your own mouth, you've got to be able to dislodge it. I just hope that U.S. policy makers have thought that through."
Was there any compromise way out of the conflict with China, I asked, for example by Washington imposing some penalty on Chinese trade but not completely dropping China's most-favored-nation status? "Probably there is," he said, but it would require a gesture from China on human rights -- one that would take patient, firm negotiating to achieve.
The Prime Minister mixed these comments with warm praise for President Clinton. "In this Presidency," he said, "there is a chance to restore the faith Americans have had in their highest office as an agency for change.
"I think that societies find leaders like this once in a generation, if they're lucky. They've got one now, and they should value it."
There was a sense in the interview of Mr. Keating's identifying with Mr. Clinton. They are of the same generation -- the Prime Minister 50, the President 47. They have in common, too, the rise from humble origins. But Mr. Keating has nothing like Yale and Oxford in his background. He left school at 15 and entered Parliament at 25.
"I learned the hard way," the Prime Minister said. "I educated myself largely. I had to build in my head a model of this country, its society and economy, how you keep a society together, how you deliver assistance to those who are disadvantaged and low-paid without holding back those who are able to create wealth."
A striking aspect of his personality is his love of the arts. He is a hard politician with a rough tongue, dismissing opponents as "low-lifes" and "grubs." But in music he goes for the romantic: from Beethoven to Elgar and Mahler. He said esthetic interests influence his view of the world: "I've always been run by my eyes and ears."

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Tobacco Industry Tests Its Influence

BYLINE: By KATHARINE SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Smoking and anti-smoking forces clashed today in a preview of what will probably occur next week when a House subcommittee takes the first vote on far-reaching legislation that would ban smoking in most public places throughout the country.
The vote by the subcommittee on health and the environment, which is expected to take place on Tuesday, will provide a gauge of the tobacco industry's influence in Congress. More and more cities, states and businesses are banning smoking. 
 The bill being sponsored by Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, and called the Smoke-Free Environment Act, would ban smoking in virtually all buildings, although smoking would be allowed in some designated areas with outside ventilation.
The pro-tobacco forces said in the subcommittee hearing today that the bill represented unnecessary regulation, impinged on individual liberties and would put tobacco farmers out of work.
A scientist from the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said the bill was the result of a desire to be "politically correct" rather than of scientific evidence. The scientist, Chris Coggins, showed a chart that he said indicated that a family history of tuberculosis and a diet high in saturated fats were more likely to cause cancer than being married to a smoker. His chart did not show the risks from cigarettes themselves.
The anti-smoking forces included business owners who testified that banning smoking made good economic sense because it cut employee absenteeism, increased productivity and reduced other costs. They also included owners of shopping malls who had their own anti-smoking rules but said they needed a Federal law that applied to everyone so that they wouldn't be hurt by people who preferred to shop or open businesses in malls where smoking was allowed. KATHARINE SEELYE

With him was Lauren Minor, 8, of Largo, Md., one of four children with asthma who spoke of their discomfort from smoke. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Winning New York Munis Took Credit Risk

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
Most of the winning New York municipal bond funds took on credit risk and won: They held big chunks of middle-tier New York issues that have rallied sharply since their ratings were lowered in early 1992.
Flagship, for example, had half its portfolio invested in debt rated BBB (just above junk-bond status) at the end of December, and Value Line had 59 percent then, according to Morningstar Inc., the mutual fund research company in Chicago. 
 Eileen Sanders, a Morningstar analyst, predicted the muni funds would chug ahead, in part because of a tighter supply of issues. Rising interest rates hurt the funds because they depress bond prices, but higher Federal taxes make the tax-free interest payments more valuable, she said.
If you believe the economy is coming out of recession, you can safely stay with the funds that own lower-rated paper.
But investors who do not want to take on that risk should look for muni funds whose BBB-rated holdings equal less than 20 percent of their portfolios, Ms. Sanders said.

STEPS TO AID MIDEAST TALKS
The United States announced steps that will help bring about a resumption of talks between Israel and the P.L.O. and said that Syria, Lebanon and Jordan will return to the broader Mideast peace talks. 1 

U.N. CONDEMNS HEBRON MASSACRE

ISRAEL PONDERS MOVING SETTLERS

SOUTH AFRICA CONSPIRACY
Senior officials of the South African police helped Zulu nationalists in a campaign of terrorism, a judicial panel reported, the strongest evidence yet of a conspiracy to sabotage a transition to majority rule. 1
 
ARGENTINA OUTBACK DYING OUT

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Markets
 
Financial markets were alarmed at what traders saw as encroachment of the Administration on the independence of the Federal Reserve after the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, was summoned to the White House for what the Administration said was a routine meeting with President Clinton. [Page 39.]
 
The Dow climbed 30.51 points in the third-busiest day ever, with nearly 450 million shares traded. The trading volume was pushed up by the "triple witching hour" expirations of options and futures and the anxiety over the meeting between Mr. Greenspan and President Clinton. [39.]
 
Treasury securities plunged as the Clinton-Greenspan meeting also rattled the bond market. Bonds gave up almost all their gains for the week, with the yield on the 30-year bond rising to 6.90 percent, from 6.82 percent. [48.]
 
Prices of precious metals rose on the widespread turmoil in the financial markets. Gold jumped $4.60 an ounce, to $387.60, in New York. Silver and platinum also gained. [47.]
 
The dollar rose against other leading currencies on expectations that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates. [47.]
 
 
The Economy
 
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen convened a meeting of finance ministers from 17 Pacific countries in Hawaii, furthering the Clinton Administration's effort to focus American business toward Asia and away from traditional European markets. [39.]
 
Dallas beat several cities to effectively win the offices of a new labor secretariat that will enforce a side agreement to the North American Free Trade Agreement on workplace standards. [38.]
 
 
Companies
 
Bankers Trust New York paid its chairman $10 million last year, an amount equal to about 1 percent of its profits. [17.]
 
Macy's senior creditors are squaring off with Laurence A. Tisch over his holdings in the company and his increasingly active role as the chairman of its finance committee. [39.]
 
Some drug companies dispute claims by lawyers for women with breast implants that a final settlement has been reached to compensate the women for health problems. [8.]
 
Whittle Communications will close its book publishing operations, which have failed to obtain sufficient advertising commitments for the next fiscal year. [41.]
 
Newmont Gold shareholders approved a complex stock and asset-balancing plan with Newmont Mining that will create the world's sixth-largest gold producer. [41.]
 
Hat Brands, the country's biggest hat maker, plans to acquire Texace, a maker of golf hats. Terms were not disclosed. [41.]
 
Gun makers like Sturm, Ruger are worried that rising concerns about gun violence will hurt business. [8.]
 
 
International
 
Foreign companies gained a bigger share of Japan's semiconductor market in the fourth quarter of 1993, which could help defuse another trade dispute with the United States. [39.]
 
The British Government will not hold antitrust hearings on a deal that would give a majority stake in The Independent newspaper to a group including the owner of the tabloid Daily Mirror, effectively ending the battle for control of the paper. [41.]
 
 
Your Money
 
All-weather funds can protect investors during downturns in the market and make money over time. [37.]
 
Increasing savings can be a powerful investment strategy that usually involves little sacrifice and few risks. [37.]
 
More young people are learning to invest long before they enter the real world, to gain security and learn to handle risk. [37.]
 
Life insurance agents' commissions are under criticism in the wake of sales improprieties at Met Life. [38.]

HEADLINE: Looking to Asia, Bentsen Sees History in Making

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 18

 BODY:
Since taking office, the Clinton Administration has tried to focus American business away from its traditional European markets and toward Asia, and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen took another step in that direction today.
He convened finance ministers from 17 Pacific nations here after tantalizing an audience of American investors in Los Angeles with the observation that the Asia-Pacific region would be starting the equivalent of 18 Santa Monica Freeway projects every day for a decade. 
 "I don't have to tell people in this town about the need for freeways," Mr. Bentsen told a business group in Los Angeles this morning, before flying to Hawaii for the Asia-Pacific Conference. "I've given you a lot of numbers, but here is some I think hit home. In Asia -- excluding Japan -- they will spend a trillion dollars in infrastructure of all types in the next decade. That's a Century Freeway every week."
 
Big, Even for a Texan
 Mr. Bentsen added: "If I were 30 years younger, I know what market I'd want to be in. I'm from Texas. I'm used to big. But it is difficult to comprehend how big that market is and how those economies are transforming."
Mr. Bentsen's remarks, and this weekend's first gathering ever of all the finance ministers from the key nations in the Asia-Pacific region, are part of the Treasury Department's efforts to redefine both the boundaries and content of American financial diplomacy.
Throughout the cold war, the financial diplomacy of the United States tended to be centered on the industrial democracies of the Group of Seven -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- and confined largely to interest-rate and exchange-rate coordination.
The Group of Seven jobs conference in Detroit this week was an attempt by the Administration to begin transforming the organization to deal with more practical matters of daily life, like unemployment.
 This weekend's meeting in Hawaii of the 17-nation Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, known as APEC, which includes economic powerhouses like China, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia and Taiwan, is the latest manifestation of the Clinton Administration's main message today to America's business leaders: "Go west."
As one Administration official put it: "The G-7 jobs summit is about what is going wrong. APEC is about what is going right."
 Whatever the geo-strategic thinking may be in other parts of the Administration, the Treasury Department is operating on the assumption that when the history of the late 20th century is written, the most important transformation historians will point to will not be the end of the cold war. Rather, it is likely to be the flow of more money more rapidly to one region -- Asia and the Pacific -- than has occurred in any decade in world history.
 
On Par With the Renaissance?
 As a result of those capital flows, two billion people -- two and a half times as many as those living in the industrialized West -- are bringing themselves into modernity in the space of a single generation. This growth spurt, Treasury experts argue, will ultimately rank with the Industrial Revolution and the Renaissance. In economic terms, South Korea alone grew as much in a single generation as the United States did in the last century.
If that is the direction history is going, said Lawrence H. Summers, Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, "we want to make sure that we don't look back in the year 2050 and say that the 1980's and 1990's were when it all began and had we only done 'X' or 'Y' we would have been fully a part of it."
 Whether the Clinton team can mobilize American business capital to exploit fully the region's opportunities is an open question, but the Administration has put its mouth where it wants its money to be.
"People, especially in Europe, think we are an Atlantic nation," Mr. Bentsen said to his audience in Los Angeles. "We are also a Pacific nation. We do more trade across the Pacific than the Atlantic. Our largest state is on the Pacific, isn't it?"
Nationally, Mr. Bentsen added, 60 percent of American exports -- $270 billion worth of products -- now go to the 17 Asia-Pacific nations whose finance ministers will be represented in Hawaii this week.
"Asia is a continent that economically could be larger than Europe and the United States combined within the next 50 years," Mr. Bentsen said, warming to the subject. "By the year 2000, even leaving Japan out, some 75 million Asian households will have incomes comparable to middle-income Americans. We are talking about economies that make up half of the world's output, but the finance ministers of these economies have never met all together in one room."
 
Ideas for Financing
 Administration officials plan to use this specific meeting, which started tonight with a reception and dinner, to discuss how Asia-Pacific countries can most efficiently raise foreign capital for development projects -- something the United States wants to make sure it is influencing from the ground floor.
"To keep growth up, there has to be financing behind it," Mr. Bentsen noted. "The Asians have high savings rates. I admire them. I am envious of them. But they are not that high to pay for a Century Freeway every week. Corporate retained earnings won't do it. Borrowing at the local bank won't do it. They need outside capital."
The Secretary pointed out that multilateral development banks, like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, had been leading sources of capital in the region. But both are short of money, and because of budget cuts the United States has not been replenishing their funds as it did in the past. The Administration is trying to persuade Congress to free some money; this conference is part of that strategy.
"In these budget-axing times, I've heard people question, 'Why do we give money to those banks?' " Mr. Bentsen said. "Let me put it this way. When you have satisfied the American market for 747's, you have to sell them somewhere else. Those developing countries are the ones that need airplanes, and they are turning out to be pretty good customers."

HEADLINE: Bentsen Says China Would Lose Trade Status Now

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 18

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen said today that if the Clinton Administration had to decide whether or not to renew China's preferable trade status now, it would not do so because of Beijing's human rights behavior.
Mr. Bentsen, speaking in Los Angeles this morning before flying to Hawaii to be the host of a conference of Asian Pacific Finance Ministers, was asked about the status of the Administration's China policy after Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit to Beijing, which was marred by repeated arrests of Chinese human rights advocates during his stay. 
 "Human rights is a major concern," Mr. Bentsen said. "To the extent that we can influence China, we want to do so. But we must balance economic interest, which is not an easy task. You have to be careful how you do that to avoid just giving competitors an advantage."
Each year in June the Administration decides whether to renew China's most favorite nation benefits, which allow it to export products to the United States at the lowest possible tariff rate. That decision depends on China's ability to meet certain minimum human rights standards, like accounting for political prisoners or ceasing the use of prison labor for exports.
"If the decision was made today, I assume China would lose its M.F.N. privileges," Mr. Bentsen said. "But we have until June and hopefully we can work it out."
Mr. Christopher's recent visit to China has been widely criticized within the Clinton Administration and White House, because it transformed an issue that was best dealt with in a quiet low-key fashion into a high profile spat between the two countries.

HEADLINE: Clinton-Fed Chief Talk Alarms the Markets

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
A Presidential invitation to the chairman of the Federal Reserve for what the White House insisted was a routine meeting today turned into an embarrassment for both men, as financial markets reacted with alarm to the appearance of Administration encroachment on the central bank's independence.
Bond prices fell sharply and stocks briefly dipped this morning after Fed and White House officials said Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, had canceled a planned trip to Houston and a short speech there. Instead, he attended the weekly meeting of the President with his top economic advisers to review the health of the economy. 
 Administration and Fed officials said the furor was a result of a succession of missteps.
 
Invitation on Thursday
 Robert E. Rubin, the head of the National Economic Council, some of whose members attend the Friday meetings, began discussing with aides on Monday or Tuesday the possibility of inviting Mr. Greenspan, but did not extend the invitation until Thursday at lunchtime.
Mr. Greenspan accepted without mentioning his plans to go to Houston for a conference sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. He canceled the trip. "What he was going to do in Houston was open a panel discussion -- it wasn't like he was going to give a major policy address," Bob Stahly Moore, a spokesman for the Fed, said.
Participants at the Houston conference, many of them economists and professional Fed watchers, became alarmed as Fed officials began to tell them on Thursday afternoon and this morning that Mr. Greenspan would not attend because he had been summoned to the White House. The Fed watchers, who had traveled to Houston to keep an eye on Mr. Greenspan, were caught flat-footed in the wrong city and began making agitated telephone calls to the East Coast to find out what was going on.
"People don't know quite what's up," Robert Eisner, a professor of economics at Northwestern University, said in a telephone interview from the conference this morning.
The White House and the Fed expressed surprise at the strong reaction to today's meeting and blamed one another for attracting attention to the meeting. "There has never been a big fuss about this before," said Gene Sperling, a senior official on the White House National Economic Council. "It appears to me that the announcement by the people who were putting on the speech seemed somehow to create a false impression."
Bonds gave up almost all their gains from the week, with the yield on 30-year bonds rising to 6.90 percent, from 6.82 percent. [Page 48.]
Administration and Fed officials went out of their way today to describe the meeting as unimportant and say that interest rates were not discussed. "We certainly didn't try to suggest or persuade Chairman Greenspan, nor should we, what his outlook or policy should be," said Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House's chief of staff. "He reviewed both the domestic and world economies, and sees good underlying fundamentals."
But Wall Street was not convinced that today's White House meeting was unimportant or routine. "I would certainly perceive it as an attempt to bring undue political pressure," said David Jones, a longtime Fed watcher at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York. A Presidential discussion of the economy's health can be a veiled way for the White House to signal the Fed that further increases in interest rates could hurt economic growth and would be unwelcome, he said.
Financial markets are particularly nervous now because the Fed's interest-rate policy committee is set to meet Tuesday and has been expected for weeks to raise rates then. Today's flap probably convinced them that higher rates were even more likely now, to avoid the public impression that the Fed had yielded to any pressure from the White House.
"The Fed is going to be tested now with regard to its anti-inflation credibility because of this meeting," Mr. Jones said. By raising short-term rates, the Fed can slow economic growth and hold down inflation.
At the Fed committee's last meeting, on Feb. 4, top Fed officials voted to raise by a quarter of a percentage point the interest rates that banks charge one another for overnight loans.
President Clinton last met with Mr. Greenspan on Jan. 21, which was a Friday, and on Nov. 8, which was a Monday. Neither meeting was publicly announced, but many Government officials and financial markets were aware of them soon after.
Today's meeting took place with the usual secrecy -- Mr. Greenspan came and went through the south entrance of the White House, out of the view of television cameras -- but became public because it was scheduled on short notice and forced Mr. Greenspan to cancel the speech in Houston at the last minute.
Robert D. McTeer Jr., the president of the Dallas Federal Reserve Bank, read aloud at the conference some excerpts from Mr. Greenspan's prepared remarks. According to a brief text of the remarks supplied by the Fed here, Mr. Greenspan had planned to offer a review of economic research into low savings rates in the United States.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan were joined at this morning's meeting by Vice President Al Gore; Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Mr. Rubin.
Alan Blinder, another member of the Council of Economic Advisers, usually attends the Friday meetings but recused himself today because he was the leading candidate for President Clinton to nominate as the next vice chairman of the Fed. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen also attends most of these meetings, but he was on the way to a meeting in Hawaii of finance ministers from Asian and Pacific Rim countries.

HEADLINE: Rally Ends Hectic Day For Stocks

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In one of the most hectic sessions ever, the stock market plunged on Washington rumors in the morning, endured the quarterly rite of passage called "the triple witching hour," then rallied as bargain hunters snapped up brand-name stocks like Honeywell, Exxon and Boeing.
But the action was over fast. In the opening 60 minutes, a record 220 million shares changed hands, two-thirds the volume of a typical day's session. 
 It was a turbulent close to a week in which most economic indicators were uniformly favorable, but market professionals continued to be unusually sensitive to any news or rumors about interest rates in advance of Tuesday's policy-setting meeting of the Federal Reserve Board.
 
Dow Up 30.51 Points
 For the day, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 30.51 points, to 3,895.65. After dropping as much as 17 points before 10 A.M., the market rallied strongly, moved sideways for much of the day, then rose more than 14 points in the last seconds of trading, probably because of high-speed computer-guided trading.
The trading volume was swollen by "triple witching hour" selling activity, as well as anxiety over a suspicious-looking, although apparently innocuous, meeting between Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and President Clinton.
After record trading in the opening hour, volume slowed, but at 462.2 million shares, it was still the third heaviest in history and the highest since Oct. 20, 1987, when 608 million shares changed hands just after the stock market plunge of Oct. 19, when 604 million shares were traded.
Yesterday started anxious. At 7:28 A.M., Bloomberg News Service ran a headline that read, "Greenspan Cancels Houston Speech to Meet With Clinton Today."
 
Bond Traders Panicked
 The headline was a signal for bond traders to whisper wild rumors. "Everybody got panicked," said Jan E. Terbrueggen, a bond portfolio manager for Flagship Financial in Dayton, Ohio, which manages $5 billion in fixed-income investments.
By 8 A.M., the price for the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond began plunging in earnest, falling as low as 9120/32 shortly before 11 A.M., when the news service's headline read, "Greenspan Arrives at White House for Meeting With Clinton." By noon, the White House began describing the meeting as routine and no cause for alarm. Bond prices began to firm, but still ended lower for the day.
For the stock market, the Clinton-Greenspan meeting dovetailed with Friday's triple witching hour, when three sets of futures and options contracts expire on the same day. The impact of such sessions has lessened substantially in recent years, with traders buying or selling stocks before the expiration date.
But as Friday opened, the last remaining contracts had to be exercised, and they involved millions of shares. Suddenly those sell orders merged with a panic selling of shares brought on by the drop in bond prices, as well as parallel stock market anxiety about the Clinton-Greenspan meeting.
 
Enthusiasm on Inflation
 Meanwhile, other traders who had been buying stocks in the nascent enthusiasm following favorable Producer and Consumer Price Indexes noticed the price drops. They bid up shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.16 yesterday to 471.06. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, after establishing a record yesterday, was little changed, rising 0.08 point, to 803.93. The New York Stock Exchange rose 0.24 point, to 261.35. Declining stocks edged advancing stocks by 1,091 to 1,071. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 2.33 points, to 472.96.
Bloomberg Financial Services recorded the Dow industrials at 4 P.M. as 3,881.55, but as late trades got counted the Dow spurted to 3,895.65. For the week, the Dow moved ahead 32.95 points.
The New York Stock Exchange, as is its practice on witching days, published a list of 61 stocks with order imbalances. They included American Express, A.T.& T., BankAmerica, Du Pont, General Motors, Pepsico, Procter & Gamble, Sears and Time Warner.
"The market always gets out of kilter," said Harrison Roth, senior options strategist for Cowen & Company, "but it's self-correcting, eventually." Does that mean that Monday will mean a down market for stocks? "The answer is yes," he said.
The most active stock yesterday was Northwest Airlines Corporation, an initial public offering that began trading yesterday after sharply cutting its offering price. Even though 9.7 million shares changed hands, Northwest's price of $13 closed unchanged from the offering price.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
When Dr. Baruch Goldstein massacred praying Muslims in Hebron, condemnations by religious leaders tumbled out one after another, in language that grew stronger by the hour.
The Jewish authorities were particularly sickened, calling the act a desecration of Judaism. And even before the deadly cycle of violence reached the Brooklyn Bridge, Muslim and Christian leaders had joined the chorus of condemnations and the pleas for religious peace. 
 For many, words issued in isolation were not enough. In New York City, Muslim, Jewish and Christian leaders and members of those faiths came together in solemn services, one night at a Manhattan synagogue, the next night at an imposing new mosque on the Upper East Side, the Islamic Cultural Center. During the main Sunday service at the Marble Collegiate Church on Fifth Avenue, which is affiliated with the Reformed Church in America, an imam, a rabbi and a minister conducted a three-way discussion about love.
Events that had been scheduled weeks earlier took on a new dimension. A Sufi mosque in lower Manhattan had invited representatives from the New York Board of Rabbis to observe the chants and prostrations of evening prayers and to share the breaking of the dawn-to-dusk Ramadan fast and the meal that follows.
Congeniality reigned as the rabbis sat cross-legged at the low tables and ate kosher dinners that the mosque provided. But the very hospitality of the banquet created its own ghost: sobering thoughts of the cost in lives of Muslim-Jewish estrangement.
Do these interfaith gestures make any difference? At the New York regional office of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the question haunted an early-morning emergency session of Muslim, Jewish and Christian leaders who meet regularly for an interfaith "trialogue."
How could they not speak out? But what would one more declaration accomplish? What could well-intentioned phrases avail against bullets spewing from a gun or against the anger that squeezes the trigger?
Two years ago, Patriarch Pavle, head of the Serbian Orthodox Church; Archbishop Vinko Puljic of Sarajevo, a Croatian Roman Catholic, and Jakub Efendi Selimoski, a leader of the Balkan Islamic community, met in Zurich under the auspices of the Appeal of Conscience Foundation, a New York-based interfaith organization. They condemned the "inhuman practice of ethnic cleansing."
So did Muslim, Catholic, Protestant, Orthodox Christian and Jewish leaders from central Asia, the Caucasus, Turkey and the Balkans when they met last month in Istanbul and denounced atrocities and violence carried out "in the name of God."
These statements -- and there have been scores of others -- always have their diplomatic lapses into vagueness. They never untie all the political knots or root out every hypocrisy. A skeptical press gives them little attention. But greater publicity would not keep them from being ignored in the churches, mosques and synagogues where distrust is bred and hatred is preached.
That people kill for religious reasons may appall believers, but it does not surprise them. It surprises only the irreligious, or at least those who have lost all sense of religion's power.
G. K. Chesterton argued that people should take up arms only for religious reasons; nothing less would do. He meant to set a high standard, not to urge low zealotry. But he was an Edwardian, and in a later age of total warfare, even talk like that seems dangerously frivolous.
Religion is deeply linked with bloodshed. Sacred texts are full of it. Purim, the religious holiday that may have set off Dr. Goldstein's rampage, has long been an innocent mix of children's masquerade and adult revelry, of Halloween and New Year's. But the festival's biblical basis, the Book of Esther, also celebrates a triumph of turnabout, when Jews in Persia were granted a spree of liquidating their enemies -- 75,000 of them, one verse says -- in a single day.
Only the modern mind can comprehend battling for land, lineage, power or gold but be baffled by religious strife. Until a few centuries ago, religion was inextricably bound up with economic and political power. Then, as today, leaders and tribes were driven to arms by greed, fear, dreams of conquest or promises of liberation -- and their gods always accompanied them.
Three centuries ago, when Western society separated life into the sacred and the secular, a major cause was revulsion from religious wars, a revulsion shared both by people who were religious and those who were secular. Since then, some secular people have felt that only the elimination of religion could free humanity of belief's bloody impulses. And some religious people have tried to create a benign blend of major faiths, purged of offensive differences and symbols.
Neither tactic has succeeded. When religion was erased from the list of things people fought about, something else, like nationhood or ideology, took its place.And attempts to devise a kind of religious Esperanto drew only coteries.
The remedy for religion's murderous toxins, it seems, must come from deep within each faith. Every world religion has its own antibodies to cruelty and fanaticism, although whether in the same proportions is an open question. Those antibodies are what interfaith encounters, rather than offering an escape from separate traditions, can discover and nurture.
To many in such encounters, they must seem terribly frail at times like these -- and utterly essential.

HEADLINE: Patagonia Fortunes Fade in Cloud of Volcanic Ash

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN JULIAN, Argentina

 BODY:
The wind whipped dust across Jack MacLean's 50,000-acre sheep ranch, where the fences are falling down, the weeds are a foot tall, and the shearing shed is coated with a thick layer of dust.
"We've hit rock bottom here," said Mr. MacLean, a 68-year-old descendant of Scottish immigrants. "It will be years before this land can recover and be used again." 
 Across the vast arid plains of Patagonia in southern Argentina, a rugged outback of legends and romance once populated by gauchos, visited by Charles Darwin and roamed by Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, the land and the livelihoods of its people are dying out.
To many in the country's big northern cities, Patagonia is a distant land they do not know. But it has caught the imagination of scientists and writers from around the world, not only for its stark pristine expanses, but also for the remarkable preservation of immigrant cultures not found elsewhere in Latin America.
Patagonia was settled in the 19th century by people from Wales, Scotland and South Africa who prospered from sheep farming and maintained tightly knit ethnic groups. But now they see their heritage and customs disappearing. Afrikaans and old Welsh, for example, once dominant languages in large sections of Patagonia, are seldom spoken today.
The region, roughly the size of Texas with one-tenth the population, seems to be reverting back to what Darwin first saw as "wretched gravel plains." Years of depressed wool prices and the centralization of Argentina's economy around Buenos Aires, the capital, have driven thousands of ranchers from their lands and forced the next generation to abandon its roots and look for jobs elsewhere.
 
Decades of Overgrazing
 Among the failing enterprises here are sprawling sheep ranches established in the 19th century that helped make Argentina one of the world's wealthiest countries. But decades of overgrazing has turned a fragile ecosystem of shrubs and grasslands into a barren plateau reminiscent of the Badlands of South Dakota.
But it is not just sheep regions that are suffering. In Puerto Madryn, in the province of Chubut, the Government-run aluminum smelter is cutting back production and seeking to lay off workers. In 1991, the Government shut down a major steel company in the Rio Negro city of Sierra Grande, leaving an entire city that grew up around the factory almost jobless. And in Comodoro Rivadavia, long prosperous from its oil industry, unemployment has soared as the newly privatized oil concern, Y.P.F., has laid off tens of thousands of workers over the last three years.
"All Patagonia is suffering," said James Gough, a sheep farmer in Esquel. "The only hope we have is to do a little tourism."
 
A Drought and a Volcano
 During the first half of this century, the wool produced in Patagonia was one of the exports that, along with beef from cattle raised in the Pampas to the north, made Argentina's per capita income the seventh-highest in the world. But eight years of depression in the sheep-farming sector has crippled the region. The world price for Patagonia wool has fallen from $1 a pound to under 30 cents, and such prices are expected for at least three more years.
The region has had three successive years of drought, with the San Julian area getting half its normal rainfall.
And in August 1991, the Hudson Volcano in the Chilean Andes some 300 miles to the northwest erupted, spewing vast amounts of volcanic ash into the atmosphere. Winds blew the ash over a triangular area in the Santa Cruz province of Patagonia, covering 25 million acres with fine gray dust and smothering vital pastures. More than one million sheep died over the next two weeks.
Now, almost three years later, much of the ash remains. Mr. MacLean has drifts on his farm up to a foot deep and he still discovers the carcasses of sheep buried beneath it.
"The ash gets into vegetation the sheep eat, and that grinds their teeth down," he said. "So after four years you have sheep with no teeth who cannot survive."
 
'Sheep Farming Was Done For'
 Mr. MacLean lost 2,600 animals, including 2,000 pregnant ewes, worth more than $100,000. After the Hudson Volcano, he locked the door to his farm house and left.
"The volcano only made us face the fact that sheep farming was done for," said Jorge Knoop, who lives in Comandante Luis Piedrabuena, 75 miles southwest of here. "It was a coup de grace for the Patagonian sheep farmer."
In his region, Mr. Knoop says 80 percent of the farms are not operating or have only a minimal number of sheep, and that 400 farms have been shut.
Enrique Ducca, president of the San Julian Rural Association, says the cost of raising sheep is now four times the price they get on the market. He calculates that almost half the land in Santa Cruz is without sheep or with fewer than 1,000 animals.
The troubles are also bringing social changes. Farmers have relatively few other skills, and their children are leaving to look for work in the major cities like Buenos Aires.
"There was no hope for my daughters here so I encouraged them to leave," said Juan Douglas Scott.
 
Selling Off Family Land
 Mr. Scott typifies the social change as well as the loss of large fortunes for those who once were considered among the elite of the country. His Scottish grandparents came to Patagonia from the British Falkland Islands in 1877 and began sheep farming. They became so prosperous that his mother and five aunts were sent to boarding school in Scotland. Mr. Scott attended St. George's, the most prestigious boarding school in Buenos Aires.
Hard times have forced him to sell most of the family's land.
Disaster relief from the central Government after the volcano has been paltry, a maximum of $12,000 per farmer. "What is so unfair is that sheep farmers for decades subsidized Argentina, paying more then 50 percent in taxes," said Mr. Scott. "What they are giving us is an insult."
San Julian, with its ornate banks and warehouses, now mostly shut, has all the markings of a once-flourishing town hit by hard times. Residents say life is boring. Cable television is the main source of entertainment.
Some assert that the natural disaster and the depressed wool industry may enable the land to regenerate after more than a century of sheep grazing.
Even so, ecologists say that that will not address the region's other environmental problems. Coastal oil spills have killed thousands of penguins and ponds filled with sludge from offshore drilling attract migrating geese that become covered with oil and die.
"The trouble is that talk about protecting the environment seems totally secondary," said Graham Harris, head of the Fundacion Patagonia Natural.
For its long-term survival, it seems that much of Patagonia will have to undergo major economic adjustment. But the future Patagonia will most likely be a humble shadow of its former self, with industries such as crate-making and ice production that provincial government officials say can complement the fishing industry.
"I really threw away a large part of my life," said Mr. Scott, who agreed at the urging of his brothers and sister to manage his family's ranch here, instead of pursuing a different career. "It's time I can't get back and now it's difficult to know what to do."

HEADLINE: Yankees Show Little Interest in Old-Style Stadium Renovation

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
New York City's plan to restore Yankee Stadium to the look it enjoyed in the days of Babe Ruth and Joe DiMaggio appears headed for a formidable roadblock: the Yankees do not seem interested.
George M. Steinbrenner, the principal owner, has not commented since the plan was formally presented by Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson to Yankees officials last month as part of a $270 million package of stadium improvements and other inducements to keep the Yankees in the Bronx after their lease expires in 2002. 
 The money would come from city, state and Federal sources, although it is not yet clear what the breakdown would be. Mr. Steinbrenner also has not scheduled any meetings with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
John Lawn, the team's vice president of operations, said Mr. Steinbrenner focused on other financial and structural aspects of the proposal when he was shown the details of the city's plan.
"The look wasn't Mr. Steinbrenner's focus," Mr. Lawn said. "He didn't say I don't care, but he asked questions about the luxury boxes and parking and other things that get people more easily into the ball park and out."
The city's proposal, which was made late last year amid rising concerns that the Yankees might abandon the Bronx for a site in New Jersey, includes a new parking garage with at least 3,000 spaces, dozens of new luxury boxes, a Metro-North station, improved roadways and a retail arcade outside the stadium.
But the most striking part of the proposal is a $90 million plan to restore the nostalgia to the 71-year-old stadium by re-creating the elegant Gothic roof facade that once ringed the ball park and by bringing some of the monuments back into center field, where they were until the stadium was renovated in 1974 and 1975.
"When they've talked about putting the monuments back on the field, that means center field will have to be 570 feet away," Mr. Lawn said, exaggerating the pre-renovation stadium's distance of 461 feet from home plate to the center-field fence. "That'll depend a lot on how good our right-hand hitters are."
Creating a new facade, which would require installing a new, overhanging roof, "was a nice touch, but the bottom line is getting fans into the seats and then out of the stadium," Mr. Lawn said. "Mr. Steinbrenner liked the luxury suite suggestions, which is what he wanted to address."
But at least one top state official has questioned whether the retro approach would be worth the money. "There are a lot better ways to use $90 million," said Vincent Tese, chairman of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
Mr. Lawn said that whether any plan is adopted, mistrust between the city and Yankees management has to be eliminated. Last year, Mr. Steinbrenner and other club officials complained regularly that the city had not lived up to the terms of the 1992 lease. "His concern is, will the city do what it's promised?" he said. "His pleasure at the proposal was tempered by whether they do what they've proposed. I'd say if this thing goes forward, a lot of things will change."
 
Waiting on Team
 Henry Stern, the Commissioner of the Parks Department, which leases the stadium to the team, said that the next step rested with the Yankees, and that the city's plan would not change until the team reacted.
"Our plan is tentative and presented to show the city's willingness to go forward," Mr. Stern said. "We're not going to spend a lot of money on architectural plans before we know we can proceed."
The urgency to sign Mr. Steinbrenner to a lease extension, so fervent last summer, seems to have faded. The election of Christine Todd Whitman as Governor of New Jersey has taken the wind out of the behind-the-scenes efforts to woo the Yankees across the Hudson River.
Ms. Whitman has already rejected a plan to build an arena in Camden for the Philadelphia 76ers, fearing the potential tax liability. And she has suggested selling off parts of the state's powerful Sports and Exposition Authority.
Michael Francis, the authority's new chairman, said: "We won't actively seek to steal a team from New York. If the city and state can't come to terms with Mr. Steinbrenner, we'd be interested."
With the baseball season to begin April 4, Mr. Lawn and city officials have discussed ways to address the team's concerns about sanitation, parking and police protection. Last year, the city added about 1,000 temporary spaces, doubled the police contingent to about 140 officers and assigned prison work crews to clean up around the ball park.
For opening day, and selected other dates, parking will be permitted at nearby Macombs Dam Park, which has 375 to 400 spots. For most night games, about 1,200 spots will be available at a nearby garage used by court employees, Mr. Stern said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Up Sharply As Traders Grow Nervous

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices of precious metals jumped yesterday after financial markets became unnerved by an unscheduled meeting between President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery jumped $4.60 an ounce, to $387.60, while May silver gained 6 cents, to $5.437. April platinum picked up $3.80, to $402.30 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 News of the meeting fueled speculation that the President was pressing Mr. Greenspan not to raise interest rates, and that the central bank's chief planned such a move to head off inflation. The White House moved quickly to quash such speculation, calling the meeting routine. 
 Still, traders in precious metals were reluctant to go home over the weekend without covering their positions, said James Steel, a metals analyst for Refco Inc. in New York.
"The market wanted to come back a little bit off the recent losses, and when the financial markets got a little spooked it was a reason to buy the gold back," Mr. Steel said.
Some analysts cautioned, however, that inflation appeared too low to sustain the rally. Investors tend to buy metals as a hedge against inflation and at times of unrest abroad.
Currently, analysts say, the main influences on precious metals prices are rising domestic demand as the economy strengthens and supply problems stemming from turmoil in South Africa.
"Over all, there's definitely a firm undertone on all these metals, and they're performing very well," said Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metals trading for Credit Suisse in New York.
On other commodity markets, lumber futures prices tumbled the daily limit for a third consecutive day amid abundant supplies because of weak construction activity. May lumber fell $15, to $401.70 for each 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
In energy futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light, sweet crude oil for April delivery settled 6 cents higher at $14.88 a barrel. April home heating oil also rose, gaining 0.23 cent, to 44.47 cents a gallon. But unleaded gasoline for April fell 0.07 cent, to 45.92 cents a gallon, and April natural gas fell 0.21 cent, to $2.103 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Whittle Set To Quit Book Publishing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Whittle Communications said yesterday that it would close its book publishing operations, which have failed to obtain sufficient advertising commitments for the next fiscal year.
The decision follows the recent closing of its Special Report Network, which involved video programs, magazines, posters and brochures that helped advertisers reach people in medical waiting rooms. 
 Both closings reflect a move by the company to focus on electronic rather than print media.
Whittle's main properties are the Channel One TV news program for schools and a Medical News Network TV service for physicians, to make its debut this fall.
 
Sponsor of the Edison Project
 Whittle, based in Knoxville, Tenn., also sponsors the Edison Project, which is developing for-profit schools. Its goals are to operate at lower costs than public schools while equaling the best of private education. Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of the project, said yesterday that Massachusetts had authorized the opening of three schools, in Boston, Worcester and Lowell, in 1995. They will be the first Edison Project schools.
Whittle gained a reputation as an innovator in the late 1980's by developing media that allowed companies to deliver advertising pitches in unusual settings like schools or doctors' offices.
But the company's revenue has stalled at about $200 million in the last two years. Whittle announced in mid-1992 that it would focus on electronic-based media projects.
 
Established Authors
 The company has profitably published books that contain advertising since 1989, and created a business unit called Whittle Books in 1991. The unit, which employs 14 people, published John Kenneth Galbraith's "A Short History of Financial Euphoria" and Richard Rhodes's "Nuclear Renewal." Among the other authors Whittle signed were: William Greider, the political editor of Rolling Stone; George Gilder, a conservative economic theorist, and Michael Lewis, the author of "Liar's Poker."
But William S. Rukeyser Jr., chairman and chief executive of Whittle Books, said the company's noncore operations like the book division must "justify themselves in every fiscal period by booking revenue in advance."
"We don't have signed contracts for next fiscal year, so we will be finishing producing our current books," he said. "We should have them finished by June and barring a sales miracle, we will close."
Whittle will have published 34 books by the time the book unit closes. The books each contain about 20 pages of ads and are sent free to targeted audiences.
 
Federal Express Bows Out
 The Federal Express Corporation, based in Memphis, sponsored the Larger Agenda series of 10 books from 1989 to 1991 for business, political and opinion leaders. The series ended when Federal Express did not renew its sponsorship, saying it had a changed its marketing objectives.
In 1991, Whittle introduced the Grand Rounds Press series for medical professionals, and the 16 books carried advertising from pharmaceutical companies.
The Chief Executive Press will have published eight books for the top executives of the nation's biggest companies. That series was sponsored by the Cessna Aircraft Company, based in Wichita, Kan.
Several Whittle books have sold well when reissued without advertising, Mr. Rukeyser said. He added that the book unit had generated "several million dollars a year" in revenue and was profitable, but he declined to be specific.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains in Expectation That Fed Will Raise Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against other currencies yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates next week.
In late New York trading, it climbed to 1.6960 German marks, from 1.6888 on Thursday. It also rose to 106.16 Japanese yen from 105.78. 
 After gaining in Europe, the dollar jumped in light but volatile American trading on news of an unscheduled meeting between President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Market participants interpreted the meeting as evidence that the President was trying to put pressure on the central bank to discourage it from raising short-term interest rates to restrain inflationary pressures.
The Administration sought to characterize the meeting as routine. But the conclusion in financial markets seemed to be that the Fed, which has historically acted independently of the White House, would have to raise rates to counter the appearance of capitulating to the President.
 
Treasury Yields Jump
 Indeed, Treasury yields jumped yesterday and prices fell as the bond market displayed nervousness about the White House meeting.
"The market read a great deal more into it than was necessary, even though it's a bit unusual," said Bob Lynch, a currency analyst at MMS International. "The President and the Fed chairman don't meet very often."
Currency traders expect the Fed to raise its target for the Federal funds rate, the benchmark for short-term interest rates, a quarter-point, to 3.5 percent, when its policy-making Open Market Committee meets Tuesday, Mr. Lynch said.
Higher rates tend to make dollar-denominated investments more attractive to foreign investors, pushing up demand for dollars and raising the currency's value.
The bulk of yesterday's trading in the United States was in German mark-dollar exchanges, dealers said. Banks were the day's most active traders.
Market participants largely shrugged off a report by the Bank of Japan that suggested the Japanese economy was still anemic.
"It's not a focus" in currency trading, said Michael Malpede, senior analyst for Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. "It's a fairly well-known fundamental that the Japanese economy remains weak."
The British pound slipped in New York to $1.4910, from $1.4935 on Thursday.
