HEADLINE: THE SEED CONSPIRACY

BYLINE: By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan, editor at large of Harper's Magazine, is author of "Second Nature: A Gardener's Education." His essays on gardening appear regularly in these pages.

 BODY:
THIS IS THE SEASON OF THE garden seed, that time of pure promise when the entire contents of a quarter-acre patch of vegetables -- the yield of which will burden a small truck come August -- can still fit inside an envelope and be sent cross-country by Fed Ex. The seeds themselves betray no sign of the prodigies they contain, but there, in a handful, they are: this weightless, buff disk packs a complete set of instructions for the making of a two-pound beefsteak tomato; that crinkled, blond tablet is etched with the blueprint for a 10-foot-tall sweet-corn tower.
But this is not the only kind of information encoded in a garden seed. For the seeds I order are inscribed with cultural, political and economic information as well. And if I am to believe some of the more polemical seedsmen whose catalogues-cum-tracts have found their way to my mailbox this season, the decision to plant one variety and not another is freighted with moral and environmental significance. A political fight is not exactly what I came to vegetable gardening to pick, but I seem to have stumbled into one anyway. 
 There I was, looking for a new variety of corn to try, and I wind up reading in the catalogue from Seeds of Change -- part of a growing army of seed firms fired with a sense of political mission -- about the negative impact that the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), of all things, will have on the free exchange of seeds and global biodiversity. Then Seeds Blum, a boppy counterculture catalogue published in Boise, Idaho, buttonholes me to explain that by planting modern hybrids, I am helping multinational corporations to monopolize the gene pool. And J. L. Hudson, Seedsman, who publishes the somewhat forbidding Ethnobotanical Catalogue of Seeds, preaches that by planting traditional nonhybrid seeds in my garden I can help to preserve cultural as well as genetic diversity.
The alternative seed catalogues paint the "F-1" hybrid, in particular, as an environmental menace and make a point of refusing to handle the dread seed. In the last few decades F-1 hybrids, which are simply the first generation produced by the crossing of two plant varieties, have become the stock in trade of the commercial seed industry, and they are gradually crowding traditional "open pollinated" varieties (ones pollinated by bees, birds or wind instead of plant geneticists) out of the marketplace. According to the Seed Savers Exchange, an organization established in 1975 to encourage backyard gardeners to preserve certain open-pollinated varieties, almost half of all the nonhybrid vegetable varieties on the market just 10 years ago have been dropped from mail-order catalogues. This often results in extinction, since many domesticated species will not survive unless they are planted over and over again by humans. W. Atlee Burpee & Company would tell you that the disappearance of traditional varieties is simply the Darwinian operation of the marketplace: if the old varieties were any good, they'd compete more successfully. In fact the chairman of Burpee made exactly that argument last spring in a Times Op-Ed piece in defense of the embattled hybrid, likening open-pollinated seeds to Model T's.
The seed savers see another, darker reason for the hybrid's predominance. As the Seeds Blum catalogue puts it, in words plain as those of Marx and Engels, "The reason hybrids exist is to protect the breeding investment of the seed company." Unlike the seeds of open-pollinated varieties, the seeds produced by an F-1 hybrid plant don't "come true" -- their offspring are apt to exhibit the undesirable traits of one or the other parent. In other words, seeds of these hybrids can't be saved or reproduced; their biology makes them proprietary. By forcing gardeners and farmers to return for new seeds each season, the companies selling F-1 hybrids have effectively taken control of the means of production.
These are not the only ways in which modern hybrids remake nature in the image of capitalism. Given heavy doses of fertilizer, F-1 hybrids grow swiftly and produce high yields. They also produce genetically uniform plants. What could better suit factory farming than a robust field of identical tomato or corn plants genetically coded to ripen all at once, thereby facilitating mechanical harvesting?
But the same uniformity that smoothes capitalism's way into the farm and garden also violates one of nature's cardinal principles: genetic diversity. A field of genetically identical plants is much more vulnerable to disease, as American corn farmers discovered in 1970 when a blight decimated the nation's crop, which had grown dependent on a few genetically similar hybrids. After such blights, breeders have historically turned to traditional varieties of corn, found in places like Mexico, to refresh the gene pool and provide new resistance. But what happens when Mexican farmers have been sold on fancy new hybrids and their traditional varieties have become extinct?
Seeds of Change claims in its catalogue that, second to destruction of habitats, "possibly the biggest single trigger of extinctions is the introduction of hybrid seeds." This sounds like hyperbole, and yet the seed insurgents are probably right to perceive a threat to biodiversity in the commercial seed trade's promotion of hybrids. We're accustomed to think of biodiversity only in connection with wild species in places like the rain forest, but the species that humans have selected and bred since the invention of agriculture are no less important. They represent a priceless worldwide store of genetic and cultural information, the heritage of some 10,000 years of coevolution between humans and their crop plants.
As the seed savers see it, the battle for the survival and control of that heritage is about to intensify. The promise of genetic engineering has set off a "gene rush" as breeders seek to identify and control plant genes for a variety of traits -- resistance to disease or frost, say, or to weed-killing chemicals. At the same time, under the new GATT accords, which will be phased in over the next five years, the world will take a giant step toward the privatization of seeds. That's because the GATT provisions on "intellectual property rights" require all signatories -- many for the first time -- to set up a system for the patenting of plant varieties.
This development has already ignited powerful protests in the third world. Many farmers worry that by promoting F-1 hybrids and patenting local plant varieties that were previously saved and exchanged freely, multinational corporations will ruin traditional agriculture. Last July a group of Indian farmers destroyed a Cargill seed-processing plant under construction in southern India, the second attack on the American seed giant's facilities there. (During the first, in December 1992, 300 protesters broke into Cargill's office in Bangalore and made a bonfire of corporate documents.) And in October, in what may be the largest protest ever against GATT, more than 500,000 farmers in India rallied in defense of their "sovereignty over seeds." Though it has gone virtually unreported in this country, India's "seed satyagraha" suggests that freedom of seeds is becoming a point of sharp contention between North and South.
SEEDS OF CHANGE, WHOSE LATEST CATALOGUE brings news of this seed savers Boston Tea Party, bids me to see a connection between my garden and the freedom and diversity of the world seed trade. Take the packet of corn seeds I'm in the market for. What I'm really in the market for, the catalogue makes clear, is a particular set of corn genes, and the choice I make will constitute a kind of evolutionary vote. I could, for example, order a hybrid from Burpee. This year I see they're offering several of the modern "supersweet" hybrids (several years ago some university researchers figured out how to double the gene for sugar in corn and slow its conversion to starch), including Illini Xtra-Sweet, which the catalogue claims is "four times as sweet as standard hybrids 48 hours after picking!" This is a revealing boast. It suggests that Illini Xtra-Sweet and hybrids like it were developed with factory farmers rather than backyard gardeners in mind. For what gardener would need a corn that holds its sweetness for two days?
To order Illini Xtra-Sweet would be a vote not just for a particular kind of corn but for a kind of agriculture -- indeed, for a kind of culture. You could probably deduce a great deal about contemporary America from the genes of Illini Xtra-Sweet; for example, that this is the product of a capitalist economy whose farms rely on petrochemicals (which most hybrids require to thrive) and are typically located a long truck ride away from their consumers, who prize sweetness over nutrition and tend to boil rather than roast their corn. (New corn hybrids have been bred for sweetness and tenderness, usually at the expense of nutritional value.)
The alternative seed catalogues brim with unusual varieties whose genes encode whole different cultures and culinary possibilities that seem worth experiencing -- and helping to preserve. From Seeds of Change I can order Black Aztec, said to be a pre-Columbian Aztec variety that does well in poor, dry soils and whose kernels stand up well to roasting. (At maturity the kernels turn blue black and can be ground into a highly nutritious cornmeal.) Seeds Blum recommends Trucker's Favorite, an heirloom "dent corn" that supposedly makes up in corn flavor what it lacks in sweetness and looks. J. L. Hudson, the most radical of the seedsmen, offers several native American field corns whose appeal seems distinctly less gustatory than, well, ethnobotanical (but then J. L. Hudson believes that we work for the seeds rather than the other way around). This year he's carrying Pod Corn, an ancestral strain whose every kernel is encased in its own husk, and Mandan Bride, "a beautiful multicolor corn said to be from the Mandan people in what is now called North Dakota."
Hudson's catalog is such a vast, teeming democracy of seeds that it makes room for common weeds such as mullein and burdock, four varieties of leaf tobacco (including one grown by Zapotec Indians), even seeds for giant sequoia trees. As one of his cranky, enlightening catalogue essays makes clear, Hudson believes in preserving human as well as genetic diversity -- hence the Zapotec tobacco and the Mandan Bride corn, both of whose genes encode specific cultural practices he's bent on saving. And who knows, one of the old Indian varieties he carries might turn out to contain a trait we will desperately need someday, perhaps the gene that will help us adapt corn to a warmer, drier climate.
That's the wager J. L. Hudson and his fellow seed insurgents are urging me to make -- to turn a corner of my garden into a kind of botanical ark, a blooming, fruiting archive of genetic and cultural information, a multicultural free-port city of open-pollinated, public-domain seeds to be saved and freely disseminated, Burpee and Cargill and GATT be damned! Hudson, Seeds of Change and Seeds Blum hold out a powerful, beguiling and wildly ambitious vision of the garden -- and yet it awaits nothing more than a handful of seeds.
I'm expecting my packet of Black Aztecs in the mail any day now.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Samples of the multicolor Mandan Bride, a traditionally pollinated field corn that is native to American soil. SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 3; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Method and Madness;
DO MOLES MATTER

BYLINE: By Nicholas Wade 

 BODY:
The cold war is dead but the spy business still lives. Last month, a C.I.A. officer, Aldrich Ames, was arrested on charges of being a longtime Moscow mole. And from dark and secret waters there suddenly surfaced a previously unknown class of Navy submarines that for decades has apparently retrieved cold war booty from the abysses of the ocean floor. These echoes from the past prompt a question: Since the Soviet Union's foremost enemy was its own economic system, what difference did 45 years of intelligence operations really make to the outcome of the cold war?

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
In hot wars, it certainly helps to have spies to signal the enemy's intentions, like those who warned Stalin of Hitler's invasion plans; too bad that Stalin didn't believe them. But when the shooting stops, spy agencies seem to spend a lot of time just chasing each other rather than things that matter. The C.I.A. vigorously tries to penetrate the K.G.B. and G.R.U. -- several of the Russians whom Ames allegedly betrayed were counterintelligence officers, as was he. Moscow's prime target is the C.I.A. and National Security Agency. It's hard for outsiders to assess the importance of these cloak-and-dagger duels because the insiders so seldom tell the truth about them. But even the figures of speech in which they are usually described -- Russian matryoshka dolls, wildernesses of mirrors -- hint of much ado about not much.
My father worked in British counterintelligence, where one of his jobs was to monitor East European emigre communities in Britain. I assume he thwarted spy rings operating against Her Majesty's Government and tried to turn them against their own. He only once told me any operational detail of his activities. He came across a Czech or Hungarian spy ring that was reporting to an unusual master -- the American Embassy in London. This was unfortunate, since the United States and Britain had agreed they would not run such operations on each other's soil. As my father told the story, he called in the C.I.A. station chief and laid out the evidence before him. "Gee, Michael," the man replied, "is my face red."
Spies are embarrassments when caught. Even with those who survive detection, fidelity cannot always be assumed, since changing masters tends to be addictive. Satellites, at first blush, have none of these frailties. They never switch allegiances or fall into sex-baited honey traps. Resembling the Hubble Space Telescope, except that they point not up to distant galaxies but down to dirty laundry, these delicate instruments provide streams of good-as-eyewitness information.
But satellites have their own limitations. Their costs, mercifully hidden in black budgets, are probably huge. They have doubtless suffered their share of setbacks, like the Hubble telescope. They can photograph the ground from their lofty orbits as well as low-flying planes can, but unlike planes, they follow predictable orbits. Devious minds seek to trick them, whether with decoys or by timing activities so no satellites are overhead. The Soviet preparation to move an army into Afghanistan was apparently undetected by satellites. So, for many years, was the Krasnoyarsk missile-detecting radar, a large and illegal edifice being constructed nakedly on a site prohibited by treaty.
Maybe more productive means of cold war espionage than either spies or satellites will prove to have been methods like signals intelligence, a less glamorous art about which little is on public record, and the Navy's salvage submarines. This fleet's existence was first reported last month by William J. Broad in The New York Times, although a few of its activities were already known. The submarines, in principle, can monitor anything that drops into the sea or runs across the ocean floor. Unlike many spies, their targets were items of direct strategic importance. Unlike satellites, they can reach down and examine their targets of interest.
Converted for use after retirement from other duties, the submarines' special equipment includes thrusters to keep them poised above their target and giant spools carrying miles of cable. The cables plummet to the ocean floor, presumably carrying devices like lights, cameras, manipulators and collectors. Unlike surface ships, the submarines can operate undetected over sensitive sites.
One submarine, the Halibut, visited the Soviet Golf-2 class nuclear-armed submarine that sank in 1968 near Hawaii and that was salvaged six years later by the Glomar Explorer. The Halibut apparently did so good a job that the Navy and Defense Intelligence Agency doubted the need being asserted by the C.I.A. to build the Glomar Explorer for a further visit. "Optimum recovery of intelligence information from this accident was achieved," the former Navy official who planned the Halibut mission wrote to Congress.
The harvest of the Halibut and its cousins is a matter of the purest speculation. The Navy has admitted to nothing. But in the case of the Golf-2 submarine the phrase "optimum recovery of intelligence information" suggests booty of some strategic weight.
Nuclear warheads are one such item. The Soviet Union is thought to have lost about 40 at sea, according to William M. Arkin of Greenpeace. Dr. Theodore B. Taylor, a former nuclear weapons designer at Los Alamos, pointed out that "bombs can be very different from one another" in a recent discussion of what might have been recovered from the Golf-2 submarine. "There's a good chance Soviet weaponry held big surprises for us."
Another prize, the guidance units of the warhead's missiles, would yield data about the missiles' accuracy. Sunken submarines might also yield code rooms and cryptographic gear.
Besides submarines, the ocean floor holds test missiles that fell short of their target and communications links like undersea cables. Ivy Bells, an eavesdropping project revealed to the Soviet Union by a National Security Agency employee, Ronald W. Pelton, is reported to have involved a large eavesdropping pod, placed round a Soviet cable carrying military communications in the Sea of Okhotsk. The Navy's submarines, whether of the Halibut or some other type, retrieved tapes from the pod, now a prime exhibit in the Moscow museum founded by the K.G.B.
The submarines' take from the ocean floor surely enhanced national security. Whether they or any other means of intelligence collection made a decisive difference in the cold war seems less certain. The C.I.A., according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a former vice chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, reckoned that the Soviet G.N.P. was roughly three times as large as it turned out to be. The agency thus missed the most critical secret of all -- that the Soviet economy could not support the Soviet empire. Beside this mountainous destructive force, a regiment of moles burrowing away in Moscow or Washington added up merely to molehills.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY VIEW;
They're Dancing as Fast as They Can

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby 

 BODY:
IF YOU'RE IN A MOOD TO CONSIDER alternative theater, you couldn't do much better than to check out "Marathon Dancing," the vivid new site-specific performance piece now being presented by En Garde Arts at the Masonic Hall at 71 West 23d Street. The Masonic Hall? Yes, but read on. "Marathon Dancing" is a musical and a melodrama as well as a very entertaining slice of American social and architectural history. It's not your average theater experience.
The time is early 1932, the hopeless height of the Great Depression, when bread lines were commonplace and bindlestiffs camped out by the railroad tracks, waiting to hop the next freight west. It's at the bleak end of Herbert Hoover's Administration and a few months before the appearance of patrician, fatherly Franklin Delano Roosevelt with his N.R.A., W.P.A., C.C.C. and various other alphabetized New Deal panaceas. The place is the sleazy Dreamland Ballroom (I arbitrarily think of it as being somewhere in the Middle West, possibly Chicago) where a marathon dance contest is in progress. 
 As the sweaty, hyped-up emcee Frankie Aragon (P. J. Benjamin), in tired black tie, welcomes his WIND radio listeners to the evening's broadcast, six couples move zombielike around the dance floor. They are the survivors of 721 hours of virtually nonstop dancing, which continues. For more than four weeks, they have been dancing 45 minutes out of each hour, using their 15-minute breaks to sleep, eat, brawl, take care of bodily functions and consider man's fate as America confronts collective despair. In the course of the next four weeks, there will be one wedding (the bride dressed in cellophane), one death and a couple of breakdowns. At the end, most of the contestants will be exactly where they were when they started: broke and bewildered.
This is why marathon dancing, which outdrew flagpole-sitting as a 1920's spectator sport, became the metaphor of choice for Depression stasis. The classic of the genre: Horace McCoy's laconic, piercing 1935 novel, "They Shoot Horses, Don't They?," which was the basis for Sydney Pollack's still disturbing 1969 film. (I've never seen June Havoc's "Marathon '33," which was originally produced in New York in 1963 and was also about the marathon dance craze.)
Yet "Marathon Dancing," conceived and directed by Anne Bogart and written by Laura Harrington, is only a part of the show on 23d Street. The other part is the performance site, the recently restored Grand Lodge Room on the Masonic Hall's third floor: a big, handsome, ornately decorated space that's something more than two stories high, all gold gilt and red and vaguely Spanish-Moorish in motif, under a ceiling of back-lighted leaded windows. Though the building was completed in 1909, the Grand Lodge Room seems to anticipate the most exotic fancies of the Roxy, Loew's Paradise and all those other huge, architecturally cross-bred movie palaces that were to be built in later decades.
The room's opulence and secure, self-assured all-American optimism don't really call to mind a place as desolate as the Dreamland Ballroom -- remember the tacky amusement park pier that was the setting for the Pollack film? Instead, the rich decor suggests everything that's beyond the reach of even the aspirations of these dance contestants. It's in this way that the site lends perspective to "Marathon Dancing," which isn't a gritty representation of a time, place and condition but a coolly stylized dream of reality. The Grand Lodge Room is the ironic frame.
As put together by Ms. Bogart and Ms. Harrington, with the collaboration of Christopher Drobny, who adapted and supervised the music, and Alison Shafer, the choreographer, the show is performed by more than two dozen dancing and singing actors. The score is played by a combo (piano, drums and bass) and contains 16 period songs. Most of these are standards, but some, such as Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart's "That's Love" (written for Samuel Goldwyn's 1934 flop film, "Nana") and "You Need Someone, Someone Needs You" (music by Lewis Gensler and Dudley Wilkinson, lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d) are brand new to me.
"Marathon Dancing" is played without an intermission. This fits the show's kaleidoscopic narrative method by which characters reveal themselves in bits of dialogue, songs, dances, strobe-lighted cinematic montages, production numbers and what amount to specialty acts. The Dreamland is always looking for ways to bring in customers to watch the freaks on the dance floor. One night, there's a brutal prizefight between a marathon contestant, Kid Alexander (Jonathan Fried), who's asleep on his feet, and a volunteer from the Dreamland audience. On another occasion, the audience is lured by the chance to gawk at Harry Miller (Andrew Weems), whose wife and partner, Jo-Jo (Jennifer Wiltsie), is pregnant, after he has hung upside down for 18 hours and attempts to hang on for another six.
All of the performers are good, but a couple are memorable: Frank Raiter as Mack, an over-the-hill vaudevillian, and Maureen Silliman as Juliet, his much younger partner, a former acrobat. Real time stops and the other performers freeze when Juliet coaxes the flagging Mack to keep on dancing, not to look down, as she sings to him Harry Warren and Al Dubin's "Sweet and Low." A lovely moment. Kristen Flanders as Ingrid, the reluctant cellophane bride from Denmark, is also fine as she sings the sentiment-loaded "Boulevard of Broken Dreams," another Warren and Dubin standard.
Not as effective, if only because they are so obligatory, are the vignettes dramatizing the social conditions (strikes, unemployment) that provided not only the contestants for marathon dance contests but also their audiences. The people who signed up to participate were hanging onto life by their fingertips. The audience came because admission was cheap, and the 24-hour-a-day show was more riveting than any radio soap opera could be.
Ms. Bogart and Kyle Chepulis, the set designer, have made no alterations to the Grand Lodge Room to turn it into the Dreamland. The principal playing area is the large open space at the room's center, which, as defined by lights, becomes the Dreamland's dance floor. When the dancers take their breaks, they retire to one end of the room where there are cots, those for the men on the left, for the women on the right. As in any site-specific presentation, the compulsion is to use every inch of the space. A certain lack of dramatic focus is built into the form. It's also reflected in the production's dominant images, those in which the entire cast is spread out on the dance floor at the same time.
In constructing this site-specific show, Ms. Bogart and her associates are intentionally deconstructing the conventionally well-ordered theatrical experience that tells you where to look. At "Marathon Dancing" you often make your own choices.
 
'The America Play'
There's a seriously comic and skeptical imagination evident in "The America Play," the new work by Suzan-Lori Parks, directed by Liz Diamond, now at Martinson Hall in the Joseph Papp Public Theater. Though a lot gabbier than Samuel Beckett, Ms. Parks reveals Beckett influences in this consideration of American history from a black point of view. She's less interested in the facts of history than in casually acquired notions of history ("so says hearsay" is a repeated theme) and where we belong in it.
Her principal characters: a black gravedigger, played with great skill and humor by Reggie Montgomery, who's obsessed by the notion that he's the spit and image of Abraham Lincoln; his wife, Lucy (Gail Grate), who picks up the whispering echoes of long-gone voices and events through her ear trumpet, and their son, Brazil (Michael Potts), who wants to follow in his father's footsteps to become a "digger and a faker." Riccardo Hernandez's beautiful wasteland set is mostly slag-gray, set off by splashes of brilliant scarlet (a curtain and the satin lining of a casket, among other things).
In the first act the gravedigger, who abandoned his wife and child 30 years before, is somewhere out West, digging his "exact replica of the Great Hole of History," which sometimes seems to be a theme park back East, sometimes the hole left in Lincoln's head by John Wilkes Booth's bullet and, more importantly, the hole in black history caused by hundreds of years of invisibility in servitude. Behind the digger's obsession with "the Great Man" (he refers to himself as "the Lesser Known"), there is an inarticulated fury. From time to time we see him in the sideshow in which he has traveled the West: for a penny patrons can pick up a pistol, loaded with blanks, to assassinate his Lincoln look-alike as he sits in a makeshift theater box, watching "Our American Cousin."
In Act II Lucy and Brazil travel west to look for the remains of the digger, now dead, and to hear his last words. The play also makes use of ragtime music and scenes from "Our American Cousin."
Ms. Parks has been quoted as saying that people must make up their own minds as to what it all means. That's fine as long as the play is evocative, which it is about half the time. She's also effectively denying her own responsibility when she overwrites, and the ideas become muddled.
Ms. Parks has a singular voice, worth attending to, but I wonder whether she is well served by the comparative luxe of this handsome, supportive physical production. It lessens the playwright's obligation. She must refine her work until it is so spare, with each word so seemingly irreplaceable, that it could be played with as much effect in the middle of an ordinary living room as in Mr. Hernandez's elegant wasteland.
 
'Titus Andronicus'
"Titus Andronicus" is always included in Shakespeare's collected works, but to many scholars it remains an embarrassment. They propose that it's really someone else's play to which Will made some minor contributions. The earliest of Shakespeare's tragedies, it is also the least introspective, the bloodiest and the most stylistically inconsistent. Yet whoever wrote it, "Titus Andronicus" is not performed so frequently that one can easily overlook a production as good looking, inventive and sometimes witty as Julie Taymor's current work for Theater for a New Audience at St. Clement's Church.
Without ever shifting into a camp mode, the Taymor version is also funny, shocked amusement being about the only way to react to the nonstop succession of Grand Guignol horrors that take place on, or just off, the St. Clement's stage. Three hands and two heads are severed, one tongue cut out and, of the dozen principal characters, only one is alive at the end.
The revered old Roman general Titus returns home from his victories over the Goths, bearing as hostages Tamora, the Goth queen, and her three sons. Titus spurns the emperor's wreath, bestowing it instead on Saturnius, the son of the recently deceased emperor. Saturnius promptly jilts Titus's daughter Lavinia (who didn't want to marry him anyway) to marry Tamora. Her beloved is Aaron, a Moor like Othello, but whose evil deeds are as unmotivated as those of Iago. This may be as much of the story as you need to keep track of.
What's fascinating about "Titus Andronicus" is its obsession with pure revenge. Everyone, the foolish Titus as much as anybody, acts in such a way as to inspire an obsession for revenge in someone else. Shakespeare here wastes no time considering the emotions that fuel revenge: honor, love, sexual passion, familial loyalties. Revenge is what gives pleasure. It's the common religion and the characters are fundamental believers, which may be a lesson for today.
With the exception of Curzon Dobell, who plays Titus's son and heir, Lucius, none of the actors at St. Clement's speaks the text with uniform ease. The words are shouted, voices are strained. Yet the production consistently engages the attention. It's like a terrible fairy tale from Mars. Ms. Taymor mixes eras in costumes and props (ancient Greek with contemporary), atonal musical accompaniment (by Elliot Goldenthal) with hints of themes that sound as if they might have been written by Federico Fellini's favorite composer, Nino Rota. The effect: hypnotic and sometimes genuinely scary.
 
MARATHON DANCING Anne Bogart's coolly stylized dream of reality has an ironic frame. It's not your average theater experience.
 
THE AMERICA PLAY A history of black and white, filtered through a seriously comic imagination, by a playwright who leaves meaning up to the audience.
 
TITUS ANDRONICUS Like a terrible fairy tale from Mars, the production by Julie Taymor is consistently engaging and sometimes even witty.

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Outlasting The Incas And Spaniards

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
THE CRAFTS OF THE MAPUCHE people reflect the rich mix of traditions inherited from their pre-Columbian ancestors or borrowed from their former enemies -- the Incas and the Spaniards. But the shimmering silver jewelry, bold capes and exotic musical instruments of these Latin American natives, who comprise the largest and one of the oldest indigenous groups of Chile, are virtually unknown in the United States.
At the time of the Spanish conquest in the 16th century, the Mapuche (pronounced ma-POO-chuh) dominated Chile, and their language was spoken throughout the land. By then, they had successfully resisted the Incas for a half century. And they remained independent, defying the Spaniards, until the late 19th century. Once subdued, they were banished to government-controlled reservations. Today, about a half million of them farm crowded plots, mostly in the southern part of central Chile. 
 Since no written record of the Mapuche culture survives from before the Spanish conquest, little is understood of their origins and early history. And while the dating and scholarship of their later crafts is also less than exact, some of their story is now revealed in "Mapuche: Seeds of the Chilean Soul," an exhibition at the Americas Society on upper Park Avenue, through April 20.
The show, the first in New York to focus on these people, is part of the nonprofit organization's program of exhibitions, concerts and lectures. The society was founded in 1965 by David Rockefeller to promote economic, political, social and cultural understanding between the United States and the rest of the Western Hemisphere.
The 80 objects on view, produced over more than 1,000 years, were lent by the Chilean Museum of Pre-Columbian Art in Santiago, which organized the exhibition. Among the earliest ceramics is a round-bellied jar from the seventh century, a terra-cotta work embellished with black stripes and triangles; the pouring spout is shaped vaguely like the head of a duck. This vessel and another one -- an anthropomorphic jar with a quizzical face and large hands -- are similar to many pre-Columbian pieces from other regions of Latin America. In fact, the show's stone pipes, whistles and clubs, although undated, are reminiscent of those made by tribal peoples everywhere.
Mapuche ceramics, when decorated, are patterned with geometric motifs much like the pottery painted as early as 500 B.C. in what is now western Mexico. And Mapuche textiles woven at the turn of the century boast some of the same wide stripes, lightning streaks and ziggurats that the Navajos favored in the blankets they wore in the same period.
According to Carlos Aldunate del Solar, director of the Chilean museum, who was the show's curator, ziggurat images represent the staircases a man must ascend to achieve the highest status in the tribe. While there are no documented connections between the Mapuche and the Navajos, in both cases the women were the weavers and were influenced by Spanish culture.
The two Mapuche deities represented in the exhibition are depicted in 19th-century silver-plated metal images of a young man and woman, both shown topless -- he is wearing pants, she is in a skirt. "The Mapuche believe in a god that is masculine and feminine, old and young, all at the same time," Mr. Aldunate said.
Virtually all the extant Mapuche jewelry was produced after the conquest, Mr. Aldunate said. But the most compelling pieces are the outsized silver disks and trapezoids, forms worn as pendants and earrings in the pre-Columbian period. The jewelry is exhibited on three mannequins swathed in black cloth and bedecked with cascading chains and necklaces, headpieces and a pair or two of earrings. The displays can be frustrating to the viewer because the individual items cannot be clearly seen, and the pieces on each mannequin represent a mix of silver from different periods.
The lone mask in the show is a hawk-nosed carved wood one worn by dancers entertaining at a hockeylike game called palin since prehistoric times. "These were ritual dances," Mr. Alduante said.
Mapuche musical instruments, though primitive in form, have influenced a number of contemporary Chilean composers. The show's prize is a 20th-century trumpet, two feet in diameter, devised from a 10-foot hollow cane, bent into a circle and fitted with a mouthpiece fashioned from a bull's horn.
"It produces a wonderful sound," Mr. Alduante said. "It's very loud and screeching -- it positively roars. These instruments were used in battle -- and later to praise god."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
UConn Moving Its Stamford Campus Downtown

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
STAMFORD'S quarter-century metamorphosis from factory town to diverse metropolis entered a new phase last week when arrangements were concluded to relocate the Stamford Branch of the University of Connecticut from its site north of the Merritt Parkway to the heart of downtown.
The school will move into the former Bloomingdale's outlet on Washington Boulevard, vacant since 1990 when poor sales, financial troubles at its parent company, Federated Department Stores, and the taint of a murder that took place in the parking garage forced the closing after 36 years. 
 Federated sold the 243,000-square-foot store, the 900-car parking garage and a small lot behind the store, totaling about 6 acres, to the state for $9.57 million. The property is assessed at $9.66 million. "Extensive renovations, furniture and equipment," said Dr. Karen Arms, president of UConn/Stamford, "could cost another $70 million."
The move will provide the school with an additional 167,000 square feet, enabling it to broaden its curriculum and install a gym, student and faculty lounges, career-planning services, an expanded library and bookstore, improved dining facilities and space for clubs and social activities.
Dr. Arms called Bloomingdale's three stories of high ceilings and wide-open spaces ideal for the free design of room configurations. The existing elevators and escalators are other pluses.
Originally housed in a high school, where it enrolled veterans returning from World War II, the branch moved in 1962 to a new, barracks-like classroom building of 41,600 feet five miles north of downtown. In 1975 a 34,200-square-foot library was built, but further expansion on the 37-acre campus is prohibited by wetlands, lack of sewers, and by a resolution of the city's legislative body designed to protect the residential character of the neighborhood.
The university's Bartlett Arboretum, which abuts the campus and is short of space, will be expanded into the school grounds and buildings.
"For the past several years the school has been under pressure to enrol more students," said State Senator George Jepson, a Stamford Democrat who is on the team negotiating team for the property, "and those that are there have not been getting a legitimate university education due to the physical inadequacy of the buildings."
He added that the downtown campus would boost property values around it and "contribute to increased safety, especially at night, by having more people around."
After Bloomingdale's closed several shops around it were vacated and the neighborhood declined sharply.
Loss of the store's $270,680 in annual property taxes is not a serious concern, according to Mayor Stanley Esposito.
"THE city will be partially reimbursed through the state's Payment in Lieu of Taxes program," he said, "and the rest will be compensated by the economic boom that will result from nearly 3,000 students and faculty members patronizing downtown services, shops, cultural offerings and entertainment."
A diverse student body of 1,600 is expected to increase to 2,800 at the new location. Ranging in age from late teens to adult, most of them live within a 50-mile radius and more than half have day jobs and attend classes at night. There are no dormitories, nor will there be any at the new location.
"Having a university within walking distance of many companies," said Kip Bergstrom, the city's Director of Economic Development, "and a few blocks from I-95 and Metro North allows employees not only from Stamford but from surrounding communities easy access to a master's degree in business administration. It's a unique resource in this region and it will give Stamford a competitive edge in attracting new business and retaining what it has."
A degree in Stamford's Executive M.B.A. program can be obtained in about 18 months on weekends or other schedules compatible with an individual's work hours.
"Stamford is the only regional campus in the state university system that has both a two-year and four-year program," said Mark Roy, spokesman at the home campus in Storrs. "Usually students at the branches transfer to Storrs for their junior and senior years." There are additional regional campuses in Groton, Torrington, Hartford, West Hartford and Waterbury.
In 1992 the state's capital budget included $10 million for site acquisition and a total of $93 million was estimated as the cost of new construction on a parcel it hoped to purchase four blocks east of Bloomingdale's on Broad Street. The tract was lost in the bidding process to Trammell Crow, the Dallas-based developer.
Since then Trammell Crow's Connecticut executives reorganized as a new company, called Avalon Properties, and are preparing to apply for final site plan approval on a complex of 381 rental apartments at that location.
"We think they will be ideal for leasing to UConn faculty, or two or three students taking a unit together," said Samuel Fuller, Avalon's vice president. The project will have a pool, racquetball and basketball courts, fitness rooms, on-site parking and a lounge. Rents for one- to 3-bedroom units will range from $1,000 to $1,600 a month.
Jack Condlin, vice president of Marlowe Associates, a Stamford real estate firm, is also keeping UConn in mind while renovating the old Y.W.C.A. building on nearby Summer Street. Thirty-four studios and one-bedroom units will rent for $650 to $900.
HIS company owns nine retail and office properties around Bloomingdale's. "Rents are still around $12 a square foot from $25 to $28 five years ago," he said, noting that the recession had added to the impact of Bloomingdale's departure. But as the economy improved and word spread of UConn's interest in the site, he said, "we rented three out of four vacant stores opposite Bloomingdale's on Broad Street."
Interest by the local corporate community in the value of a bigger and better downtown UConn was demonstrated two years ago by contributions totaling $500,000 from General Reinsurance Company, Champion International, Xerox and American Brands.
The money was used to establish and staff a development office for UConn/Stamford as an ongoing fund-raising vehicle for items not covered by state allocation and to heighten interest in what has been a very small and quiet university campus.
"We are opening a capital campaign for $15 million," said Mary Gorham Franco, development director for the Stamford Partnership, a nonprofit civic group, "in endowments for scholarships and financial aid, for recruiting talented minority students and top flight professors in the financial and telecommunications fields which we feel are Stamford's strengths."
Money is also needed for development-office equipment, legal fees, studies, research, and a continuously updated data base of donors. "So far we have obtained substantial pledges from several individual, corporate and foundation contributors," she said.
Senator Jepson noted that this year's bonding package contained a request of $4 million for site development, architectural and engineering planning. "If the schedule is in sync we will go back next year for construction financing of $40 to $50 million," he said. "Public construction moves slower, so the fastest we can expect to open is late 1997."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Karen Arms, president of the University of Connecticut/Stamford, at the library on the present campus. (Susan Harris for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2743 words

HEADLINE: In Real Estate, New Faces, Old Names

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
EVEN if you can't place the face, the name may be familiar: Durst. Galbreath. Koeppel. Malkin. Rose. Rudin. Silverstein. Wilpon. Zeckendorf. A takeover generation is coming to the fore among New York's leading real estate families. Men in their 20's, 30's and 40's are taking a more visible role in the leadership of second- , third- and fourth-generation businesses.
So too -- in a departure from their parents' era -- are a number of women, among them Robin Abada, 26, leasing representative at the Muss Development Company; Sarah K. Cohn, 32, general counsel of Koeppel Tener Riguardi; Beth Rudin DeWoody, 41, vice president of Rudin Management Company; Lizanne Galbreath, 36, vice chairwoman of Galbreath Riverbank, and Amy Rose, 27, assistant vice president of Rose Associates. 
 "Women have just as much of a gut feeling about real estate and a sense of business as men do," said Ms. DeWoody, a commercial broker who was recently named president of the Samuel and May Rudin Foundation. "In a family business, this is also their heritage and it's important for them to be part of the direction."
As a girl, Ms. Rose recalled, she would ride with her father, Elihu Rose, in the construction hoist of an apartment tower on West 57th Street or visit the site of a condominium complex in Bayside, Queens.
"I've grown up with these buildings," she said. "These buildings are in my blood."
Deal-making also seems virtually a birthright. "My earliest memories of vacation were negotiating with tenants with my father," said David M. Katz. His father, Saul B. Katz, is president of Sterling Equities. Growing up in the early 70's, Mr. Katz and his cousin, Jeffrey S. Wilpon, made up their own business cards: "President for Construction" or "President for Leasing." Today, they are both vice presidents of Sterling Equities.
At a time of convulsive change in other industries, the ascent of this younger generation -- which also includes members of the Fisher, Milstein, Resnick and Tishman families -- seems to guarantee continuity.
"My job is a lot easier because of the previous generation's hard work," said William C. Rudin, 38, the new president of Rudin Management. "I don't have to tell a tenant what my organization is about."
But the younger men and women understand that they cannot duplicate the expansive careers of their fathers and uncles, at least for the time being. With the devastation of the real estate market, they must find new ways to do business, whether in management, ownership, brokerage, assemblage or construction.
What is likely to remain unchanged is a network among the families, who have many political and charitable interests in common, even as competitors in business.
"I go to twice-monthly meetings with Adam and Amy Rose," said Anthony E. Malkin, 31, the president of W & M Properties. "Will and Arthur Zeckendorf and I get together socially. Doug Durst and I trade calls often. It's not a country club or a coterie. But these are the folks who are doing business in the 1990's."
In the 1980's, newcomers seemed "more supple in their financial thinking than the multigenerational families," Tom Shachtman wrote in "Skyscraper Dreams," a 1991 portrait of New York's real estate families. Existing clans, he wrote, were "less inclined to shift from tactics that had always proven viable" and "overly cautious in the wake of the disasters of the 1970's."
Continuity can be the enemy of innovation when heirs wed themselves to longtime family practices. "Sometimes, there's a desire to carry forward what the founder did and that becomes outdated," said Wendy C. Handler, an assistant professor at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., who specializes in family-business management.
On the other hand, the caution of the old families may have helped preserve them.
THAT is not to say they were completely spared. Ms. Galbreath, for example, spent a lot of time in Columbus, Ohio, working closely with her father, Daniel M., on restructuring the troubled Galbreath Company. "It was a very painful process," she said, "but I think we're a stronger company for it." Ms. Galbreath is vice chairwoman of the Columbus-based company, which is the parent of Galbreath Riverbank in New York.
Scott N. Resnick, 29, a managing director of Jack Resnick & Sons, cut his teeth on the failed attempt to renovate the 40 Wall Street office tower, which fell apart in 1991 when the building lost its largest tenant and Citicorp halted financing. "The financial unraveling was an incredible education," Mr. Resnick said. "It absolutely made me a lot more cautious and conservative in my outlook."
Conservatism is the self-professed watchword of the coming generation.
"The way to survive in this business is to be conservative, to have a relatively low amount of leverage," said 33-year-old Douglas A. Morse, a cousin of Mr. Malkin, who is director of acquisitions at the Lester Morse Company, a mortgage brokerage.
"Our fathers were more builders than we will be," said Douglas Durst, the 49-year-old managing director and executive vice president of the Durst Organization. "That's mostly due to the economic times we face. A lot of what we're going to be focusing on is rebuilding." That effort includes office towers on the Avenue of the Americas and Third Avenue.
"When there's a chance to develop," Ms. Rose said, "believe me, we'll be there." For now, she is working on renovating retail space in a block bounded by Broadway, University Place, Eighth and Ninth Streets.
"I plan and hope to be a developer," Mr. Resnick said. "However, in the 80's, I thought that would be my primary focus. I guess I've resigned myself to the fact that in the first major part of my career, I will be dealing with existing property."
After graduating from New York University, Mr. Resnick worked at the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, then spent a year in law school before joining the family business. He was prompted by the impending construction of the Oxford, a 44-story apartment tower at 422 East 72d Street.
"I always wanted to work with my father," he said, "and I strongly felt that this might be the last time in quite a while to see a building go from the ground up. I learned an incredible amount about planning, leasing, marketing and the financial aspects."
Large projects also drew Daniel R. Tishman, 38, into the family business. Having studied environmental sciences, he moved to Maine 15 years ago, where he started a small development concern. "I realized how much I enjoyed the process of building something," he said. In 1988, the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, based in New York, was awarded Boston Crossing, an ambitious combination of offices, stores, a hotel and theaters. Tishman was also negotiating to build a large office tower in Hartford.
This prompted Tishman to open a New England office, with Daniel Tishman in charge. Although the Boston and Hartford projects were never built, the company has a "significant amount" of work, said Mr. Tishman, who is senior vice president of both Tishman Construction Corporation in Boston and the New York-based parent company.
Ms. Galbreath also came into the family fold because of a large project. She had attended Dartmouth College and the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, had worked at Chemical Bank and was looking for a job on Wall Street.
But in the early 80's, Galbreath-Ruffin (predecessor to the Galbreath Company) planned a 2.5-million-square-foot office tower in Chicago, with a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation. "It was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," Ms. Galbreath said.
For want of tenants, the Chicago project was never built. Meanwhile, in New York, Ms. Galbreath watched as builders took "huge risks" in the late 80's. "The way of doing business in New York no longer fit our risk profile," she said. "We decided we did want to stay, but we changed from development to third-party management."
A large project also engaged Ms. Rose, who had not expected to wind up at Rose Associates virtually the day after she graduated from the University of Michigan. What brought her in was the imposing job of converting nine Rose apartment buildings, with some 3,000 rental units, to co-ops.
The conversion was undertaken by her cousin, Adam R. Rose, who preceded her into the company. "If we had been in a steady-state operation," he said, "then I would have insisted she conform to the iron-clad theory that it's absolutely better to work elsewhere before joining the family business."
After Mr. Rose graduated from Yale College in 1981, he moved to San Antonio and worked for Guido Brothers Construction Company, a third-generation enterprise.
"I THINK I needed for myself -- and, frankly, for the family -- the validation of working in an external situation," said Mr. Rose, now 34 years old and an executive vice president at Rose Associates.
Mr. Rose said his father, Frederick P. Rose, and uncles, Elihu and Daniel, "were similar in encouraging their children to do what they wanted and in emphasizing the need to have broad interests."
Jonathan F. P. Rose, Adam's brother, once worked at Rose Associates but now, at 41, is president of the Affordable Housing Construction Corporation in Katonah, N.Y., a development and consulting firm.
One of Daniel Rose's sons, Joseph B. Rose, 34, was appointed chairman of the City Planning Commission in January. He was never at Rose Associates, although he has long been involved in land-use and development issues, as chairman of Community Board 5 and executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.
"There was a concern by some, when I became chair of the community board, that this was an arm of the development industry," he said. "I think my record quickly dispelled any concerns about that."
As with the Roses, several members of the Rudins' third generation have come and gone from the business. A second cousin, 38-year-old Jeffrey Steinman, remains and is a vice president in the residential department.
Ms. DeWoody said her grandfather, Samuel Rudin, "was always encouraging me to come into the business." Before she joined Rudin Management in 1982, she had been a production assistant on the movies "Annie Hall," "Hair" and "The Front."
The elder Rudin took the same approach with her brother, William, who recalled: "My grandfather always said when we were growing up: 'Don't go to college. Come put a desk in my office and see how things are done.' "
Mr. Rudin went to the University of Arizona instead but wishes he had taken up the offer from his grandfather, who died while he was still in college. "If I could do something over, that would be it," Mr. Rudin said. "I could have gone to college at any time."
Grandfathers figure prominently in several stories from the younger generation.
Anthony Malkin, who had been an investor, was brought into the family business after the death in 1988 of his grandfather, Lawrence A. Wien, who had pioneered real estate syndications. "It became obvious that we were going to have our fair share of shakes in the upcoming turbulence," Mr. Malkin said, "and that the focus would have to be on a company that was management intensive."
AS boys, the Zeckendorf brothers visited their grandfather's office, a cylindrical glass turret atop 383 Madison Avenue. They might be international diplomats today, had they followed the footsteps of their other grandfather, Trygve Lie, the first Secretary General of the United Nations, whose daughter, Guri, married William Zeckendorf Jr.
"It was either Wall Street, foreign policy or real estate," William Lie Zeckendorf said, "and the real estate business -- by the time I got out of school in 1980 -- began to expand dramatically. It was a pretty easy choice."
At the age of 35, William Lie Zeckendorf is executive vice president of Zeckendorf Realty, alongside his 34-year-old brother, Arthur William Zeckendorf.
"My grandfather and father are developers -- they live to build," said William Lie Zeckendorf. "Arthur and I enjoy development, but we are willing to look at the service side as well."
In its second generation, the Milstein family became heavily involved in service, with the purchase in 1989 of Douglas Elliman & Company. Howard P. Milstein, the chairman, who is in his early 40's, prompted the current investigation into payoffs to apartment house managers by contractors after he discovered questionable practices.
Mr. Milstein refused to be interviewed for this article, as did his brother, Edward, the vice chairman of Douglas Elliman, who is in his mid-30's and their cousin, Philip L., president of Milford Management Corporation, who is in his mid-40's.
Kenneth and Steven Fisher, who are in their 30's, also declined to be interviewed. Their presence carries Fisher Brothers into its fourth generation.
Not all families stay together. The brothers Max and Harry Koeppel split many years ago, so unreconciled that neither would give up the company name. As a result, there are two firms called Koeppel & Koeppel today.
Harry Koeppel's grandson is William W. Koeppel, 34, a partner in Koeppel & Koeppel at 641 Lexington Avenue.
Max Koeppel's grandchildren are Caleb D. Koeppel, 37; David J. Koeppel, 35 and Edward A. K. Adler, 45. They are partners in Koeppel & Koeppel at 26 Broadway and officers in the Koeppel Tener Riguardi brokerage and management concern, where Ms. Cohn, the Koeppels' sister, is counsel.
How could they not be in the business, when it permeated their lives? "You never leave it at the office," Caleb Koeppel said. "It's at family dinners and holidays."
"I never really thought seriously about doing anything else," said Michael T. Cohen, 34, the president and chief executive of the Williams Real Estate Company, which has been led by the Cohen and Roos families for three generations. Andrew H. Roos, 40, is the executive vice president.
ROBIN ABADA, Joshua L. Muss's daughter, came to the business straight out of Boston University in 1989. "When I graduated," she said, "I had a month that I was allowed to take off before my father said, 'Now it's time to start in the business.' " Her 28-year-old brother, Joseph, also works at Muss Development.
Roger A. Silverstein, 30, joined his father, Larry A. Silverstein, soon after his graduation from New York University in 1986. "I jumped right into the fire," he said. He is now an assistant vice president at Silverstein Properties, in leasing and management.
But Mr. Wilpon, 32, said the "house rule" in his family was that "we all had to go outside and work somewhere else." He was drafted by the Montreal Expos and played for its minor-league team in Jamestown, N.Y. (His father, Fred Wilpon, is co-owner of the Mets.) Before joining Sterling, he also worked for the Lehrer/McGovern construction firm, the Resnicks and at the Hines Interests.
His cousin, Mr. Katz, who is 30, worked for Tishman, Niko Construction and Cushman & Wakefield before joining Sterling.
Mr. Wilpon is not the only member of the takeover generation to have played sports.
Jonathan Durst, 37, competed professionally as a triathlete and worked as a mechanical engineer for Chrysler and the FMC Corporation before joining the Durst Organization in 1984. His 35-year-old brother, Joshua, came into the company in 1983, after getting a master's degree in business.
Their cousin, Douglas, was the first to join the Durst Organization, in 1967. "I had always thought this is what I'd do," he said.
At the age of 50, Robert Durst is the oldest member of the takeover generation. In January, he was appointed managing director of the Durst Organization, together with Douglas, Jonathan and Joshua Durst.
"When I was growing up, it was the days of long hair and marijuana," he recalled. "In terms of announcing you were going into the family business -- that was extremely uncool." So why, in 1973, did he join his father, Seymour, and uncles? "I got married," he answered. "Seymour decided I lacked ambition. These type things."
A cousin, Peter Askin, 47, worked for the Durst Organization in the 1970's and 80's. But he had studied dramatic literature and the theater eventually exerted a greater pull.
"Writing was always an interest and involvement," he said, "and then directing became one as well." He is now director of the Westside Theater, 407 West 43d Street. But family ties are not wholly severed.
He leases the building from the Dursts.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 8; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1879 words

HEADLINE: Board Looks at Urban Areas

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THIS city is preparing the way for construction of a traffic artery designed 20 years ago to facilitate access to the downtown business district, linking the hub to the Bronx River Parkway at the County Center.
Known as the Grove Street extension, it would ease rush-hour delays on Main Street in the morning and Hamilton Avenue in the evening and complete the city's last major road segment of its postwar revitalization plan. 
 The revival of interest in the long-dormant project came with the new administration of Mayor Sy J. Schulman, who sent a memo to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke on Feb. 28, saying, "As you know, this key arterial link has been in various stages of planning for two decades, and it is time for all of us to move it ahead."
 
'A Key Participant'
 Mr. Schulman said he had written to state transportation officials urging action. "In recent city-county-state staff discussions there was general agreement on the project's design," he said, and the State Department of Transportation "is firmly committed to including it on its program and will be asking the Mid-Hudson Planning Group at its next meeting to confirm the project's scheduling."
"Thereafter," the Mayor stated in his memo to Mr. O'Rourke, "state and Federal approvals should be forthcoming, and funding and construction would follow." Mr. Schulman proposed an intergovernmental commitment to the project, "adding the county as a key participant in the project."
Drawing the county into a proposed Memorandum of Understanding fit neatly, and apparently coincidentally, with a new effort by the Board of Legislators to help in the revitalization of Westchester's urban areas.
The Board chairman, Stephen J. Tenore, Republican of New Rochelle, declared his interest in having the legislators pay more attention to the cities when he was named to the post two years ago and underscored this concern with establishment of a new Urban Affairs Committee in the current session.
Operating under bipartisan leadership, with two first-term Legislators, Lois T. Bronz, Democrat of White Plains, and Michael J. Spano, Republican of Yonkers, sharing the chairmanship, the committee began its work 10 days ago by inviting the county's mayors to state their needs.
 
A Change in Attitude
 Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle recalled the attitude in his City Hall before he took office. "It was that you don't go to the county government" for help, because "all they care about is White Plains and the Golden Mile" of corporate development along I-287, he said.
That attitude appears to be changing, he indicated. "Things have improved over the last two or three years, especially in terms of how the villages and towns view the county's cities," a point frequently made by Mr. Tenore, the author of the plan to help the cities.
"It's not just a local problem," Mr. Tenore said. "The flight of businesses from downtowns is a national problem. At the same time, these cities and their problems can't be extracted from the rest of the county."
Referring to the value of property subject to taxes, he added: "If cities like Yonkers, New Rochelle and Mount Vernon had not lost ratables, then the thriving communities would not be taxed as heavily. It's in everyone's interest to help the cities."
 
Dispute Over Bridge
 And what could the county do to help Mr. Idoni? He expressed the city's gratitude for the transfer of some county offices to downtown New Rochelle, but he said even more was involved in developing the city-owned Davids Island.
A year ago the city gave up on a developer's proposal to build a $1 billion residential complex because, among other factors, it faced governmental opposition to a bridge linking the 78-acre island with the mainland.
Mr. Idoni said members of the Board of Legislators "expressed real opposition to the bridge," which he said influenced Albany's opposition. He asked that a subcommittee of the Board work with the city in studying the feasibility of a bridge.
The Mayor has also said that it might be better for the city to set the framework for development of the island and then seek a builder rather than wait for developers to initiate plans.
The city of Mount Vernon, although experiencing "severe financial stress," in the words of Gerrie Post, the Planning Director, has a flourishing downtown. A new Pathmark store, which is open 24 hours and "carries a huge product line, including a pharmacy and bakery," has brought in "a lot of shoppers from neighboring communities," she said.
 
Reversing a Trend
 This is a reversal of the postwar trend of placing shopping malls outside city centers and giving once flourishing downtown areas the look of a ghost town. Ms. Post said Mount Vernon was "very happy with the partnership that we have been building over the last few years with the County Board and with the county government.
She said, "We look to the county to help us when it can with inquiries from businesses seeking to relocate in Westchester." The city covers only 4.4 square miles, and 99 percent of the land is developed. It has catalogued vacant space and is aware, Ms. Post said, that "this whole region is changing in terms of business environment, from manufacturing and heavy industry to more service-oriented and consumer-emphasized businesses."
Ms. Post said the city seems to have reached the limit on property taxes. "People can go only so far in terms of how much they can pay in property taxes, so we have to do something else," she said.
 
Peekskill's Turnaround
 The answer, she added, "may be to increase our sales taxes," especially through new enterprises. The planned refurbishing of Memorial Field by the county at a cost of $6 million, plus the development of a retail center on Sandford Avenue, should help bring in revenue, she said. .
Ms. Post said the Board of Legislators could help Mount Vernon and other similarly developed areas to establish affordable housing by changing limitations on the long-standing Housing Implementation Fund. The county is barred from building housing, but it can assist by supplying the infrastructure, like sewer lines.
Cities already have most of the infrastructure, but the county could help them by constructing things like sidewalks and parking areas, in order to bring the price of housing down to a level that municipal employees making $20,000 a year could afford, she said.
Another Mayor, Frances S. Gibbs of Peekskill, also spoke of a city's changing profile. In 1989, when Steinbach's Department Store closed, it signaled the beginning of the end for the city's central business district.
Peekskill's response? The Artist Spaces Program, an 18-month effort to identify appropriate space with the result that 35 studios were converted and occupied. With this start, attention was turned to broader rehabilitation of the downtown.
 
Waterfront Project in Yonkers
 Police patrols were enlarged, and parking lots were built. Youth services were expanded and a youth center opened. A Saturday farmers market was initiated, and affordable-housing sites were selected. An $8.4 million 100-unit project for the elderly and disabled was built and occupied.
Peekskill, meanwhile, has gone beyond finding space for artists; it is assisting small arts and crafts businesses. Mrs. Gibbs said that a key to Peekskill's successful rebirth was the county's Charles Point waste-to-energy plant that converts garbage into electricity for Peekskill and industries clustered nearby.
Mayor Terence Zaleski of Yonkers, who did not accept the Urban Affairs Committee's bid to say where he thought the county and, particularly, the Board of Legislators, could help the troubled city, responded later in an interview.
He said the county "has committed $15 million for downtown waterfront rehabilitation, a substantial amount that will "reproduce a waterfront esplanade, a public marina and other infrastructure." The state has pledged $1 million for roads. Also planned for the waterfront is commuter ferry service.
 
Sales Tax Continuation
 He said that the city's downtown reaches out from Getty Square, which has also been the object of plans and projects and which the Mayor insists is a thriving retail center "where rent per square foot is greater than sections along Central Avenue," the heavily commercialized artery that connects Yonkers and White Plains.
"The county can assist us in our outreach, for Getty Square and other sites around the city. They have an economic development arm that enables us to work with other communities," Mr. Zaleski said, adding that he intended to work closely with the Urban Affairs Committee.
The county government, meanwhile, has hardly ignored the plight of the cities. In Yonkers, in addition to the waterfront project, the county has opened new quarters for the Social Services Department, where it can handle 1,800 clients a day.
It is footing the $6 million rehabilitation cost of Mount Vernon's Memorial Field and will operate the stadium for 30 years as part of the deal. The county is also spending $50,000 to move utilities and make other improvements for a retail center across the street from the field.
Meanwhile, Mayor Schulman of White Plains, who met with the Board's Urban Affairs Committee a week before the first open session with the mayors, had another request. He said the county could do a lot by supporting continuation of the extra 0.5 percent city sales tax, which is to expire in the city on Aug. 31 next year.
State lawmakers have the final say in such tax matters, but Albany will act only if the Board of Legislators supports the bid.
 
Reasons for County's Support
 Joining in completion of the Grove Street extension was clearly topmost in the minds of the Mayor and members of the city's Common Council, who accompanied him in the session with the Urban Affairs Committee.
The artery, extending beyond the bus terminal, at the city's western edge, to meet the Bronx River Parkway at the County Center, would also provide access to Central Park Avenue and Route 119, which motorists currently reach as part of a Hamilton Avenue flow that takes traffic under the Metro-North Commuter Railroad station.
Mr. Schulman said White Plains needed the county's support for the Grove Street extension for several reasons.
"First, it's county property where the arterial meets the County Center, so the county must be part of the project," Mr. Schulman said.
Second, the arterial has been designed with county needs in mind, including improved access to the County Center and linking the rest of the county to what is probably Westchester's largest transportation hub.
In a memorandum that Mr. Schulman said he would like to see co-sponsored by the county for presentation to the state, which will provide most of the funds for the project, the point is made that the arterial was planned with "efficient motor-vehicle access" to the transportation center in White Plains in mind.
The area includes the White Plains station of Metro-North, the county's Bee-Line bus system, a long-distance bus station and a taxi center. Easy access to the Grove Street extension "is desirable," the memo states, "to foster increased usage of mass transportation."
