HEADLINE: Art Advocates Troop to Albany to Seek a Piece of the Pie

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
AS thick as the fog rising from the melting snow, the lobbyists arrive here each March, bringing their fact sheets and well-honed pleas. Heeding the maxim, "Those who don't ask, don't get," they swarm through the state capital at budget time.
Among the recent throngs were advocates of the arts from Westchester County, who took part in a day of campaigning sponsored by the Alliance of New York State Arts Councils, based in Spring Valley. Vying for elevator space with American Legionnaires, 4-H clubbers and a host of others, they made the rounds of legislative offices, asking members of the Westchester delegation to the capital to approve more spending for the arts. 
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed $1.5 million more for the New York State Council on the Arts in next year's budget, which legislators say they expect to complete well before the April 1 deadline. Arts advocates are asking for an additional $6 million for the council, which would bring its total for "local assistance" projects statewide to $34 million -- still only about 62 percent of the peak total, in 1989, of $54.8 million. This year's total is $26.5 million.
The 11 county advocates, who included members of the Westchester Arts Council and its affiliates and several school arts coordinators, also came to ask for money for Arts Excel, the Westchester Arts Council's education program. The Westchester council must raise funds to match a $250,000 grant from the state council for the three-year program.
The advocates came ready to sell, but it seemed the legislators were already sold.
 
'The Arts Equal Jobs'
 "I know, the arts equal jobs," said Senator George E. Pataki, Republican of Peekskill, appearing cornered at the far end of a conference table in his office. Janet T. Langsam, executive director of the Westchester Arts Council, was holding up fact sheets printed in oversize letters. "Funds Generated to New York State from the Arts: $2.2 Million," one sheet seemed to scream.
The Senator nodded agreeably. "You don't have to surprise me," he said. "We have to spend more on education, our correctional system and the arts. The arts in Peekskill have changed the real-estate market and the commercial market. It works. Period."
Lobbyists must often settle for a legislative aide, and the arts advocates almost did not see Mr. Pataki. After 10 minutes of discussion with Sandra Sloane, one of Mr. Pataki's aides, about why increased spending for the arts was important, a wilted-looking Ms. Langsam whispered something to one of her staff members, Joanne Mongelli. She in turn whispered something to Ms. Sloane, who went to get the Senator.
Once he was seated, Ms. Langsam warmed to her opportunity. "The arts in Westchester more than pay their way," she said, standing for emphasis.
"I know," Mr. Pataki said, calling himself "one of the many arts friends you have in the Senate" before leaving for another meeting.
Assemblywoman Cecile D. Singer, Republican of Yonkers, also called herself a friend of the arts. Exuding the warmth and naturalness that is her trademark, she spoke to the county group in the elegant lobby of the Assembly chambers. "There can be no adequate education without the arts," she told the advocates. "I support everything in the county."
 
Personal Enthusiasm
 Ms. Singer can often be seen at concerts at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College and has arranged for student musicians from Hoff-Barthelson Music School in Scarsdale to perform at centers for the elderly in her district. No one in the advocacy group questioned her personal enthusiasm for the arts.
But Ms. Singer, a Republican, also said that Saul Cohen, a Westchester resident who that day was elected to a five-year term as a regent of the State University, was eminently qualified for a top education post. Yet she was one of a handful of legislators who voted against him and the second new regent, R. Carlos Carballadi, at a rare joint session of the Senate and Assembly.
She supported the regents as individuals but voted on principle against the institution of the Board of Regents, she later explained to the arts advocates, who watched the proceedings from the balcony of the Assembly chamber. The advocates did not ask Ms. Singer what principle might keep her from voting against an increased arts budget, but in a telephone interview she later said she would vote against the budget if it did not include more school aid for Yonkers.
Mr. Pataki, who officially announced his candidacy for Governor last week, also voted against the two new Regents. (He is a sponsor of a bill to abolish the Regents altogether.)
The joint session, which took the lobbyists by surprise, nearly spoiled the trip, because it disrupted their schedule of meetings with the legislators. But Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Democrat of Scarsdale, saved the day, not only inviting the group to observe the session but also rounding up county members of the Assembly to meet with them outside the chamber afterward.
 
All This and Jobs, Too
 The impromptu meeting -- which included all seven of Westchester's Assembly members -- resembled a huddle, as the legislators and the constituents stood elbow to elbow in a circle. During the animated discussion, there appeared to be full agreement that the arts are worth supporting, that they bring increased tax revenues to the county, that they keep elderly people stimulated and that they are essential in the schools.
"And they create jobs," Ms. Langsam added, hammering away at the economics, as she had done unflaggingly all day.
It fell to a legislator to sound a different note, one that had been conspicuously unheard. "I believe there is an intrinsic value to the arts" that shouldn't be overlooked, Mr. Brodsky said. Assemblywoman Naomi C. Matusow, a Democrat of Mount Kisco, who Ms. Langsam said had emerged, along with Mr. Brodsky, as one of the strongest arts proponents in the Westchester delegation, spoke about the arts as a bonus for the county. "We should make it possible for people to participate," she said.
The way to do that, Ms. Langsam said, was for the delegation to give the Westchester Arts Council money for Arts Excel and for capital improvements at sites like Caramoor in Katonah and Lyndhurst in Tarrytown. Mr. Brodsky balked at this, saying there was "a tradition of not financing organizations two years in a row." Last year, Arts Excel received a total of $40,000 in aid from Albany.
Repeating that this was "not a policy, but a tradition," Mr. Brodsky mused aloud about where the money might come from, starting to say something about nickel deposits on bottles. "We don't care where you get it, Richard," Ms. Langsam said half jokingly. "We just want the money!"
In the morning, the advocates had visited Senators Joseph L. Galiber, Democrat of the Bronx; Guy J. Velella, Republican of Yonkers, and Suzi Oppenheimer, Democrat of Rye, spending more time thanking Ms. Oppenheimer for her support than on persuasion.
Ms. Langsam said she was also meeting regularly with the lawmakers back home, usually at various cultural sites in their own districts.
"Our advocacy effort is year-round, not a single day in Albany," she said. She promised to "keep meeting with these people until the budget is adopted."
"I consider that my job," she said. "To get money for the arts."
 
Evaluating the Day
 When the long hours of trekking through the marble halls and endless corridors of the capitol were over, and the group was ready for the minibus trip home, the advocates took time out to evaluate their day.
"They seem to be making the arts a priority," Rita Weingarten, a Westchester Arts Council trustee, said of the legislators.
Others spoke of having given a human face to the dollars allotted for arts projects.
In a telephone interview later, Mr. Brodsky said the arts lobby had grown more effective in recent years. "The arts have come to recognize that what's important is how people vote," he said.
"Their political sensibilities have gotten toughened up over the years, and I think that's great."
Ms. Singer said it was vital for groups to come to Albany to plead their cause at budget time. "By not being here, you cede the field to all the other people," she said. "It's critically important to be a presence and get a piece of the pie."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Market Message: Business Up, Bonds Down

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE economy is growing nicely, and higher interest rates present little threat to that growth.
That, in any case, seems to be the opinion of the financial markets. Six weeks after the Federal Reserve's Friday frolic, in which both stock and bond markets plunged on news of a small increase in one short-term interest rate, the bond market continues to quake, and interest-sensitive stocks are also weak. 
 But at the same time, the small stock indexes are setting records. Last week the Russell 2000, the best indicator of small stock performance, rose every day and broke through the record it had set just before the Fed's move on Feb. 4. The Nasdaq composite also set a record.
To be sure, the more widely followed stock indexes remain in the doldrums, having recovered less than half of the losses they sustained following the Fed move. The Dow Jones industrial average remains 2.1 percent below its recent high, and the Standard & Poor's 500 is still 2.3 percent below its peak. More significantly, the Dow Jones utility average is off 19.6 percent from its peak, reached last September. It has plunged 8 percent since the Fed's surprise.
The popular perception of small stocks is of emerging growth stocks. There are some, of course, but they don't dominate the group. "There are some very boring companies," says Satya Pradhuman, a senior quantitative analyst at Merrill Lynch who studied the universe of small stocks and discovered that it has a larger proportion of cyclical issues than does the Standard & Poor's 500. And the world of small stocks has a much larger proportion of companies that benefit from capital spending.
What the small stock world does not have is a lot of defensive stocks, the type with good dividends. And if you were valuing a stock for its dividend payout, you are no doubt less eager now that interest rates have zipped up. In the six weeks since the Fed move, which the folks in Washington hoped would raise short-term rates while perhaps lowering long-term ones, the rates on three-month Treasury bills have climbed about one-third of a percentage point, while the rates on five-year bonds have leaped by four-fifths of a point. Perhaps that is what led President Clinton to have his little chat with Alan Greenspan on Friday.
We don't know what happened at the meeting. But what Mr. Greenspan might have said is that the economy is doing just fine, thank you, and the rise in interest rates is a sign that loan demand is finally starting to pick up a bit, as businesses grow more confident about demand for their products. The smaller stocks, more likely as a group to benefit from a stronger economy, are sending out a signal that would please the Administration, if it were not so fixated on interest rates.
Stock market history shows that an unfriendly Fed is eventually fatal to bull markets, but that effect can take a long time. In the interim, it is quite possible that good earnings will carry share prices higher, even if the bond market continues to dip every time Mr. Greenspan is seen in public.

LENGTH: 1578 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: March 13-18

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Michigan Rewrites the Textbook on School Financing
Any list of today's fashionable political ideas has to include these: property taxes are too high, discrepancies in districts' school budgets are unfair and cigarettes are an easy target for higher taxes. In Michigan last week, the three ideas converged with a vengeance. Shattering the traditional method of financing public education, the state voted to shift most of the burden from property taxes to sales taxes. It will also triple the cigarette tax, to 75 cents a pack, to help pay the bills. Together, these taxes will raise about $2 billion. A key goal of the plan is to smooth out the disparities among school districts. The poorest now pay $3,200 per student each year, while the richest pay $10,400 (that's nothing compared with New York, though, where the high is close to $46,000). Each district will now get at least $4,200, and wealthy districts will face spending limits. Other states are probably watching carefully; 28 of them are in the midst of lawsuits involving the redistribution of school aid. 

The Endless Inflation Vigil
So much talk, so little inflation. The inflation cops keep crying wolf, the markets keep recoiling in dread, but the wolf just isn't there. At the risk of sounding like a stuck compact disk, here's the latest: inflation's still in check. February price data, out last week, showed a 0.5 percent gain at the producer level and just 0.3 percent for consumers. And even that gain was propelled by high energy demand during this nasty winter (which ends today!). Interest rates fell on this news, but, inevitably, were spooked again on Friday when Alan Greenspan was summoned to the White House -- to some, an ominous sign, since the Fed's interest-rate panel meets this Tuesday. Anybody see a wolf this time?
 
Cuomo Wants Those Nickels
When budgets get tight, many people turn to bottle deposits for a few extra nickels, and Gov. Mario Cuomo is no exception. In what one critic calls a "political obsession," he has long coveted all those nickels that pile up when bottles and cans are not returned -- an estimated $70 million each year in New York State. Last week he stepped up the battle, saying he'd use subpoenas to audit the beverage industry's books. The industry says it needs the extra money to set up redemption centers, but Mr. Cuomo just calls it "a rip-off."
 
One World, One Job Crisis
Jobs were on President Clinton's mind last week, and he had his sights far beyond our borders, far above the low-wage jobs now abundant. At a jobs conference in Detroit, he challenged the Group of Seven industrial nations to create "a high-wage, high-growth society." Among his specific messages was a call on Japan to stimulate its economy and a call on Europe to lower its interest rates. And he urged all the nations to focus on retraining and productivity. His clear message: unemployment, and underemployment, are global problems. No nation can stand apart.
 
Get Your Dirty Air Here!
To all the things that are swapped and bartered in our national bazaar, we can now add dirty air. The Clean Air Act of 1990 authorized a market in "pollution credits" -- a utility that finds it too costly to clean up to meet the law can buy from another the right to be dirty. Last week two utilities decided to try it out. Public Service Electric and Gas, of New Jersey, will cut emissions more than it has to, and Northeast Utilities, of Connecticut, will buy some of the credits. But this is better than a zero-sum game, merely shifting smog state to state. For one thing, some credits will be retired, a net gain for the air. And because of the air flow, more smog will be sent out to sea. Finally, the deal shifts more pollution to winter, when smog's less of a problem.
 
Paying to Stay in the Jet Set
If a highway is built next to a city, the city can be pretty sure the road will be there a while -- and plan its dreams accordingly. But air travel is more slippery. The jittery airlines are fickle these days, adding routes, dropping routes, in a constant fine-tuning. So just because you've got an airport doesn't mean airlines will keep coming. With such uncertainty, how is a medium-size city to lure businesses? When Amarillo, Tex., learned recently that American Airlines planned to drop jet service to Dallas, the city chipped in $1 million to guarantee American a profit on those flights if it gets to keep the jets. Now, all the airlines have to do is get these guarantees from every city they fly to, and their troubles will be over.
 
COMPANIES
 
In Paramount's Hot Seat
During that endless takeover battle, Paramount began to look like a magic carpet that would whisk the victor to a land of untold riches. Just think what now faces the person assigned to run it -- there'll be some powerful pressure to deliver on that promise. Having decided that it would not be Stanley Jaffe, the president, last week Viacom picked the person for that hot seat: Jonathan Dolgen, president of the Sony Motion Picture Group, who will head what's to be called the Viacom Entertainment Group. Mr. Dolgen is little known outside the industry, but within it he is widely respected. And it's probably a signal of what Viacom wants from the studio that what Mr. Dolgen is known for is being a tough negotiator -- and a fierce cost-cutter.
 
Kemper, Defiantly Single
Kemper was awfully huffy in its formal rejection of GE Capital's takeover bid last week. "Attend to your own business," it urged. "And allow us the same courtesy." GE Capital wants to make a bigger splash in mutual funds, and it sees Kemper as its ticket. But Kemper wants none of it. Or, some say, it merely wants a higher price -- even though the $55-a-share offer was a hefty premium. That $55 sounds good to shareholders, though, some of whom are already suing Kemper for its handling of the offer. And if GE Capital walks away in its own huff, a move sure to send Kemper's stock plunging, shareholders will be certain to storm the barricades.
 
Rich Rewards at Chrysler
If a company prospers, it makes sense to reward those who made it happen. Chrysler has done spectacularly, so it more than tripled the bonuses for top executives, including its chairman, Robert J. Eaton. But it was vehicles like the Dodge Ram and the LH sedans that fueled the comeback, and, as Mr. Eaton himself points out, they were already in the works when he arrived two years ago. No matter. Mr. Eaton's '93 bonus soared to $1.9 million, putting his total pay at $6.79 million -- equal to the total salaries of perhaps 200 assembly-line workers. "Conspicuous, excessive compensation," the U.A.W. said. "It sends the wrong message to workers."
 
Empire: Adding It All Up
New York's Insurance Department added up the facts about Empire Blue Cross in a report out last week, and it wasn't a pretty picture. Managers did just about everything, the report said, to mislead examiners -- denying there were two sets of books, withholding profit data, distorting figures.
 
At Fleet, No Job Is Safe
When a company hacks away at its work force, no one, it seems, is exempt -- not even those doing the hacking. Fleet Financial recently said it was cutting 5,500 jobs, and one executive who planned this cutback was Edward Devin, senior vice president for human resources. Last week, Mr. Devin was laid off.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Cashing In on Scarce Hondas
It makes an awfully good case for free markets: If you create an artificial shortage of something people crave, you can be sure the scoundrels will find a way to cash in on this distorted market. In the 80's, before Detroit figured out how to make cars people liked, everyone wanted a Honda, but Honda imports were limited under voluntary quotas. So Honda executives in the United States seized on this opportunity, prosecutors say, taking more than $10 million in kickbacks from dealers, who, if they got extra cars, could easily sell them well above sticker price. Last week the indictments came in, and eight former Honda executives pleaded guilty. A lot of people clearly overpaid for Hondas to feed this little game, but their complaints will have to be heard another day.
 
A Rescue for Euro Disney
For the moment at least, Euro Disney is alive -- if not exactly kicking up its heels. The losses piled up so steadily for a while that it started to look like a scene from "The Sorcerer's Apprentice" -- bucket after relentless bucket of bad news. In December, Walt Disney's chairman, Michael Eisner, said it was even possible that the French outpost might close. But last week, after months of haggling, Euro Disney worked out a deal with Disney -- which owns 49 percent of Euro Disney -- and its creditor banks, giving it more than $1 billion in new capital. But everyone knows the formula has to change: the park lost nearly that much in its first year of operation.
 
More Trouble for Mexico
Mexico has stabilized greatly since President Salinas took office in 1988. The Government tamed runaway 150 percent inflation to 8 percent, and the economy expanded steadily. But on Jan. 1, when the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, the Chiapas uprising spread uncertainty through the land, and stocks soon started sliding. To top it off, new figures show that Mexico actually dipped into recession in late 1993. The Government went too far, some say, in squashing inflation.

LENGTH: 1885 words

HEADLINE: For Oil Industry, That Next 'Elephant' Proves Elusive

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
MOBIL executives thought they had a live one about two years ago. The geology looked promising for a major oil find in Peru. After long haggling over environmental concerns and hauling equipment into a remote area, the well was sunk.
"I mean this was classic -- this is the classic way of how to do it," recalled Lucio A. Noto, chairman of the Mobil Corporation. Yet, "We came up with a dry well -- $35 million later." 
 Such stories abound in the industry. Despite intense drilling and huge spending in many places in Southeast Asia, Latin America and Africa, oil companies have not made many big strikes.
This lack of new discoveries could ultimately lead to an increase in the price of oil. While an oil surplus has driven down prices and has weakened the pricing power of OPEC, renewed economic growth in many countries is making the world hungry for oil again. And only the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has the huge oil reserves to meet the increased demand.
With that kind of power, OPEC will be in a better position to control the price of oil, just as it did so dramatically in the 1970's. That is comforting to the OPEC ministers as they gather this week for a meeting in Vienna.
It's not that the major oil companies aren't trying. ARCO drilled 13 wells and spent $163 million in Alaska in 1993, but it came up with only modest finds. British Petroleum made a large discovery in 1992 in Colombia, which for a while had the industry anticipating an "elephant field," but that field fell short and there has been little to crow about since. The last huge oil discovery was made in the North Sea in the late 1960's.
"Whatever discoveries have been made, they have been smaller," said Constantine Fliakos, the oil analyst for Merrill Lynch. Nothing has approached the fields of the North Sea, which have reserves of about 13 billion barrels, and Prudhoe Bay in Alaska, at about 10 billion barrels.
As a result, many oil companies have moved their exploratory efforts to places where they have already found a lot of oil, like the North Sea, or are confident that a lot of oil exists, like the nations that were once part of the Soviet Union, as well as China, Vietnam and Venezuela.
"In the 1980's they spent a hell of a lot of money and a hell of a lot of time looking in funny places," said Bill Cline, an oil economist for Gaffney, Cline & Associates in London. "It didn't work out. Now we are seeing a refocusing to areas where we know there is oil."
The surge of oil from Alaska and the North Sea put OPEC on the defensive in the 1980's and cut its share of world oil production from more than 50 percent in the 1970's to about 30 percent in 1985. Since then OPEC's share of the market has rebounded to 43 percent.
THE OPEC ministers are expected this week to weigh whether to continue production at 24.5 million barrels a day, or to cut back further to raise oil prices, which have shown little resiliency.
Whatever their action, many industry experts think that despite OPEC's largely passive role and a surge in oil from non-OPEC areas, the fundamentals have not changed for the organization.
For one thing, the lack of major finds has kept the OPEC nations with about 77 percent, or 770 billion barrels, of the world's proven reserves, according to a recent survey by British Petroleum.
"The current low prices are masking OPEC's long-term strength," said John H. Lichtblau, the head of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, a consulting group to the energy industry. The price of crude oil for April delivery closed at $14.88 per barrel on Friday, down from about $20 last spring.
BUT OPEC first has to deal with some short-term problems. The surge of oil coming from the North Sea, which is expected to reach an extra million barrels a day by the end of the year, is adding to the world oil surplus of a few hundred thousand barrels a day, and is keeping prices depressed.
The ability of oil companies to squeeze out more production from mature fields by using new technology has also added to the surplus.
The expected re-entry of Iraq into the oil market once the United Nations embargo is lifted, which is expected this year, could force the OPEC countries to cut production further to absorb the million barrels a day Iraq is expected to produce.
Combined with recessions in some big consuming countries, these trends have kept oil prices down.
Nevertheless, the ability of the organization to push up prices is still there. If Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer and a member of OPEC, should decide to support a major cut in production, prices will rise, most analysts and economists agree. Thus far, Saudi Arabia has been unwilling to significantly reduce its output. The Saudi position, which has led to reduced revenues for the OPEC nations as the price of oil has fallen, has prevented the organization from acting.
But that stalemate should not lull consuming nations into thinking that the organization has lost its influence.
As demand for oil increases, the OPEC nations are the only ones with the reserve capacity to meet that demand. That capacity is estimated at about 10 percent of the 25 million barrels a day OPEC pumps.
Meanwhile, production in some major areas, such as the United States, is continuing to decline. That creates more demand for OPEC oil. In the United States, domestic crude oil production continued to plunge, falling to less than 6.9 million barrels a day in 1993, the lowest level since 1958.
"The fundamentals are shifting in their favor," Mr. Fliakos, the Merrill Lynch analyst, said. "Oil demand has been flat for the past four years, but there is a major recovery under way."
With economies beginning to grow again in much of Asia, India and China, and with a strong recovery in the United States, he said, the demand for oil is expected to grow by 3.5 percent to 4 percent this year. Even if demand grows by just 2 percent, he said, that would add about 1.5 million barrels a day to consumption, enough to soak up the surplus and put OPEC back in a strong position.
"The added demand has to come from OPEC," he added. "They are the only ones that can produce the additional oil that the world is going to need."
As demand recovers, the United States Geological Survey has forecast that OPEC's share of the market will grow from the current 43 percent to about 50 percent by 2010, making it even more dominant.
At the same time, the chances of oil companies finding the elephant fields that could cut into OPEC's share have become slimmer as they have shifted exploration into areas where they have already found oil, such as the North Sea.
The wild cards in this scenario are the former states of the Soviet Union, including Russia and Kazakhstan, where major oilfields exist and the potential of finding more is very high.
BUT the drilling there is still many years away for most companies, like Mobil, the Chevron Corporation and the Amoco Corporation. They plan to invest billions of dollars in new exploration in the former Soviet Union, but they are still working out agreements with highly unstable governments.
Meanwhile, the prospect of finding elephant fields elsewhere has dwindled.
Between 1981 and 1987, the 18 largest oil companies in the United States pulled out of many areas where oil deposits are promising but unproven. Spending for exploration declined from $14.3 billion to $5.6 billion during those years. Since then, the oil companies have been spending between $5 billion and $7 billion on exploration each year.
The Exxon Corporation, for example, did extensive exploration in Somalia, Mali, Tanzania, Mozambique, Chad, Nigeria and Morocco in the early 1980's. Now it is only in Chad and Nigeria. The Royal Dutch/Shell Group has pulled out of Madagascar and Guatemala, and has shifted much of its effort to the North Sea.
"Most places we're going into, by and large the governments are very receptive to having us come in," said Paul J. Hoenmans, the executive vice president for worldwide exploration and producing at Mobil. "American technology still is the leader. It is to Houston and Dallas that the world looks."
He said the oil companies could eventually find huge fields "by applying the new technology in the new areas and avoiding some of the mistakes we've made in the past by just setting out at random to search for oil."
 
 
 
CHEVRON'S LONG ROAD IN KAZAKHSTAN
 THERE is a sea of oil below the flat windswept desert of Kazakhstan, about 25 billion barrels, making it one of the largest oilfields in the world.
But Chevron is getting just a trickle out of the ground. And the oil it is getting is laden with poison and has a stench, making it difficult to handle and transport.
What could turn out to be a bonanza for Chevron remains as elusive as the nomadic horsemen who occasionally appear outside the barracks of the 3,500 workers who are helping Kazakhstan restore its shattered oil industry.
It may be many years before oil flows in large enough quantities to make a joint venture between Tengizchevroil, the state oil company, and Chevron pay off. Chevron figures the partnership will spend about $20 billion over 40 years. By 2010, the partnership hopes to be pumping 700,000 barrels a day, bringing in about $4 billion in revenue a year at today's oil prices.
Chevron has shifted its exploration from areas abroad where oil reserves are promising but unproven, and from mature fields in the United States to known fields, such as Tengiz in Kazakhstan. The challenge is not whether oil will be found, but how to get large quantities out of existing wells and ship the oil to world markets. After seven years, and after spending more than $300 million, Chevron is producing only about 30,000 barrels a day, although that is expected to grow to about 130,000 barrels soon.
Tengiz is a paradox. Its crude oil, the color of light honey, is perfect for gasoline. But it is also full of poisonous hydrogen sulfide, which must be removed at a special plant. Workers undergo safety training and carry gas masks.
The oil is also full of mercaptans, sulfur compounds that can cause a stench in the countryside if they leak from the pipeline. To be commercially viable, the crude must be transported through Russia, but the Russians limit shipments of the Kazakh oil in their pipelines because they don't have a recovery system to contain the vapors.
The partners want to build their own pipeline, at a huge cost, but there is a problem with where to build it. If it is connected to the existing Russian system, Chevron and its partner will remain hostage to expensive transport fees. Other routes would take it through risky areas, like Iran and Iraq.
While production has been restored at about 20 of the 85 wells originally drilled when Kazakhstan was part of the Soviet Union, oil from just 10 can be shipped because of the transport restrictions.
The multinational work force is made up mostly of Kazakhs, but there are many Russians, Hungarians and Americans.
The 250 workers from the United States are learning to live with the harsh conditions, where temperatures can reach 130 in summer and 40 below zero in winter. The wind blows powdery sand, making mouths gritty and contact lenses uncomfortable.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Betting the Bull Market Is Finished

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
THE sky is falling! The sky is falling! But Chicken Little and other mutual fund investors won't be hurt at all if they invest in two new bear market funds, say managers of the Robertson Stephens Contrarian and Lindner Bulwark funds.
The funds use antipodal approaches to a financial markets meltdown: Robertson Stephens aims to profit; Lindner seeks to preserve capital. 
 Even so, the funds are very risky because their managers can invest almost any way they want. "It's blind pool," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds in Chicago. "I'm skeptical."
"We created the equivalent of a public hedge fund," said Paul Stephens, who runs the Contrarian fund in San Francisco. Hedge funds usually have very high minimums -- $250,000 to $10 million or more -- and use leverage, short sales and other risky investment methods to profit in good markets and bad.
Contrarian, however, is constrained by mutual fund laws that prevent managers from taking too much risk. For instance, the fund cannot invest more than 25 percent in one industry or take short positions in more than a quarter of its assets.
But Mr. Stephens still has a fairly wide berth, and he has been making the most of it, with Contrarian's short positions nearly at the maximum. "I'm very bearish on the stock and bond markets," he said.
So far, more than a handful of investors have agreed. The fund, which started last June with $5 million, now has $345 million.
About 22 percent of Contrarian is in short positions right now, but Mr. Stephens refuses to disclose the companies' names "because they would stop doing business with us." He will say that the 50 short positions include "nearly every tea and soft drink company, restaurants, mortgage banking, overpriced tech stocks and almost all the public mutual fund companies."
Another 5 percent is invested in S.& P. put options, a bet that the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index will drop.
The fund is mostly invested in gold and other commodities stocks because the gradually rising inflation that Mr. Stephens predicts over the 90's "will be commodity driven, not wage driven," he said.
In particular, he likes what he calls "growth gold" companies, mining companies that should be able to post profits by increasing their reserves even if the price of gold stays flat. Most are Canadian companies with explorations outside Canada. Among the largest he owns today are Cambior and Golden Star Resources.
The fund's biggest holding is Santa Fe Pacific, which Mr. Stephens calls a "hidden gold company" because of its large gold operation.
Six percent of the fund is invested in three aluminum companies: Alumax, Kaiser Aluminum and Maxxam, which owns shares of Kaiser and Pacific Lumber.
Another 6 percent is invested in real estate stocks, mostly companies that have holdings in Texas, California and Florida. The largest, accounting for 2.5 percent of the fund, is Avatar in Florida; next biggest is Catellus in California.
Contrarian's charter allows it to invest entirely abroad. Only about a third is invested outside the United States today, but that should increase over the next three years, Mr. Stephens said.
Potential investors should heed Mr. Stephens's warning: the biggest risk for the fund is if the market's future performance is strong. "We've made the bet that the bull market is over," he said.
Some analysts think that's a bad bet, among them Ken Gregory, editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst in San Francisco. But, he added, Mr. Stephens is a "successful investor who may well generate good returns even without his disaster scenario unfolding." One hurdle will be Contrarian's unusually high expenses, which equal more than 2.5 percent annually of the amount invested.
The $1.9 million Lindner Bulwark Fund was started in February. Although its charter is similar to Contrarian's -- heavy investments in precious metals, short sales, options and futures -- its aim is radically different.
"It's a capital preservation fund" designed to perform when the equity and fixed-income markets are declining, said Larry Callahan, the fund's lead manager.
Like Contrarian, Bulwark grew out of the concern over the outsized gains of the financial markets. It was conceived, Mr. Callahan said, "for people who feel that now is the wrong time to invest but want to do something for their future."
The fund will invest in undervalued stocks as opportunities arise, but "at this point in the market, we don't see a whole lot of buying opportunities in individual stocks," Mr. Callahan said. Right now the fund is only 20 percent invested, mostly in shares of C.P.T., the Peruvian telephone company, and two Canadian gold companies, Wharf Resources and Hemlow Gold. No shorts, yet.
The high cash position is not unreasonable, Mr. Callahan said; as much as 60 percent of the fund could regularly be in cash when no buy opportunities exist.
Bulwark's expenses are more reasonable than Contrarian's, at 1.4 percent of assets annually, but that's still a high price for what may amount to a money market fund, almost 60 percent of which charge no fees.

HEADLINE: In Scolding China, Washington Loses Face

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In August 1944, John S. Service, a career diplomat then acting as political officer to the United States Army's observer group in Yanan, had a lengthy conversation with Mao Zedong. The defeat of the Axis powers was in sight, and Mao was thinking of how to build a new China once the war ended. He told Service he would be willing to go to Washington and discuss future Chinese-American relations with President Roosevelt. He never received a reply. 
 Coolness became overt hostility when the People's Republic of China was proclaimed in 1951. The United States Seventh Fleet plied the strait separating Taiwan from the mainland. The United States imposed an economic embargo against China and pressured its major trading partners to do the same. Guns were fired in anger just on the other side of Chinese borders, in Korea, then in Vietnam. China felt threatened. During the Korean War, Gen. Douglas MacArthur boasted his troops would be "over the Yalu by Christmas."
The effect was to thrust China into the arms of the Soviet Union, which proved very bad for China and created serious consequences for the United States. The lesson was not lost on Washington. Friendly relations with China were obviously in America's best interests. Starting with the visit by President Richard M. Nixon and Secretary of State Henry Kissinger in 1972, the climate improved, followed by extensive commercial activities fueled by China's economic boom.
But cold war warriors die hard. Though small in number, they are vociferous. Their favorite weapon is alleged violations of "human" rights. Against Asian nations this proves to be not a spear but a boomerang.
The Chinese have a strong sense of dignity and propriety. They think it presumptuous for a mere infant of a country, historically speaking, to tell a sovereign state 10 times its age and possessed of a highly cultured civilization, how to live. China has its own Constitution and a body of laws guaranteeing internationally recognized civil rights, including the right to a decent livelihood. The Chinese consider specious the argument that economic well-being is only a "social," not a "human" right. They believe democracy cannot survive on an empty stomach, any more than a full stomach can supplant democracy. They want both, simultaneously.
While most Chinese will admit to some failings in the protection of their civil rights, they insist that interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign nation is a violation of international law. Moreover, they claim to be competent to deal with such problems themselves.
In any event, the Chinese are well aware of America's military incursions into little countries abroad and its miserable civil rights record at home. They witnessed the beating of Rodney King on their television news. They read in their newspapers about American jails overflowing with prisoners -- mostly black. Their daily press gives wide coverage to United States crime, drugs, poverty, homelessness, graft and corruption. Such a country, the Chinese maintain, is not fit to talk about violations of citizen rights in other lands. America is lacking in moral authority.
And now, to heap absurdity on cant, the statements of visiting American politicians and trade negotiators make it apparent that they care nothing about Chinese rights, whether labeled "human" or "civil." They promise to tone down their slanders immediately, if only the Chinese will grant them more economic concessions. That is the name of the game.
America's human rights razzle-dazzle has brought loss of face and less respect for American policy makers in China, and Asia in general. The Chinese made it clear to Secretary of State Warren Christopher and his delegation that China will not accept "linkage." It is time Washington stopped the fruitless gesturing and got on with genuine, mutually beneficial, business.
 
SIDNEY SHAPIRO
Beijing, March 17, 1994
 
The writer, long a resident of China, is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Council.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
For the Presidents, The Polls Are Irresistible

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY 

 BODY:
CARTER had his Caddell and Reagan his Wirthlin. And for every President of the last 50 years, there have been polls to provide political intelligence.
Franklin D. Roosevelt indeed recognized the possibilities that arose with the beginning of modern public opinion polling in the late 1930's. F.D.R. encouraged Hadley Cantril of Princeton University, a pioneer in the academic use of polling, to periodically gauge public sentiment about increasing aid to England, changing the Neutrality Law and adopting the policy that became Lend-Lease. In 1940 and early 1941, the charts Professor Cantril provided showed a public initially reluctant, subsequently divided, and then progressively supportive of aiding England. 
 David W. Moore, in his book "The Superpollsters" (Four Walls Eight Windows, 1992), describes how more recent Presidents relied on their campaign pollsters after reaching the White House. Jimmy Carter had Patrick Caddell test support for various energy policies. After Ronald Reagan became President, Richard Wirthlin explored economic questions when Mr. Reagan's ratings dipped in the recession of the early 1980's, then sounded out public opinion on the nuclear freeze issue.
And Fred Steeper recalled in a telephone interview the extensive polling he did in the Bush years for the Republican National Committee -- polls of great interest to the White House -- on alternative types of spending cuts and tax increases.
But if Presidents have drawn on polls to anticipate public reaction, that's not to say any ever tailored his political principles to the computer printouts.
"As far as I am aware," Mr. Cantril wrote, "Roosevelt never altered his goals because public opinion appeared against him or was uninformed. Rather, he utilized such information to try to bring the public around more quickly."
 MICHAEL R. KAGAY

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
In 1994-Model Politics, Loyalty Is Often Optional Equipment

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
GLADSTONE said that the first requisite of a prime minister is to be a good butcher.
Like British leaders, American Presidents must know when they have reached the limits of loyalty, and be prepared to cut off troublesome friends and advisers, or persuade them to fall on the knife so obligingly held out. 
President Clinton has been sacrificing friends and advisers at a rather brisk pace since he came to town. From Lani Guinier to Les Aspin to Bernard Nussbaum to Webb Hubbell, Mr. Clinton has shown a willingness to part with those in whom he detects albatross tendencies.
So does this make Bill Clinton a smart politician who moves quickly to correct mistakes and protect his Presidency and his party, even if it is personally hard for him? Or does it make the President appear unsentimental and reluctant to fight for friends who are in trouble -- an image that is out of sync with his empathetic, lip-biting, share-your-pain persona?
The answer, as usual with Mr. Clinton, is all of the above.
Psychologists say that the way you exit a relationship can speak worlds about you, and Presidents are no exception. "This is one of the truest reflections of Presidential character," said Marlin Fitzwater, a spokesman for both Presidents Reagan and Bush. "Where you draw the line on loyalty, how you come down on questions about dropping people or sticking with them, are judgments so individual and personal that, in the end, the President has to make them by himself."
Loyalty was the principle George Bush held most dear, an old-fashioned view of friendship and obligation baked into him on the playing fields of Greenwich, Andover and Yale.
While Mr. Bush was admired for his steadfastness, it could be argued that this very quality led to his downfall. Even when many Republicans were yelping back in 1991 that the President was being badly served by his economic team -- Nicholas Brady, the Treasury Secretary, and Richard Darman, the budget director -- Mr. Bush tuned out all criticism.
He did send his son, George, to dismiss his fractious chief of staff, John Sununu in 1991, but it was only after Mr. Sununu had abused the perquisites of his office and alienated much of Washington.
President Bush's rigorous requirements for staff loyalty became crippling because he continually turned to mediocre Bush loyalists for top jobs over talented Republicans who had worked for his rivals.
He continued to let his old friends, James Baker, Fred Malek and Robert Teeter, run his 1992 campaign after it became abundantly clear that they were running it into the ground. Mr. Bush asked Mr. Baker to give up his cherished job as Secretary of State in 1992 and return to the role of political handler, which he despised. Mr. Baker said yes out of loyalty, but could not conceal his feeling that this was one favor too many, since he had helped make Mr. Bush President in the first place. His resentment, and his fear that he would be associated with a losing campaign, undermined his ability, and the handler once revered as "the Velvet Hammer" ended up so far behind the scenes as to be invisible.
What is surprising about Bill Clinton, given his hugging-and-sharing political style, is the absence of sentimentality when he cuts people loose.
The President, whose career was a triumph of baby boomer networking, has now shown the limits of such bonds. While it is nice, in this communitarian world, if everyone advances together, the Friends of Bill and Hillary now understand that their falling back does not prevent others from going forward.
"Yuppies don't have loyalty," noted William Kristol, the head of the Project for the Republican Future and an acidic Clinton critic. "They have useful relationships and meaningful encounters."
 
Before the Fall
 When Mr. Clinton abruptly dumped his old friend Lani Guinier, after it became clear that she would have a rough time being confirmed in a top civil rights post at the Justice Department, there were complaints, even among those who agreed with the decision, that the President had not handled it well.
Many Democrats, and many black leaders, argued angrily that the President had set up Ms. Guinier for a fall by ignoring all the red flags about the nomination from Capitol Hill, and by failing to read her more controversial articles before announcing the appointment. They felt that, once he had committed to her, he should have let her argue her case on the Hill; wasn't Mr. Clinton, after all, the "Comeback Kid" who thrived on steep odds and taking his case directly to the people?
What many people found most strange was that once Mr. Clinton dropped Ms. Guinier, he never called her again, not when they were both on vacation in Martha's Vineyard last summer, not in all the months since. Asked to explain why Mr. Clinton, who attended her wedding, has never gotten in touch, Ms. Guinier replied: "I've certainly thought about it a lot. I don't get it."
By contrast, the soft-hearted Mr. Bush not only stuck with beleaguered nominees, such as John Tower and Clarence Thomas, but when an appointment did blow up, he would make a point of trying to rehabilitate the reject with a dinner invitation or another job offer.
Another example is Les Aspin, the Secretary of Defense who got the ax. Even Democrats who agreed with the decision were angry that White House officials badmouthed the popular Mr. Aspin in background interviews. And Aspin loyalists were outraged by the suggestion that the President had dropped him once he found he was a poor administrator.
"If Bill Clinton didn't know Les ran a sloppy office, he was the only person in Washington who didn't," an Aspin crony said. "You hire Les to think, and he thought. That 'poor organizer' rap was just a cop-out."
Ms. Guinier said she agreed with a friend who had compared the political culture with the gang culture in the inner cities. "A sociopath can kill without remorse because he's conditioned by the environment to treat life with little respect as a way of gaining status in that environment," she said. "Now politicians are being trained by their environment to feel that in order to succeed, they have to be prepared to sacrifice friends and then move on."
Another Southern governor, Earl Long of Louisiana, once offered quite a different view of the nature of political loyalty.
When one of his aides said to him, "I'm with you when you're right, Governor, but not when you're wrong," Mr. Long retorted: "You stupid S.O.B., I don't need you when I'm right."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
North Korea, on Long Leash, Runs Circles Around Its Foes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
Say this about North Korea's leaders: They may be Stalinist fanatics, they may be terrorists, they may be building nuclear bombs, but they are not without subtlety. They have mastered the art of dangling Washington on a string.
Few international crises have brewed as long as the North Korean nuclear weapons project. Depending on how you count, it started 27 years ago. It has looked threatening -- first vaguely, then very -- for just shy of a decade. Yet at major milestones along the way, the West has always found reason for hope that Kim Il Sung, who is 81 and the world's longest surviving leader, was one step away from trading his nuclear ambitions for a way out of his country's economic wasteland. 
 There was hope in 1985, when he signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, and hope again in 1991, when he finally obeyed the treaty's provisions and allowed international inspectors into the nuclear installations at Yongbyon. There was hope last June, when Mr. Kim's Government "suspended" a decision to become the first country to back out of the treaty, and a declaration of victory in December, when the Clinton Administration thought it had clinched a deal on inspections, in return for talks about aid and recognition.
Yet every time some last-minute glitch mocked the hopeful headlines. Last week came one of the biggest of all: After taking months to negotiate an inspection that would allow talks with the United States to go on, the North once again thwarted inspectors. On Saturday, its representatives walked out of talks with the South Koreans at Panmunjom, and threatened war if the United States and the South mounted a pressure campaign.
To many, such frustrations are the price of negotiating with the world's most impenetrable country. Others, from generals in Seoul to some of George Bush's national security officials, believe the Clinton Administration needs to dramatically toughen its approach.
"The United States has responded to every broken promise, every lie, every threat with the groundless optimism that tomorrow will be a better day," Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, said last week. "It is time for North Korea to overcome our concerns or live with the consequences -- consequences that will hasten the collapse of that despicable regime."
Senator McCain represents one side in the endless sticks-or-carrots debate on how to deal with the North, but the chronology that appears below suggests that Washington's biggest problem has been the time it took to engage the issue. "We have been watching and talking for 20 years when we should have been acting," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control and an author of the chronology.
 
'Asleep at the Switch'
 In the 1980's, the Reagan Administration did not pay much attention to Korea, and the Bush Administration, Mr. Milhollin argues, was "basically asleep at the switch." So was the North's perpetual enemy in Seoul. "From time to time we received reports, but it didn't catch us as a big threat at that moment," Lee Hong Ku, South Korea's unification minister until 1990, said in a recent interview. "Had we given a consistent and clear warning, perhaps the North Koreans would not have made such a big investment in it."
Since the world finally awoke, North Korea has used what Leonard Spector of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace calls salami tactics: "Every time they promise a slice, they actually give us half a slice."
But the fact is that, despite all the talk of sanctions and resuming military exercises, President Clinton's options are limited. He and his allies are as divided as ever about the wisdom of provoking a country with a mad-dog reputation and so much artillery so near Seoul. South Korea swings from one anxious extreme to another, one day fearful of pushing its enemy too far, the next day fretting that the United States won't be tough enough. Japan is equally cautious, and the Chinese are not in a mood to make life for Mr. Clinton any easier.
The architects of the West's strategy are a bit defensive, arguing that they have taken the only prudent course: Pursue every hope that the North's real goal is to trade away the bomb project for benefits that will help prop up the regime. If that is so, they point out, Mr. Kim has gotten nothing so far -- not a cent of aid or trade. "We're not backsliding," argues Han Sung Joo, South Korea's Foreign Minister. "Presumably we are paving the way for ultimate resolution of the issue -- although it is not clear if we can get there at this point."
The problem is that the North has its own logic; Mr. Kim has long seen nuclear weapons as the only equalizer with the West. He has given in to threats, but only a bit, and only enough to buy time. The shell game over inspections, the carefully maintained mystery about the bomb's existence, is the one asset he holds. And he is betting, probably rightly, that no one is willing to take the considerable risks to make sure Korea is nuclear-free.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
If Money Buys Good Schools, We Can Fix the Schools. If.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
LAST week, when Michigan voters approved a radical change in public school financing, many were probably less concerned about the future of education than with their pocketbooks. The landmark plan, which is being watched closely by policy-makers in other states, will reduce property taxes by shifting the burden of school financing to sales and other taxes.
But educators will be watching another provision of the Michigan plan, which seeks to narrow the gap between rich and poor schools by guaranteeing each district a minimum of $4,200 a student -- $1,000 more than the least affluent districts get now. 
 The idea, of course, is to improve the educational prospects of poor students by giving their schools more money. But experts have learned over the years that spending more on a school doesn't necessarily mean that its students will learn more. From an economist's point of view, the connection between money and education is maddeningly unclear.
"We have a lot of studies that show little impact from spending," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution. "Then, too, we have a lot that show tangible benefits."
The debate dates from 1966, with the publication of an ambitious study of some 600,000 students in 3,000 schools by the United States Office of Education. The Coleman Report, as it came to be known (after John Coleman, who led the research team), concluded that it was attitudes of families and fellow students rather than the quality of schools that largely determined educational achievement.
For all the initial stir, however, the report did not inhibit spending. Eric Hanushek, an economist at the University of Rochester, estimates that per pupil outlays, adjusted for inflation, rose from about $2,700 to $4,900 from 1965 to 1989. Average class size fell from 25 to 18, while the proportion of teachers with a master's degree rose from a quarter to half and median teacher experience went from 8 to 15 years.
As widely bemoaned, however, American students' performance on a variety of tests (notably in mathematics) remained well behind those in countries that spent far less on schools. Scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test fell about 5 percent across the quarter-century.
To be sure, there are problems with correlating spending with test scores. For example, a disproportionate chunk of the extra education dollar in recent years has gone to government-mandated programs for the disabled. And the pool of students taking the S.A.T. has grown along with the proportion attending college, making comparisons of average test scores hard to interpret.
 
Evidence of Perverse Effects
 What is more, average pay in competing professions has gone up sharply with average productivity in the economy, presumably driving up the cost of hiring comparably qualified teachers. This effect has probably been magnified by the reduction in discrimination against women, who are now freer to compete for jobs in law, medicine and business. But in Mr. Hanushek's view, these and other factors are not decisive. He analyzed the results of 187 studies of the last two decades, many inspired by the Coleman Report, and found little confirmation that teacher credentials or class size influenced test scores. Indeed, there is almost as much evidence of perverse effects as positive ones.
That is hardly the last word on the subject, though. Two Princeton University economists, David Card and Alan Krueger, argue that the ultimate output of public education isn't the ability to answer multiple-choice questions, but to earn a living. They took averages of teacher pay and class size, state by state, and then looked at the average earnings of workers educated in those states decades later. The cumulative results over a lifetime of work were striking: Mr. Krueger estimates that for each extra dollar spent on education, total annual wages rose by 10 cents -- a return on the investment of roughly 10 percent.
Confusing matters, Julian Betts, an economist at the University of California at San Diego, tried a variation on the Card-Krueger approach with very different results. He measured the impact of individual schools on a sample of 1,810 people in all 50 states. Neither class size, teacher pay nor teacher credentials seemed to make a consistent difference on earnings a decade later. Jeff Grogger, an economist at the University of California at Santa Barbara, found similar results: The standard measures of school quality accounted for little of the variation in wages between blacks and whites who went to high school in the early 1970's.
Statistical studies are always tricky to interpret. It requires a leap of faith -- sometimes unwarranted -- to infer cause and effect from statistical correlation. Some researchers have relied instead on something closer to a controlled experiment, in which children and teachers are randomly assigned to small and large classes and tested on various skills. The largest of these experiments, analyzed by Jeremy Finn of the State University of New York at Buffalo and Charles Achilles of the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, involved some 6,500 kindergartners in Tennessee from a variety of social backgrounds. Students in small classes did better in both reading and math achievement, with the greatest differences seen among non-whites.
What is one to make of these contradictions?
Mr. Betts thinks the Card-Krueger study is seriously flawed because it lumps together data from whole states rather than focusing on individual schools. And Larry Hedges, a statistician at the University of Chicago, argues that Mr. Hanushek's analysis of the 187 earlier studies is far off the mark: Crank up the computer with a different set of assumptions about how to weight the results of the same studies and out pops the opposite conclusion.
Orley Ashenfelter, an economist at Princeton University who was once in charge of evaluating the Department of Labor's research efforts, believes that, done properly, further research along the lines of the Tennessee experiments might produce decisive results. "It's a scandal," he argues, "that education programs aren't held to the same standards as new drugs."
The one very real accomplishment of the continuing controversy has been to refine the terms of the debate. It is possible that societal changes in the 1980's, like the breakdown of the family, have simply overshadowed the positive effects of increased spending. It is also possible that money matters -- sometimes. Much early spending went, in response to court mandates, to people and places that were glaringly starved of educational resources -- rural, inner city and previously segregated black schools.
It may even be possible that money could matter more under the right circumstances. Experts on both sides of the debate agree that schools vary radically in their ability to translate dollars into better educated students. "Everybody knows the differences in school quality are there," said James Heckman, an economist at the University of Chicago, "but nobody knows how to quantify them."
Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, acknowledges that a good portion of the increase in real outlays per pupil over the last quarter-century has gone for naught because "nobody sat down and thought about how to spend it."

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL URGE U.N. TO PLAN SANCTIONS FOR NORTH KOREA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration decided today to ask the United Nations to lay the groundwork for economic sanctions against North Korea as diplomatic efforts to persuade Pyongyang to end its nuclear program neared collapse, Administration officials said.
Cabinet-level officials met at the White House today to map out a strategy to compel North Korea to allow international monitors to complete their inspections of Pyongyang's nuclear sites. 
 Administration officials said later that Washington had decided to ask the Security Council to adopt a measure next week that would warn North Korea that economic sanctions will be imposed if inspections are not completed.
 
Agency Board Meets Monday
 Administration officials said the warning would be issued after the International Atomic Energy Agency, whose inspectors were rebuffed in visits to North Korean sites during the last week, formally meets to take up the issue. The agency's board of governors, which is scheduled to meet on Monday, is expected to declare that it can no longer certify that plutonium is not being diverted to build a bomb, and to demand that North Korea allow inspectors to finish their work. They are expected to refer the matter to the Security Council.
Administration officials said Washington plans to press the South Koreans to permit the deployment of Patriot anti-missile interceptors.
Unless the North Koreans abruptly change course and allow the inspections of the nuclear sites to be completed, Washington will also ask South Korea to agree to go forward with annual joint military exercises sometime later this year.
One senior official described today's decision as a milestone for the Administration, which has spent months trying to negotiate a solution with North Korea over the nuclear issue.
 
'Ratchet Up The Pressure'
 "We are going to go step by step to ratchet up the pressure," a senior Administration official said.
But with China reluctant to support economic sanctions and ties between Washington and Beijing severely strained, the prospects for winning Security Council support for tough measures against Pyongyang are uncertain at best.
The Administration's decision came hours after North Korean officials walked out of talks with South Korea representatives at Panmunjom, and threatened war if Washington and Seoul mounted a pressure campaign.
"Seoul will turn into a sea of fire," Park Young Su, the North Korean delegate said before abruptly ending the talks.
In seeking to build support at the United Nations for sanctions, the Administration's plan is to pursue a graduated set of measures to give North Korea time to change its stance and to persuade China to abstain on the issue of sanctions rather than wield its Security Council veto to prevent them.
One sanction that could be imposed quickly would be severing financial transfers from Japan to North Korea. Cutting off oil shipments to North Korea would be among the toughest measures the Council could enact and would take time to pursue.
By starting with a warning and then taking a gradual approach on sanctions, the Administration hopes to argue that it is giving North Korea time to change its stance and to persuade China to abstain rather than wield its Security Council veto to prevent sanctions.
The breakdown of the talks in Korea today capped months of laborious diplomacy in which a complex, step-by-step agreement to end a long standoff over the North's nuclear program was negotiated and then came unraveled.
The dispute began when North Korea last spring barred international inspectors from two nuclear waste sites and withdrew from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, reviving fears that it was continuing to develop nuclear weapons.
 
U.S. Pursued Talks
 The Administration responded with a diplomatic initiative meant to find areas of common ground.
Earlier this month, the State Department announced a breakthrough in which North Korea would allow inspections of seven officially disclosed nuclear sites -- but not the two waste sites that caused the initial suspicions -- and resume talks with South Korea meant to lead to an exchange of envoys.
In return, Washington and Seoul suspended for this year their joint military exercise and announced that high-level talks with North Korea would open on March 21.
But the diplomatic initiative began to unravel when North Korea blocked inspectors from the Atomic Energy Agency from taking some samples from their plutonium reprocessing plant at Yongbyong. Then the North Koreans broke off talks today with the South.
That left the Administration with a dilemma.
On one hand, Asian nations have avoided tough sanctions, fearing that the North might lash out militarily or that the measures might topple the Government of Kim Il Sung, leading to instability on the Korean peninsula. China's support for sanctions is particularly important since it is a member of the United Nations Security Council, supplies North Korea with much of its oil and has a long common border with North Korea.
 
Seoul Aide Opposes Sanctions
 Today, Zhang Tingyan, China's Ambassador to South Korea, argued against sanctions in an interview with the Yonhap news agency.
"It's an international rule now to solve all issues through dialogue," he said. "Why should the North Korean nuclear problem be an exception? China cannot agree to sanctions or any other stringent measures."
But while Asian nations have been urging Washington to go slow, the Administration has been buffeted by criticism from Republican lawmakers and former Bush Administration officials that it has not been forceful enough with the North Koreans.
Even Democrats like Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, were saying it was time to seek sanctions through the United Nations.
"The Clinton Administration is ending up in the right place," said Arnold Kanter, the Under Secretary of State for Policy in the Bush Administration. But Mr. Kanter said the Clinton Administration's reluctance to adopt a resolute take-it-or-leave-it stance during long months of negotiation had "undermined some of its credibility."
 
Leadership Faulted
 Some former officials also say the Administration has been too solicitous of the views of China and other Asian nations and has not adopted an effective leadership role.
Brent Scowcroft, the former national security adviser to President Bush, says Washington should make it clear to South Korea, Japan and China that the United States is prepared to take unilateral action if Asian nations do not support tough action.
Mr. Scowcroft has also said Washington should be ostentatiously building up its forces on the Korean peninsula to put pressure on Pyongyang and to keep open the possibility of a preemptive military strike against the North's nuclear installations.
But a senior Administration official rejected the criticism by former Bush Administration officials, charging that the problem of a nuclear North Korea "developed on the Bush Administration watch" and that an overly confrontational approach to solving it would backfire.
"To go it alone is foolish in the extreme," the Clinton Administration official said, asserting that it would be more effective if world powers showed a united face to the North. "I do not believe that chest-pounding and saber-rattling are the way to go."
Further fueling the debate is the uncertainty over what effect sanctions might have on the reclusive North Korean regime.
A comprehensive intelligence analysis of the North's nuclear program provided to the White House last year argued that sanctions would be unlikely to sway Kim Il Sung's Government, which might, for instance, simply choose to subject its citizens to new levels of privation.
 
Sanctions May Prompt Attack
 The intelligence assessment also warned that sanctions might prompt an attack by the North, which has said it will consider economic sanctions an act of war.
Because of that danger, the American military has insisted that steps be taken to bolster the readiness of troops in South Korea if sanctions were imposed, including the dispatch of the Patriot anti-missile interceptors. Gen. Gary E. Luck, the commander of American forces in Korea, told Congress that it would be important to send the Patriots if tensions heated up.
It takes many cargo flights to transport the missile batteries. General Luck wants to make sure that the available cargo planes would be free to move some of the 400,000 reinforcements that would be sent if a new Korean war broke out.
