LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: Fretting Over Prospect of Losses, Democrats Plot Fall Campaigns

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Facing up to the near-certainty of major losses at every level in this year's midterm elections, Democrats are increasingly looking to passage of a health care bill this fall as their best hope for limiting the damage.
But even as they set to work to overhaul health care, President Clinton's top policy priority, Democratic candidates for the House, the Senate and governorships are more and more concerned about a spillover from the President's political troubles, particularly the Whitewater investigation. 
 The nervousness among Democrats is not simply prompted by their having more House and Senate seats to defend than the Republicans, and more governorships, or the historical pattern that the party in the White House pays the price in the next midterm election. There are several factors making their task tougher this year.
 
Many Incumbents Leave
 For one thing, the Democrats are losing a particularly high number of incumbents and having a hard time recruiting strong candidates to replace them. At the same time, those remaining in office face the same anti-incumbent anger that fueled Ross Perot's 1992 Presidential race. The danger signs are most pronounced in the Senate, where Democrats are bracing for hard-fought races in states where they now hold seats, including Arizona, Maine, Michigan, New Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Virginia.
Few analysts predict that Republicans will pick up the seven seats needed to give them a Senate majority. But at the very least, most Democrats expect their working majority in the chamber to be eroded. That is a significant problem given the closeness of Mr. Clinton's victories on issues like the budget last year, which was rescued when Vice President Al Gore broke a tie in the Senate.
Complicating all this for the Democrats is the growing preoccupation in Washington over the investigation of the Clintons and the Whitewater affair. While polls show that the case has not greatly affected public attitudes toward the President or the Democratic Party, even party officials acknowledge that it has knocked them off stride.
 
Desertion and Unhappiness
 Already, the party chairman, David C. Wilhelm, sounds defensive when he warns Democratic candidates that it would not be in their best interest to distance themselves from the White House. That tactic was used by House Republicans who disavowed President George Bush after he broke his pledge of no new taxes before the 1990 election. (The Republicans lost eight seats that year, which was fewer than many in the party had predicted.)
While a President's coattails do not often extend to local races, those contests are a way for voters unhappy with the White House to vent their frustrations. A poor showing is also bound to be cast by Republicans as a referendum on Mr. Clinton and could weaken his influence with Congress.
So the Democrats are running scared. Charles Cook, editor of a political newsletter that analyzes elections, said the situation looked as dire for the Democrats as it was when they last lost control of the Senate -- when Ronald Reagan was elected 14 years ago.
"In 1980, there was always the suspicion that Democrats could get hammered, but it wasn't obvious that it was going to happen," Mr. Cook said. "Deep down nobody had any idea of the magnitude of the losses that would be suffered. There are more dark clouds on the horizon this time."
 
Long Time to Go
 November, of course, is a long way away, and the Democrats assert that they can weather Whitewater and other controversies that may lie ahead and demonstrate to voters that they can pass important legislation, like revisions of health care and welfare. They have also successfully begun to seize Republican issues like crime as their own.
No one can predict the forces that will come into play beyond partisan politics. A foreign policy crisis could affect the voting. And if the economy continues to rebound, that would probably do more for Democrats than any strategy from the White House or Democratic Party.
"There's no single factor that is as significant in 1994 as the state of the economy," said Senator Bob Graham of Florida, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
But in recent weeks, the party has seemed to suffer only setbacks: Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, unexpectedly announced that he would retire, giving Republicans a good shot at what was considered a safe Democrat seat. In Texas, the acquittal of Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison on charges that she misused her office dashed the hopes of most Democrats that they would retake the seat that had been held by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
 
Huge House Turnover
 There is also great uncertainly among Democrats in the House because of the huge turnover in their ranks. More than 40 members, most of them Democrats, have already announced their retirements or plans to run for other offices. The pace is approaching that of two years ago, when there were an unprecedented 65 retirements in the wake of the House post office and banking scandals, as well as redistricting. Many who are seeking re-election are braced for stronger challenges than they have had in years.
Some of the same problems that plagued incumbents in 1992 and in a handful of races last year are still around. Despite the victory in Tuesday's primary by Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, a titan of Capitol Hill, party strategists still report a strong anti-Washington sentiment in the country. And because of redistricting, many Democrats who won in 1992 did so by slim margins and find themselves facing tougher races this year.
Both Democrats and Republicans are also keeping a watchful eye on Mr. Perot. Despite his diminished standing in the polls, his money and influence have the potential to influence the outcome of close races, particularly in the House, should he intervene.
In races for governor, Democrats also have far more seats to lose, and Republicans are eagerly seizing on Mr. Clinton's weak points. For example, they hope to prevail in western states by underscoring the increases in grazing fees.
 
Seeking Concrete Results
 Democratic officials say the way for their party to make sure that Republican attacks over Whitewater collapse is for lawmakers to return home with results, particularly passage of a health care bill.
The Democrats are eager to prove that the oratory from the 1992 campaign about eliminating paralysis between the White House and the Democratic-controlled Congress was not empty. And in contrast to crime, another issue that is important to voters, the health care system is something that lawmakers can do something substantial about.
But while their election-year nervousness could motivate incumbents to push for health care, their goals and those of Mr. Clinton may be different. The pressure on incumbents is to get a health bill, not necessarily Mr. Clinton's bill. This could lead them to be quicker to compromise away part of Mr. Clinton's approach than the White House would like.
Mr. Wilhelm, the Democratic chairman, said the challenge is for his party to counter a Republican strategy of using Whitewater to derail the them. "Obviously, it is diversionary," Mr. Wilhelm said as he was peppered with questions about Whitewater at a breakfast with reporters on Friday. "This whole Whitewater has the effect of diverting attention from the real issues."
Republicans are not without their own problems, like failing to get former Gov. Thomas H. Kean to challenge Senator Frank R. Lautenberg in New Jersey or Gov. William F. Weld to oppose Senator Edward M. Kennedy in Massachusetts.
Democrats have had the harder time convincing strong Senate prospects to run. Among the disappointments were the decisions by these people to stay out of the arena this year: Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle; former Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan; Lieut. Gov. Buddy McKay of Florida and Representative Bill Orton in Utah.
Republicans already sound jubilant. "I don't think we can count on Bill Clinton to do everything himself, but he sure is trying," said Alex Castellanos, a Republican who is advising a handful of gubernatorial and Senate candidates this year. "He's going to help give us the biggest Republican year we've had in a long time, since the beginning of the Reagan Administration."

For the Senate . . .
 Democrats now control the Senate, with 56 seats to the Republicans 44. There will be 34 Senate contests in November, including 21 for seats now held by Democrats and 13 for seats now held by Republicans. In eight contests, incumbents -- five Democrats and three Republicans -- are not running. Map shows senate races by state, the party that controls the seat, and whether the state is open.
Arizona: Democrats are worried that they will lose the seat now held by the retiring Senator Dennis DeConcini. In the Republican primary, the leading candidate is Representative John Kyl, who has long had his eye on the seat. There is no leading candidate so far in the Democratic contest.
 California: Senator Dianne Feinstein, who was elected in 1992, is considered relatively safe. But California is known for its anti politican mood and is always an important state to watch. Her Republican opponent, Representative Michael Huffington, is a millionaire willing to make this one of the costliest Senate battles ever.
Delaware: Democrats say one of their strongest challengers is in Delaware, where Charles Oberly, the Attorney General, hopes to unseat Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Republican.
Maine: The retirement of Senator George J. Mitchell, the Democratic majority leader, set off an unexpected scramble. Both of Maine's United States Representatives are seeking his seat. If they win their primaries, expect a lively race between Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican, and Thomas H. Andrews, a Democrat.
Minnesota: With Democrats holding a slight voting edge in the state, the party hopes it can take the seat being vacated by retiring Senator Dave Durenberger, a Republican. Freshman Representative Rod Grams leads the Republican field; the Democratic side has yet to take shape.
Montana: Senator Conrad Burns, a Republican, is viewed as vulnerable; he beat Senator John Melcher last time mainly because the incumbent ran an inept campaign. He may face Melcher again, or Jack Mudd, a little-known lawyer.
New Jersey: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg is a major Republican target in a state where the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, was defeated in an embarrassing upset last year. He also may suffer from his opposition to President Clinton's budget last year.
Ohio: Fierce primary battles are already under way for the seat held by Howard M. Metzenbaum, a Democrat, who is retiring. For the Democrats, Metzenbaum's son-in-law, Joel Hyatt, who runs a multistate chain of legal service offices, is running against Mary Boyle, a Cleveland official. The Republican primary pits Lieut. Gov. Michael DeWine against Bernadine Healy, who was director of the National Institutes of Health.
 Pennsylvania: Senator Harris Wofford, a Democrat who is seeking re-election, won an upset victory in 1990 by largely emphasizing the health-care issue. This year, Republicans want to turn the issue against him by focusing on his record. Representative Rick Santorum is the leading Republican.
 Tennessee: Senator Harlan Mathews, appointed as a caretaker to replace Vice President Gore, is not running. An aggressive battle is developing between Representative Jim Cooper, a Democrat who has drawn national attention for his health care proposal, and Fred Dalton Thompson, an actor and former Republican Watergate counsel.
Virginia: Senator Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, is trying to overcome damage from what he now admits were personal indiscretions while he was Governor. But while Oliver L. North has built up a loyal conservative following for his involvement in the Iran-contra affair, other Republicans say he is a disgrace to the party. Challenging North in the Republican primary is James C. Miller, a budget director in the Reagan Administration.
 Washington: Slade Gorton, a Republican, has very low poll numbers, but the Democrats failed to get the popular Mayor of Seattle, Norm Rice, to oppose him.
 
. . . And the State House
There are now 29 Democratic governors, 19 Republican and two independent. There are 36 contests in November: 21 for seats now held by Democrats, 13 for seats held by Republicans and two for seats hold by independents. Incumbents -- eight Democrats, two Republicans and one independent -- are not running in 11 contests. Map races by state, the party of the governor now in office, and whether the state is open.
Arizona: Gov. J. Fife Symington, a Republican, is the subject of a Federal inquiry into his role in the failure of a savings and loan. He could face Terry Goddard, a Democrat who is the former Mayor of Phoenix and barely lost to Symington four years ago.
California: Given the size and importance of California, and the vulnerability of Gov. Pete Wilson because of the state's recession and natural disasters, this may be the most watched race for governor. Wilson will face Kathleen Brown, the state Treasurer who is the daughter and sister of the state's last two Democratic governors, or John Garamendi, the insurance commissioner. Another Democratic contender is Tom Hayden, a state senator and 1960's radical.
Florida: Gov. Lawton Chiles is viewed as one of the most vulnerable Democratic incumbents. Competing in the Republican primary are Tom Gallagher, the state insurance commissioner, and Jeb Bush, the former state Commerce Secretary and son of George Bush.
Illinois: Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican, is preparing for a spirited challenge from the Democratic nominee, Dawn Clark Netsch, a former law professor and the first woman to win a major party nomination for governor in the state.
Minnesota: Gov. Arne Carlson, a first-term Republican, has not been particularly popular in his own party, where he has been criticized for being a proponent of abortion rights and homosexual rights. A leading Democrat rival is Mike Freeman, the Hennepin County Attorney.
New York: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's performance ratings are down in public polls, but, as usual, he lacks a formidable Republican challenger.
Rhode Island: Gov. Bruce Sundlun, a Democrat, is considered vulnerable as he seeks a third term, and Representative Ron Machtley is running an aggressive race in the Republican primary to challenge him.
Texas: Gov. Ann W. Richards, a Democrat, is relatively popular, but is bracing for a strong challenge from George W. Bush, the former baseball team owner and son of the former President. (pg. 28)

HEADLINE: DEAL WITH CHINA URGED BY BENTSEN

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 19

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen says he would like to see a compromise worked out with China that can spare the Clinton Administration having to withdraw Beijing's beneficial trade status.
Mr. Bentsen, speaking Friday night, seemed to be going out of his way to try to lower the Administration's volume on China after Secretary of State Warren Christopher's confrontation with Chinese authorities in Beijing last weekend. Mr. Bentsen was in Hawaii for a meeting of 17 finance ministers from Pacific Rim countries, many of whom took the opportunity to tell their American hosts that it was wrong-headed, arrogant and not in America's interest to use trade leverage to try to influence China on human rights. 
 It was clear that Mr. Christopher's visit to China, during which Beijing seemed to go out of its way to arrest several dissidents to embarrass their American visitor, has rattled Asian countries, not to mention some members of the Clinton economic team. The Asians fear a confrontation between Washington and Beijing over human rights could destabilize the region.
 
U.S. Approach Is Suspect
 The dominant mood at this conference is that the Clinton Administration may have gotten locked into an overly confrontational approach with China, and that it might be more productive to explore a different strategy to persuade Beijing to make enough progress on human rights so Washington can renew its low-tariff trade benefits when they expire this June.
"I think we have to explore alternatives to see if we can work this out," said Mr. Bentsen. He said the goal must be "to keep some pressure on to try to help as far as human rights, but not find ourselves disengaging."
"I think from an economic standpoint that hurts both of our countries," he added.
Administration officials said that it is already clear that even under the best scenario, China's behavior by June is not going to be fully satisfactory from an American human-rights perspective, and may at best just barely clear the hurdles set out by the President in his executive order last year -- such as accounting for political prisoners and ending the use of prison labor. Mr. Clinton said China must meet those minimum conditions to be able to continue exporting its goods to the United States at the lowest possible tariffs.
 
Time to Prepare Public?
 Because the situation in June is likely to be ambiguous some officials argue that the Administration should start laying a foundation with Congress and public opinion now for renewing China's trade benefits.
That means, they say, avoiding more confrontations with Beijing and emphasizing instead the importance of trade for human rights development in China. It also means considering, instead of a blanket removal of China's trade benefits, possibly a more selective removal, so that most of the commerce can continue.
China's Finance Minister, Liu Zhongli, said in an interview that it was the Clinton Administration's responsibility to find a way down from this tree.
"To give you an old Chinese saying: 'It is up to the one who ties the knot to untie the knot,' " Mr. Liu remarked.
The United States, Mr. Liu added, "maintains a triple standard."
"For their own human rights problems they shut their eyes," he said. "For some other countries' human rights questions they open one eye and shut the other. And for China, they open both eyes and stare."

HEADLINE: In Miami's Little Haiti, Fears of Assassination

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 19

 BODY:
When two gunmen shot and killed Daniel Buron here last week, another wave of fear quickly spread through the neighborhood that is home to thousands of Haitian exiles and refugees.
For the fourth time in three years, a prominent opponent of Haiti's military dictatorship had been killed on the streets of Little Haiti, and for the fourth time, the police and prosecutors seemed to discount politics as a motive. 
 To supporters of Haiti's ousted President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the shooting of Mr. Buron, and the official reaction to it here, are frightening proof that the Haitian military's enforcers can act with impunity anywhere, even in a major American city. Mr. Buron's killing, they say, coincided with a campaign of terror in Haiti and was intended as a warning to the more than 100,000 exiles here to halt their marches, speeches and broadcasts promoting the overthrow of Haiti's military leaders and the restoration of Father Aristide, who was ousted in a coup in September 1991.
 
'Psychological Warfare'
 "We know they are here, too," said Marcus Garcia, the editor of the exile newspaper "Haiti en Marche," speaking of the bands of hired thugs and killers that Haiti's military leaders employ against their opponents in Haiti. "This is psychological warfare."
The authorities here are reluctant to theorize about the motives for the killings, but court papers suggest that they see drugs or personal disputes as contributing factors.
Mr. Buron, a 37-year-old bus driver for a car rental company who was buried today, was shot to death on March 9 as he and two friends were talking after the regular Wednesday night board meeting of Veye Yo, the fiercely antimilitary political organization to which all belonged. Two gunmen approached and, without saying a word, sprayed them with gunfire, a survivor said.
"I think they were trying to kill all three of us," said Max Delva, a 47-year-old carpenter who survived the attack.
 
Broadcasters Killed
 Mr. Buron's killing followed the fatal shootings of three other Haitians active in exile politics here: Jean-Claude Olivier, Fritz Dor and Dona St. Plite, all hosts of talk shows on local Creole-language radio stations that can sometimes be heard in Haiti. Like Mr. Buron, the other victims, who were killed from 1991 to 1993, were affiliated with Veye Yo, which means "Beware of Them" in Creole, the popular language of Haiti.
Nevertheless, a spokesman for the Miami Police Department, David Magnusson, said that in the Buron case "speculation that the motive may be political is premature." And prosecutors scoff at the notion that the earlier killings, which led to the arrests of several Haitians living here and a series of court proceedings that have not yet been concluded, were political assassinations. The political affiliations, if any, of the suspects is unknown, as is their immigration status.
"What you've got is a hysteria founded on rumors," said John S. Kastrenakes, an Assistant State Attorney in Dade County who is prosecuting the Olivier and Dor cases.
"It is important," he said, "that the community know there is no evidence that these murders are related to the question of who is in power in the country of Haiti."
 
'Transnational Terrorists'
 A spokesman for the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Paul Miller, said that his agency had begun a preliminary inquiry to determine if "outside forces" were involved, but that there was "no indication of that so far."
However, Beverly Bell, a spokeswoman for Father Aristide's government-in-exile, said she had no doubt that "transnational terrorists" supported by Haiti's military-run government were responsible for the killings and other acts of violence against Haitian exiles in Miami, New York, Boston and Montreal.
If the killings here were recognized as political, there could be important implications. Most Haitians arriving in the United States are considered economic refugees; acknowledging that Haiti's military is attacking exiles on American soil could strengthen refugee claims of political persecution.
Mr. Kastrenakes would not say what led him to discount politics as a motive in the shootings of Mr. Olivier and Mr. Dor, nor would he discuss what other factors might lie behind the killings.
But court documents indicate that the authorities believe the shootings may have been associated with drug dealing or involved personal feuds.
 
Dor Would 'Pay Dearly'
 In a deposition filed as part of the Dor case, a police investigator said a suspect had told him that the shooting "was a cocaine deal that went bad." But another deposition quotes a second investigator who said he was told that "Fritz Dor was going to pay dearly" for trying to undermine a concert promoted by a Haitian businessman, whose name was given as Louis Thermitus. The deposition provided no further background on Mr. Thermitus, but Haitian exiles said he was a member of the Tontons Macoute, the paramilitary units formed in the late 1950's during the dictatorship of Francoise (Papa Doc) Duvalier to kill, beat, rob and intimidate opponents.
In the Olivier case, Hitler Fleurinord, 22, has been charged with first-degree murder and is to go on trial in May. He is accused of driving the car from which a gunman, unnamed in court papers and still at large, fired three shots at Mr. Olivier outside a nightclub in Little Haiti on Feb. 18, 1991.
Mr. Dor was killed less than a month later. Glossy Bruce Joseph, a 22-year-old admitted small-time drug dealer, pleaded guilty last year to acting as a lookout in the shooting and was sentenced to 25 years in prison. Mr. Olivier and Mr. Dor were killed with the same gun, but Mr. Kastrenakes said Mr. Joseph had provided no information that linked the two killings and in general "was not extremely helpful," despite the plea bargain, which also encompassed a murder attempt unrelated to Haitian politics.
 
An Exile 'Hit List'
 Mr. St. Plite, the third victim, was robbed and killed last fall outside a benefit dinner in Little Haiti in memory of Mr. Dor. Three men were arrested, but two were released after prosecutors concluded there was not enough evidence to convict them. The third suspect, Francky St. Louis Joseph, was indicted on a charge of first-degree murder and is to stand trial on April 4.
Shortly before his death, Mr. St. Plite was among more than a score of Haitian exiles here whose name was on a hit list circulated in Little Haiti. The list, whose provenance was unknown, included a preface praising Haiti's military government and proclaiming that those on the list should be killed to keep Mr. Aristide from returning to Haiti.
Rolande Dorancy, the director of the Haitian Refugee Center here, said that despite the misgivings of the police she was convinced that "these are all political murders." All four victims "were very outspoken people against the criminals who are running the country," she said, and it would have been easy for Haitian assassins to "make it look like something else."
"We are not satisfied" with the way police and prosecutors have handled the investigations, Ms. Dorancy said. If the F.B.I. and the police had been more aggressive about pursuing the earlier cases and had taken the political dimension more seriously, "then maybe Daniel would not be in the funeral home today," she said.
 
Grisly Warning From Home
 In a case that several Haitian exiles cite as another example of the Haitian military's effort to intimidate Aristide supporters here, Ms. Dorancy's childhood nanny, Orilia Joseph, was kidnapped last fall in Port-au-Prince by a paramilitary squad and shot, burned and decapitated. That killing, like Mr. St. Plite's, occurred in October, when the Haitian military stepped up its effort to prevent Mr. Aristide from returning to Haiti under the terms of a United Nations accord.
Because the police and prosecutors continue to say that politics plays no role in the recent killings here, Haitian exiles say they fear that Haitian Government enforcers may continue to prey on them. But they continue to hope that the authorities will have a change of heart, and they say that in the meantime they will continue their political activities.
"The current investigation is very important, because the only way you can stop this trend is by showing that the police are taking it very seriously," said Mr. Garcia, the editor. "It's like the killings of the tourists last year: they need to show some muscle and say that they are not going to tolerate this any more."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Four Haitian exiles who were actively opposed to Haiti's military-run government have been killed in Miami since 1991, and thousands of Haitian emigres say the deaths were political assassinations. The funeral for the latest victim, Daniel Buron, who was killed on March 9, was yesterday. (Cynthia Karp for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Motives of Quiet Congressman Who Is Making Much of Whitewater's Noise

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
In a city where bombast and pomposity are the rule, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa is quiet and modest.
In a Congress riven by partisanship, he has sided with Democrats over the years almost as often as he has lined up with his fellow Republicans. 
 So it seems out of character that Mr. Leach is now President Clinton's main antagonist in Congress on the Whitewater case. He not only has his name on front pages and on evening news programs these days but he also has attacked the President on "Donahue" and "A Current Affair."
It seems almost as if Madonna were cast to play Queen Victoria or Shaquille O'Neal had started shooting jump shots from behind the 3-point line.
But it seems out of character only to people who do not know Mr. Leach -- to those outside the Capitol, where he enjoys almost universal respect, and his Congressional district in eastern Iowa, where he has held a safe seat for the last 18 years.
Those who know him best say Jim Leach is doing exactly what they would have expected on the question that has guided his political life: public ethics.
 
Preferred Ethics to Dream Job
 Many of them disagree with him. None question his motives.
After all, this is a man who resigned from the Foreign Service in 1973 on the eve of his dream assignment in order to protest President Richard M. Nixon's dismissal of Archibald Cox, the Watergate special prosecutor, in the Saturday Night Massacre.
This is a Congressman who sharply criticized a President of his own party, Ronald Reagan, over the Iran-contra affair and one who told his colleagues to their faces that they were responsible individually and collectively for the savings and loan mess because they had abandoned the national interest in favor of regional and industry concerns.
This is a politician who has never accepted a campaign contribution of more than $500 or taken a dime from political action committees or people who live outside Iowa.
He is fond of repeating an adaptation of Barry M. Goldwater's famous line about moderation and extremism. "Moderation in the pursuit of truth is no virtue," Mr. Leach says in his public speeches. "Vigilance in the defense of public ethics is no vice."
At the beginning of last year, Mr. Leach became the top-ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee, a position that gave him a small staff and a responsibility to be his party's spokesman on issues before the committee. By summer, he had the staff investigating the failure of Madison Guaranty, the Arkansas savings and loan owned by the Clintons' business partner in the Whitewater real-estate venture, James B. McDougal. The collapse of Guaranty cost the Government $60 million.
 
'I Feel So Strongly About This'

In an interview in his office last week, Mr. Leach explained his interest this way: "I am fulfilling my obligations as I see them under the Constitution. The Constitution gives Congress oversight accountability of the executive branch. And I will go further, because I feel so strongly about this I can't stand it. It's the responsibility of all parties out of power, all minority parties in all Western democracies, to hold accountable the executive branch of the governing party when there are breaches of public ethics or public law. Not to fulfill that responsibility is a dereliction of duty."
Mr. Leach, who speaks so softly that you have to strain to hear him even when he is next to you on the couch, insisted he had no interest whatsoever in harming President Clinton or his Presidency.
"On the grand scope of public scandals, this is a bump," he said, referring to Whitewater. "But it has mountainous implications for public ethics."
 
Seeking Full Disclosure
 He continued: "My argument is that this is a full-disclosure issue. I've tried to walk the line between public embarrassment, which I think is deserved, and either Presidency-toppling or Presidency-debilitating, which are not deserved.
"I thought initially it was a one-to-three-week issue, that you'd have a hearing and then put it behind us. Now the great challenge is how you bring the issue to resolution. I will be steadfast in seeking full disclosure. But once there is disclosure, I will do my best to put it behind."
Out of the mouth of almost any other politician that would sound self-righteous, and at the White House, Mr. Leach is seen as a man on the make, who wants to rise by stepping on the President's back.
But politicians from across the political band who know him well say Mr. Leach's explanation is the full story of why he is challenging Mr. Clinton.
 
Praise From an Opponent
 One longtime political opponent, Dave Nagle, a former Democratic Party chairman in Iowa who once served in Congress from a district adjacent to Mr. Leach's, said: "For Jim, this is completely in character. He has a reputation for impartiality, for listening to both sides, for integrity, for being reasonable. So when he takes on something, people have a tendency to listen. When he says it, it lends instant credibility to it. You're inclined to believe that he honestly believes, even if you think he's mistaken, that he's right."
Mr. Leach, who grew up in an affluent family in Davenport, said he entered politics almost by accident. By the eighth grade, he said, he knew he wanted to be in the Foreign Service, and he went to Princeton University and graduate school at Johns Hopkins with that in mind.
 
At College in 60's, He Studied
 He graduated from Princeton in 1964, the year of the Free Speech Movement at Berkeley, the beginning of a decade of monumental change on campuses from coast to coast. But Mr. Leach was a bookworm, a Russian studies major and a 147-pound wrestler, and he had little interest in popular culture or student politics.
By the fall of 1973, Mr. Leach was an experienced Foreign Service officer. Fluent in German and Russian, he had just received what he felt was "the best assignment possible," to be an aide to the United States Ambassador in Moscow. He was at home on a brief leave to try to handle some urgent problems in his family's petroleum products business when the Saturday Night Massacre occurred.
"That night," he said, "I sent a telegram to Henry Kissinger with my resignation. I really felt that what that firing was all about was the President putting himself above the law."
 
In a Democratic District
 Three months later, he said, the Republican Party in Davenport persuaded him to run in a Congressional race he had no chance of winning. No one else wanted the nomination. Indeed, he lost to a popular Democrat. But two years later, the national economy had turned sour, and Mr. Leach ran again and won. He has never been seriously challenged since, although his district tends to vote Democratic in other races.
This sounds too pat. The man had little interest in politics, who resigned on a matter of principle from a job he loved, who announced his candidacy for Congress three months later. Surely he must have had running for office in the back of his mind.
No, Mr. Leach said. He really did not. And politicians in Iowa who remember the times say everything happened just the way Mr. Leach recalls it today.
 
A Moderate Stripe
 In Washington, Mr. Leach sailed under the banner of Jacob K. Javits, Nelson A. Rockefeller and other liberal-to-moderate Republicans who were influential in the 1960's and 1970's. But Mr. Leach had come aboard too late. Ronald Reagan had become the party's general, and the right wing dominated his troops.
So Mr. Leach, part of a small minority within a minority, confined himself legislatively mainly to banking and foreign policy issues that do not tend to divide along party or ideological lines. His most noteworthy achievement in Congress up till now was to lead the fight to knock out of the savings and loan bailout legislation provisions that gave special benefits to Citicorp, Merrill Lynch and other large financial institutions.
Since taking on the Whitewater case, Mr. Leach's tone has sharpened.
He promised a "blockbuster" if he has the chance to question witnesses in public, without saying what it would entail. He gave a speech in Chicago this month in which he compared Bill Clinton to Michael Milken, the financial wizard who went to jail for fraud. Last week, he told reporters he had sent a confidential memorandum to the special prosecutor about the way bank regulators in Kansas City were being "gagged" by their superiors.
To the suggestion that this talk is rather intemperate for a man with a reputation for understatement, Mr. Leach acknowledged that his voice now has "a little more of a Republican Party clip to it than I'd evidenced before."
He spoke as if his new voice were a matter he had lain awake nights worrying about: "One of the really difficult roads to walk is that between reflecting individual conscience and that of being a member of a team. I always think the first outweighs the second. But the second is not unimportant. We govern through teams in America. It's important to be loyal to teams."

HEADLINE: School Board Is Criticized On Recycling

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Nearly five years after enactment of the mandatory recycling law, New York City's public-school system has no formal recycling program, and for three and a half years has been in violation of that law. The Board of Education has yet to adopt regulations placing responsibility for meeting the law's requirements.
A wide range of city officials and environmentalists, from the City Councilman who wrote the 1989 recycling legislation to frustrated school administrators to Department of Sanitation specialists, have sharply criticized the Board of Education's failure. They have also expressed regret at what they call a lost opportunity to use the schools as the training ground for future generations for whom recycling would be essential. 
 Last week Amy Linden, the Board of Education official in charge of recycling, said a draft of institutional regulations was being circulated and likely would be adopted by Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines within the month. But she offered no reasons for the delay in producing the regulations or answers for why the city's public schools still lacked a comprehensive and functioning recycling program.
"I'm not going to make excuses," said Ms. Linden, the chief executive for school facilities at the Board of Education. "There was a long delay."
 
'A Significant Disgrace'
 "The Board of Education has been mocking one of the most important city laws adopted in its history," said Mark Izeman, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council. He asserted that "absolutely nothing had changed" since the group's 1992 public report on recycling in the schools, which sharply criticized the board for its failure to recycle. "It's a significant disgrace," Mr. Izeman said.
The Board's effective violation of Local Law 19 has prompted a range of elected officials and environmentalist to call for punitive measures, like having the city, which picks up garbage free at the schools, charge the Board of Education for garbage removal. Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate, sent a letter to Mr. Cortines on Friday asking that the board's recycling regulations be adopted and released as soon as possible.
"It's inexcusable that the Board of Education's foot-dragging has gone on for five years," Mr. Green said. "We can't undo the board's malfeasance, only hope that other governmental institutions do everything possible to accelerate the recycling programs."
Sheldon S. Leffler, the City Councilman from Queens who wrote Local Law 19, which requires recycling, said, "There have been many gross violations of the law since it was enacted, but this one by the Board of Education is especially unacceptable because it was our thinking that the absolute best way to reach a diverse city was through its schools."
Everyone involved in the issue agrees that the delay has had measurable consequences. The city's 1992 solid waste management study, using data from the 1990 school year, estimated that more than 120,000 tons of waste was generated annually by the public schools, 3 percent of the city's nonresidential garbage. Of that, the audit concluded, roughly 33,000 tons could have been recycled.
While conceding that their information is more anecdotal than documented, officials at the Board of Education and the Department of Sanitation guess that perhaps 100 or so of the city's 1,069 public schools have recycling programs in place. But the officials admit that those programs are often only modest projects, and have been started only with the initiative of individual school administrators and teachers.
 
Wider Considerations
 The debate about recycling in schools takes place amid wider wrangling over recycling. The State Court of Appeals last month upheld a ruling that the city, which had failed to meet required levels of recycling, was effectively breaking the law. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose proposed budget calls for scaling back recycling pickups to every other week, has responded to the court decision by asking the City Council to consider reducing the recycling law's requirements.
"The administration is operating on two levels," said Mr. Leffler. "Publicly, it says it wants recycling. Behind the scenes, it is trying to turn it back."
Mr. Leffler and others maintain that the reduction of recycling pickup schedules to every other week would doom any hopes of starting an effective program in the city's schools.
"Given that storage is perhaps the largest obstacle for the schools to overcome, if Mayor Giuliani's budget proposal ever takes effect, it would seriously undermine the Board of Education's plans," Mr. Green said.
 
Not Insurmountable
 Allan Fromberg, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, said the Mayor remained committed to recycling, and he rejected the assertion that the Mayor's budget proposals would undermine any Board of Education recycling programs. The spokesman said the Mayor was convinced that the Department of Sanitation would be flexible in dealing with pickups at schools.
"There's no problem that isn't surmountable," Mr. Fromberg said.
According to critics of the Board of Education, as well as school officials, the reason a recycling program has not been instituted is not one of lack of money or other problems, but simply bureaucratic apathy. Concerns about the custodians' union and whether sufficient space exists in the schools to store recycled material safely have not been addressed because recycling has not begun.
"No one ever seemed to be in charge," said Tony Solomita, a Department of Sanitation recycling specialist who has worked with school officials. "No one was ever smart about it. I never got the sense anyone was even trying to work it out."
While citing delays resulting from the hiring of a new chancellor last summer and the asbestos crisis last fall, Ms. Linden said she did not dispute the Department of Sanitation's contention that recycling at the schools can be accomplished.
"I have never said that the implementation of the programs would be too complex, only that there were some basic questions to be addressed," she said. "And the custodians have not been the problem. The delay in drafting the regulations was a delay because there just happened to be a million other things to do."
But the circulation of the chancellor's regulations hardly pleases the board's critics, who have argued that the draft regulations, written in a seven-page document that basically says who is answerable to whom, are inadequate.
"They could have been written in an afternoon four years ago," said Susan Cohen, an economist and a member of the Manhattan Citizens Solid Waste Advisory Board. "There is nothing in the regulations that lays out how the schools will execute their recycling programs. The battles are still going to have to be fought at every single school."
 
Complaints on Draft Plan
 Those fights could be sizable and sustained without direction from the board, sanitation officials, the custodians and elected officials said. Complaints have already been lodged about the draft regulations from district superintendents and school principals. There is also widespread confusion about Fire Department and Health Department regulations that affect recycling. And an official with the custodians' union said Friday that the union had not yet received a copy of the regulations.
"I have been in schools where I've been told the Fire Department won't allow paper to be stored in certain rooms, or that the Board of Health won't allow bottles to be kept for certain lengths of time," Mr. Solomita said. "People's senses of what the rules are have taken on lives of their own.
"And so we have had people at the Board of Education telling people it's the principal who is in charge, principals telling people it's the custodians who are responsible, custodians saying it's the kids," Mr. Solomita said. "Now there are Board of Education regulations on paper talking about recycling committees being set up at schools. It looks nice on paper. Let's see if it works. Hey, all I know is that there aren't committees at schools for taking out the garbage."

HEADLINE: Massacre at Hebron Exposes Anti-American Mood in Israel

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 19

 BODY:
In some Israeli circles, a new dirty word has popped up in the last few weeks: Brooklyn.
Brooklyn produced Benjamin C. Goldstein, who as Baruch Goldstein of the Qiryat Arba settlement massacred at least 29 Palestinians in Hebron three weeks ago. And Brooklyn, of course, is part of the United States. That has been enough to touch a certain anti-American streak that lies just below the surface for many Israelis. 
 These are far from the best of times for American-born Jews who made aliya -- the complimentary Hebrew word for immigrating to Israel -- and who tend to be referred to here as "Anglo-Saxons," even if their families never got closer to the British Isles than Slovakia.
 
Vulnerable to Criticism
 If they wear yarmulkes and are on the political right -- a group filled with former New Yorkers and constituting a clear majority of the 2,000 to 3,000 Americans now immigrating here each year -- they sense they are now automatically vulnerable to criticism. And if they live in Judea and Samaria, the names of biblical origin widely used here for the West Bank, they feel it even more strongly, especially from the Government.
"We're all tagged as 'settlers,' and with that word alone we're already put two pegs below everybody else," said Bob Lang, originally of Nanuet, N.Y., who lives south of Bethlehem in the settlement of Efrat. Roughly one-third of the 5,000 residents of Efrat are from the United States.
"After the massacre, those of us who are Americans dropped down another peg," Mr. Lang said. "Now we're all seen as Baruch Goldsteins."
Even American-born Jews who are secular and lean politically leftward find this an uncomfortable period. Not that anyone has been physically attacked or subject to blatant discrimination. The situation is hardly that bad. And the United States is, at heart, an admired ally and Israel's main source of political solace, financial support and pop-culture guidance, from Big Macs to Madonna.
 
Marginal to the Israelis
 Still, Stuart Schoffman, a screenwriter and magazine columnist who attended the Yeshiva of Flatbush about a decade before Baruch Goldstein, found that "Israelis were too hasty to blame this on an American."
"It reminded me of how marginal we are to Israelis," Mr. Schoffman said, talking about an attitude that many Americans sense in secular native-born Israelis -- that anyone who gave up life in the United States cannot be playing with a full deck of cards.
"It's a common perception that if you come from America you have to be crazy," Mr. Schoffman said. "Over and over, you hear Israelis ask, 'Why did you come?' "
Anti-American, and specifically anti-Brooklyn, sentiment surfaced immediately after the massacre, and although it was aimed primarily at Americans on the religious and nationalist extremes, it was sufficiently scattershot to hit other targets as well.
The newspaper Maariv complained about American parents who "send their lunatic children to Israel."
"In Qiryat Arba," it said in a commentary, "the raw material is American, the money is American. We have to do the work."
Immigration Minister Yair Tsaban singled out Brooklyn, warning about "that gang" there, meaning people like Dr. Goldstein who are rooted in the Arab-loathing ideology of another Brooklyn product, Rabbi Meir Kahane.
 
Two Groups Are Banned
 Urging the Government to outlaw Kahane-spawned movements, an action taken last weekend against the Kach and Kahane Chai groups, Mr. Tsaban said, "If we don't declare them illegal, we will have no legal basis to prevent the immigration of their brethren from Brooklyn."
Yitzhak Rabin contemptuously rejected that militancy as "a foreign implant," and even though aides later insisted that the American-oriented Prime Minister was talking about views alien to Judaism, some Americans took it personally and found it a dissonant observation in a nation of immigrants.
Some ordinary Israelis, too, have taken up verbal cudgels, like a retired businessman in Tel Aviv who said a day after the massacre, "Most of the American Jews are extremists, and troublemakers, too."
In fact, Americans account for a tiny fraction of Israel's five million people, barely one percent. Olga Rachmilevitch, national executive director of the Association of Americans and Canadians in Israel, estimates that since the creation of the state in 1948 not more than 80,000 North Americans immigrated to Israel and stayed.
 
From New York to West Bank
 But the Americans often have a disproportionate influence on the national political and social agenda -- from the left as well as the right -- because they bring an activism that many other Israelis lack.
On the right, American accents are unmistakable not only at the Kahane-inspired fringes but also among more moderate settlers in the territories.
According to some estimates, 15 percent of the roughly 130,000 settlers are originally from the United States, many of them people who went straight from New York to the West Bank and who have at best a tenuous connection to mainstream Israel. The average Israeli on Saturday is generally less interested in the weekly Bible reading than whether the Maccabi Haifa soccer team won yet again.
But while precise figures are hard to come by, American-Israelis are also prominent in disproportionate numbers in leftist or liberal groups like Peace Now, the New Israel Fund and the Association for Civil Rights in Israel.
"Americans tend to feel that each person can make a difference, and so when they come here many gravitate to grass-roots movements akin to the ones they knew back home," said Galia Golan, a political scientist at Hebrew University who immigrated in 1966 and is a leader of Peace Now.
 
On a Different Plane
 Part of what separates the Americans from others is that, as a group, they did not come here in desperation. In that sense, they live on a different plane from the hundreds of thousands of Moroccans, Russians, Ethiopians, Romanians and others who simply wanted out, whether because of economic hardship or religious persecution.
Zeev Chafets, a Michigan-born writer and 15 years ago a spokesman for the Government of Menachem Begin, said: "People who move here are highly motivated ideologically. They want to feel that there's a deeper purpose, whether it's religious or Zionist. So it's not surprising that there's this activism among the Americans."
Yet the activism tends to be channeled into groups working to influence official policy, not make it.
Beyond a few notable exceptions -- including the late Prime Minister Golda Meir, born in Kiev but reared in Milwaukee, and former Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who grew up in the United States although born in Lithuania -- Americans have been almost invisible in the front ranks of Israeli politics, diplomacy, big business and that most important force of all, the army.
In part, Israelis say, it is because those institutions have "old boy networks" formed in the barracks and at school.
Nonetheless, Mr. Chafets worked in a high Government post, and says that "no one ever questioned the propriety or security implications." Gerald Steinberg, a San Francisco-born military expert at Bar-Ilan University, says his access to senior army ranks is "much greater" than he had expected.
Like most American arrivals over the last dozen years, Professor Steinberg is an observant Jew, and lives in Jerusalem. But he finds that secular Israelis tend to see his knitted yarmulke and immediately "categorize me as a right-wing settler type until it is proven otherwise."
"These are Americans whose life's dream is to live in the land of Abraham, not the state of Israel," Professor Steinberg said of the settlers. "They're not a large group, but they're visible. And they're alien to Israelis, and that makes us all look alien."

HEADLINE: Income-Tax Cut: Hopes and Fears

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMILTON, N.J., March 19

 BODY:
Even when her campaign promise to cut taxes was so derided that it was costing her points in the opinion polls, Christine Todd Whitman stuck to her guns.
As Governor, she has begun to make good on that promise, cutting taxes by 5 percent during her first two months in office and, in her Tuesday budget message, asking to cut 10 percent more starting next January. 
 And up and down the state this week, New Jerseyans have been talking about Mrs. Whitman, talking about the tax cut and figuring out how much it will yield them -- probably little at first for most. They voice a mixture of optimism and skepticism, worrying about the impact of the state-aid cuts on their towns and schools.
"I knew she'd do it," said Martha Ceminowicz, the wife of a retired state worker who lives in this Trenton suburb. "A lot of people said she wouldn't, but she's a woman, and it's the women who know how to make the money last."
 
Cutting One, Raising Others
 In Cherry Hill, Marla Weinstein, 35, a homemaker, said: "It seems crazy that they're cutting taxes right now. I think that, I believe that our property taxes in every town will go up, and I don't know how that makes sense, to cut one tax and have other taxes raised."
Those are also the concerns of most New Jerseyans, according to a poll conducted by The Star-Ledger of Newark and the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University. It concluded that residents will gladly embrace income tax cuts so long as they do not result in higher property taxes. The poll was conducted in mid-February, as the first, 5 percent tax cut for 1994 was nearing enactment. The poll of 800 respondents had a margin of sampling error of 3.5 percent.
The poll found that 61 percent of respondents said the 30 percent income-tax cut that the Governor has promised over three years would help the state economy. But 72 percent said the cuts should not be made if they would force up property taxes.
Wall Street has also begun to mutter concerns. On Friday, Standard & Poor's Ratings Group issued a statement lamenting the Governor's reliance on one-time revenue sources to close a $2 billion budget gap and to pay for a $549 million tax cut.
 
Burdening the Next Century
 The bond-rating firm was particularly critical of the Governor's decision to change the financing of state retirement benefits, using a method that many believe will only put off into the next century an even greater financial burden on taxpayers.
"Of course, as the state keeps digging into one-shot revenue sources, the fiscal hole just gets deeper," said Hyman C. Grossman, Standard & Poor's managing director. The firm will issue its rating of New Jersey bonds sometime in June. (A budget must be adopted by July 1). By June, Whitman administration officials hope, an improving economy may have increased revenues enough to offset the one-shot budget deals.
Awareness of the 10 percent cut may be particularly intense because of the way Whitman officials orchestrated the publication of the Governor's first budget.
On Friday, March 11, Treasurer Brian W. Clymer held a news briefing on state income projections that included hints of another tax cut, but no details. "See me on Monday," Mr. Clymer told reporters who pressed for information.
 
Prime-Time Audience
 But the Monday briefing outlined only deficit closing measures, along with a few more figures suggesting another tax cut.
Finally on Tuesday, Governor Whitman made her budget speech in prime time, not in the afternoon, as was traditional. She clearly aimed over the heads of the Legislature, who shared the well of the Assembly chamber with her, to the television audience statewide.
In her speech, the Governor filled in the blanks: a 10 percent cut to couples earning less than $80,000, with smaller reductions for incomes over that level. To help pay for it, she would eliminate two state agencies, end 1,100 state jobs, close several National Guard armories and privatize New Jersey Network, the state-owned public television network that broadcast her speech.
The long buildup to the budget message allowed the Democratic minority in the Legislature to imbed a sub-theme about tax cuts in the public mind: that reducing the state budget in the name of lower income taxes would force cuts in state aid to schools and municipalities and so raise property taxes for everyone.
 
Wary About Property Taxes
 And that concern was widespread in conversations with New Jerseyans after the budget message.
"Let's say that the Governor is going to save me 5 percent a year," said Linda James, a Hackensack homeowner. "Well, that's all fine and good, but if my property taxes go up 8 or 9 percent a year, well, simple mathematics tell me I'm losing money, not saving." Ms. James added that her property taxes have recently increased to over $4,000.
"What do we get? A few bucks?" Paul Murray said from his driver's perch in a bread truck after making a stop at the Halo Farms dairy store in Trenton. "So, a few bucks, and our school taxes go up instead."
Residents of the state's struggling cities, meanwhile, worry that reduced state aid would fall particularly hard on the poor.
"I am appalled by the tax cut," said Mark Watson, a Camden paralegal as he waited for a bus at the Camden Transportation Center. "I don't understand how someone can do this in times of such trouble here."
In fact, Mrs. Whitman shifted about $38 million from wealthy school districts to urban districts under her spending plan.
 
Business People Love It
 If Mrs. Whitman has an ironclad constituency for her tax cut, it seems to be among business people.
"I don't care how much I'm going to get back -- that's not important," said Harry Wilson of Pennsauken, 37, the manager of a Cherry Hill Mall jewelry store.
"What is important is that people are starting to realize you can't just tax constantly," Mr. Wilson said. "Governor Whitman is finally doing something about the constant higher and higher taxes."

HEADLINE: Seeing Beyond the American Trees

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Institutional Investments That Grow With Trees" (Feb. 20) dealt exclusively with United States timberlands, which because of concern over the spotted owl and similar matters have become significantly overvalued in some regions. However, 85 percent of the world's timber production comes from outside the United States, and two-thirds of that percentage comes from tropical forests. Such forests are rapidly disappearing because of conversion to agriculture. For numerous biological reasons, tropical forests do not regenerate as readily as woodlands in temperate zones do. A tropical forest that has been clear-cut is lost for all economic purposes. 
 Operating a rain forest for profit on a sustained yield basis is a serendipitous opportunity to maintain a critical part of the planet's ecosystem while simultaneously achieving higher returns with less risk than investing in United States timberlands. The risks are lower because of the diversity of the forest and the lower probability of fire. The expected returns are higher because of lower land prices and operating expenses, faster growth rates and higher finished-product prices.
 
GEORGE H. MASON
Hartford, Feb. 22
 
The writer is the executive in residence at the Barney School of Business and Public Administration at the University of Hartford.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT;
Ship Contract Enlivens Piers

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE 

 BODY:
The old Brooklyn Navy Yard, the once-solid symbol of America's naval dominance put out of action by the decline of the shipbuilding industry, has attracted small, land-based companies over the last decade. But now a $9.4 million conversion contract is enlivening the yard's becalmed piers and docks.
Eastern Technical Enterprises, a company based in Norfolk, Va., with offices in the Navy Yard, won the contract to convert the Harkness, a naval oceanographic survey ship, into a nautical school for the Maine Maritime Academy. 
 The restoration project -- which includes a new deck house to accommodate 312 cadets, two marine sanitation devices and a machinery space for a new distiller -- is expected to last about a year and employ roughly 150 people, said Peter Beys, the president of Eastern Technical Enterprises.
While ship repairs have continued at the yard, this will be the largest project undertaken there in about a decade, said Thomas Montvel-Cohen, vice president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Company.
"This is a pretty large contract and it helps to maintain a ship repair work force that has existed in Brooklyn for over 200 years," Mr. Montvel-Cohen said.
In 1798, workers there nailed together the wooden frames of the Adams, the country's first home-built warship; in 1861, they constructed the Monitor, the United States Navy's first ironclad ship.
But the Navy Yard suffered a series of blows, most notably in the late 1960's, when much of the nation's shipbuilding industry migrated to the Gulf Coast states.
New York City bought the sprawling 260-acre yard in 1966, intending to turn it into an industrial park, and then set up as its manager a nonprofit agency, the Brooklyn Navy Yard Corporation.
It has managed to lure small businesses -- including a jewelry factory, a Haitian newspaper and All Ways Natural, a company that makes grooming products -- at a time when manufacturing jobs are leaving the city and loft spaces are continuing to beg for tenants.
But in 1986, Coastal Dry Dock, an anchor of the Navy Yard, went out of business, and uncharacteristic calm fell over the six docks and five piers of the once bustling yard.
Last week, the yard suffered another setback. City officials had applied for a Federal grant to establish a job corps center there to give disadvantaged youngsters basic job skills. But the yard was not among the nine sites across the country chosen to receive the grant.
Joan Bartolomeo, president of the Brooklyn Economic Development Corporation, said that a recent discovery of high levels of toxic chemicals in the soil of the southwest section of the shipyard was not likely to alter the yard's ability to attract businesses.
The discovery prompted a formal investigation by the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, which is expected to take a year, and may result in the yard's being placed on the Superfund list of toxic waste sites.
"I don't think it would make much of an impact," said Ms. Bartolomeo. "We're talking about an industrial area. People don't live there." GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Key Food Departs But Jobs May Stay

 BODY:
After 38 years of selling groceries to the Upper West Side, Key Food has announced that it will close its store at Broadway and 91st Street in May. But in a kind of economic recycling, the drug store chain that plans to take its place, Duane Reade, has promised to hire as many of the supermarket's 80 employees as it can.
Richard Durso, the manager of Key Food, said the promise was part of the agreement to turn over the store's lease. 
 "It was time to move on," Mr. Durso said, "but I also did not want to leave my employees without jobs."
Bruce L. Weitz, chairman and chief executive officer of Duane Reade, said he could not say exactly how many employees would be hired.
"Nothing would make me happier than to hire all of them," he said. "We intend to hire as many as we can, not only for that location but for other Duane Reade stores in the city as well."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE;
Poor Gain, Rich Gain a Lot

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
The Dickensian breach between Manhattan's richest and poorest areas widened in the last decade.
Both groups gained in average family income. Still, the differentials between the top 10 percent of the census tracts in Manhattan and the bottom 10 percent grew. The reason? The richer census tracts grew much richer. 
 According to a computer analysis of census data by Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, who directs the Program for Applied Research at Queens College, the ratio of income was 9 to 1 in 1980, when the poorest tracts reported average family income of $13,449 (in 1990 dollars) and the richest made $119,164 (also in 1990 dollars). By 1990, the figure for the 29 poorest tracts rose 22 percent to $16,420. But the average family income soared 72 percent among the richest, to $205,408. The ratio was 12.5 to 1.
Both the city's richest census tract and the poorest are in Manhattan, the richest bounded by Fifth and Park Avenues and by East 86th and 91st Streets on the Upper East Side, and the poorest bounded by Bradhurst Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard and by West 145th and 150th Streets in West Harlem.
Average family income in the richest was $301,209 -- or about 50 times more than the $6,019 average in the poorest.
In the richest, 6 in 10 households consisted of married couples; in the poorest, 1 in 4. In the richest, 2 in 3 adults were employed or seeking work; in the poorest, where the median age is seven years younger, only 1 in 3 were. Fewer than 1 in 100 households were poor in the richest tract; three-quarters were living below the poverty level in the poorest tract.
There are several ways to measure income. The two census tracts were selected on the basis of average family income and because they are largely residential. Most of the poorest tract is encompassed by the Bradhurst Redevelopment Project, which is to renovate and build apartments for about 2,200 families. SAM ROBERTS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN;
Restaurant Pact: Isolated Victory?

BYLINE: By JANE LII 

 BODY:
Although the union representing workers at the Silver Palace restaurant in Chinatown proclaimed victory last Sunday over the end of a bitter seven-month labor dispute, many in Chinatown say they doubt the settlement will have any impact on the working conditions in other restaurants there.
"It's a great political victory for the union in the sense they got very positive media coverage," said David Chen, executive director of Chinese-American Planning Council, a nonprofit social services agency in Chinatown. "But I think it's an isolated victory rather than a growing trend for Chinatown." 
 Traditionally, Chinatown restaurants have resisted attempts to unionize and mainstream unions have stayed away. Owners would rather close down than deal with unions. The latest such casualty, the East Village in Flushing, Queens, closed in January after some employees tried to unionize.
Even at the height of the Chinatown union movement in the 1980's, only about a dozen restaurants were unionized. Today, except for the Silver Palace, all have closed. (Efforts to organize garment shops are much more successful because of support from pro-union designers and contractors, Mr. Chen said.)
Working conditions remain poor in many Chinese restaurants, said Wing Lam, adviser to the striking workers and executive director of the Chinese Staff and Workers' Association, a Chinatown labor organization. He likened the workers' plight to slavery.
The unions' lack of success is attributed to cultural differences and the economy of Chinatown, where immigrants' desperation for jobs gives employers little incentive to improve working conditions.
To many owners and workers, a union is an unknown concept and is therefore shunned in favor of a more familiar, paternalistic management style. Competition is another factor.
"People come to Chinatown for cheap food," said a Chinatown banquet restaurant owner who did not want his name used. "You can get nine jumbo shrimps for less than $10. You have to pay $20 for the same thing elsewhere. I can only afford to give union benefits if I increased the price."
Until four years ago, before other banquet restaurants emerged, the Silver Palace enjoyed a near-monopoly on banquet business in Chinatown. To keep its competitive edge, the management demanded concessions from the independent union, Local 318 Restaurant Workers Union, when its contract expired in February 1993. It proposed dropping its contribution to the union's medical benefits, laying off workers at its discretion and having waiters share tips with maitre d's. It sought to reduce dim sum workers' pay from about $8.50 to $3 an hour, with a new share in tips. Negotiations broke down and the workers were locked out.
The workers drew support in Chinatown, but the Silver Palace also drew sympathy.
"The Silver Palace was within reason to ask for concessions," said Victor J. Papa, whose organization, the Lower East Side Catholic Area Conference, helped mediate the dispute. "They are paying $500,000 a year in union benefits no other Chinatown restaurants have to. Where is their fairness?"
The union claims victory in its three-year-contract because management will continue to contribute to medical benefits; the dim sum workers will remain on salary only and management must notify the union of layoffs and not use overtime to compensate for laid-off workers. On the downside, the pay of most dim sum workers will be cut by about 30 cents an hour and workers with three weeks vacation will get only two weeks in the first year. JANE LII

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
An Embarrassment on the Amex

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE American Stock Exchange requires listed companies to provide financial information to their shareholders. But for nine months, an insider at one Amex company sold his shares while the company kept its bad news secret.
That news, much of which came out last week, includes a default on loans, a two-year lag in filing tax returns, and a lawsuit that could put the company out of business. 
 The company in question is North American Recycling Systems, a small firm based in Fort Edward, N.Y. The company has been losing money at a rapid rate, selling assets to stay barely afloat. Its chairman and largest shareholder, Robert Barber, goes on trial tomorrow on charges of bribing a former supervisor in Washington County, N.Y., to get approval for a company plant. The supervisor, William Nikas, who is also a defendant, is now general counsel of North American.
The company's annual report for the fiscal year ended May 31, 1993, was due by the end of August, but was filed with the S.E.C. only last week. Before that, there had been no S.E.C. filings since last April.
During that period, the Amex seems to have done exactly nothing to protect shareholders in the company, although officials knew North American was missing S.E.C. filing deadlines. Amex officials last week refused to be interviewed, but did provide a written statement saying that the decision to allow the company to continue trading was made in light of the fact it had issued a few news releases during the long period when it was delinquent in its S.E.C. filings. Those press releases failed to mention numerous important facts, however, including the existence of a major lawsuit against the company that was filed 14 months ago.
In a brief interview last week, David Norris, the president of North American, said the Amex had not put any pressure on the firm to file its financial statements. He blamed the long delay on the company's former chief financial officer, and said two delinquent quarterly reports would be filed soon.
But while the Amex was doing nothing, John P. McGrain was quite busy. Mr. McGrain runs Conversion Industries, another Amex listing whose business is finding small companies and, in return for a cut of the equity, taking them public. That is how North American went public in 1992. Mr. McGrain is a director of North American and a member of its executive and audit committees, and, Mr. Norris said, was kept fully informed of the company's situation.
Mr. McGrain sold North American stock in the open market in July, October, November and December of 1993, and in January of this year. Reports of such sales by directors are due by the tenth day of the month following the sale, but Mr. McGrain did not get around to filing any of his reports until last month. Early this month, he advised the S.E.C. of his intent to sell still more shares. If those sales went through, as appears likely, he took in about $400,000 selling 73,728 shares, the bulk of his holdings, for an average price of about $5.38 per share. Conversion also was a seller of 5,000 shares at an average price of $4.38.
It is illegal for a director to sell stock in a company while in possession of material non-public information. How does Mr. McGrain justify his actions? We don't know, because he did not return repeated phone calls. Donald Clark, the No. 2 man at Conversion, dismissed the Conversion sales as being so small they would not be of "any concern to anybody," but he said he could not speak for Mr. McGrain. Late Friday, someone dumped 110,000 shares of stock at $5 a share, 75 cents below the market price at the time. Mr. Clark said the seller was not Conversion.
The legal problems besetting Mr. Barber, the company's chairman, and Mr. Nikas, the company's general counsel, stem from the period in the mid-1980's when Nr. Nikas was a supervisor of Washington County, a dairy-farming region with 55,000 residents north of Albany. He also served as chairman of the county's solid-waste committee.
In those roles, he led the negotiations with Mr. Barber for the construction of a trash-burning plant in the county, to be owned partly by North American. The county promised to cover losses if not enough trash came in, a promise that is costing it a lot of money.
The bribery and conspiracy charges against the two men claim that during the same period Mr. Nikas provided legal services to Mr. Barber and companies he controlled, and was promised an interest in other companies Mr. Barber was starting, without disclosing such conflects of interest.
In a news release last week, North American expressed confidence that the two men would be exonerated, and added that the company "is not affected and has no liability with regard to the pending litigation."
That is not the way E. Stewart Jones Jr. sees it. Mr. Jones, who is representing Mr. Nikas in the matter, says the criminal charges are part of an effort by Washington County to get out of its contract. "It has worked out economically badly for the county, and they are taking a financial hit," he said, adding that the county hopes that a conviction will lead to its victory in a civil racketeering suit filed in early 1993 against the two men, North American, and other defendants, seeking damages of more than $10 million.
North American now has a negative net worth of $3.9 million. One of the loans that is in default has been extended only through next month. Its auditor has questioned its ability to continue as a going concern. But its stock price has held up remarkably well, falling just 25 cents to $5.625 last week, giving it a total value of $30 million. Whether it will hold up after the annual report is more fully disseminated remains to be seen.
But what is clear is that the Amex gave its good name to the stock by continuing to trade it for months and months while complete and accurate finanacial information was available only to corporate insiders. And that allowed one of those insiders to get out while the getting was good.

It was in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in February 1993, not last month, that North American first disclosed a civil suit accusing it and other defendants of racketeering violations.
