HEADLINE: Health Coverage Declining

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
FUELED by cuts in coverage among small businesses, the number of workers without health insurance on Long Island is steadily growing. So are business owners' worries.
Last year 11.5 percent of the 1.3 million workers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties had no health insurance, according to the State Health Department division of planning, policy and resource development. That is up from 11.2 percent in 1992 and 8.9 percent in 1990. 
 The increase was most dramatic for businesses with fewer than 25 employees. Of the more than 425,000 people who worked in those enterprises last year 20 percent were uninsured. That is, proportionally, up a third from 1992 and two-thirds from 1990.
Among the 1.7 million Long Islanders in the traditional working age of 18 to 64, 14.5 percent had no insurance last year, up from 13.3 percent in 1992 and 9.1 in 1990. "It's clearly a significant problem and will remain a significant problem," said Matthew Crosson, president of the Long Island Association.
"Health insurance is everybody's No. 1 biggest problem," said Kathy Adams, president of the Long Island chapter of the National Association of Women Business Owners, a group with about 100 members on the Island.
The problems grew in the late 1980's, when costs soared and the economy soured. Many business owners began requiring employees to pay part of their premiums or started replacing permanent with uncovered temporary workers.
Although cost increases last year were half those of the late 1980's owners still regarded them as excessive and apparently continued to cut coverage as the number of uninsured workers continued to rise.
Insurers generally show little sympathy for the plight of business owners. "Those employers who do not provide health insurance are receiving an unearned largess," said the director of the New York office of the Health Insurance Association of America, Stephen Young. The association represents 275 companies. Uninsured workers, Mr. Young said, still receive treatment. To pay for that, he added, health centers charge extremely high rates for insured services, driving up premiums and placing a special burden on private insurers.
"You have a system where people are perceived of as having deep pockets," Mr. Young said.
Premiums, he said, have also increased, because of changes in state law requiring insurers to offer to cover everyone regardless of medical condition.
 
Higher Premiums in the Northeast
 Like the owners, he said, his association opposed mandatory regional alliances. But unlike the owners the trade group supports legislation requiring employers to pay most of the cost of health insurance. That would maintain an adequate flow of premiums and reduce increases in rates dramatically, Mr. Young said, adding that without changes that included employer mandates "it would be a very disillusioning experience for the American public."
In recent weeks Congressional committees and an army of interested parties in Washington have begun debating proposals for universal health insurance. The resulting legislation could be a problem for business owners, they say, if it requires them to buy insurance without adequately controlling costs.
Employers in the Northeast paid an average 10 percent more last year than in 1992 for premiums, or more than $4,000 an employee, according to a survey by Foster Higgins, a benefits-consultant in Manhattan.
"It's like madness," said Phyllis Hill Slater, who owns a paraprofessional engineering company, Hill Slater Inc., in Deer Park and advises the Long Island Association on minority affairs. "It's out of hand."
Ms. Slater's company, which her father founded 25 years ago, employs an average of 23 people, of whom six have insurance.
For years the company paid the full premium. But with huge increases in costs -- in one six-month period the premium rose 40 percent -- employees began paying part of the bill.
 
'They Are Brazen'
 In the last few years, Ms. Slater said, she has contracted with three or four insurers, none of whom offered assurances that they would not raise rates quickly.
All did.
"They are brazen," Ms. Slater said.
Costs have risen so much, Ms. Slater said, that some colleagues have stopped health insurance. "A lot of people are not even dealing with it. They're taking their chances and not even offering it."
She added that some engineers who had lost their jobs and were earning much less as consultants were forgoing insurance rather than pay high individual rates.
Some people pay more than $10,000 a year for insurance, according to Ms. Adams, a partner in the accounting firm of Adams & Jaskot in Commack. As an individual, she said, she pays $600 a month, or more than double the 1987 rate. "And the policies are not good," she added.
Often the first question prospective members ask Ms. Adams is whether her group offers health insurance. "Most small businesses can't afford to pay premiums for their employees," she said. "Part-time employees often have no coverage."
To combat the problem, the Long Island Association is forming a health-insurance purchasing cooperative through which businesses with fewer than 50 employees in Nassau or Suffolk Counties could buy coverage.
In forming the cooperative, which could serve 800,000 workers and their dependents, the business group hopes "to be ahead of the wave" of insurance legislation, Mr. Crosson said.
The cooperative could show that by creating a sufficiently large pool to increase purchasing power, small businesses could wrest control of the market from the insurance companies, said Stanley Altman, the health-finance adviser to the president of the State University at Stony Brook. "They are moving to fill a vacuum that exists now," Mr. Altman said.
"It's especially important because of the importance of small business to Long Island," said Manny London, director for the Center for Human Resources Management at Stony Brook.
 
Groupings Under State Rules
 The coop would negotiate with, perhaps, 15 insurers and providers offering community-rated policies, Mr. Crosson said. New state rules require that insurers charge all individuals or businesses with fewer than 50 employees rates based on a formula that groups Nassau and Suffolk with Westchester and the five counties of New York City.
By serving just Nassau and Suffolk, the cooperative would reduce costs, Mr. Crosson said.
Last year, he added, Long Islanders paid an additional $40 million in premiums because their rates were tied to the city, where medical costs are higher.
That figure could quadruple this year, he said, and the situation could worsen if proposals to include the Island with the city in a regional health alliance become law.
The coop would also reduce premiums if insurers pass on savings they achieve in marketing costs, Mr. Crosson added.
Mr. Altman said a committee that he is on has been meeting to establish bylaws for the coop.
The association hopes to begin operation by June 1, Mr. Crosson said, adding that initial reaction from small business owners had been positive.
"We'd definitely be interested," Ms. Adams said. "If it's cheaper than what they have people will look at it."
"I think it would make prices come down," Ms. Slater said. "I'm just so crazy with anything that's mandated."
 
What Decline Indicates
 EVEN as the number of Long Island workers without health insurance increased last year, the number of Islanders overall without such insurance declined.
The proportion of uninsured people in the general population of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which had increased to 11.5 percent in 1992 from 7.3 percent in 1990, dropped last year, to 10.8 percent, according to the State Health Department.
 The decline, department planners say, was less the good news of more insured people than an indicator of spreading poverty in an aging population.
More people, proportionally, have qualified for public insurance in Nassau and Suffolk in each of the last four years. The number receiving Medicaid and Medicare last year increased to 440,000, or 17.1 percent of the population. That is up from 374,000, or 13.7 percent in 1990.
More people also received private insurance last year after declines since 1990. The increase, planners said, was partly a result of increasing involvement by health maintenance organizations with poor or elderly patients, whom the H.M.O.'s have aggressively recruited.
Last year the proportion of uninsured New Yorkers increased, to 13.5 percent across the state. In that context, the decline in the number of Long Islanders without health insurance last year was a slight fluctuation, said Deborah Traynor, associate planner in the Health Department.
Between 1990 and last year, said Ms. Traynor, who is in charge of research on the uninsured, the number of Long Islanders without insurance increased 38 percent, to more than 276,000.
She added, "There is a definite increase over time." PHILLIP LUTZ

HEADLINE: Sun City Builder Mounting a South Carolina Venture

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: BLUFFTON, S.C.

 BODY:
THE Del Webb Corporation, builder of several large retirement communities in the West, has embarked on its first project in the East: a 5,100-acre, 8,000-detached-home development near this coastal Carolina community 12 miles west of Hilton Head Island.
The $110 million project is considered a major boost to this state's southeastern sector, known as Lowcountry, a region facing an uncertain future with the imminent closing of the Charleston Naval Base. Government leaders say the project is as vital an economic stimulus for that area as the $300 million BMW Manufacturing Corporation plant is for the northwestern industrial quadrant of the state. 
 It also enhances the image of South Carolina as a good place to retire, a major goal of the state's government.
"The Del Webb project gets the attention of lots of other people in that business and prospective retirees," said Patrick Mason, the executive director of the Center for Carolina Living, a private association working to advance the retirement industry here. "It causes a definite lowering of the fear barrier to go to the Deep South."
Already, Mr. Mason said, he knows of several retirement projects being planned for the rural communities near the so-called "Sun City East" site -- the project has yet to be formally named -- although they are much smaller, between 200 and 400 acres.
Del Webb, the Phoenix-based developer of five Sun City communities in arid regions in the Southwest, faces a new challenge in carving a city from a pine tree farm in the humid, subtropical South. The land will be developed in phases over the next 17 to 19 years. When the project is built out, a population of 17,000 people aged 55 or older is anticipated.
Groundbreaking for the first phase of 1,700 houses is scheduled for May, with first move-ins expected a year later. There are to be 15 floor plans for houses of 1,000 to 2,800 square feet, priced in the $90,000 to high-$200,000 range but averaging about $140,000.
The project is far less dense than other Del Webb developments, with about 1.5 units per acre compared with three per acre at the first Sun City, about 12 miles northwest of Phoenix. Begun in 1960, it was a new concept in retirement living, a full-scale recreation complex with 10 golf courses and 26,000 homes on 8,900 acres.
The late Del E. Webb, the company's founder and a former owner of the New York Yankees, gambled on the active retirement concept, which had bankers wondering whether they wanted to risk a 30-year mortgage on a 50-year-old. But by the end of the first year, Mr. Webb had sold 1,300 units, and the business was launched.
Mr. Webb died in 1974 and company officials began to sell many of the company's assets to resolve financial troubles and to concentrate on retirement communities. Since then, the corporation has built four more communities: a smaller complex also near Phoenix plus others in Tucson, Las Vegas and Palm Springs. A 1,200-acre development near Sacramento, Calif., is under way. A project outside of Austin, Tex., is also being considered.
Philip J. Dion, Del Webb's chairman, said the expansion was part of what the company calls "Webb Across America" that came about following an in-house study showing that about 90 percent of those surveyed wanted to retire within a short distance from the homes they had lived in while they worked.
As a result of the study, the corporation began looking for sites outside of the Southwest in 1989.
Said Leon Harper, a senior program specialist for the American Association of Retired Persons: "It is a harder sell to get people to give up their homes to go into retirement communities."
A 1986 AARP study showed 78 percent of those polled wanted to stay in their own homes after retirement. In 1993, in another study by the association, 85 percent said they did not want to move. That preference has caused a distinct shakeout among developers of retirement communities, with the weaker companies selling out to the stronger ones, Mr. Harper said.
"There is a market for the upscale older person, but it's not as large as people thought it would be," said Mr. Harper. "It's just not one that can encompass the whole country. Instead of running to Florida or Arizona, the new retirement havens are North Carolina and South Carolina and New Jersey."
But Mr. Harper said Del Webb is in a category of its own: He knows of no other company that launches projects on such a grand scale. In all, Del Webb's five existing projects will at build-out include nearly 68,000 homes. The original Sun City is so large it merits its own zip code.
The South Carolina coast is peppered with expensive retirement communities, said Mr. Mason of the Center for Carolina Living, with home prices averaging around $250,000.
"Del Webb is building Chevies and Buicks, not Rolls-Royces, which is what is mostly in place now in South Carolina," he said. "Others have planned for the high-end profile, with Pete Dye golf courses and palaces but the vast majority of people don't want to spend more than $175,000."
It is expected to take the company 9 to 12 months to build the golf course, recreation center, roads and model homes, Mr. Dion said. The company is trying to tie its marketing to the success of the large nearby boot-shaped Hilton Head Island, which has been carved into numerous upscale "plantations" for second-home owners and retirees.
Although Del Webb's land is more than 12 miles from the ocean, the company's 1993 annual report shows John H. Gleason, a Del Webb vice president, standing at the edge of the Atlantic as the sun rises behind him. Company officials regularly refer to the project as "Sun City-Hilton Head."
The land actually straddles a link now under construction from Interstate 95 near Hardeeville to Route 278, which runs southeast to Hilton Head. The project will be as close to historic Savannah, Ga., and stately Beaufort, S.C., as it is to Hilton Head.
ITS major water artery is what is called "The Great Swamp," which the company will try to develop as an amenity by erecting boardwalks for bird watchers, joggers and walkers.
The swamp, plus the trees, mostly loblolly pines, have posed a new challenge for Del Webb planners, who usually plan for tracts that are 100 percent developable. Thirty percent of the South Carolina property is wetlands.
Nevertheless, all the building permits have already been obtained, said Mr. Dion, the Del Webb chairman, and a temporary sales office has been established near the site in Bluffton. The homes will be built on the same theme as most South Carolina Lowcountry homes, with muted colors, clapboard exteriors, porches and steep roofs. Out west, most of the Sun City homes are of stucco and have tile roofs.
Mr. Mason said the state estimates that the net economic impact of Sun City would be $1.2 billion. A number of retail and other commercial ventures are already being planned for the area.
"This project requires no new schools," said Mr. Mason. "It's clean. It creates a community where there is a very low tax base now. It's as big as a Mercedes or a BMW plant coming to the area."

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 20 about a planned retirement community in South Carolina referred incorrectly to the previous activity of the developer, the Del Webb Corporation. The South Carolina development is not Del Webb's first project in the East; the company built Sun City Center south of Tampa, Fla., in 1962 and sold it eight years later.

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE;
Recession-Influenced Dining

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM 

 BODY:
WHEN Pollo Pazzo opens in Huntington Village in the spring and Route 66 follows a few months later in Merrick, they will mirror a now familiar pattern. Like the soon-to-open Caswell's in Montauk and Calaluna in Southampton, they are casual restaurants that plan to serve earthy substantial food and, above all, stress value.
Pollo Pazzo, or crazy chicken, an eat-in carry-out combination, will feature flattened boneless chicken marinated in rosemary, garlic and olive oil and grilled on an open fire. Route 66 is billing itself as a Texas steakhouse offering Southwestern-style beef and ribs. 
 Caswell's, an informal rotisserie restaurant and carry-out, and Calaluna, a Sardinian restaurant offering ethnic peasant fare, also conform to the recession-born trend.
Luxurious, pricey and ostentatious restaurants are out, as are nouveau and nouvelle. Good-size portions of simple satisfying food served with flair and imagination at easily affordable prices are in. Restaurateurs opening places are well aware of the preferences of the Island's frugal diners.
 
Uncomplicated Food a Lure
 The continuing downward pressure on prices has inspired a sucession of restaurant-markets, takeouts, delicatessens and bakery amalgams. They lure penny-wise diners with tasty uncomplicated food that depends on good ingredients, modest surroundings and reasonable prices.
Bairrada, a Portuguese storefront barbecue in Mineola, is part of the new wave. So is the new Major's in East Williston, where a 24-ounce steak costs $10.95.
Although high-quality midprice restaurants continue to open in Nassau and Suffolk, not since East Hampton Point opened nearly a year ago has a luxurious, big-deal spot ventured forth.
The 15-seat Pollo Pazzo at 366 New York Avenue, with its terra cotta floor, white tile walls and chickens' grilling in the window, is typical of the new breed. Its chicken is served with basil mashed potatoes or polenta.
Aside from grilled chicken, the scant menu offers spaghetti with tomato sauce or meat balls and lasagna. Gelato for dessert and six focaccia sandwiches, including grilled tuna, roast vegetables, veal and chicken breasts with arugula, are the only other possibilities.
 
Bicycle-Delivery Fleet
 All the dishes are available to be eaten in, taken out or delivered via a small fleet of red bicycles. The economical 900-square-foot Pollo Pazzo is being opened by Fabio Machado, who also owns the four Pomodoro restaurants of Long Island and Manhattan.
The 120-seat Route 66 at 33 West Sunrise Highway in Merrick is the latest venture of George Korten, a restaurateur who has been associated with slightly pricier operations like George Martin's in Rockville Centre and Mim's in Syosset. Mr. Korten says Route 66, which is scheduled to open in June, "will be a retro-Texas roadside cafe that recreates a 1940's or 50's roadhouse along Route 66."
Prime steaks, grilled meats, barbecue, regional Southwestern dishes and cutting-edge Mexican cuisine will be featured. Entrees will range from $12 to $23 and average around $14 or $15.
The rustic rough-and-ready decor will resemble Main Street America of another day, with its roadhouse-red booths, jukebox and wood paneling. It is being designed by James Bieber, who was architect for the Mesa Grill and Gotham Grill in Manhattan.
POTPOURRI Diners at 107 Forest Avenue in Locust Valley are contributing $200 a month to hungry people. Donations to the Food and Hunger Hot Line are made possible by a menu listing called the Hungry New Yorker. It enables customers to earmark $5 at lunch and $10 at dinner.
Most contributions are charged on credit cards. The restaurant absorbs the credit-card fee and sends the entire donation to the hot line. Andrea Buffa, a social worker who runs a shelter for the homeless in San Francisco and is a sister of John Buffa, the co-owner of the restaurant, suggested the project, the only one of its kind on Long Island.
Tom Shudel, the chef and the other owner at 107 Forest Avenue, will shuttle between Locust Valley and the Downtown Grill in Montauk in the warm weather. He will spend his weekends on the East End and weekdays in Nassau County, alternating with Noelle Iffhin, his sous chef.
Pomadoro, of Huntington and Port Washington, is opening a second restaurant in Manhattan, at 1424 Third Avenue, at 81st Street (212-794-1810). The commonly owned Trattoria Tulipano in Huntington, Stresa in Manhasset and Navona in Great Neck have hired two chefs from Italy. Carlo Gobbi from Lossa Maggiore Restaurant at the Milan Airport is the new executive chef at Tulipano. Ginni Bugivrolli of Hotel de la Poste in Cortina will see service at both Stresa and Navona. Stresa, like Navona, is now open daily.
Caffe Milano in Woodmere has been sold and will reopen in mid-April as Carmelinas. Antonio and Carmelina Zubo, who were formerly associated with Il Bagatto in Valley Stream, are the new owners of the restaurant at 1034 Broadway (569-7604). A four-week redecoration that includes carpeting, painting and an enlargement of the bar area is in progress. Carmelinas will continue to make use of the restaurant's wood-burning pizza oven.
WINE TASTINGS 107 Forest Avenue in Locust Valley (674-3441) is holding a four-course $65 California wine dinner at 7:15 P.M. tomorrow. Frog's Leap, Sonoma Cutrer, Caymus and Deloach wines will be poured, and dishes like bouillabaisse of salmon with shrimp, scallops and garlic toasts will be served.
San Marco Restaurant, 658 Motor Parkway, Hauppauge (273-0088), will hold a Winter's Gourmet Dinner accompanied by California wines from Franciscan Vineyards on Wednesday at 7 P.M. The five-course $49.95 meal includes a veal-and-chicken Calvados main course.
The fourth Windows on Long Island wine tasting will be at Brightwater's at the South Street Seaport in Manhattan on May 10 at 6 P.M. The two-hour event sponsored by the Long Island Wine Council attracts more than 1,000 people each year and features the wines of all 16 Long Island vineyards, as well as hors d'oeuvres from 15 to 20 leading restaurants. All participants receive a souvenir tasting glass and a program booklet. Tickets, priced at $45, will go on sale on March 31. They can be ordered by calling 475-5492 or (800) 464-L-I-W-C.
CHANGES Danford's Inn of Port Jefferson has been undergoing major changes since the Fisher Hotels Group took over its management. A completely new menu, a resumption of wine-tasting dinners and new murder-mystery weekends that include dinner are intended to spark the waterfront property, which encountered financial problems last year.
Andrew Seaman, the new food and beverage manager from the Tarrytown Conference Center, has wisely retained Stephen Meade as executive chef. His new menu lists just two holdovers, lobster ravioli and penne jambalaya.
The new entrees, priced from $17.95 to $23.95, include pork medallions served with port-wine sauce and grilled leeks and a seafood mixed grill with grilled salmon, seafood sausage and shrimp.
When the Basil Leaf in Locust Valley reopened in mid-November, it retained its name and telephone number (676-6252), but that is all. The original restaurant at the Plaza Shopping Center had closed, and its owner had departed when Dino Ferrari and Vito Patronelli moved in and began a two-month renovation.
Mr. Ferrari, who is in the Italian clothing business, and Mr. Patronelli an olive oil importer, changed the decor, chef, menu and style. What had been an eclectic casual Italian-American cafe has become a more sophisticated restaurant.
The new husband-and-wife cooking team, Mario and Tina Maggi from Milan, worked at Bice in Manhattan, Chicago and Tokyo, as well as Trattoria Tulipano in Huntington, before moving to Locust Valley.
Entrees at the new restaurant are in the $12.95-to-$22.95 range. Among the five or six nightly seafood specials, a lobster antipasto and crab cakes have proved especially popular.

HEADLINE: Lawyers Debate the Insurability of Bone-Marrow Transplants

BYLINE: By CHERYL P. WEINSTOCK

 BODY:
SPEAKING at a meeting of the American Bar Association in New York City, Kathy A. Cochran of the law firm of Wilson, Smith, Cochran & Dickerson in Seattle described why she thought there were no "evil forces at work" when often refuse to pay for high-dose chemotherapy with autologous bone-marrow transplants in breast-cancer cases.
"Skeptics argue that treatment for desperately ill women should not await the rigors of scientific scrutiny, as these women do not have the time to wait for science to prove the treatment. Much the same would have been said by women who received radical mastectomies at the hands of enthusiastic surgeons convinced that this was the 'only cure' for their breast cancer. Unfortunately science later proved this to be untrue in many cases."
Ms. Cochran said it was paradoxical that customers should criticize insurers for failing to reimburse a treatment that, some companies say, has not proved to be superior.
Another lawyer, L. Susan Slavin of Slavin & Steinberg, said that in most cases insurers cited contractual agreements that really did not limit the procedure, because it is merely an extension of high-dose chemotherapy, which is usually covered.
"It's just a matter of dollars and cents," Ms. Slavin said. "It's an expensive procedure, and every time they say no to it they save $150,000."
On Long Island, where the incidence of breast cancer is higher than the statewide average, the battle is frequently played out. Those women with advanced breast cancer who have been told by their physicians that they have no treatment options other than transplants and whose insurers have refused to pay for the procedure are being encouraged by advocacy groups to take further action.
Insurance companies are fighting back. Liz LoRusso, executive director of one local advocacy group, 1 in 9, said the cases of 11 women seeking reimbursements had gone to litigation and been settled in favor of the patients. Many other battles have been fought over the telephone and through the mail, she added.
"Two to three years ago there were no attorneys trained to help us fight," Ms. LoRusso said. "Now there are. Women with breast cancer are viewed as very weak. Well, we're the strongest people you'll ever find, because we're fighting for our lives. We'll leave no stone unturned."
Arlene Pokorny, 47, of Melville, was given a diagnosis of breast cancer in 1979 and is now fighting her third recurrence. At her physician's urging, she requested clearance from her insurance carrier to pay for transplants.
"I've never been denied anything," Ms. Pokorny said. "Now my life is hanging on a thread. I'm living in terror all the time that they'll say no."
She added that she had hired a lawyer "just in case I'll need one."
After weeks of legal proceedings her insurance company agreed to cover her transplant.
 
Role of Bar Associations
 The chief of psychiatry service at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, Dr. Jimmie Holland, said: "I think this adds to the already high sense of vulnerability and uncertainty that women already feel about the disease. It's kind of a betrayal. Anxiety and depression are already felt by women with breast cancer. The need for this kind of fight just compounds it."
Ms. Slavin said she worried about "how many women out there who, when they know their insurance company won't pay for their treatment, just walk away from the fight."
To assist women who have been denied reimbursements for transplants or other procedures or who face other obstacles from their carriers the Nassau and Suffolk Bar Associations will soon distribute brochures to breast-cancer coalitions, doctors' offices, hospitals and clinics announcing their free law program, said Tom Maligno, executive director of the associations. "It's a chance to reach the clients who need us most and a unique opportunity for the health and legal professions to work together," he said.
What remains to be seen, however, is whether legal help will settle differences between carriers and clients. Many insurers say they are prepared to change their contracts and claims reviews to avoid being responsible for procedures like transplants.
Kathy Olson, a spokeswoman for Mutual of Omaha, which insures more than 10 million individual and group policyholders, said there was no way that Mutual could have anticipated the surge in technology. As a result, she said, Mutual will try to clarify its new policies to avoid disputes.
Insurers usually wait for a procedure to be accepted by medical experts before they extend coverage to it. "In the future," Ms. Olson said, "we'll use the percent-success rate of a treatment to measure the success of it, so that there's a clearer understanding of what is experimental."
The associate general counsel of the Blue Cross-Blue Shield Association of Chicago, Mary Ader, said: "We're working for the benefit of the subscribers. Our desire is to cure our patients. We don't want them languishing in hospitals. We want them to live, and live a healthy life."
 
'Sympathy and Concern'
 The associate director of the cancer-therapy-evaluation program at the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Michael A. Friedman, said that he had "enormous sympathy and concern" for people who wanted to optimize their chances of living, but that he was not sure that the relentless pressure that patients and their doctors and lawyers put on insurers was in the patients' best interest.
"Look, this is not a story that lends itself to simple truths," he said. "In certain selected situations bone-marrow transplants can be very efficacious. But there are many unanswered questions."
Dr. Friedman cautions patients about being too optimistic about the possibilities of transplants and suggests that they wait for the results of four trials that are under way. The tests are intended to compare the benefits and risks of the procedure to conventional chemotherapy for treating localized breast cancer at high risk of recurrence and metastatic breast cancer.
"Patients should opt for a treatment that's indisputable, one that's ethically and scientifically correct," he said.
From the point of view of many physicians, the criticism of using transplants outside clinical trials for their patients is unfounded. The physician in charge of the Adult Bone Marrow Transplant Program at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, Dr. Michael Schuster, said:
"The problem is that treatments for all cancers might be viewed as experimental, in the sense that they're constantly evolving, constantly moving forward. The only way we can move forward is to introduce new treatments in the hope that we can cure a larger percentage of patients.
"If third-party payers slam the door on new treatments by using the 'E' word, then no progress will be made. We'd be using the same kind of medicine that we did five years ago."
Health-care economists say physicians are part of the problem in the equation that divides the insured from insurance companies. Prof. Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said:
"On the one hand, physicians tell you they were trained in school to fight for their patients and do their best. But they were not trained as guardians of the U.S. Treasury. If there's any hope that something will work, then they are morally obliged to do it.
"On the other hand, you can't run a health system on that algorithm. You have to allow nonphysicians further upstream to actually make the hard calls and not give away the Gross National Product."
Professor Reinhardt suggested that a dispassionate panel of experts intervene when a doctor proposes to treat a patient with a controversial therapy. Many insurance companies have begun to do that, and more say they will follow that route.
 
Use of Independent Panel
 The director of technology assessment and policy for Aetna Health Plans in Hartford, William McGivney, said that in the 20-month period that Aetna has used an independent panel to help it decide financing in more than 100 decisions, one case against it has gone to court.
"We've extended ourselves to meet the needs of our patients," Mr. McGivney said. "If we've got three experts who are saying no to a treatment then we're pretty sure it's not appropriate care for a patient."
Aetna, Prudential and Travelers subscribe to the Medical Care Ombudsman Program in Washington. The director of the program, Grace Powers Monaco, said it promised to provide fast authoritative reviews of treatments. The program will work with a patient and insurer to resolve any issues "in a sensitive and personal matter," she said.
"I think grown-ups have to be grow up about their medical care," Ms. Monaco, a lawyer, said. "They don't want to waste their money and resources on a procedure that can't really provide them with an increased amount of life. I think, unfortunately, we've made a big mistake in this country that we've not educated our children, young people and adults about how to evaluate their medical care options. If you see something like H.D.C./A.B.M.T. depicted in the media as a treatment for one thing you might not understand that it only works in a patient that looks, tastes and smells a certain way. It may not be for you."
 
Votes of Confidence
 Some lawyers say they feel confident about the future. Louis J. Castellano Jr., who successfully represented Joseph Scalamandre in a suit in Federal District Court in Uniondale, said the value in overturning a denial of coverage by Oxford Health Plans Inc. for a transplant for Mr. Scalamandre's wife was that "carriers now notice there was a case tried to conclusion, and the determination was made against the carrier."
That was just one more case that seems to add to "the majority rule in the United States that this treatment is not experimental in most jurisdictions," Mr. Castellano said.
Ms. Ader of Blue Cross-Blue Shield disagreed, saying: "The effect of judicial opinion, as defined by law, is that there's precedent only in jurisdictional issues. Such opinions have no value outside of that jurisdiction. The courts are not required to follow it elsewhere. It is not binding."
In one of the largest challenges to the denial of "investigational chemotherapy," Memorial Sloan-Kettering, in a complaint filed in State Supreme Court, maintains that Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield should be ordered to pay $12 million in compensatory and punitive damages for refusing to cover transplants for cancer patients.
Who will ultimately have the power to make health decisions is certainly going to be a "major issue for the women here,' said Patricia Spicer of Cancer Care in Woodbury, a clinical coordinator for breast-cancer services on Long Island. "This issue has already been coming up more often in our groups, because more doctors are recommending H.D.C./A.B.M.T. early on."

HEADLINE: We Still Have to Do Something About Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Maybe it was best that the balanced-budget amendment was voted down, but there is still a critical need to force the country to mend its profligate ways. I believe the structural deficits of the last decade are almost criminal. Everyone vaguely understands that our debts will be handed down to future generations for them to pay. In the strictest sense, this burden imposes taxation without representation on those generations. They will have no say in how the money is spent, yet they will be responsible for providing the funds. 
 It is a tired argument that says governmental deficits are a small percentage of the economy. More and more of each tax dollar is used to pay interest on the accumulating debt, leaving less and less for productive capital spending. And it is also spurious to claim, as some do, that the practices of the 1980's resulted in 20 million new jobs, since our annual deficits are sufficient to finance, directly or indirectly, 20 million low-paying jobs.
How can we address these deficits? By creating an amendment that allows deficit spending in bad times, but requires that we repay the debt in good times. This would allow Congress to overspend when necessary, but force the country to repay the debt whenever, for example, the economy exceeded a certain growth rate. Such predictability would allow rational planning by taxpayers and financial markets, since both would know that, as things improved, there would be a requirement to pay the bills (through temporarily reduced spending or increased taxes).
Nothing says we cannot experience what South American countries experienced when they took on excessive debt. We are not immune to hyperinflationary pressure. Neither is there any natural law that says the dollar must remain the world's prime currency.
 
CHRISTOPHER J. LAHODA
Lawrenceville, N.J., March 12, 1994

HEADLINE: Gauging the Consequences of Spurning China

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

 BODY:
As the Clinton Administration weighs whether to renew China's "most favored nation" status after the strained visit by Secretary of State Warren Christopher to Beijing, legions of American business leaders and Washington lobbyists for industry and trade associations are describing the consequences of withdrawing the designation in near-apocalyptic terms.
But some economists and legislators, pointing to the United States' $22.7 billion trade deficit with China -- second only to its $59.32 billion deficit with Japan -- suggest that much of the oratory about damage to American exports and investment in China is overstated and that higher duties could go some distance toward trimming the trade deficit. 
 In fact, both sides, while summoning considerable data, have shaped their analyses to suit their arguments. Any clear-cut assessment remains elusive.
"Our exports were $9 billion last year to China," said Donald M. Anderson, the president of the United States-China Business Council, a group that promotes trade between the countries. "No one really knows how much they would be hit, but they would be hit because the Chinese would unquestionably retaliate."
Jagdish Bhagwati, a trade economist at Columbia University, does not agree. "All this number-crunching is purely hypothetical," he said. "Would the Chinese retaliate by saying, 'The U.S. wants to play hardball so we'll play hardball' ? That is a vague, general fear, in my view. If they start playing that game, we are a superpower and we have lots of leverage. We have a whole range of punishments and rewards at our command."
The threat of Chinese retaliation against American companies selling to China and what would be a surge in duties on Chinese products exported to this country have rattled industries with large stakes in China and worried trade experts about the broader relationship between the two countries should China's trade privileges be revoked.
By June, President Clinton must decide whether China has made "significant, overall progress" toward improving its human rights record, a condition of an executive order that the President issued last year on renewing China's trade status. Virtually every country with which the United States trades holds most favored status, which results in significantly lower duties on their exports to this country than would otherwise be the case.
The Boeing Company, one of the most influential American manufacturers -- and with orders from China for $3.9 billion in new airplanes -- has led the charge against any change in China's trade status. Last Tuesday, at a panel discussion in Washington sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations, Lawrence W. Clarkson, Boeing's corporate vice president for planning and international development, attacked proposals to link renewal of most favored nation status to China's record on human rights.
"Boeing currently has orders for 64 planes for delivery to China with a value of $3.9 billion," Mr. Clarkson said. "These orders, plus an additional $2 billion to $3 billion in near-term potential orders, would be at great risk if M.F.N. was not renewed. During the next 15 years, China will need 800 airplanes worth $40 billion, making it the world's third-largest aviation market."
 
Offering a Bigger Context
 Like many executives who have urged renewal of China's trade privileges, Mr. Clarkson couched his argument in broader social and political terms as well. "We believe strongly that this U.S. trade is contributing to the rapid decentralization and transformation of China's economy, helping millions of Chinese to obtain greater freedom to choose their work, their employer and their place of residence," he said. "As in Taiwan and South Korea, the development of a vigorous middle class will bring the development of social and political freedom for all Chinese more than any other factor."
American industry leaders often say, as some business executives did to Secretary of State Christopher in Beijing on March 13, that 167,000 American jobs depend on trade with China. This figure comes from a Commerce Department estimate that every $1 billion in exports generates 19,000 jobs; thus, the roughly $9 billion in exports to China accounts for 167,000 jobs.
The calculation implies that most if not all of these jobs are in jeopardy if China responds to a cutoff of trade privileges by slashing imports from the United States. But, as economists like Mr. Bhagwati note, this inference is not warranted given the uncertainty of the Chinese response and the complexity and size of trade between the two countries.
Still, Lawrence Chimerine, the chief economist at the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based economic and trade policy lobby organization, said cases like Boeing suggest that American manufacturers could lose large chunks of the China market. "I think Japan and Europe would get a lot of orders that we wouldn't get," he said.
 
A Wide Range of Trade
 In 1993, according to the Commerce Department, the United States exported $8.76 billion worth of goods to China, including airplanes, fertilizer, wheat and automobiles. China, during the same period, sold $31.53 billion in goods to this country, products ranging from toys and shoes, to combs and clocks.
Peter T. Mangione, president of the Footwear Distributors and Retailers of America, said that ending China's access to low duties would mean higher shoe prices for Americans because China accounted for one of every two pairs of shoes sold here. "Almost 90 percent of all shoes sold in America are imported," Mr. Mangione said. "And China is by far the largest supplier of imported shoes; it supplies 60 percent of all imported shoes."
Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at CS First Boston, has calculated the potential inflationary impact of revoking China's most favored status. If this trade privilege is denied, he said, the increase on duties on Chinese products imported into this country would fuel inflation by at least 0.15 percent annually. "The slippery slope of protectionism is the reason," he said.
But Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from San Francisco who has led the campaign in Congress against renewing China's trade status, argues that the size of America's trade deficit with China suggests that China needs American markets.
"China's economic growth depends on preferential access to the United States markets," Ms. Pelosi said. "The deficit is growing. Compound that with cheap labor and you see that they are flooding our markets with products made by people making $24 a month."
Even some supporters of extending China's preferential trade status, however, are concerned about the chilly reception that Mr. Christopher received in Beijing. "Right now I'm a bit fed up," Mr. Anderson of the United States-China Business Council said. "The Chinese could help, and it would be in their interest to help."

HEADLINE: California Race May Be the Key To White House

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 18

 BODY:
The most important electoral battle of 1994, they say with metronomic regularity at the White House, is the contest for the governorship of California.
"From President Clinton's point of view," agreed Bob Mulholland of the California Democratic Party, "it's even more important than keeping control of the Senate. If we shoot ourselves in the foot and lose this race -- and we well may -- the Republicans could have 54 electoral votes in their hands." 
 That judgment, which is shared by many here, rests upon the conviction that Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, has a solid chance to defy the odds, win re-election this fall, and set himself up for a 1996 Presidential bid.
For all its recent economic travails and natural disasters, this vast state has the kind of raw political power few have wielded in the long history of the Republic. It is the first state ever with more than 50 House seats. It has grown so much faster in the last three decades than the big states of the East and Midwest that it can now deliver, by itself, one-fifth of the electoral votes needed for victory in a Presidential election.
Winning California "is like hitting a $15 million lottery," said Stuart Spencer, a veteran Republican strategist. "None of the rest is worth more than $2 or $3 million."
The Presidential calendar has just been changed in a way that gives the state even more political leverage. Instead of voting in June, when the race for party nominations is usually all but settled, Californians will now vote in a Presidential primary in March, when it is usually not. And the Republicans, who will presumably have the more interesting primary contest two years from now, intend to keep their winner-take-all rule, which guarantees the victor a huge block of delegates.
Governor Wilson has mounted an impressive comeback after a disastrous start marked by tax increases and fumbles on several important issues, including homosexual rights. His most likely challenger, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, has raised a $5 million war chest but has failed, so far, to project a clear picture of herself and her views.
This week, in a tacit acknowledgment of trouble, Ms. Brown dropped her campaign manager, Teresa Vilmain, and replaced her with Clint Reilly, who is experienced if abrasive.
"Kathleen's ahead a bit in the polls," said Willie L. Brown Jr., the canny and outspoken Democrat who has served for nearly 14 years as Speaker of the California Assembly. "But Pete is the clear favorite. Her campaign has been a mess, enough so that the White House ought to be worried. Wilson wins, he runs in the Presidential primary, and he's on the 1996 ticket, first or second spot. That makes California a whole lot harder for Bill Clinton to carry."
Even if Mr. Wilson decided not to run himself, Mr. Spencer suggested, "they will have to deal with Pete, because he'll have this big state behind him."
Not everyone thinks Mr. Wilson would automatically become so formidable a national force. A member of the California group that went to Washington with Ronald Reagan, speaking on condition of anonymity, predicted that Mr. Wilson would "encounter real credibility problems with the Republican right wing." In addition, the Governor said in announcing his candidacy this month that he had no interest in running for President. But few politicians believe that.
 
One State Becomes Soul of Body Politic
 Mr. Clinton has taken California more seriously as a political base than any other modern Democratic President, traveling here nine times since taking office, sending top aides when he could not come himself and funneling as much money into the state as possible, given the straitened condition of the Federal purse. He won the state in 1992 with only 46 percent of the vote, and the 21 percent that went to Ross Perot may well be up for grabs by the major parties in 1996.
Since World War II, no President who came from a state other than California has carried the state twice except Dwight D. Eisenhower, the all-conquering war hero. Mr. Clinton's task is complicated by the state's anxieties, born of floods, fires and earthquakes, riots and bank failures and military base closings. Californians have become Cassandras, fretting in the sunshine.
While other local industries are flourishing, including biotech, entertainment and computer software, and while reconstruction efforts have given the Los Angeles economy a temporary post-earthquake lift, California has been devastated by base closings and the shrinkage in military procurement. According to a study by the Southern California Edison Company, the state has lost 700 businesses in five years.
The total job loss has been variously estimated at 500,000 to 800,000, and some economists have suggested that 100,000 more may go before the state finally joins the national upturn in the final quarter of this year or the start of 1995. Unemployment stood at 8.7 percent in December while the national figure was 6.4 percent.
The Administration has pledged to spend $19.5 billion on shifting military plants to peacetime production over the next five years, and 20 percent or more of that is earmarked for California. Prohibitions on exporting some computers, computer chips and other high-tech goods made here have been lifted, and a sale of California-made warplanes to Saudi Arabia was approved.
Cabinet members are as thick on the ground as movie moguls in Los Angeles these days, led by Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena and Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros. Lloyd Bentsen, the Treasury Secretary, works the Central Valley, which is not unlike his own native Rio Grande Valley. Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown flies in at least once a month.
What has helped the President most, politicians of both parties agree, has been his prompt assurances of help and his personal visit after the January earthquake. Statewide, according to the Field Poll, more than two-thirds of voters say Mr. Clinton responded well to that crisis, though 57 percent described his response to the state's overall problems as poor or only fair.
"Clinton is in far better shape here in 1994 than Bush was in 1992, even with all the base closings," said the pollster, Mervin Field. "People give him credit for trying."
Still, Tom Epstein, the White House official who spends his full time worrying about California, acknowledges, "We have only a limited capacity to fix things out there, and if the Southern California economy doesn't come back strong in the next two years, then all the good deeds in the world aren't very likely to save us."
Senator Dianne Feinstein, a first-term Democrat who is heavily favored in her re-election campaign this fall, argues that Mr. Clinton could have done much more. Specifically, she said the President should either defer the next round of base closings or exempt California from it, and improve the defense conversion program.
In the end, said a Democratic campaign consultant who knows the state well, "Clinton may stand or fall in California on whether he can reverse this insidious feeling that the land of dreams has become the land of unrelenting and insoluble problems."
So far at least, the Whitewater affair has cost Mr. Clinton little or nothing here. Kam Kuwata, Senator Feinstein's campaign manager, said, "People out here on the other side of the country don't really understand it." But, he warned, "they do understand words like 'cover-up' and 'subpoena,' so the White House had better stick to this new policy of openness."
 
Staking Out Stand On a Pair of Issues
 Despite praising Mr. Clinton for his help after the earthquake, Governor Wilson complained in an interview this week that the President "keeps saying that California is important, but the problems of our economy have been aggravated, not relieved, by his tax increase, his base closures, his defense cuts and so on."
Mr. Wilson's campaign for re-election is rooted in two issues -- crime and illegal immigration. Like most other California politicians, including Ms. Feinstein and Ms. Brown, Mr. Wilson argues that the Federal Government must help pay for the services the state provides illegal aliens. Such services, including health care and schooling, consume nearly 10 percent of California's $39 billion annual budget, the Governor said.
By all accounts, Mr. Wilson has won support for his position. But he has also suggested barring illegal aliens from some services, and that has proved far more controversial. Ms. Brown called it "heartless and unwise" to try to deny certain medical services and said that would only "fill the state with people with contagious diseases."
 
Name and Images Could Cut 2 Ways
 On crime, Mr. Wilson is clearly in his element. Earlier this month, he signed the "three strikes, you're out" bill, which imposes life sentences after a third serious crime. He wants to build a network of new prisons.
As Mr. Epstein of the White House concedes, "if he can turn this into a referendum on who's the meanest, baddest ex-Marine on the block, he wins, so we have to make Californians think more about jobs and health care and stuff like that."
Ms. Brown, widely expected to be the Democratic nominee for governor, opposes the death penalty but says she would enforce it if elected.
Nevertheless, said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political scientist at the Claremont Graduate School, "like her father, Pat, and her brother, Jerry, like Rose Bird, the Chief Justice who was voted out of office, she is hurt by the notion that she is soft on crime." The problem is worsened, Ms. Jeffe added, by voters' tendency to distrust female candidates on law and order.
"There's no doubt that California is fixated by crime at the moment," Ms. Jeffe said. "It ranks ahead of the economy in the polls of public concerns. The murder of Polly Klaas, the child who was abducted in Petaluma last year, took crime out of the inner city in this state and put it into the middle-class bedroom, where high-turnout, highly independent voters live. A big change."
Ms. Brown readily admits that she faces a close race. She said during a breakfast interview: "It's always tough to take out an incumbent governor. And look at the issues: Pete Wilson is on their hot-button wavelength."
She argued, however, that she could win because Mr. Wilson has raised taxes and presided over an unprecedented era of decline in California.
But Ms. Brown must first clear a primary hurdle. Her opponents, Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi and State Senator Tom Hayden, are well-known enough but underfinanced. The pollsters and the pundits alike expect her to prevail, though a few give Mr. Garamendi a shot.
There is something of her father's charm about Ms. Brown, and also something of her brother's flakiness. ("Leadership is a circle, not a straight line," she earnestly told an interviewer.) Her fate may depend on which parallel takes hold among the voters.
Despite a raft of position papers and a lead in the polls, she remains little known to the public, professional observers say. Bill Bradley, a Sacramento columnist, says her campaign is "still circling the parking lot." Ms. Jeffe says Ms. Brown is "just waking up to the fact that we elect our governors, we don't anoint them."
Mr. Wilson is a formidable campaigner. He was elected to the Senate in 1982 and 1988 and as governor in 1990 against tough opposition. But his negative ratings in the polls run close to 40 percent, a tough handicap.
Ms. Brown, who has served only one term as Treasurer and a partial term as a school board member, is unproven. She may suffer from that and from what Michael K. Deaver, the old Reagan hand, sees as a possible aversion to three women in the state's top three jobs -- Senator Feinstein and Senator Barbara Boxer being the others.
In the past, the Republicans pulled big votes out of the collar counties around the big cities, like Orange County, the one-time conservative bastion south of Los Angeles. But the big Asian and Mexican immigrations have changed the state's demographics.
"The Hispanics could make or break Wilson," said Mr. Spencer, the Republican strategist. "They may make or break the Republicans nationally. Whoever gets them in the next two cycles will have them for good, just the way F.D.R. got the blacks for the Democrats for good."

HEADLINE: Beijing Says It Could Live Well Even if U.S. Trade Was Cut Off

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 20

 BODY:
Foreign Minister Qian Qichen said this weekend that the importance of China's trade with the United States had been overstated, and that China was prepared to return to the cold war status of no trade relations with Washington if the dispute over China's human rights record could not be resolved.
"For 23 years before President Nixon opened the door of relations between China and the United States," he said in an interview, "there was no trade whatsoever between China and the United States. 
 "I think you lived quite well. And so did we."
 
Clinton Said to Be 'in a Web'
 Still combative a week after China's brusque welcome and harsh treatment of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Mr. Qian said that President Clinton had "enmeshed himself in a web of his own spinning" over the June deadline he had set for China to make "overall significant progress" on human rights or else lose its favorable trade status with the United States.
"If a politician always sets such deadlines," Mr. Qian said, "then he will only have his own hands and feet bound."
Mr. Qian's tone, and that of other senior Chinese officials interviewed in recent days, raises questions of whether Beijing is reconsidering its pledge to "make an effort" to respond to Mr. Clinton's demands on human rights this year, as President Jiang Zemin said in January.
Mr. Qian said China still believed that "progress can be made" on its differences with Washington, provided that discussions took place "on the basis of equality" and mutual respect.
But Mr. Qian, other Chinese officials and Western diplomats were at a loss to describe how negotiations would proceed in the 10 weeks before the June 3 deadline.
Most analysts here are somewhat baffled over China's apparently sudden decision to confront Washington over its admonitions that time is running out before Mr. Christopher must recommend whether to renew or withdraw China's "most favored nation" trade status.
That status, which has been under contentious review in Washington each year since the military crackdown at Tiananmen Square in 1989, entitles China to export to the American market on a low-tariff basis like most other trading partners of the United States.
After Mr. Christopher's visit, analysts here saw two possibilities as the most likely explanation for Chinese behavior.
One is that China's leadership is seeking to demonstrate its strength internally by showing a determination to stand up to the United States. From such a position of strength, any concessions on human rights would be easier to sell to hard-liners at home.
The other possibility is that China's hard-liners have already persuaded President Jiang that he does not have to make any concessions to Washington on human rights, because a combination of political and economic pressures at home will force President Clinton to renew China's trade status in June even without evidence of significant progress on human rights.
 
The Whitewater Factor
 Some analysts have suggested that another factor is the Whitewater investigation. One senior Foreign Ministry official spent much of his time during a luncheon with an American journalist last week seeking to understand what potential the Whitewater matter held for weakening Mr. Clinton's presidency and his ability to conduct foreign policy.
In an interview on Saturday evening, Mr. Qian appeared to be softening his earlier criticisms of Mr. Christopher's mission. He said the meetings during the Secretary's four-day visit had "yielded some results" and had not been a waste of time because they afforded Mr. Christopher a chance to reacquaint himself with China after an absence of 10 years.
He said China understood that the United States, by setting conditions for human rights improvement, was seeking to move United States-China relations out of the shadow of the Tiananmen Square massacre to a new stage of cooperation.
"I believe the U.S. side wants to do that," Mr. Qian said, "and I hope that the U.S. side will be successful in doing that." But he offered no specific commitment that China would contribute further to the diplomatic bargain.
Restating what has become a boilerplate phrase for Chinese leaders, he said China was hoping for the best, but prepared for the worst.
Mr. Qian and other senior Chinese officials have begun to play down the consequences of losing trade privileges in the American market.
A senior economist and research director for China's State Council, the cabinet-level body under Prime Minister Li Peng, said in an interview last week that a loss of trade status in the United States would seriously affect only 10 percent of China's exports.
The research director, Sun Shang qing, said that all of the affected exports could be redirected to Asian markets this year, and that even with the disruption, China's economy would still meet its 9 percent growth target for the year.
Addressing the same point, Mr. Qian said: "The United States often says that in its trade with China, China runs a $20 billion surplus. However, such a conclusion is not all that correct."
Much of that trade originates with Hong Kong, Taiwanese and other foreign-financed enterprises, including American joint ventures, set up in China to export to the American market, he said. Thus economic damage from a cancellation of China's trade privileges would have an impact on Hong Kong, Taiwan and American investors in China.
 
U.S. Businesses' Stand Recalled
 "That is why when Secretary Christopher met with representatives of the big companies of the United States" during his visit to Beijing, "all of them voiced their strong opposition to the revoking" of China's trade status, the Foreign Minister said.
Some estimates have characterized the loss of China's most-favored-nation trade status in more severe terms for the Chinese. A World Bank study says that raising the average tariff on Chinese export goods by 5 to 10 times would reduce exports to the United States between 42 and 96 percent. The problem of redirecting these exports to other markets was not addressed by the study.
The United States exports about $9 billion a year in goods to China, and any retaliatory step by China could put that trade at risk, along with the 200,000 American jobs that are estimated to depend on it.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
CHRISTOPHER ON CHINA TRIP
 WASHINGTON, March 20 (Special to The New York Times) -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that on his trip to Beijing he had sought to carry out Congressional policy toward China and that he had the "full concurrence" of President Clinton.
Mr. Christopher, appearing on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," denied Chinese assertions that Beijing had asked that he postpone his trip.
"There was never any request that I not come," he said. "It's just a bit of Chinese disinformation, apparently, to perhaps justify the rough treatment."

HEADLINE: Empty Shelves, Empty Minds;
Budget Problems Drain Libraries of Their Lifeblood: Books

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
At the Bloomingdale branch of the New York Public Library, a teen-ager asked for Richard Wright's "Black Boy," a toddler requested "The Little Engine That Could" and a businessman asked for any of several computer books. None of the books were available.
The Bloomingdale branch, like others in the city's library system, is suffering from too many empty spaces. In field after field and collection after collection, the branch, at 150 West 100th Street, finds it has a dearth of the books people most want. It is a condition that Paul LeClerc, president of the Public Library, worries will result in "sclerosis of the collections" as critical books go unacquired, unrepaired or unreplaced. 
 And the problem has been made more evident by the library's success in another area: longer hours of operation since a sixth day was added to the weekly schedule in September. Even as attendance at the Bloomingdale branch leaped 16 percent in the first quarter of full operation, circulation climbed just 7.9 percent.
 
'A Second Chance'
 Statistics only hint at the story. "It's heartbreaking to have students come in to do their homework and not be able to give them the materials," said Becky Koppelman, the children's librarian at the Bloomingdale branch. "And they're not always going to let you give them a second chance."
This oft-repeated situation, librarians say, is a direct result of a reduction by nearly half in the libraries' budget for materials -- mainly books -- over five years. At the same time, book costs have raced ahead of general inflation. Librarians say books are less well made and wear out faster; computers and new library technology divert money from books, and school libraries are suffering from their own shortage of funds.
"Many of the public-school libraries are really nonexistent," said Jean Paul Michaud, the Public Library's coordinator of information and reference services. "In many ways, public libraries have really become school libraries."
It is the same story all over the New York Public Library system, which serves Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island. Funds for materials plunged from $7.4 million in 1989 to $5.3 million this year. And $3.9 million is the amount in the city's preliminary budget for next year. Annual spending has droppedto a proposed $1.26 per capita from $2.52.
 
'It's Beyond Crisis'
 Similar cuts have hit the separate library systems in Queens and Brooklyn. "It's beyond crisis," said Barbara Genco, chief new-book buyer for the Brooklyn Public Library. "It's an implosion."
Accordingly, libraries are pushing for a return to 1990 financing levels; officials of the administration of Rudolph W. Giuliani have met with representatives of the three systems to explore methods of raising more money from the private sector, and the City Council held hearings this month on book funds.
"Libraries are an integral part of a good society," said Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for planning and community relations. "You build neighborhoods around libraries. The question is not whether you fund them. The question is how you fund them."
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said, "You can be sure that every Council delegation from every borough feels very strongly about its libraries."
Typical is Councilwoman Kathryn Freed, who gave $2,500 to each of the two library branches in her lower Manhattan district to buy books. "It's nice we have them open six days a week, but what good are they if there are no books?" she asked.
The Bloomingdale branch is typical of the 205 branches in the city in that it must serve multiple needs and constituencies. It serves older readers with large-print books and serves children with sturdy picture books. Students from public, private and parochial schools use it. The branch offers books in Spanish, French, Japanese, Chinese and Creole as well as English.
"It's really a microcosm of the city's population," said Telza Gardner, the branch's head librarian. "What they have in common is that they all expect to see some books."
But where once there were three shelves of sports books, there is now a half shelf and gaping open space. There were five dinosaur books on a recent day, compared with three dozen a few years ago. Best sellers, once staples, are now sought-after gems. Even dictionaries, which many library users do not have in their own homes, are in short supply.
"We're going to have to make some hard choices between popular reading and the needs for school materials," said Constance Cooke, director of the Queens Borough Public Library.
Library funds both for personnel and materials were cut back in the early years of the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, who later fulfilled a promise to restore service, which had been cut back to two or three days a week at most branches. In 1992, he succeeded in having service returned to five days at most branches. A year later, most expanded to six.
The increased funds were earmarked for longer hours, meaning mainly more staff members, and not books. Increased hours prompted greater circulation as people flocked back. But then the effect of longer hours boomeranged, and circulation actually fell by more than 5 percent after a sixth day was added at most branches.
"The people who came more often began to find less," said Donald Kaplan, a spokesman for the Brooklyn Public Library. "They've read everything."
Ellen Loughran, a top official in the Brooklyn system, explained, "We have libraries that are open twice as much as they were last year, and they probably have 15 to 20 to 25 percent fewer books."
New York's experience is not singular. Nationally, "libraries have gone through a real period of drought in the past five years or so," said George Needham, executive director of the Public Library Association.
The effects may be irreversible. "When there's a huge gap for a number of years, many books will go out of print and will never be available in public libraries," Mr. Needham said. "You lose a generation."
Mr. Needham cited recent Federal tax-law interpretations that have caused publishers to drastically cut inventories that might have been used for replacement.
At the same time, Mr. Needham's association calculates that people keep demanding more and more books, even as their availability shrinks. Each year, he said, circulation grows by 6 to 7 percent, making overall public library circulation around 1.6 billion books.
This wide use, he said, makes libraries big winners in local ballot initiatives. He said nearly three-quarters are successful. Given this popularity, smaller libraries in more affluent areas are often very well financed.
According to the Public Library Association, the Middle County Library on Long Island received $13.85 per capita for materials, Boston libraries got $10.81 and Cleveland's $12.92 in 1992. In the same year, Queens libraries received $2.72, Brooklyn's $2.15 and the New York system's $2.01.
 
Loyalty Is an Issue
 Jerry Nichols, director of the Suffolk County Cooperative Library System, which claims to be the country's biggest, said local municipalities vote on library budgets in both Suffolk and Nassau counties. "Because of this, there's a great deal of loyalty to their institutions," he said.
And he said the resulting investment is critical to maintain a library's usefulness. "If there's no investment in libraries, people will stop using them," he said.
Despite the availability of such items as videos in many libraries, books continue to be the biggest draw. A recent Gallup poll conducted for the New York Public Library showed teen-agers preferred wider book availability to more hours by a 31 to 24 percent margin.
"That's one of the most reassuring pieces of news about that generation that you could hope for," Mr. LeClerc said. "There are so many false stereotypes out there about the non-reading habits of the American public."
Libraries are shaving expenses wherever they can, though often with a two-edged blade. Paperback books are less expensive, for example, but wear out more quickly. Books are still occasionally rebound, but the process costs as much as new books and the result can be unpopular with readers. Computer technology offers the prospect of centralized information, but the initial investment is often large.
At the Bloomingdale branch, where Dr. Seuss's "Cat in the Hat" is almost never available, the frustration for librarians is daily and large. "We want to connect books and people," Ms. Gardner said. "When we can't do that, it's a great disappointment."
