HEADLINE: Polls Indicate Victory by Rightist in Salvador Election

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, March 20

 BODY:
El Salvador's conservative ruling party appeared tonight to be heading toward a strong victory in the first national elections since a peace accord two years ago ended a civil war, according to independent projections tonight.
With 26 percent of the votes counted, elections officials said Armando Calderon Sol, the presidential candidate of the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance, had 50.7 percent, while the leftist coaliton candidate, Ruben Zamora, had nearly 28.6 percent. 
 One poll indicated that Mr. Calderon Sol would win with just over 50 of the vote. Over 50 percent is required to avoid a runoff election, and it remained uncertain whether a runoff would be required.
Highlighting the uncertainty, Mr. Zamora, the candidate of a coalition that includes the former guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, said at a news conference, "Our projection clearly indicates that there will be a second round," and he predicted an ultimate victory for the left.
 
Charges of Fraud
 The suggestions of Mr. Calderon Sol's success were tempered by bitter assertions by Front leaders that the election was riddled with fraud. Signs multiplied that voter turnout was lower than expected, and the ex-rebels, taking part in elections for the first time, said 300,000 Salvadorans had been deprived of voting cards by what they said was a politicized electoral tribunal.
Moreover, the former guerrillas charged, more than 12 percent of the voters who got voting cards were turned back at the polls because their names did not appear on master rolls.
In a heated news conference shortly after polls closed, one of the former guerrilla leaders, Joaquin Villalobos, said the Government had disenfranchised large numbers of voters in areas of traditionally heavy support for the rebels. "It is incredible to see this after the peace process, after the campaign of the century," he said.
Mr. Zamora, in predicting the need for a runoff election, said, "Let the second round be a clean round."
 
Denial of Fraud
 Electoral officials rejected the charges. "The elections were clean," said Alvaro Cruz, the chief elections auditor. "There were no significant problems." His view was supported by international observers.
The bitterness generated challenges to the credibility of the results, and left El Salvador facing two potentially disturbing outcomes.
If Mr. Calderon Sol is declared the winner, his victory and the legitimacy of the elections is likely to face a harsh attack by the left. If a second round is required, tensions between the two camps could become dangerous.
 
A History of Violence
 El Salvador has seen more than its share of war. As many as 75,000 Salvadorans are thought to have died in the 12-year civil war, in which the United States spent as much as $6 billion to support conservative governments in their fight against the Front, a coalition of Marxist guerrillas.
The war ended two years ago when the United Nations brokered an accord between the two sides, who were both fatigued by the long war. The agreement called for a cease-fire, the disarming of the guerrillas and reforms of the Salvadoran security forces, including the training of a new civilian police force and the retirement of the most notorious army leaders. The accords also called for land reform and credits to help former combatants resettle.
Guerrilla leaders say many prescriptions have been only partly fulfilled.
The voting today was not always smooth, but independent monitors did not report any widespread fraud.
In Aguilares, 45 minutes north of the capital in a region that saw frequent fighting during the war, voting was delayed for two hours. Finally, frustrated voters waiting in lines that stretched several blocks angrily rushed the election headquarters, causing a brief panic before order was restored.
"This was very poorly coordinated," said Vincente Gutierrez, an official monitor for the Authentic Christian Movement, one of a number of small parties taking part in the elections. "Delays like this are not an unimportant detail. A lot of people could get discouraged."
"People are feeling cheated, especially if their party loses" said Issac Gonzales Ramirez, an election official in Santa Clara, where some party officials said that as many as 60 percent of those eligible voters were unable to vote. "There will be a lot of resentment. This could affect the credibility of the whole process."
But in most places the number of voters who complained to United Nations officials or to the 2,900 international monitors here fell far below the 60 percent cited by former rebels.
 
Monitors Seem Satisfied
 In the gritty merchant town of Mejicanos, on the outskirts of San Salvador, United Nations officials and international observers at several polling stations said they had seen few problems.
"One of the party representatives here was claiming that 30 percent of the voters were being turned away," said Osborne William McConathy, an American observer in Mejicanos. "At the tables I've been watching, though, only a couple of people have been denied. From my observation the system is working pretty good."
Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, the head of the United Nations mission, saluted the elections for "their extraordinary normalcy, even if we have seen some irregularities." Mr. Ramirez estimated last week that about 74,000 Salvadorans had been left off voter rolls, principally for lack of birth certificates.
Even if that number is small in an electorate of over 2.4 million, the problems of people missing from voter lists and the difficulties others encountered in getting voter cards could haunt El Salvador.
After four decades of military-dominated governments and 12 years of civil war, El Salvador remains deeply divided between left and right, and a tradition of election fraud renders people all the more suspicious. Skepticism is particularly evident in small towns like Tecoluca, a voting center for a broad swath of the countryside.
"It just takes one or two votes to change things," said Juan Francisco Velasquez. He took a bus to Tecoluca from his village, La Pita, at 3 A.M. to be sure to reach the polls early, only to be told that his name was not on the voter list. "A lot of other people from where I live didn't bother to come, because they never got a card."
 
EL SALVADOR AT A GLANCE
 
ELECTION: El Salvador held its first elections yesterday following the end of its 12-year-long civil war two years ago. The presidential election pitted Armando Calderon Sol, candidate for the ruling Nationalist Republican Alliance, against Ruben Zamora, whose leftist coalition is dominated by former guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.
 
BALLOT: In addition to voting for a president, Salvadorans are selecting a vice president, 84 members of the National Assembly, 262 municipal governments and 20 deputies to the Central American Parliament.
 
VOTING: About half the country's 5.5 million people are eligible to cast ballots. About 2,900 foreign observers are expected, including about 550 from the United States.
 
ISSUES: Both major candidates have promised to rebuild the country and to work to eliminate poverty and social injustice. But the campaign has centered on accusations of abuse by both sides during the war.
 
COUNTRY: About the size of Massachusetts and Central America's smallest, with annual per capita income of about $750. Economy is heavily agricultural. The population is 5.4 million. About 75,000 people died in the war.
 
HISTORY: El Salvador was ruled by Spain until 1821 and became independent in 1839. It's history has included frequent political violence and coups. In 1980, the country moved closer to civil war with the assassination of the Catholic Archbishop of San Salvador, Oscar Romero y Galdames, a supporter of human rights. Jose Napoleon Duarte became president in December 1980, and his Government received United States support as civil war spread, human rights abused were widely reported and hundreds of thousands of people fled. The right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance gained effective control in the 1988 election in which Alfredo Cristiani won the presidency. Peace was negotiated in 1992 with the help of the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Asia Pacific Alignment Is Off to an Upbeat Start

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, March 20

 BODY:
The intriguing question raised by the first meeting of the finance ministers of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum is whether the world is seeing the birth of a new alignment that will eventually replace the Group of Seven as the globe's most influential economic-political club.
The 18 finance ministers ended their two days of talks here on Saturday night by announcing a series of studies on how to better manage the $1 trillion in capital expected to flow into the Asian and Pacific region in the next decade and by scheduling meetings to coordinate financial activities. 
 "We share a goal to keep up the growth in investment, and we think it is a goal that we can achieve," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, the host. "We can do it best by strengthening our ties. Over and over I heard that from the finance ministers."
 
Bentsen Moves With Caution
 For now, though, Mr. Bentsen is proceeding cautiously. The Asians, led by China, Japan and Malaysia, are wary of being part of an American-dominated economic alliance that might force them to follow Washington's dictates on human rights or trade.
And while these countries increasingly need to coordinate their finances, they are widely divided on security issues -- most notably on North Korea, with no consensus on how to deal with the nuclear threat.
Nevertheless, American officials could not help commenting on the contrast between the Group of Seven jobs conference they played host to in Detroit on Monday and this weekend's session of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC.
In Detroit, the mood was somber and the discussion was about unemployment that was reaching critical proportions among the exclusively Atlantic members of the Group of Seven (Britain, France, Germany and Italy) but not in the Pacific ones (Japan, Canada and the United States).
At this meeting, with such economic powerhouses as China, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, Hong Kong, Japan and Chile present, the mood was upbeat.
As Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim of Malaysia remarked: "We couldn't have been invited to Detroit. Our problem is a labor shortage."
 
Looking to the Future
 American officials do not want to say it out loud, but the conclusion is obvious: the Group of Seven increasingly seems like a relic of the cold war. The Asia Pacific group reflects the transformation of its region into the economic center of the world. It is about the future.
Dressed mostly in blue blazers and casual slacks for a "class photo," framed by palm trees and a deep blue Pacific, the ministers had a jaunty air about them -- 18 men who control more than half of the world's economy.
It was clear from their final statement here that the financial integration already under way in the region was forcing these economies to coordinate more, despite their initial hesitations. They have $1 trillion a year in intra-regional trade alone, and economies now so intertwined that runaway inflation or unemployment in one major country can spill over into all the others.
Their communique endorsed plans to double the capital of the Asian Development Bank. It asked the International Monetary Fund to study cross-border private investments into and within the region, to better understand how money is being raised, and it called on the Asian Development Bank to arrange a symposium on the problems of financing roads, bridges and power-plant projects.
The ministers agreed to meet in Indonesia next year, and their heads of state have already scheduled a summit meeting for the Indonesian island of Bali this November.
 
Contrasts With Europe
 The Group of Seven began the same way in the mid-1970's. But turning the Asia Pacific group into a more permanent alliance will not be easy. The contrasts with Europe could not be more stark, said Michel Oksenberg, president of the East-West Center at the University of Hawaii. European regional integration took place under a single dominant power, the United States, in the face of an external threat, the Soviet Union. In Asia there is no dominant power and no external threat to drive the countries together.
In Europe, Mr. Oksenberg added, it was the governments that led the drive to regional cooperation. In Asia the private sector and the financiers are leading the way. Finally, he said, in Europe nationalism had become something of a dirty word, given its links with protectionism and the two World Wars. In Asia nationalism is still seen positively, linked with independence from colonial masters and healthy economic competition.
Maybe the biggest problem for the United States in trying to build a significant regional association is the tension in Washington's relations with Asia's two biggest powers -- Japan and China.
Still, despite these cross currents, there are strong incentives for greater cooperation. As David McLain, dean of the business school at the University of Hawaii, said, "The region is growing pell-mell, and there is the potential for instability" should efforts to strengthen financial institutions and improve coordination not come to fruition.

HEADLINE: Welfare Planners Struggle Over Final Sticking Points

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Mar. 20

 BODY:
Three days before presenting President Clinton with a plan to transform the welfare system, dozens of his aides gathered behind closed doors on Saturday for a frank, sometimes anguished, debate about race, class, sex and the impact of their decisions on the lives of millions of poor people.
Some officials likened their work to that of the civil rights pioneers, praising the emerging plan as a historic opportunity to fight poverty and reverse family breakdown. Others called some of its provisions misguided, hubristic or downright mean. 
 The three chairmen of the 32-member group drafting the plan barred reporters and asked that no one discuss what was said. But several officials provided accounts of the meeting, held across the street from the White House, arguing that the difficult issues should be placed in public view.
By turns earnest and sardonic, the unusual five-hour gathering captured the welfare issue in all its complexity. It reveals a plan being shaped by a mix of political promises, social science, grim Government finances and deeply held beliefs about family, work and personal morality.
 
A Million Mentors
 Contemplating a Presidential campaign against teen-age pregnancy, which would place a million mentors in the nation's poorest schools, some officials even referred to their own experiences with premarital sex.
"We can all admit we enjoyed the pleasures of premarital sex," one senior Administration official said, in stressing the need for birth control.
Both the powerful and the powerless have great stakes in the debate over welfare. President Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it" was one of his most popular campaign themes, and it remains a cornerstone of his assertion that he is a New Democrat.
He has said the plan will expand training opportunities for the record five million households on the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. But after two years, he has said, adults who remain unemployed must join a work program.
Behind that broad theme, however, a host of complicated issues remain unresolved, and the meeting produced many sharp exchanges, several people present said.
They said Joycelyn Elders, the Surgeon General, warned that one money-saving option could backfire by increasing the number of children in foster care. Andrew M. Cuomo, an Assistant Housing Secretary, warned that the plan had the potential to drive families into homelessness.
 
Illustrating the Risks
 Gene Sperling, a White House economics adviser, said financing the plan by cutting programs for immigrants could produce "a political firestorm." Christopher Edley, a White House budget aide, said some aspects of the pregnancy prevention plan were based on fantasies, and he likened them to the the world of Mary Poppins.
While politicians have crusaded against welfare for decades, they have found it easier to denounce than to fix.
The Clinton Administration is the first in a generation to try such an ambitious solution. The planners' own sometimes heated criticism of one another illustrates the risks involved.
Among the most difficult issues is how to pay for the plan, which is expected to cost about $15 billion in the first five years. While the public often thinks work programs save money, in fact they are expensive, at least in the beginning. That is because the government will provide recipients with day care and subsidize their wages to encourage employers to hire them.
Some members of the task force were said to have objected strongly to the plan to raise the money by cutting programs for the needy. But David T. Ellwood, a co-chairman of the group, argued the Administration had little choice, given the difficulty of raising taxes.
Mr. Ellwood advocated a strategy that would remove about 250,000 children from the welfare rolls by changing the rules that govern households in which only a child receives aid, as when a grandmother takes in a child whose mother has a drug problem.
 
The Meaning of $200
 Such a change would save about $800 million a year by removing about 40 percent of the 650,000 households in the program. Mr. Ellwood and Mary Jo Bane, another co-chairwoman, said such families received about $200 a month. And they argued that many of them, with higher incomes than the average welfare family, had the ability to get by without it.
But a roomful of Federal officials, many earning six-figure salaries, then engaged in a heated debate about what $200 means to the disadvantaged. Mr. Cuomo and Ms. Elders, among others, were said to have warned that the cut could force children into homelessness and foster care. Mr. Sperling warned that the proposal could be perceived as "really mean."
In response, Mr. Ellwood said that every suggested cut had the potential to hurt someone and that such child-only families had more money than most.
The group referred the issue to the Cabinet, which is to meet alone on Monday and again with Mr. Clinton on Tuesday.
The group also disagreed over how many hours welfare recipients should work. Noting that most recipients are single mothers, some officials said they wanted to limit the work week to 20 hours so parents can tend to their children. Others, arguing the need to appear tough, said states should have the option of requiring 30-hour or even 40-hour work weeks.
Even the question of what constitutes success was up for grabs. Some officials stressed the need simply to cut welfare caseloads. Others said some people should be allowed to stay on the rolls as long as they were performing some work. Mr. Ellwood, who has a flair for the flamboyant phrase, said it was essential to convince Americans that welfare recipients were "getting off their duffs."
To reduce costs, the Clinton plan would be phased in slowly. At the end of the five years, only 130,000 of the five million families receiving aid would actually be enrolled in a work program.
Those present at the meeting said Ms. Bane urged her colleagues to discourage reporters from noting the small number of people in the work program, which could make it hard for Mr. Clinton to say he did in fact "end welfare as we know it."

HEADLINE: Plush Condos Do Not a Russian Venture Make

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 20

 BODY:
Isolated on a remote field of a vast Russian collective farm called Lenin's Legacy, lies a freakish sliver of the suburban American dream.
Behind high steel gates, rows of semidetached, pearl gray wooden town houses are artfully arranged along flagstone paths. Each of the 67 prefabricated units is equipped with plush wall-to-wall carpeting, a working fireplace, two-car garage, air-conditioning, microwave oven, washing machine, dryer and cable television. A few yards away, 40 more units are under construction. 
 It could be Potomac, Md., or New Canaan, Conn., but in fact, the condominium-style community known as Rosinka is just outside Moscow, 15 miles from the Kremlin.
And beneath its air of dreamy suburban perfection lies a complicated tale of folly and greed straight out of Gogol, with a dash of John Grisham's legal melodrama.
 
Partners Differ Vastly
 The partners in the joint venture -- a Westport, Conn., real estate development company, Senie Kerschner International Housing, and a former Soviet model collective farm that has fallen on hard times -- are locked in a bitter dispute over who owns the property. Each side accuses the other of deception, greed and theft.
Such conflicts are not rare in post-Communist Russia, where joint ventures between Western companies and their Russian partners are new and risky, and cultural collisions inevitable. This has especially been true lately; as the Russian economy worsens and the political situation becomes more unstable, most joint ventures are experiencing tension.
For example, Occidental Petroleum, which has a joint enterprise in Siberia, is tied up in a dispute with its Russian partner over ownership of the oil that is not earmarked for export -- 1.2 million tons in 1993. Because of that, Occidental has recalled all but 6 of its 48 Western experts from the site, and the joint venture, called Vanyoganneft, is not producing any oil for export.
But the battle over Rosinka has a special flavor. "This case is unusual for the degree of acrimony," said Marc J. Halsema, a lawyer with Steptoe & Johnson, which represents Senie Kerschner and more than 50 other Western companies with joint ventures in Russia. "It's a little unusual to see a joint venture deteriorate this badly."
The dispute is also unusual because the United States is the leading tenant at Rosinka, renting 40 units for embassy personnel and 9 for employees of the Agency for International Development, at a 5 percent discount on apartments that lease for $4,000 a month. (Executive town houses, with five bedrooms and saunas, go for $7,000, but even at those rents, the community is fully occupied.)
So far, officials at the United States Embassy have listened sympathetically to American complaints, but continue to pay rent to the Russians. Embassy spokesmen declined to comment on the case.
"There is a sense here that we don't have the full story from either side," an American diplomat said. "Neither side seems to have behaved according to Hoyle."
Oleg A. Zakharov, who manages Rosinka as the collective's farm's representative, says the Americans never provided the $2.1 million capital contribution they pledged to the project and instead, using sneaky American accounting ruses, funneled money lent to Rosinka back to their businesses. "They cannot be robbed of something they never owned," he said scornfully.
Nolan K. Kerschner denied such machinations, and retorted that the Russians took advantage of complex new Russian laws to re-register the joint venture as a Russian company, usurping the Americans' half share and investment, which they calculate at $3.5 million.
Mr. Kerschner, who has complained to the embassy, the State Department and Congress, is seeking arbitration in Sweden and a Congressional investigation. "Why should the U.S. send all this aid to Russia if they are going to treat American companies like this?" he asked.
The partnership collapsed as Rosinka appeared to be teetering on the brink of profit. Christopher Senie, the former managing director of Rosinka and the son of Alan Senie, thought that the United States Government was considering a plan last year to buy the units it was leasing, which could have brought Rosinka $10 million. The State Department has denied this.
Mr. Senie estimated that in five years, if other corporate tenants elected to buy, profits could reach $150 million. "What is being fought over is power and money and access to millions of dollars," he said.
 
Optimism and Vodka
 It all began in a haze of laughter, vodka toasts and vows of eternal friendship in April 5, 1990, when Mr. Kerschner and Alan Senie formed a joint venture with the collective farm, represented by Mr. Zakharov, a suave former K.G.B. officer who looks a little like James Mason.
Their dream was to build an $88 million development of 478 town houses to pamper Western executives in the kind of gilded ghettos that a Moscow magazine once described as "hygienically sealed hard-currency colonies."
The Americans promised to provide financing, building materials and know-how. The Russians would find the land and negotiate the bureaucratic maze.
Mr. Zakharov became the godfather of Christopher Senie's first child. "These people were my best friends in the world," he said. Two years later, Mr. Senie and his family fled Moscow, saying the Russians were trying to intimidate him by turning off his utilities. "They were trying to make my wife and children uncomfortable, to drive the American partner out," he said.
"Preposterous," Mr. Zakharov replied with a shrug.
 
Nonpayment of Salaries
 Each side has a different version of how the relationship soured, and a competing list of grievances. Mr. Zakharov said the Americans refused to pay the hard-currency salaries and bonuses they had agreed upon, including his own. That was supported by Richard D. Williams, the construction manager, who quit Senie Kerschner and stayed on at Rosinka, working for the Russians.
"They just didn't have the money to stay on for the long term," Mr. Williams said. "They were using so-called 'fees' out of here to prop up their business at home."
The relationship was irreparably damaged when Mr. Zakharov brought together a group of Russian businessmen, including himself and Viktor P. Malnev, general director of the farm, to buy some of its shares. The collective farm, under Mr. Malnev's leadership, agreed to sell, but the American partners refused.
Christopher Senie said Mr. Zakharov was trying to enrich himself and wrest control of the property. Mr. Zakharov said he was only trying to raise money for a farm community in desperate financial straits. The director, Mr. Malnev, declined to be interviewed, saying he was too busy trying to keep the collective farm afloat.
There were other battles, but both sides agree that the critical issue was the $2.1 million each says the other stole. The Americans, who say they spent $2.1 million in expenses just trying to put together a financing package, hired the Moscow office of the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, which reported that the money could be accounted for. A Russian accounting firm drew the opposite conclusion.
"I'm not saying either side is at fault," said Donald E. Meske, president of Deluxe Homes of Pennsylvania, in Berwick, Pa., which built Rosinka's houses and guaranteed its first construction loan, $1.5 million from the First Eastern Bank in Wilkes-Barre, Pa.
"I think both sides are at fault," Mr. Meske said, noting that he is still owed the $1.5 million. He said he expected Mr. Zakharov to repay it soon, in which case, he would enter into new deals with him.
The directors of Senie Kerschner say their last resort is in arbitration in Swedish courts, under the joint-venture agreement, but even there, each side says the other is stalling.
 
Back on the Collective Farm . . .
 Rosinka itself -- serene, well-tended and eerily quiet -- appears unruffled by the fight over its control. "It's a little bit like living in the twilight zone," Richard A. Conn said smilingly of the suburban patch grafted onto Russian soil. Mr. Conn, managing partner of Latham & Watkins's Moscow law office, said the Russian managers and maintenance workers "do a great job."
"We have no complaints," he said.
On the collective cattle farm that now owns Rosinka, the commotion over the joint venture is unnoticed. Lenin's statue still presides over the main entrance, faded Communist exhortations to produce are still posted on a giant red billboard, and very little meat or milk is being produced by the 400 workers who are housed, fed and employed there.
Though the farm is technically independent now and owned by the workers, five-year plans seem alive. None of the workers interviewed had any sense that they owned shares of their farm, or for that matter, a piece of the shining American hamlet on the hill.
"I've seen it on TV," a ruddy-faced welder named Nikolai remarked. "I've never gone to look at it," he added with a wry smile. "It would only upset me to see those rich houses."

HEADLINE: District of Columbia May Seek Federal Bailout

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The District of Columbia has such financial problems that it may be forced to borrow money from the Federal Government to pay its bills, a blow to efforts by the municipal government to win more independence from Congress, officials say.
"The situation is that they have really had unbalanced budgets for the last several years," said Philip M. Dearborn, a financial research director of the United States Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations. "They've used up all their cash and are in a very difficult cash situation now." 
 The possibility of a Federal bailout was reported today in The Washington Post, which quoted officials as saying that borrowing from the Government was under consideration. "We are exploring our authority for borrowing from the Treasury," Ellen O'Conner, the District's chief financial officer, told the newspaper. She could not be reached for comment today.
Already, the District gets about one-fifth of its $3.4 billion budget from the Government; the rest is supposed to come from taxes and fees.
To avoid a bailout, which many politicians here would see as undermining the District's efforts to gain more control over its own affairs, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly has proposed postponing a required payment of $230 million to the city's pension fund this year. That would allow the District to end the year with $75 million, but it would also face challenges in the courts and in Congress and seemed unlikely to succeed.
Cutting spending enough to find the pension money is virtually impossible, officials say.
The District of Columbia, though governed by a Mayor and a 13-member City Council, is a unique entity whose political decisions, including its budget, can be vetoed by Congress. The District does not have the power that the states and some cities do to raise money, but it still must provide the kind of services that states do -- welfare, Medicaid, prisons and courts.
The District is also prohibited by Congress from taxing commuters to recoup the cost of public services used by suburban residents who work in the city. Moreover, half of the real estate in the District is exempt from taxation because it is used by the Government, embassies or nonprofit institutions.
The city has faced financial problems since it won limited political independence in 1974. During Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s 12 years in office, the city borrowed $150 million to $300 million a year from private lenders. Mayor Kelly eliminated that practice with a $336 million bond sale in 1991, at the end of her first year in office. That erased the city's accumulated deficit and put the District in its best financial condition since limited home rule began, experts say.
But over the last three years, the city's budget has been balanced only through a series of accounting maneuvers. City officials said the financial cushion from the bond sales was used to provide city services during the recent recession. Now the Mayor's Office projects that if nothing is done the city's annual deficit will increase to almost $800 million by the year 2000 from $225 million in 1996.
 
Council Chairman's Frustration
 John A. Wilson, the late chairman of the District of Columbia City Council, had voiced concern over the city's financial state after the Rivlin Commission reported four years ago that the city would become insolvent without major cuts in spending and substantial increases in revenue. Some associates attributed Mr. Wilson's suicide last year to his frustration with the city's failing fiscal health.
"To go back to the Treasury now -- and that's assuming the Treasury would honor their requests -- is a step away from home rule," said Mr. Dearborn, a longtime analyst of the city's finances who was once a financial adviser to Mr. Barry. He said if such a request was honored, "based on what has happened in Philadelphia, New York, and Cleveland, there would be some kind of oversight board, some kind of supervision."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Russia: A Tougher Tone and a Shifting Glance

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Stung by months of criticism that it has favored Russia unduly, the Clinton Administration has altered its policies, adopting a tougher tone toward Russia and focusing more than before on other former Soviet republics.
Although the Administration seems too proud to admit that any new approach was needed, there is an unmistakable change in tone toward a newly nationalist Russia and far more emphasis on bolstering the security and economies of the other republics. 
 The recent visits of the presidents of Ukraine, Georgia and Kazakhstan have demonstrated this new focus and appear, at least in part, to be a response to the many criticisms from Congress and foreign policy experts that the Administration has maintained a Russia-first policy.
"The Administration is reeling from the criticisms of its Russia policy," said Morton Abramowitz, director of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "I think we're seeing a certain amount of rethinking and repositioning."
Evidence of that can be seen in President Clinton's decision to double economic aid to Ukraine and Kazakhstan and his call for an international peacekeeping force to help end Georgia's civil war -- a move that is widely seen as an effort to check Russia's muscle-flexing beyond its borders.
 
Insuring Independence
 Administration officials say their stepped-up efforts to help the economies of Ukraine and other non-Russian republics are another way to insure their continued independence.
"We feel economic security is inextricably related to political and military security," Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott said in an interview. "If these countries undergo a profound and protracted economic crisis, it will undermine their viability as states. Ukraine is a particularly vivid example of that."
Reluctant to give an inch to critics who have attacked their policy, Mr. Talbott and other Administration officials deny that the visits of the leaders betoken a change.
But at the same time, the Administration is proud to point out that it is spending more energy and money than before on the 14 non-Russian republics. Officials are also happy to note that while Russia received more than half the aid to the former Soviet Union over the last two years, next year more than half will go to other republics.
"They are changing their policy somewhat, but are reluctant to admit it," said Zbigniew Brzezinski, the Carter Administration security adviser who has repeatedly criticized Mr. Clinton for tilting toward Russia. "They are being more even-handed and are emphasizing much more than in the past that they're interested in what I call 'geopolitical pluralism,' meaning the preservation of the states other than Russia."
 
Showing New Toughness
 After the surprising surge of nationalist forces in Russia's elections in December, Moscow's foreign policy statements have grown more shrill, and in response Washington has shown a new toughness.
While there is plenty of talk about the need for Russian cooperation to bring peace in the Mideast and Bosnia, the Administration's warnings about Russia's nationalist ambitions are far more frequent and slightly firmer than before.
In a speech on Monday, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said the United States must help Russia consolidate its transition to democracy, but cautioned that "it is possible that Russia will emerge from the turbulence as an authoritarian, militaristic, imperialistic nation hostile to the West." Mr. Perry's recommendation -- one that should please those who say the Administration has pampered Russia -- was that Pentagon must keep up its defenses. Mr. Perry is traveling his week in Russia, Kazakhstan, Ukraine and Belarus.
When President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine visited two weeks ago, Mr. Clinton and other officials repeatedly emphasized that they support the "territorial integrity" of Ukraine at a time when Russian nationalists are clamoring that Crimea belongs to them and not Ukraine.
Perhaps because they do not want to offend their friend, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, or perhaps because they do not want to acknowledge that there may be a need for any mid-course corrections in policy, Administration officials are reluctant to discuss their approach in terms of a tougher stance.
Mr. Talbott said the Administration has always stressed maintaining the territorial integrity of the former republics. Nonetheless, many foreign policy experts say the Administration's frequent recent assertions of that view regarding Ukraine, Georgia and the Baltic republics signal such a change in the face of increased Russian nationalism.
"They're moving in the right direction, but I'm not going to start applauding the Administration yet," said Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the senior Republican on the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, He has threatened to vote against new Russian aid because he says the Administration has improperly favored Moscow. "I'm still not convinced we've seen a real change in policy," he said.
The way Mr. Talbott explained it, the Administration has naturally paid more attention to Russia than to other republics because it is the biggest republic and because the others would be greatly affected if Russia's democratization and economic reforms fail.
He described the warmer relations with Ukraine and Kazakhstan as a response to their decisions to eliminate nuclear weapons and get serious about economic reforms.
"There is broad continuity in our policy," a senior Administration official said. "But as events change, our policy has evolved with them."

HEADLINE: Mail Order Shifts Its Pitch to Cable

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Direct mail is about to become even more direct.
Eight catalogue retailers are bypassing the post office and beaming their merchandise right into homes. Catalog 1, the new cable shopping channel developed by Time Warner and Spiegel that hits the airwaves in four test markets next Monday, features the wares of eight well-known retailers with sophisticated direct-mail operations. 
 The channel makes its debut at a time when consumer complaints about cluttered mailboxes are growing louder and angrier and when electronic retailing threatens to make catalogues obsolete.
But Catalog 1 is more than an "if you can't beat 'em, join 'em" effort. From the way its business is structured to the goods it will try to sell and the pitch it will use to sell them, Catalog 1 is breaking the television shopping mold set by Home Shopping Network Inc. and QVC Network Inc.
Highbrow production techniques and scripts that read more like afternoon talk shows than sales spiels are aimed at enticing affluent shoppers who have thus far eschewed electronic retailing. Catalog 1 will feature merchandise from Spiegel and its Eddie Bauer outerwear subsidiary, as well as from Williams-Sonoma, Sharper Image, Neiman Marcus, the Nature Company, Crate and Barrel and the Bombay Company.
And unlike QVC and the Home Shopping Network, whose fees and other requirements make it almost impossible for a retailer to make a profit selling on their networks, the direct-mail companies participating in Catalog 1 are paying the channel about what it would cost them to produce and mail a catalogue.
"We're not trying to create just another shopping channel," said Rod Parker, the former Spiegel executive who is the manager of Catalog 1. "We're trying to create an entirely new channel of distribution for people who already have distribution through other channels, like retail stores and catalogues."
 
An Expensive Experiment
 But Catalog 1 and several other shopping channels being introduced this year must also prove that high-end electronic retailing is cost effective. Although the company will not discuss its finances, retail consultants believe Catalog 1's cost to produce a single program for its participants is probably between $300,000 and $500,000, about as much as for the highest quality "infomercials" -- lengthy television advertisements that appear to be programming.
"Because of the technology, it's going to be a lot more expensive than the average retail test, and companies are going to have to be in it for the long haul," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Marketing, a consulting firm in New York. "That's the real question for me."
Being on the set of Catalog 1 incites the same sense of incredulity that Clara must have felt when she crept downstairs on Christmas Eve and found the Nutcracker dancing about her living room.
"It's a cross between '20/20,' the evening news, a talk show and the very best infomercials," said Richard Thalheimer, chairman and chief executive of Sharper Image. "It gives the merchandise a context that you can't provide in a catalogue."
Suddenly the candlesticks, plates, carpets and other tchotchkes that are so one-dimensional on the pages of Neiman Marcus's Horchow Collection catalogue of home furnishings come to life, seeming to have a place in the real world that they lack in the suspended fantasy of glossy photographs and grand descriptions.
 
Tips on Home Decorating
 Carol Helms, creative director of Metropolitan Home magazine, demonstrates how to mix and match chargers, plates and napkins from the Horchow Collection, chatting all the while about entertaining in the 90's. She talks about societal trends and how they relate to entertaining and decorating while demonstrating how to use items from the collection to achieve a contemporary look.
"Let's talk about the new informality, about gathering around a table with family or friends and about how the beautiful things from the Horchow Collection can help us do that," she says.
A segment on a snore control device sold by Sharper Image takes place at a sleep research laboratory, where a doctor who specializes in sleep disorders explains why people snore.
On Catalog 1, the line between selling and telling is much fuzzier than on QVC or the Home Shopping Network, where program hosts shamelessly hawk products, and where horns and whistles are used to keep viewers attentive. The risk in such low-key selling as Catalog 1's is that the potential shopper will have trouble distinguishing between entertainment and marketing.
But Mr. Parker cited a survey from Yankelovich Partners that found that women are more interested in information about the products they might buy than in a sales pitch. The appearance of an "800" number and a description of the merchandise will also help remind Catalog 1 viewers that they are listening to a sales pitch.
 
Ability to Recycle Programming
 Mr. Parker predicts that Catalog 1 will ultimately prove more profitable for its owners than QVC and the Home Shopping Network, which broadcast much of their sales spiel live.
"We have the ability to repeat, re-use, edit, literally recycle the existing product into an entirely different program if we want," he said. "That ability will allow us to amortize the production costs over time in a way that you can't with live broadcasts."
For example, the footage shot for Catalog 1 is also being used to develop a shopping channel for Time Warner's interactive cable system that is scheduled to begin its test run in Orlando, Fla., later this year.
While the jury will be out for some time on whether Catalog 1 can earn its keep, it has at least devised a cost structure for its catalogue partners that virtually guarantees them a return in the short term: the partners pay Catalog 1 between 20 percent and 30 percent of the sales they make on the channel.
 
Test to Reach 400,000 Homes
 "For the first time, retailers, whether they be Neiman Marcus or a traditional catalogue retailer like Spiegel, can get into this new business within an economic framework that allows them to make money," said R. Fulton MacDonald, president of International Business Development, a retail and marketing consulting firm.
Catalog 1's first test will reach about 400,000 homes in Nashua, N.H.; Columbus, Ohio; Rochester and suburban Milwaukee. The participants do not expect the initial test to have any significant short-term impact on their sales or profits, although some of them believe the programming may ultimately add as much as $50 million to their sales annually.
"There's no way anyone is going to make any money on this thing for a while," said B. D. Feiwus, president of Neiman Marcus Direct, which operates the Horchow Collection and the company's other catalogues. "That's not the purpose."
Instead, Mr. Feiwus and others say, the limited introduction will give them an opportunity to measure the potential impact on their businesses in a controlled manner and then plan accordingly with staff and inventory.
QVC and the Home Shopping Network charge participants between 40 percent and 50 percent of sales, which makes it almost impossible for a retailer or cataloguer to turn a profit. Those channels charge more because they process each order that comes in, handling everything from the operators who take calls from viewers to warehousing, sorting, packaging and shipping.
In contrast, Catalog 1 participants will handle their own orders through the same distribution systems they use to process catalogue orders.
 
Valuable Customer Information
 "The economics of Catalog 1 offer retailers something no one else in this business has yet offered them -- a way to make a profit," said Mr. Thalheimer, whose Sharper Image did an hourlong program on QVC earlier this year.
Because they will process their own orders, the catalogue operators will glean valuable information about their customers. "The information you gain from processing a transaction -- names, telephone numbers, addresses -- is what you need to build a relationship with a customer," Mr. Feiwus said. QVC and Home Shopping Network do not share that information with their vendors.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Seeks to Sweeten Proposals for Tax Cutting

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo wants to sweeten his election-year package of tax-cut proposals by giving credits to companies that paid taxes on operating losses from 1990 through 1993, most of them large manufacturers and securities concerns.
The retroactive credits represent a new twist on a tax-reduction proposal made by Mr. Cuomo in January when he introduced his $33.4 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning on April 1. In his original plan, Mr. Cuomo called for giving companies credits on future operating losses. 
 The retroactive credits would cost the state about $150 million but could be phased in over several years, Cuomo aides say.
Securities concerns, which provide 144,000 jobs in New York State and are major campaign contributors to both major political parties, have been the most aggressive in lobbying for the retroactive credit. The industry suffered large operating losses in 1990 and 1991 and would receive between $30 million to $40 million of the credits, according to state and industry estimates.
 
'A Very Clear Signal'
 As with other aspects of the Governor's tax-cut package, Cuomo aides portray the retroactive tax credit as a way to encourage companies to stay or expand in the state, which has been racked by tens of thousands of layoffs in just the last year.
"It's a major issue for some of the biggest employers in the state," said Andrew J. Zambelli, Mr. Cuomo's secretary. "It sends a very clear signal that New York State is trying to be fair."
But the proposal also underscores the perception held by many that Mr. Cuomo feels vulnerable on economic issues. A recent poll by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie showed that taxes and jobs are among voters' main concerns. The same poll showed Mr. Cuomo's approval rating at 36 percent, near its all-time low.
The retroactive tax credit has been supported in somewhat different form by the Republican-led State Senate. However, it has received a cooler reception among Mr. Cuomo's fellow Democrats in the Assembly, where some lawmakers view it as an election-year giveaway to an industry that has been highly profitable in recent years. Many Assembly Democrats want to spend additional revenues in next year's budget on social services for the poor or tax cuts for the middle class.
 
Concerns About Cost
 Assembly Democratic leaders support expanding a Cuomo proposal to give low-income working families a tax credit. Mr. Cuomo has agreed to discuss the expansion, but his staff has expressed concerns about the cost.
In conversations with Mr. Cuomo and security industry officials, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has said he wants assurances that financial concerns that benefit from the retroactive credits will keep their jobs in New York State.
"We are now being pressured by Jersey City and Greenwich, Conn., which are seeking our downtown jobs," said Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat. "I think it is important to know that if we do these things, they have an effect on the economy, on the job picture here."
Last week Mr. Silver received what he considered such assurances from Robert Denham, the chairman of Salomon Inc., which has 4,000 employees in New York State.
"We told the Speaker that what we expect of the state is a fair business environment, and as long as there is a fair business environment, it is our desire to remain here," said Saul Rosen, a managing director at Salomon.
Mr. Cuomo's tax-cut proposals, which are subject to Legislative approval, include reducing the state corporate surcharge, giving tax credits to poor working parents and phasing out the state tax on hotel rooms that cost over $100 a night. When fully put into effect over the next several years, the cuts would cost the state more than $800 million in revenues.
With only two weeks left before the current fiscal year ends, budget talks are stalled on a wide range of issues, and some negotiators now think it inevitable that the state will have a late budget for the 10th consecutive year.
Mr. Cuomo's newest tax-cut proposal would affect the state's 5 percent minimum tax, which is assessed on companies that have accumulated enough tax credits to reduce their state corporate taxes to little or nothing.
New York does not currently allow companies to use past operating losses as a deduction when filing minimum taxes. Mr. Cuomo's proposal would give those companies a credit, which could be used to reduce future taxes, for minimum taxes paid on operating losses. And it would make the credits retroactive to taxes paid since 1990.
 
'An Inequitable Tax'
 Lobbyists for the securities industry argue that the Federal Government and most other states already provide such credits, and they suggest some companies might sue the state if it does not change its law. They also contend that the state could pay for the credits using a "windfall" from new tax laws that increase state revenues from securities concerns by between $150 million and $250 million a year starting this year.
"The state has an inequitable tax that is about to get more so," said Jeffrey M. Schaefer, senior vice president of the Securities Industry Association, a trade organization representing 140 New York State-based securities concerns.
In other aspects of the budget talks, Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders remain deadlocked over a Medicaid takeover plan, welfare cuts, school aid and criminal-justice issues.
 
Local Medicaid Costs
 Under a Cuomo proposal, the state would assume local Medicaid costs gradually over the next eight years in exchange for receiving a portion of local taxes. But this has encountered resistance from both Senate Republicans, who want to slash Medicaid services, and some Assembly Democrats, who say the proposal will have little benefit for upstate cities.
With little time left, some negotiators now say it is likely that, at most, only a partial takeover of local costs can be achieved.
Mr. Cuomo and the leaders do seem to be moving closer on how to cut Medicaid costs. Both the Senate and the Assembly had said Mr. Cuomo's proposal to reduce costs by $185 million was too onerous for poor people and hospitals. Mr. Cuomo has now agreed to reduce the cuts, starting by restoring about $17 million for transportation services.
But in an indication of how slow talks are progressing, Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders remain unable to agree on how much money the state will have to spend next year, which is usually the starting point for serious budget discussions.

HEADLINE: Lawyers in New York Defend Their Right to Mislead

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., March 19

 BODY:
Ten months after Armand P. D'Amato was convicted of fraud in a scheme to influence his brother, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York legal establishment has taken up his cause, saying he was convicted of something many lawyers do and should be allowed to do: filing misleading bills.
While the case drew much attention with revelations that an official at the Unisys Corporation had paid Mr. D'Amato to win access to the Senator, as a legal matter the crime was not influence-peddling but mail fraud. Mr. D'Amato was convicted and sentenced to five months in prison because his law firm sent bills to Unisys for consulting work that Mr. D'Amato never did. 
 Now, as Mr. D'Amato pursues his appeal, his case has become something of a cause celebre in legal circles. Five bar association groups, along with the prominent New York lawyer Arthur Liman, have filed a brief on Mr. D'Amato's behalf, and he has also found an ally in the New York Civil Liberties Union.
The bar groups maintain that billing practices like Mr. D'Amato's are commonly employed and are protected by the confidential relationship between a lawyer and client. They say lawyers have the right to obfuscate or even misstate their charges if a client asks them to.
But others are surprised and angry about Mr. D'Amato's newfound support. Richard Uviller, a former prosecutor and professor at Columbia University Law School who teaches criminal law and ethics, said, "I frankly am ashamed of the bar associations and Arthur Liman for arguing that deception should not be liable for criminal prosecution."
A bill is "a lawyer's statement of what he did," the professor said. "A lawyer is not required to lie, even at the request of a client. A bill that states that services were rendered for something not rendered is a deceptive statement."
But in briefs filed in January, Mr. D'Amato's lawyers for the appeal, John L. Warden and Robert J. Giuffra Jr., the five bar groups and the Civil Liberties Union said that such billing practices were not unusual and that using them as a basis for convicting Mr. D'Amato could have serious repercussions.
"We're clearly concerned with an overcriminalization of the law," Mr. Liman said. "If the management of a corporation asks that a bill be described in general terms rather than specifically, can that be treated as a fraud on shareholders, especially when the management of the corporation knew what the services were, that they were of lawful purposes, and asked that the description be opaque?"
This case, Mr. Liman added, is part of a "tendency to use criminal law where the issues are ethical, not criminal."
And a brief by the Civil Liberties Union called for a reversal of Mr. D'Amato's conviction, because there is "no evidence that the Federal mail fraud statute was ever intended to reach this far." Based on previous decisions, the brief argues, the law should not be applied to minor corporate transactions, like Mr. D'Amato's deal with Unisys, that do not cause a substantial economic loss for shareholders and that do not conceal illegal activity, like bribery or kickbacks. The Government disagrees with this interpretation.
 
Free on Bail
 Mr. D'Amato, 49, formerly a partner in a thriving law firm in Mineola, is free on $10,000 bail pending his appeal. He was convicted on May 7 of seven counts of mail fraud involving $32,500 he was paid by Unisys for several reports that he did not write.
At his trial, the Federal Government argued that Mr. D'Amato was hired by a rogue Unisys employee to provide access to his brother. They said he defrauded the company by taking part in a billing scheme to conceal the true reason the company hired him.
The Senator has said he was unaware of his brother's arrangement with Unisys.
At the trial, both sides agreed that Armand D'Amato's lobbying of his brother was not illegal. Indeed, at a sentencing hearing in October, Stephen P. Scaring, Mr. D'Amato's trial lawyer, argued that Mr. D'Amato had provided "true value" to the company, describing him as a man who could "reach out to Senator D'Amato not like everyone else can," who could contact the Senator "by picking up the telephone," and who could "get a letter written maybe that wouldn't have been written otherwise."
 
Simply Following Orders
 As Mr. Scaring told it, Mr. D'Amato was simply following the billing orders of the executive who hired him and had provided other valuable services that the bills did not mention.
But the Government contended that Unisys was defrauded because top Unisys officials would not have agreed to pay Mr. D'Amato for such ethically questionable services.
The two sides disagree over whether Mr. D'Amato's contacts at Unisys were acting without proper authorization, and if so, whether Mr. D'Amato knew it.
A major piece of evidence was a purchase order that Mr. D'Amato told his law partner, Jeffrey Forchelli, to sign in February 1988. The order was for reports on Congressional proceedings that Mr. D'Amato never wrote. He admitted in court that Unisys employees had written the reports, none longer than five sentences, and given copies of them to him to place in his files.
The prosecution argued that this arrangement was so unusual that Mr. D'Amato must have realized something strange was going on.
But the bar groups, in their brief, gave examples of similar situations in which they said lawyers, at their clients' request, might properly send bills that are vague or misleading in their description of services.
For instance, the groups said, a law firm working for a corporation planning a major acquisition might slip the charges into bills for other services so that others in the company would not learn of the potential purchase. Similarly, a law firm might conduct a confidential investigation of a company employee accused of wrongdoing and then roll it into bills for other services to protect the employee's reputation.
And a law firm, again at a client's request, might also bill for complex litigation under a different corporate budget line if the company had reached the internal budget limit for the litigation and the company still wished to pay the firm promptly.
In each of these instances, under the Government's theory of the D'Amato case, the outside lawyers would be "chargeable with mail fraud" even though the company was not harmed, the brief says. "It would criminalize a broad range of conduct that until now no one would have reasonably considered to be illegal," the brief concludes.
The brief noted that even Judge Jacob Mishler, who presided over the case in Federal District Court in Uniondale and upheld the verdict, conceded at Mr. D'Amato's sentencing hearing that "maybe one out of 100 would say no" to the deal that Mr. D'Amato entered into.
Besides the State Bar Association and Mr. Liman, the other groups signing the brief were the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, the New York State Trial Lawyers Association and the New York Criminal Bar Association.
In a separate brief, the Civil Liberties Union argued that the way the Government used the mail-fraud law against Mr. D'Amato violated the constitutional right to due process. "The mail-fraud statue would reach so much day-to-day corporate activity as to render the statute entirely open-ended and susceptible of invocation whenever and wherever law-enforcement officials seek its deployment," the brief states.
Arthur Eisenberg of the New York Civil Liberties Union explained, "It violates our civil right to know what is and what is not prohibited, and the statue is so open-ended that it gives unfettered discretion to prosecutors."
The case has not yet been scheduled for oral arguments before the Second Circuit Court of Appeals, though lawyers said they expected it to come before the court in the next few months.
 
'Rogue Employees'
 While the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District declined to discuss the issue, its brief rejected the claims of the lawyers' groups, insisting, "Nothing in this case threatens to criminalize any form of legitimate conduct by attorneys." It maintained that Mr. D'Amato's situation was different because he was not dealing with an authorized representative of the company, but with "rogue employees."
Professor Uviller said it was unfortunate that the bar groups saw this appeal as important to the profession. "I am appalled at the ease with which lawyers lie," he said. "I don't want to share the popular myth about lawyers, but I find that the authority of the profession is undermined by this cavalier attitude toward their own honor and their own obligation to be scrupulous about the truth."

HEADLINE: North Korea Bars A-Plant Survey; Threatens to Quit Nuclear Treaty;
Japan Seeks Chinese Help

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 20

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan pressed Chinese leaders today to exercise greater influence on North Korea so it would give up any nuclear ambitions, saying he was "gravely concerned" about the looming crisis.
"More than any other country, China has the deepest relations with North Korea," Mr. Hosokawa said at a news conference today after talks with President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng. "Therefore China could work to move North Korea in a positive direction instead of a negative one." 
 But there were conflicting reports about the Chinese response. Japanese Foreign Ministry officials, briefing reporters on two hours of talks between Mr. Hosokawa and Mr. Li, said the Chinese Prime Minister had pledged to "persuade North Korea" to accept full inspection of its nuclear sites.
The official New China News Agency, however, reported that Mr. Li had "stressed that the issue should be solved through dialogue and negotiation," which has been China's longstanding position.
Asked if Japan would support possible sanctions, Mr. Hosokawa said his Government would respond "in a responsible way."
The Japanese leader's diplomatic initiative toward North Korea today followed an effort by his aides in November at a meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders in Seattle. Despite low-key and private entreaties to the Chinese leadership at the time, Japanese diplomats said later, they were rebuffed with explanations that Beijing exerts little influence on North Korea.
With Japanese and South Korean officials still hoping that China will do more, there have been indications that Chinese military leaders have stepped up their contacts with their North Korean colleagues. So far, though, all such efforts have been rejected by the North Korean leadership in Pyongyang, prompting Mr. Hosokawa to declare today that "I am gravely concerned about the situation."

HEADLINE: Force Won't Solve Turkey's Kurdish Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Turkish antiterrorism police detained six Kurdish members of parliament after the Turkish parliament voted to lift their immunity March 2. The state security court wants to charge the lawmakers with supporting the Kurdish separatists of the Kurdistan Workers Party, or P.K.K. The action could ruin elections scheduled for March 27, especially as Ankara has brought respected observers in to monitor the election, as requested by the European Parliament. More violence and instability are expected in Turkey, which already suffers from a 10-year war and crumpled economy. 
 From the early 1920's to 1990, Turkish administrations banned the very word Kurd from public discourse. There were bans on Kurdish language, music, clothes and, of course, political organizations and publications focusing on Kurdish issues. The situation changed positively under President Turgut Ozal in 1990.
Recently, however, President Suleyman Demirel and Prime Minister Tansu Ciller have denied the existence of a Kurdish issue in Turkey. They consider it a "terrorist" problem. Therefore, they handed it to generals to "solve." The Turkish military believes it can solve the problem with force. Human rights are violated today more than ever, as reported by Turkish Human Rights. More than 12,000 people have been killed. About 850 villages have been demolished or evacuated. In December, Prime Minister Ciller stated that military operations in the Kurdish region have cost more than $30 billion.
To overcome difficulties caused by its clashes with the P.K.K., Turkey turned to the United States. The Clinton Administration agreed to go beyond military aid and offer economic and political aid. When the House Foreign Affairs Committee raised concern about Turkey's human rights record, State Department officials commented they use private channels to advise on and discuss the issue with Ankara. United States policy toward Turkey has been governed by the Administration's belief that Turkey plays a key role in regional stability from the Balkans to Central Asia.
Events of the last year contradict that belief. Tensions exist between Turkey and such neighbors as Armenia, Iran and Syria because Turkey accused them of supporting the P.K.K. American and European tourists were taken hostage by the P.K.K. Mobil Oil Turk, the third largest producer in Turkey, stopped operations following a P.K.K. attack in September 1992. Many observers predict the situation will be worse this year.
Politicians in Ankara need to be reminded that there is no military solution to the Kurdish issue or to any similar ethnic problem. Turkish interests can be achieved by developing democracy to serve Kurdish interests, too.
 
SALAH AZIZ
President, Badlisy Center for Kurdish Studies
Tallahassee, Fla., March 14, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Film and Television

 BODY:
New York City's feature film industry recovered strongly last year after a poor 1992. Total shooting days, a barometer of the industry's health, rose 65 percent, and feature film starts statewide jumped to 53 from 43. The surge followed a economic recovery in film and television production and the resolution of a labor dispute that led Hollywood studios to boycott the city for seven months in 1990-1991. Last year seven productions started shooting in New Jersey, while Connecticut had none for the third year in a row. Television production in New York City has grown steadily in recent years, but production of commercials has continued to fall off, a trend begun in the late 1980's.

HEADLINE: Look What the GATT Dragged In

BYLINE: By Jean Anne Casey and Colleen Hobbs; Jean Anne Casey is a farmer. Colleen Hobbs is a writer.

DATELINE: HENNESSEY, Okla.

 BODY:
This rural town of 1,800 people is now home to the largest hog-breeding company in the world, the British-owned Pig Improvement Company. For urbanites who think that hogs smell like frying bacon and associate pigs with Wilbur in "Charlotte's Web," here's some news: Pork is political, and pigs are an environmental hazard.
Many European companies, hampered from expanding at home by tough pollution laws, are taking advantage of America's less stringent standards. And the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade will dramatically increase the amount of pork the U.S. can export to Europe -- 624,000 metric tons in 1999, up from less than 100,000 tons in 1991. This will make the U.S. the center of global pork production, and companies are rushing to raise hogs in new places. One Danish company even plans to raise 600,000 hogs in Alaska. 
 The problem with huge hog farms is the manure they produce. The Environmental Protection Agency rates animal wastes among the nation's top 10 sources of pollution. Leon Chesnin, a retired University of Nebraska waste-management specialist, estimates that the waste generated by 10,000 pigs equals that produced by a city of 17,000 people. If the Pig Improvement Company brings 100,000 hogs to Hennessey, as it plans, the result will be the sewage equivalent of 170,000 people.
"These operations are not family farms," says Barbara Grabner of Prairie Fire Rural Action, a support group for family farms. "They are large corporate ventures that attempt to influence state legislatures to eliminate environmental, corporate farming and zoning laws." The result, she says, is "environmental classism" that exploits the residents of sparsely populated areas.
Corporate hog farms collect feces and urine into small ponds lined with plastic sheeting, called lagoons, and the wastes are later used as fertilizer. In practice, this system allows nitrates to leach into the water table and enter the drinking supply. Nitrate contamination can result in circulation problems, and in extreme cases has caused a condition called blue baby syndrome that can be fatal to infants. Pig waste also gives off airborne ammonia, which can cause respiratory ailments.
How bad can the contamination get? Bob Bergland, the Secretary of Agriculture under Jimmy Carter, said this month that the super-concentrated pig industry in North Carolina was in danger of "collapse" because in some counties the "ground is saturated with hog manure."
Because of the oil industry's decline, Oklahoma has been aggressive in courting hog raisers, allocating $8 million to advertise that the state is livestock-friendly. In the name of this lucrative friendliness, Oklahoma is willing to compromise its rural residents' quality of life and health. Last year, the state legislature severely limited landowners' rights to file nuisance suits against these livestock operations. The state is apparently banking on the fact that protests are much more difficult to mount with a scattered, rural population.
The state's system for regulating the livestock industry is a joke. Officials at every state and Federal agency charged with protecting the air and water agree that the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture is in charge of regulating feedyards and their application of animal waste. This department, however, has created a brilliant catch-22: a 1991 rule repealed any regulations pertaining to such operations and no replacement rules have been adopted.
The huge livestock companies say that they are just honest farmers and that standard E.P.A. regulations keep them from making much of a profit. Don't believe it. These are nothing less than factories, and their proliferation is an indication of their profitability. Like any other manufacturing industry, state and Federal regulators should institute and enforce strict controls on emissions.
The Pig Improvement Company has introduced the micropolitics of pork to Hennessey, polarizing the town. Some defend the company as an economic savior; others protest, with equal passion, the odor and pollution they fear will make their homes unlivable. The conflict between economics and quality of life is the 1990's version of a range war, where nitrate tests and sewage studies have replaced wire-cutters and six-shooters. So if you plan to visit the world's largest hog-breeding operation, follow the advice they gave in the Old West; keep your head down, and be sure to drink upstream from the herd.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
One Who Escaped the Ranks of the Endangered

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ERIC DYSON; Michael Eric Dyson, a professor of American civilization and Afro-American studies at Brown University, is the author of "Reflecting Black: African-American Cultural Criticism."

 BODY:

Parallel Time
Growing Up in Black and White
By Brent Staples
274 pages. Pantheon Books. $23.
Debates about black males in our nation have increased in proportion to black men's rising social misery, indexed in withering numbers that barely detail the impact on their lives of informal drug economies, escalating unemployment and stunning rates of homicide. The plight of most black males has become so bad that some social commentators have come to refer forebodingly to black males as an "endangered species." Trapped between statistics and stereotypes, however, the gritty textures and uncomfortable truths of black male life are too often smoothed over to fit easily into pat explanations of either their prosperity or failure. 
 Brent Staples's poignant memoir offers a glimpse behind and beyond the recitation of black male decline. The world in which Mr. Staples was shaped, a world where working-class black people brought value and dignity to their labor and lives, is vividly realized. Mr. Staples, who writes editorials on politics and culture for The New York Times, is a writer of edifying eloquence whose hunger for memory -- for the dirt and light of everyday experience as it is transformed by forces both natural and contrived -- is fed by the discipline of an obsessive will to observe.
He turns time and again in his memoir to the wombs that gave him life, from the community of black women in Chester, Pa., who gathered around his mother and granted him status as an "honorary woman," to the black male circles in which he ran, populated by brothers and cousins, schoolmates and neighborhood boys. Mr. Staples, who was born in the early 50's in the belly of an eastern industrial city, recalls the virtues of the work then available for black men, writing, for instance, of their employment in the shipyards that dominated the area, or, as his father did, driving trucks.
He returns years later to Chester after a decidedly unsettled childhood (the family moved constantly because of evictions), and to Roanoke, Va., where his family, sans father, had sought out earlier roots. There he confronts the postindustrial collapse of the job market, its harmful effects on black males no more powerfully illustrated than in the life and death of his own brother Blake, a drug dealer killed by a vengeful rival.
Blake's life and death provide the narrative bookends of Mr. Staples's remembrances, a mournful reminder that, increasingly, black male life is archetypally embodied in its violent, premature end. With painful, pitiless honesty, Mr. Staples writes of his refusal to attend his younger brother's funeral, and how his repeated, failed attempts to rescue his brother from the inevitable consequences of his drug dealing exacted a costly moral toll. "I mourned Blake and buried him months before he died," he writes. "I would not suffer his death a second time."
At first blush, this seems a callous, cruel act of bad faith, the ritual sundering of family ties by the "successful brother" from a past too painful and embarrassing to bear. But as Mr. Staples's narrative makes clear, events take on a second life when memory and wisdom mingle to give meaning and purpose to the past. His decision to forgo his brother's funeral became part of a lifelong attempt to turn painful isolation into fruitful solitude.
Escape, sometimes thwarted, sometimes painfully realized, is a common motif of these memoirs. When Mr. Staples writes of attending a college near his home in Chester -- the only one of the family's nine children to do so -- as a result of a chance meeting with one of its black professors, he underlines just how tenuously his escape was connected to circumstance, how luck often allows talent to shine.
A less successful attempt at escape -- from the frozen regions of racial stereotyping -- is symbolized in his strange, patently quixotic stalking of the novelist Saul Bellow after Mr. Staples became a doctoral student in psychology at the University of Chicago. Mr. Staples jogged by Mr. Bellow's apartment and tried to force a chance sidewalk meeting because he wanted to be Mr. Bellow, to "steal the essence of him, to absorb it right into my bones." But Mr. Staples came away only with the harsh caricatures of black male life that he found in Mr. Bellow's fiction; he could not escape meaning far less to his idol than what Mr. Bellow meant to him.
Mr. Staples's frustrated quest expresses more than it intends; it speaks to the attempt of black people to secure somehow the approval of a culture that deadens itself to the variety and complexity, the sheer ingenuity, of black life. But there is sometimes a little too much of the fascination with the exotic in Mr. Staples that blinds him to the virtues of what is closer to home. It started early, too. He records that his friendships with black kids in the neighborhood were "largely disappointing" and that "The kids were just like me; there was nothing exotic about them . . . The Polish and Ukrainian boys were alluringly exotic."
But with "Parallel Lives," Mr. Staples has surpassed the need for imitation, revealing a resolutely distinct voice as he negotiates the treacherous shoals of racial identity in American culture. One need not agree with all of his conclusions about how those racial identities are shaped -- much less how they should be politically employed -- to appreciate this moving book. With its army of metaphors marching across the map of the unruly but rewarding terrain where personal experience reflects and refines national identity, "Parallel Lives" reminds us that the best personal writing is born of the courage to confront oneself.
