HEADLINE: Giuliani Tells Blacks His Budget Won't Cut Into the Gains They Have Made

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani told a predominantly black group of business owners yesterday that although his budget-closing plans would be painful, the pain would not fall disproportionately on black New Yorkers.
Speaking at a luncheon of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, the Mayor noted that it was unlikely that many in the audience were among his supporters and he sought to ease fears that his administration's budget plans would be more severe on black New Yorkers 
 "I understand people's disappointment," he said. "But the reality is that I don't want anyone in the city of New York to feel that anyone has taken a step backward, because they have not. People in Harlem, people in the African-American community,made advances over the last three to four years. I don't want to see them diminished."
Although Mr. Giuliani was politely received by the more than 150 people attending the luncheon, leaders of the Harlem business group said that extending the invitation to the Mayor had been a contentious issue for the 1,600-member organization.
Following the luncheon, at the Faculty House at Columbia University, Lloyd A. Williams, president and chief executive of the organization, said that complaints had come from politicians, business owners and religious leaders who are members.
Specifically, Mr. Williams said that some members had complained that Mr. Giuliani had appointed no black deputy mayors and said that they were offended by Mr. Giuliani's dismantling of one portion of the city's women- and minority-business affirmative action plan.
But Mr. Williams said that Mr. Giuliani and his senior aides had been responsive to the Harlem group's requests and inquiries.
In addressing the audience, Mr. Giuliani largely repeated his standard economic message: that the city must reduce the size of the government and lower the tax burden, which he said would attract and retain business.
Mr. Giuliani also expressed support for the designation of Harlem as an urban empowerment zone, a Federal program under which 10 cities nationwide will be selected to receive $100 million each over two years for job training, drug treatment and social services.
While Mr. Giuliani said that Harlem "makes a good case" for being such a zone, he added that it might be best to parcel that money to more than one community in the city. The administration has also been considering requests from the South Bronx and from the Satmar Hasidic Jews of Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He said Federal housing officials had indicated they would not oppose an arrangement to divide the money.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Market Bouncing Back

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Tuesday, March 22

 BODY:
Stock prices were staging a recovery here early today after tumbling in the previous two trading sessions amid concerns about rising interest rates.
At midday, the Hang Seng Index of 33 leading stocks was up 230.97 points, or more than 2.6 percent, to 8,898.00. The index is trying to bounce back from a two-day plunge of more than 9 percent. At the end of trading Monday, it had fallen 28.7 percent since the Federal Reserve pushed up short-term American rates on Feb. 4. 
 Analysts said that Hong Kong traders continued to be worried by widespread expectations that the Federal Reserve would push short-term American interest rates higher after today's meeting of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee.
 
Hong Kong Dollar Pegged to U.S.
 American rate increases often lead to higher interest rates in Hong Kong, because the territory's currency is pegged to the United States dollar.
"There is great concern that we will see a further increase in U.S. interest rates," said Andrew Hall, research director at Morgan Grenfell Asia Securities.
Analysts attributed the selloffs on Friday and Monday mainly to heavy redemptions in mutual funds that invest in Hong Kong stocks, as investors shifted some money into bond funds.
They also said some American investors were cashing out of Hong Kong funds. "U.S. investors want to bring the money back home and keep it closer to where they are," said Mark Konyn, associate director at Indosuez Asia Investment Services.
But there were also mutual fund redemptions in Europe and Japan, David Bulbeck, assistant director at Schroders Securities in Hong Kong, said. Many fund investors are not used to the Hong Kong market's volatility, he added, and sold shares because they were unnerved by the market's recent fall.
"The concern is exaggerated," Mr. Hall said. Other analysts agreed that higher interest rates would not hurt the Hong Kong stock market as much as some investors perceive, despite numerous holdings in interest-sensitive real estate.
The Hang Seng Index more than doubled to 11,888.4 on Dec. 31 last year from 5,437 on Jan. 4, but many investors doubt that the Hong Kong market will be able to repeat that performance this year.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Restrictions on Abortion Take Effect

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 21

 BODY:
The waiting room at Planned Parenthood's abortion clinic here was crowded as usual with somber young women and a few male companions. But today was different. The 14 women were the first group that the clinic was serving under the state's new abortion law, which took effect on Sunday after nearly six years of litigation.
The clinic's staff clearly resented having to comply with the regulations: a lecture on abortion by a doctor; a 24-hour waiting period, and, for women under the age of 18, the consent of a parent or a judge. 
 But women seeking abortions in the Planned Parenthood center and other Philadelphia abortion clinics did not express strong feelings about the law in interviews today. Complaints were few and slight -- "It's a bit inconvenient having to come into the city twice," said a 26-year-old homemaker from nearby Upper Darby -- and a few said the law had some value.
The law requires a woman seeking an abortion to listen to a doctor's 10-minute lecture on the procedure and then wait 24 hours before having it. The procedure itself can take as little as five minutes. If a woman under 18 cannot or does not want to obtain a parent's consent, she can ask a Family Court judge to declare her sufficiently mature to make the decision. The clinic must also provide on request an illustrated booklet about fetal development.
A few women said the law had some value. "It gives me more time to think, to make sure this is what I want to do," said Monica Fisher, an 18-year-old college freshman, who had come to the Elizabeth Blackwell Health Center for Women in Philadelphia.
Ms. Fisher said she had come to the clinic for the 10-minute lecture and to schedule her abortion for this week. "This is probably the hardest thing I'm going to ever have to do," she said.
Connie D. Ringgold, a 38-year-old city worker, found the law less onerous than expected. "When I heard it was harder for women to get abortions, I felt it's not right," she said after the lecture in the Blackwell Center. "But the 24-hour waiting period does give you time to think. You can make sure this is what you really want."
But several women at the Philadelphia Women's Center, another clinic, said the law served no useful purpose. "If you are here, you've already decided," said a 24-year-old unemployed woman who would not give her name.
 
Conflicting Views
 Kathy Coll, president of the Delaware County Pro-Life Federation, said the law's provisions were reasonable, and she pointed to public opinion polls showing widespread support for it among Pennsylvanians. "A child can't even take a school trip without a parent's consent, but you used to be able to perform an abortion on that same child without the parents' knowing," Ms. Coll said. "It's just an outrage that the law took six years to go into effect."
Abortion-rights advocates say the law, which survived challenges all the way to the United States Supreme Court, increases costs for clinics and their patients and creates great hardship for some women, especially for those who do not have easy access to a clinic and for teen-agers from troubled families who must navigate the legal system to obtain an abortion.
Abortion clinics in neighboring states like New York and New Jersey reported no surge in patients today, but they said they expected to see a rise as more women decided they did not want to deal with the new restrictions.
Joan S. Coombs, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Southeast Pennsylvania, said today: "The more we have dealt with the refinements of implementing this law, the more we have been struck by how clear it is that the goal of this law is to interfere with access to abortion. Period."
This morning Dr. Cathy K. Dratman, medical director of Planned Parenthood's clinic here, gave the brief lecture on abortion to the women in the waiting room. She apologized for having to enforce the law and suggested that the women use their votes to change it. "All of you who are old enough to vote need to find out where your elected leaders stand," she said.
Dr. Dratman then read a 1,200-word statement, which described the abortion procedure and its risks, the availability of information about alternatives to abortion, and miscellaneous facts, like a father's responsibility for paying child support if a woman decided to continue her pregnancy. When Dr. Dratman finished, there were no questions.
 
Redundant Lecture
 Dr. Dratman said the required lecture was redundant at her clinic because its counselors had customarily provided this information and more to patients individually before an abortion was performed.
The homemaker from Upper Darby confirmed that, saying the clinic's counselors had already discussed these issues in detail with her when she visited the clinic last week for counseling and laboratory tests. "Some people seem to think that Planned Parenthood herds women in here and brainwashes us to want abortions," she said. "There is a lot of emotion and a lot of thinking behind my being here. It's not a decision I made in one night or one that I'll change in one night."

HEADLINE: Russia Is Holding Up Seed Bought by U.S. For Armenia Relief

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YEREVAN, Armenia, March 21

 BODY:
More than a thousand tons of wheat seed purchased by the United States for this beleaguered country, where there are lines for rationed bread, are being held up by Russia, which is demanding payment of a 30 percent export duty, according to relief organizations and American diplomats here.
Under an agreement signed by the United States and Russia two years ago, no duties are to be imposed on the import or export of relief assistance. 
 Describing the matter as "extremely sensitive," the American Embassy here declined to comment other than to confirm the basic facts as provided by relief agencies.
The wheat seeds, purchased from Russia, have been in the warehouse ready to be loaded on planes since early February, and a desperate moment has arrived for this country of 3 million people, which did not receive wheat seeds that Congress mandated for last winter's planting.
"If the seed doesn't arrive within a day or two, it will be another disaster for this country," said Stuart Willcuts, the regional director in the Caucuses for Save the Children - U.S., which administers American-supplied relief.
Many Armenians these days are eating little more than bread because of extreme shortages of food and high prices for the little available.
Traditionally, about 70 percent of Armenia's wheat, as well as other agricultural products, was imported from Russia, primarily through Azerbaijan. But for more than two years, Azerbaijan has imposed a strict economic blockade of Armenia because of the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, the Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan.
Last fall, as part of an $18 million relief package for Armenia, Congress designated $3 million for wheat seed. It was to have been used for winter wheat, but the United States Agency for International Development was unable to arrange the purchase before the beginning of the winter planting.

HEADLINE: Somalia's Faction Leaders Agree to Form an Interim Government

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 21

 BODY:
Somali faction leaders agreed today on the formation of an interim government and said they would sign a "declaration of national reconciliation" on Tuesday, a United Nations spokesman said.
The spokesman for the United Nations operation in Somalia, George Bennett, said the agreement was reached after several days of talks in Nairobi between leaders of all 15 Somali factions. The meetings were mediated by the United Nations special representative to Somalia, Lansana Kouyate. 
 Mr. Bennett would not give any details of the accord before a public signing ceremony on Tuesday. But the "declaration of national reconciliation" does not spell out the details of distribution of power in a new Somali government, leaving them for the leaders to work out later.
Mr. Bennett said that at the Tuesday ceremony the Somali leaders were also scheduled to announce the site of a conference that would convene in the next few months to determine how power would be distributed and other details.
 
Majority Rule or Consensus
 Still being discussed, United Nations officials said, are issues such as whether a new government should operate by majority rule or by consensus. The leader of the strongest faction, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, does not want majority rule because his faction, although militarily powerful, is relatively small.
If a new government is established, it would be the country's first since Mohammed Siad Barre was ousted in 1991. The groups that toppled Mr. Siad Barre then fell to fighting among themselves, wrecking the economy and the agricultural countryside and contributing to a famine in 1992. An American-led international military operation to feed the hungry and restore order began in December 1992.
"Ambassador Kouyate considers it a major step forward and is very pleased that Somali faction leaders have put their differences behind them and have agreed on a new political strategy for Somalia," Mr. Bennett said. "I'm cautiously hopeful."
 
Last U.S. Troops Leaving
 The public reconciliation between warring Somali factions comes four days before the last American troops are to leave Somalia. United States and United Nations officials say the accord shows that the Somalis are aware that their country cannot go on functioning without some form of an interim administration and that they risk the loss of foreign aid.
The foreign officials are also concerned that large-scale violence might erupt if the vacuum left by the American departure is not filled by a political solution. Already, widespread banditry and looting is increasing throughout southern Somalia. On Sunday, two Italian television journalists were shot and killed as they were driving in the northern sector of Mogadishu, the capital.
Despite deteriorating security, there has been political progress. In the last week there has been a marked change not only in the often bitter relations between the United Nations and General Aidid's faction but also among Somali factions themselves.
An earlier peace initiative broke down in December when General Aidid and his chief rival, Mohammed Ali Mahdi, refused to meet and when General Aidid refused to deal directly with the United Nations, particularly with its special representative, Jonathan Howe, a retired American admiral.
 
Admiral Is Replaced
 Admiral Howe was reassigned in February and was replaced by his deputy, Mr. Kouyate, and since then the Somali general has been taking a more conciliatory stance toward the United Nations.
Then last Thursday in Mr. Kouyate's hotel suite, General Aidid and Mr. Ali Mahdi met face to face for the first time in a year, and talked for three hours.
"It was very, very constructive talks," said Osman Ato, one of General Aidid's chief advisers. "All I can say is that they talked about some form of future government."
The weekend meeting brought together in Nairobi more than 50 Somali leaders. All the major political players were present, including Col. Omar Jess and Gen. Mohammed Hersi Morgan, two rivals who as recently as last month were fighting over control of the southern port city of Kismayu.
"We are no longer warlords but peacelords," General Morgan said.

 BODY:

The Economy
American companies are prospering, but announcements of job cuts this year are more numerous than ever and seem likely to continue. Technological advances let companies produce more with fewer employees. With price increases harder to get, corporate America often maintains profits by slicing labor costs. And job shedding has become fashionable. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Gore Sees Privatization Of Global Data Links

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, March 21

 BODY:
Discussing a favorite theme, Vice President Al Gore told a United Nations telecommunications conference here today that a "planetary information network" should be created to promote economic growth, foster democracy and "link the people of the world."
"It will be a means by which families and friends will transcend the barriers of time and distance," he said. "It will make possible a global information marketplace, where consumers can buy and sell products." 
 The Vice President's proposal sounded somewhat like an international version of the national information infrastructure he proposed for the United States in January.
He offered no American funds or detailed blueprint today and said that the network should be created by private industry.
 
Not Just Privatization
 But his remarks were interpreted as a signal to the representatives of 132 countries gathered here, including business executives, that the United States wanted developing countries to open their telecommunications industries entirely to private enterprise and competition. "Privatization is not enough," Mr. Gore said. "Competition is needed as well."
Argentina, Chile, Peru and some other Latin American countries have sold Government-controlled telephone companies, radio and television stations and other communications systems, bringing vast new capital into the country as well as modern management techniques and technology. But such arrangements often give effective monopolies to the private buyers, raising prices for consumers and threatening to impede the introduction of leading-edge technologies over the longer term.
"Today, there are many more technology options," the Vice President said, "and it is not only possible but desirable to have different companies running competing but interconnected networks."
The potential for the growth of telecommunications is enormous. The 24 richest countries, with 15 percent of the world's population, now have 70 percent of the telephone lines.
Mr. Gore is the highest-ranking member of the Clinton Administration to have come come to South America, on a tour that includes Argentina, Bolivia and Brazil.
In Argentina, entrance into the trade zone created by the North American Free Trade Agreement is a big issue for the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem. The Government believes that such trade advantages could greatly extend the country's three-year economic boom. In addition, there is intense competition with Chile, playing on historical tensions, over which will be first to join the trade pact created by the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Washington has said that until Argentina passes a law that protects intellectual-property rights, it will not become a member of the trade pact.
Mr. Menem has tried for more than two years, under American diplomatic pressure, to get the Argentine Congress to pass a law that would force the nation's pharmaceutical companies to pay royalties when they use American patents. So far, the companies have lobbied effectively against such a law. A joint statement today said, "Vice President Gore welcomed President Menem's personal commitment to passage of legislation improving patent legislation."
Mr. Gore met twice with Mr. Menem, and in addition to the North American trade pact, discussed drug-trafficking and subsidized sales of American grain to Brazil. Argentina, like the United States, exports grain, but does not subsidize grain prices.

HEADLINE: First Fidelity To Buy Bank In Baltimore

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., March 21

 BODY:
First Fidelity Bancorp said today that it had agreed to acquire Baltimore Bancorp for $346 million in cash to expand its 630-office system along the Eastern Seaboard.
"Our view of the geography for First Fidelity, certainly within the immediate time frame, is a franchise that might reach from Boston to Baltimore," First Fidelity's chairman, Tony Terracciano, told analysts during a telephone conference call.
 
Seaport Business Sought
 Mr. Terracciano said he wanted to expand, serving all Eastern Seaboard ports, to accommodate increased business from middle-market companies doing business with Europe. "It positions us in a new market which is experiencing economic growth and which is contiguous to our Philadelphia-area and southern New Jersey operations," he said. 
 The acquisition of Baltimore Bancorp's 42 branches will increase First Fidelity's network to almost 700 branches spanning Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.
To get around the Southeast Regional Banking Pact, which affects states from Florida to Maryland, Baltimore Bancorp will change its charter and become a savings bank shortly before the acquisition. The plan, which has been approved by Maryland's Attorney General and bank supervisor, is subject to final approval by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve and the Office of Thrift Supervision.
 
Price Is $20.75 a Share
 First Fidelity plans to pay $20.75 a share in cash for each share of Baltimore Bancorp, which rose yesterday by $1.25 a share, to $19.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. First Fidelity's shares fell 25 cents on the Big Board, to $45.25.
Baltimore Bancorp disclosed in January that it was in acquisition talks and hired Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. of Baltimore for advice. The $20.75-a-share offer is in line with analysts' expectations of $20 to $22 a share and is more than double the stock's book value of $9.73 on Dec. 31, 1993. Its assets are $2.2 billion.
"The sale price represents a significant return to our shareholders over the average market price of our stock over the last few years," Baltimore Bancorp's chairman, Edwin F. Hale Sr., said.
First Fidelity plans to cut 300 of Baltimore Bancorp's 1,125 jobs.

HEADLINE: Clinton Target: Teen-Age Pregnancy

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
President Clinton's assistants have drafted a plan that urges him to lead "nothing less than a national mobilization" against teen-age pregnancy and promote some of the values that have historically been seized by Republicans, including sexual abstinence.
The plan is intriguing less for its specific recommendations, which are still being debated, than for its thematic thrust. It would use a Democratic bully pulpit to emphasize the importance of work, family and personal responsibility -- the same themes that Republicans have often used in contending that the Democratic Party lacks mainstream values. 
 The plan calls teen-age pregnancy "a bedrock issue of character and personal responsibility." It says the spiraling number of births among unwed mothers is the driving force behind many of the nation's problems, including poverty, crime, drugs and educational failure.
"I think that what is important here is a Democratic President saying it," said Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, who contends that the Democrats have been unfairly accused in the past of neglecting such values."
 
'Dramatic' Events Urged
 The draft has not been circulated in public, and Ms. Shalala agreed to comment on it only after a reporter obtained a copy. "This is, frankly, breathtaking," she said.
The plan calls for Mr. Clinton to conduct several "dramatic Presidential events," while creating a new, non-governmental agency to raise and dispense grants, and sending one million mentors to work in the nation's 1,000 poorest schools.
While the plan echoes themes sounded by the Republicans, officials point to what they call subtle but important differences.
In promoting personal responsibility, for instance, it also emphasizes the need for "enhanced opportunity." And while it talks about helping adolescents to "say no to demands for premature sexuality," it also envisions "family planning" services.
The Democratic embrace of the values agenda comes after a Presidential campaign in which Republicans had less success with it than usual. The Republican Party heavily stressed family values at its national convention in Houston in August 1992, but it was done in a fashion that critics inside and outside the party called harsh and divisive.
 
Uncertainty Over Money
 The paper was developed by a 32-member group drafting the President's welfare plan, and was debated in a closed meeting on Saturday. People who attended said there was general agreement on the overall theme but uncertainty over the amount of money and the actual policies needed.
Several people present at the meeting said Christopher Edley, a White House budget aide, argued that without a significant financial commitment the plan would fail. And Gene Sperling, a White House economics aide, was said to have noted that there are political risks in a public discussion of sexuality and birth control.
"There was a concern that these sets of issues would be misconstrued on the Hill and used for partisan gains," said one person who attended.
Another official urged colleagues to be candid about their own experiences with premarital sex in calling for the availability of birth control. Several people present quoted the official as saying, "We can all admit we enjoyed the pleasures of premarital sex."
 
Praise and Criticism
 The plan drew a mixed reaction today when it was described to Douglas Besharov, a social policy analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization that promotes conservative views.
"This is a terrific message and you applaud Democrats for saying it," Mr. Besharov said. "It stresses that the way to not get poor is to finish school; get a job, any job, and don't have a baby until you get married. This used to be considered a conservative view."
But he questioned some of the provisions. For instance, Mr. Besharov said mentoring programs, which pair part-time counselors with troubled youths, remain unproven.
He argued that distributing birth control through school-based clinics could backfire and encourage early sexuality. And he maintained that the test of the Administration's commitment would reside partly in the amount of money it is willing to provide.
"The solutions are at best naive, and at worst dissembling," he said, contending that the plan's talk of school-based community centers was an euphemism for distributing birth control.
 
Local Officials Have Option
 Secretary Shalala said the decision over whether to offer birth control in schools would be left to local officials. "The President has been very clear on that," she added.
Out-of-wedlock births are an expensive and growing problem. In 1990, unwed mothers accounted for 28 percent of the nation's births, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Two-thirds of the black children born that year had unmarried mothers.
The plan says that almost 80 percent of the unmarried women who had a child before finishing high school are living in poverty. By contrast, the poverty rate is only 8 percent for those who finish high school, marry and have a baby after the age of 20.
"Make up your mind you're not going to have a baby until you are old enough to take care of it, until you're married," the plan quotes the President as saying in a visit to a junior high school last month.
"Is it right or wrong, if you're a boy, to get some girl pregnant and then forget about it?" Mr. Clinton continued. "I think it's wrong."
 
'Putting Children First'
 The strategy envisions several similar talks by the President, organized around the idea of "Putting Children First." It calls for him to make critical remarks about the role of the news media, especially television, "in sending young people damaging messages about sexual conduct, impulse control and violence."
In the 1992 Presidential campaign Dan Quayle, who was then Vice President, was ridiculed when he made similar remarks, singling out the television show "Murphy Brown" for special criticism.
The new private agency would raise money for "challenge grants" that would go to communities with innovative strategies for curbing teen-age pregnancy. The plan emphasizes partnerships with a variety of community groups, including the police, churches, businesses and colleges or universities.

HEADLINE: Political Chaos in Zaire Disrupts Efforts to Control AIDS Epidemic

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire

 BODY:
While many African countries denied the existence of an AIDS problem for much of the last decade, Zaire was different. It had a vigorous prevention campaign, the continent's best-trained scientists and best-equipped laboratories outside South Africa, and a steady flow of money from abroad to help fight the epidemic.
These days, Zaire's fortunes have never seemed bleaker. Recent surveys and anecdotal evidence suggest that the epidemic is accelerating at a startling rate. Some hospitals report that close to 80 percent of their patients are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. 
 Scientists and doctors fear that if current trend continues, Zaire's infection rate may soon exceed those of Uganda, Rwanda and other East African countries hardest hit by the virus, sowing death, disease, sorrow and fear among tens of millions.
 
Political Chaos and Loss of Aid
 The sharp reversal in this Central African country's efforts to fight the epidemic was brought on by two events: Zaire's descent into chaos as President Mobutu Sese Seko, the longtime autocratic ruler, has tried to hold on to power in the face of popular discontent, and the subsequent withdrawal of virtually all economic aid by Western donors. AIDS prevention programs and research have collapsed, and medical workers lack even the money to test blood.
"Zaire is facing a tremendous tragedy," said Dr. Helene Gayle, AIDS coordinator for the United States Agency for International Development in Washington.
Dr. Eugene Nzilambi, director of a research program known as Project SIDA, for the acronym in French for acquired immune deficiency syndrome, said: "I hate to think what will happen if things continue this way. We're back to where we started a decade ago in terms of education and prevention."
He added, "The only thing for sure is that the worst is yet to come."
Like many African nations where infection rates soared in the early 1980's, Zaire first reacted by denying the severity of the epidemic.
It was not until 1987 that the first case of AIDS was officially reported among Zaire's population of about 35 million. Then, Government officials here quietly made it known that they were receptive to foreign scientists and public health specialists who wanted to study what many viewed as the epicenter of a worldwide scourge.
In 1984, Project SIDA, the continent's largest AIDS research program, was started in Kinshasa at Mama Yemo Hospital, which is named after President Mobutu's mother. It is not entirely clear why Zaire's leaders, who have often displayed a suspicion of Western scientists, journalists and even teachers, allowed the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta and the National Institutes of Health, Project SIDA's main sponsors, to carry out intense and painstaking research on tens of thousands of Zairians.
Some say it was because many in Zaire's social and political elite were themselves falling victim to the disease, at rates conspicuously disproportionate to their numbers, and thus had a personal stake in encouraging research. It has become common, in fact, for Zairians to speculate about who among President Mobutu's closest aides are afflicted with the disease.
 
The Poor Die Sooner
 "Rich people here suffer more from the disease than poor people do, because when the first opportune sickness hits poor people, a chest cold or whatever, then they die because they cannot afford the treatment," said John Loftin, an American who has lived in Zaire for 22 years and now heads a condom distribution program. "However, someone with some money is able to go to the hospital, and it goes on, and on and on."
The initial results from Project SIDA were striking. Its studies played a key role in proving that H.I.V. could be spread through heterosexual intercourse, the main mode of transmission in Africa. These and other projects enhanced Zaire's reputation among scientists as a place likely to yield vital clues for fighting the disease.
As evidence grew about how AIDS spreads, the research projects had another salutary effect: in a country where talk about AIDS had been taboo, local officials were prodded to start one of the frankest and most widespread education campaigns on the continent.
Zaire's national committee on AIDS, for example, in cooperation with Psi, a nonprofit American company, began an extensive condom marketing and distribution campaign. Hardly a day would pass without Zairians hearing about the virus in offices, bars, churches or classrooms.
 
Infection Rate Stabilized
 No one knows precisely what effect the research here had on Zaire's population, but though Kinshasa had been hit hard by AIDS, by the late 1980's the rate of infection appeared to have stabilized at 7 or 8 percent of adults.
By contrast, surveys done about the same time in Kampala, the capital of neighboring Uganda, and Kigali, Rwanda, showed infection rates of about 30 percent among adults.
But Zaire's emerging network of research, prevention campaigns and grass-roots social service organizations began to unravel in September 1991, after disgruntled soldiers seeking back pay went on a rampage, pillaging homes and shops and setting off violence that left dozens dead.
Rioting broke out again in February 1993 when soldiers discovered that newly minted currency used to pay them was impossible to spend. Soldiers seized control of the Parliament building and held several hundred lawmakers hostage, demanding that they order local merchants to accept the new bank notes.
 
Research Project Closed
 Hundreds of people, including the French Ambassador, were killed. Since then, Zaire's economic collapse has been staggering, as many of the foreigners who held vital technical and managerial positions have fled.
One result was the abrupt closing of Project SIDA. After the September 1991 rioting, the project's nine foreign scientists -- six Americans, two Belgians and a Frenchman -- were all evacuated. A local staff of about 200 doctors, nurses and technicians was left to guard against looters, but research effectively ended.
"We are completely bankrupt; there's no money at all,' said Dr. Nzilambi, a Zairian educated at the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore, who now heads the project. And while the Government does provide some money to keep the operation from shutting its doors entirely, it is meager even by local standards, Dr. Nzilambi said. For example, he cited his own Government salary, which now amounts to about $5 a month.
Diplomats, relief officials and human rights campaigners say the country's growing chaos has taken what little stability there was for beleaguered individual Zairians.
 
Indifference and Complacency
 "It's hard to focus on the AIDS epidemic when you have an empty stomach, no job and often no place to sleep," said Atondoko Negefa, president of the Zaire Association for the Defense of Human Rights. From a public health perspective, doctors and public health specialists say, many Zairians have become dangerously indifferent to the dangers posed by AIDS and complacent about taking steps to avoid infection.
In particular, many Zairians, out of ignorance or denial, continue to have unprotected sex with multiple partners. The number of garishly dressed young prostitutes along Boulevard June 30, the city's main thoroughfare, has visibly risen in the last six months, reflecting a growing number of customers.
A 22-year-old prostitute said: "I've got two children to feed, and I know I have something that men want to pay for, so why not. It doesn't hurt anybody."
And although condoms are relatively cheap and readily available in most pharmacies, young sexually active Zairians seem increasingly reluctant to use them. "If a girl looks clean, why use a condom?" a 24-year-old university student said. "No man wants to make love while wearing a raincoat."
John Grinling, director of Amo-Zaire, an organization that provides help to families affected by AIDS, said, "It's taken as a kind of insult if a man is asked to wear a condom, because it suggests there's something wrong with him, that he's infected."
 
U.S. Withdraws Aid
 In the early 1990's the United States Agency for International Development employed nearly 70 Americans and several hundred Zairians on various projects. It has since cut back its program here to a lone American, whose job is mainly to sell off the agency's assets and dismiss its Zairian employees.
In another jolt to Zaire's growing need for assistance, last January the World Bank, citing the country's debt arrears, closed all of its projects and transferred its officials elsewhere -- the stiffest action it has ever taken against a member country.
One of the consequences of the withdrawal of aid has been a sharp reduction in the size and scope of the Psi condom distribution program, which was financed primarily by the Agency for International Development.
Four years ago it employed about 80 people full time, but with the loss of funds it is now down to three administrators, three night guards and a driver. One graphic indication of the slackening in the use of condoms is the vast inventory -- more than 23 million, Mr. Loftin says -- now decaying in warehouses here.
 
Condoms Go Begging
 Although the condoms cost less than a penny each, Mr. Loftin says demand for them is now so low that he "can barely give them away." On a broader scale, because of poor testing and weak medical management, health authorities here say the distribution of blood tainted by the virus that causes AIDS has become increasingly common, although the extent of the practice is unknown.
"We just don't have the money to screen blood for the virus," said a doctor at General Makala Hospital, one of Kinshasa's largest public institutions. Since the closing of Project SIDA, the prevalence of H.I.V. infection here has not been well documented.
But the consensus among medical workers is that infection is rampant.
Last year Christine Lusamba, a nurse at the Kingasani Hospital and nutritional center here, said 50 to 60 percent of the patients admitted had tested positive for H.I.V. So far this year, she said, the infection rate is running at 80 percent.
Not far away at Mama Yemo Hospital, Zaire's largest, half to two-thirds of the beds in the internal medicine ward are now occupied by AIDS patients.
Nearly 40 beds are crammed into two large rooms, one for men, the other for women. The patients are surrounded by relatives who sleep on straw mats and try to pull together the money to buy drugs prescribed for their loved ones.
On a recent Saturday afternoon, not a single doctor was on duty. "There's no money in caring for AIDS patients," said one of a handful of weary and dispirited nurses.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Jump as Bond Traders Expect a Fed Increase Soon

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Short-term interest rates jumped to their highest level in nearly 21 months yesterday as investors and dealers sold Treasury securities on expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise its interest-rate target this week.
Traders and investors are focusing on when and how large the next interest-rate increase by the Fed will be. The Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the central bank, meets today for the first time since short-term interest rates were raised on Feb. 4. 
 The longer the Fed waits to raise short-term rates, the more investors grow concerned that the central bank is not being aggressive enough in combating inflation. This fear has already played a major role in pushing short-term interest rates higher and pushing long-term rates near 7 percent.
At the Treasury's weekly auction yesterday, the average rate of a three-month bill was 3.61 percent, up from 3.57 percent last week. The average rate for a six-month bill was 3.90 percent, up from 3.85 percent.
The rate on a three-month bill is now more than a percentage point higher than its low of 2.58 percent on Oct. 1, 1992, and the highest since it was 3.62 percent on June 26, 1992.
Long-term rates also rose yesterday. The yield of the 30-year bond climbed to 6.95 percent, from 6.90 percent on Friday. Its price, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped 21/32 , to 918/32 . The yield on intermediate-term securities also gained, with the yield on the seven-year note rising to 6.17 percent from 6.11 percent.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading specialist at CS First Boston, said the Fed's job now was to raise short-term interest rates and stabilize the market. "Raising interest rates is easy, bringing stability to the market will be more difficult," he said. Some analysts and traders said a half-point increase in the Fed's short-term interest-rate target would lend some stability to the government securities market and show investors and dealers how serious the Fed was about fighting inflation in the future.
The Fed uses the Federal funds rate, which is now 3.25, as its short-term interest rate benchmark. The Federal funds rate is interest banks charge each other for overnight loans. The Fed raised the rate from 3 percent on Feb. 4, its first increase in five years. But many traders have argued that the February increase was too small.
Mr. Alexy said the market would not be satisfied with another quarter of a percentage point increase in the Federal funds rate. But he said traders and investors might be placated if such an increase was accompanied by a half a percentage point rise in the Fed's discount rate, which is now 3 percent. The discount rate is the interest the Fed charges banks for loans. An increase in the discount rate would be seen as another signal of the Fed's toughness, especially because it would lead to an increase in banks' prime rates.
"The problem the market has with a gradual approach to raising rates is that it will get one tightening and still be expecting more," Mr. Alexy said. "How can you expect investors to buy securities if they think rates will be going up again soon. Rising interest rates will cause the securities to lose value."
Mr. Alexy said the timing of any move by the Fed was another concern for the market because dealers worry about the impact of higher rates ahead of the Treasury's sale of $28 billion in new two- and five-year notes today and tomorrow. A poor auction could leave many dealers holding more Treasury securities than they would like.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.13 percent, up from 5.09 percent on Friday, while the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.05 percent, up from 6 percent last week.
Analysts said the widespread speculation that the Fed would increase short-term rates had grown more feverish since Friday's meeting between President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed. Although the White House denied that interest rates or today's policy committee meeting were discussed, many analysts believe that the credibility of the Fed is on the line and that it will have to tighten credit just to prove that Mr. Greenspan was not pressured by the Administration.
Most economists polled by the Reuters news service expect the Fed to tighten with a 25-basis-point increase in the Federal funds rate today. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The Treasury, meanwhile, yesterday reported a budget deficit of $41.6 billion in February, which was smaller than the $44 billion deficit that had been expected. Last month, the Treasury reported a $15.6 billion surplus.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall on Anxiety Over Interest Rates

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Stock traders did not have to reach for their third cup of coffee yesterday. The pre-dawn news of a sharp drop in the Hong Kong market was eye-opening enough. But if today is anything like yesterday, many sleepless traders may be carrying thermoses of coffee with them.
If the Federal Reserve Board does not deliver today the interest-rate increase that traders and investors seem to be demanding, to stem an inflation that does not yet exist, then traders will swoon, and stocks may plunge. Traders will spend the next few days or weeks trying to outmaneuver the expectations that a rate increase is still around the corner. 
 If the Fed does deliver an interest-rate increase, then traders will respond with the Wall Street equivalent of a Gallic shrug. They may even go back to paying attention to something tangible, like earnings for the first quarter, which will soon end. In that case, stock prices may rally.
Then again, stock prices may just drift. "I'm not going to do anything special when the Fed raises rates, unless it's a big number," like half a percentage point, said Ronald K. Stribley, senior portfolio manager for the Glenmede Trust Company of Philadelphia. Glenmede has $1.1 billion under management, about 90 percent of which is in stocks. "If it's a big number, I'd be less aggressive in buying stocks," he said.
 
Plunge in Hong Kong
 In trading yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 30.80 points, to 3,864.85. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2.52 points, to 468.54. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index, which has outperformed both the Dow and the S.& P. 500 recently, fell 6.63 points, to 797.30, after setting two records last week.
An overseas omen stirred the waters early yesterday. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped more than 5 percent, nearly the equivalent of a 200-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. The Hang Seng plummeted merely in anticipation that the Fed would raise interest rates today, which could send Hong Kong investors flocking to dollar-denominated securities.
The Dow's decline yesterday was attributed in part to selling in stocks that were bought after the quarterly expiration of options and futures on Friday. But the magnitude and speed of the Dow's fall was clearly a result of continuing anxiety about interest rates and inflation.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.44 points, to 259.91, on a trading volume of 247.4 million shares. Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks, 1,580 to 627. The American Stock Exchange market value index fell 2.19 points, to 470.77.
Based on the industry groups that make up the S.& P. 500, oil companies like Chevron, telephone companies like Ameritech, chemical companies like Du Pont and electrical equipment makers like Emerson Electric were hurt the most. Many of these stocks are sensitive to cycles in the economy.

HEADLINE: Lazard Finds Brawny Ally for Derivatives

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The growing derivatives business requires brains, to concoct complex financial transactions, and brawn, to have the financial strength to stand by what are generally private contracts between two parties that can extend as long as 10 years.
So when Lazard Freres, the brainy 98-pound weakling of investment banks, decided to start trading derivatives, it needed a muscular financial partner. And today it plans to announce a joint derivatives venture with one of the world's burliest banks, Credit Agricole of France, the 11th largest in the world. 
 Lazard, which is actually three interlocking partnerships in New York, London and Paris, is minimally capitalized; Credit Agricole, with about $300 billion in assets, carries a double-A credit rating. A high credit rating is essential to attract derivatives customers.
Derivatives are really a broad category of transactions whose value is based on -- or derived from -- the movement of stocks, interest rates, currencies or commodities. Common examples include options that protect investors from declines in the stock market, or swaps that let corporations lock in fixed interest rates on their borrowing.
While some standardized contracts are traded on exchanges, many banks and brokerage firms have turned customized derivatives into a high-volume business. Lazard, however, intends to specialize in doing only a handful of complex transactions for large companies.
"We had from time to time started working on problems where these products would have been useful, but we had to farm out the derivative portion," said Michel David-Weill, senior partner of the three Lazard firms. The new venture will allow Lazard to create these products itself and capture what can be very high profit margins.
"Our aim is not to trade or take positions, "Mr. David-Weill said. "Ten or 12 times a year we will solve sophisticated and intricate problems for everybody's benefit." The average transaction is expected to be nearly $1 billion.
Credit Agricole, which already has a more generic derivatives trading operation, is looking for new customers.
"The partnership with Lazard will bring to Credit Agricole new special relationships with multinational companies and experience in structured finance," said Lucien Douroux, the chief executive of Credit Agricole, which is the central organization of more than 3,000 rural banking cooperatives in France. The bank has by far the largest share of the domestic French banking market, but it has been less active in international finance.
Derivatives are becoming increasingly common in corporate finance. In its bid for Paramount, for example, Viacom offered a form of derivatives called "contingent value rights," securities that offered Paramount shareholders some compensation if Viacom's stock declined. Lazard was Paramount's adviser.
One type of deal Lazard might do, executives said yesterday, would be a swap that allowed one company to borrow money from a bank to buy another company, with interest payments on the loan set to rise and fall with the profits of the acquired company. In other words, if the acquisition makes money, the acquirer pays more interest.
 
Some Derivative Examples
 In this case, the acquiring company would pay a portion of its target's profits to the Lazard-Credit Agricole venture, which in effect, would pay the bank's regular interest rate.
"A bank would be much readier to lend to you if it knew that if you got into trouble, your interest rate would be lowered," said Edouard M. Stern, the Lazard partner based in Paris who will be the chief executive of the new derivatives venture.
Another example would be the plight of a company that has taken a 5 percent stake in another company for strategic reasons, but is afraid that the value of its holdings is about to decline. Lazard and Credit Agricole might concoct what is called an equity swap, in which they would pay the company money that would compensate it for any losses on the stock position; in return the company would have to pay them if the stock went up. This transaction would allow the company in effect to sell the stock, but still keep its voting rights.
Bankers Trust, which is one of the leading derivatives trading companies, is also attempting to offer derivatives instruments to large corporations, but it does not have the high-level investment banking practice that Lazard does.
 
Based in London
 The new firm will be called Credit Agricole-Lazard Financial Products and will be organized as a commercial bank, based in London. Three-quarters of the capital will be contributed by the bank and one quarter by the three Lazard Houses: Lazard Freres & Company in New York, Lazard Brothers in London and Lazard Freres & Cie. in Paris.
While the potential loss from the operation to Lazard is limited to its capital contribution, which was not disclosed yesterday, Credit Agricole will stand behind all of the derivatives transactions. As a result, one of its chief contributions to the venture will be financial executives who will monitor risk.
Lazard had offers to form similar partnerships with other banks, but chose Credit Agricole because of longstanding personal relationships, Mr. Stern said. Mr. Stern, the chief executive, is a former banker as well as Mr. David-Weill's son-in-law.
The head of trading and product development for the new venture will be Philippe Magistretti, who was the head of the French derivatives operation for the American International Group, the large insurance company that is also a leading derivatives dealer.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Drops as Traders Await Fed Move on Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped against most currencies yesterday, as many traders stayed on the sidelines or sold dollars because of uncertainty over whether the Federal Reserve would decide today to raise interest rates.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 105.89 Japanese yen, down from 106.16 yen on Friday. It also slipped to 1.6895 German marks from 1.6960 marks. 
 There were widespread expectations in the financial markets that the Federal Reserve would vote to push up interest rates when its policy-making body meets today. But some currency traders were concerned about possible surprises.
"People would rather be light on dollars, and not take too much risk," said Belal Khan, a senior dealer at the Bank of Tokyo Ltd. in New York.
Normally, higher interest rates would help the dollar, since they would result in an increase in the return on dollar deposits, making the currency more popular.
 
Rate Increase Discounted
 But Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, said the market had already priced the dollar as though there had been a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate, a short-term interest rate that the Fed can control. Therefore, he said, only a bigger increase would help the dollar.
The Fed last month engineered a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans.
The dollar was helped against the yen briefly on news that the United States would deploy Patriot anti-missile batteries in South Korea, as tensions increased with North Korea. The dollar is often seen as a haven in times of international conflict.
But "suddenly everyone realized the dollar wasn't going any higher," and they sold it, said Paul Alley, an associate at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, in New York.
Gold prices fell in New York after rising in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery fell $1.30, to $386.30 an ounce.
The British pound also slipped, falling in New York to $1.4895, from $1.4910 on Friday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4310 Swiss francs, down from 1.4420; 5.7623 French francs, down from 5.7830; 1,669 Italian lire, down from 1,675, and $1.3693 (Canadian), down from $1.3698.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Private labels, once dull, no-frills staples, are now being promoted with the fanfare of name brands.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
PRIVATE label is going public.
Private-label products are the pantry staples usually sold under the names of the supermarkets and other stores offering them to shoppers as lower-priced alternatives to nationally advertised name brands. Traditionally, they have been shelf sleepers, clad in prosaic packages, bearing soporific names and promoted only in ad circulars and along the aisles in which they slumbered. 
 In the last five years, value-conscious consumers, willing to forgo glitzy imagery in exchange for tangible savings, have become increasingly willing to try labels not bearing brand names. A report issued last week by the Private Label Manufacturers Association, a trade organization, showed that market share of store brands reached a record 19.7 percent last year, compared with 16.4 percent as recently as 1989, while dollar share climbed to 14.9 percent, compared with 11.6 percent in 1989.
As a result, private-label products are getting wake-up calls in the form of slick packaging, catchy names, broadcast ad campaigns, promotional programs -- even in-store sampling. In other words, retailers are enthusiastically mimicking the sales tactics that manufacturers of packaged goods have pursued for decades.
Indicative of these significant changes is an ambitious effort by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to consolidate the various store brands sold at the chains it owns, including A.& P., Waldbaum's, Farmer Jack, Kohl's and Food Emporium, under the jingoistic banner of America's Choice. The line is planned to grow to more than 1,400 products in a year from 450.
"Our private-label strategy now is to go out and support them with more advertising and marketing approaches," said Michael J. Rourke, senior vice president of communications and corporate affairs at A.& P. in Montvale, N.J. "It's something quite different," he said, "almost a national-brand approach to support the introduction of a new product line."
America's Choice is the subject of a $2.7 million television and radio campaign by Sillery Mayer Skurnik Advertising that runs through next month in markets including Atlanta, Detroit, New Orleans and New York. The softly selling commercials, virtually indistinguishable from image-building ads for name brands, carry the theme "Real value, real savings. That's America's Choice."
And America's Choice will even sponsor an hourlong syndicated comedy-variety special, celebrating its parent's 135th anniversary, on more than 60 TV stations in April.
"The philosophy behind the campaign is that America's Choice is a brand, not a private label," Barry Hogan, vice president of operations at Sillery Mayer in Stamford, Conn., said yesterday. "By building it as a brand, you get long-term identity, not something that will go away."
Mr. Hogan's reference was to a vexatious problem that retailers must confront in selling private-label products: their popularity has historically waxed with hard times and waned with good times. In the inflation-plagued, recession-racked period of the late 1970's and early 1980's, private labels prospered, only to slump during the boom years of the 1980's.
To counterattack, retailers like A.& P., the American Stores Company (Jewel, Star supermarkets) and Safeway Inc. are starting to stress the quality of their private-label lines as much as their prices, if not more so.
"Improving private-label programs, turning them into brands, is a real attempt to extend their value," said Brian Sharoff, president at the private label association in New York. "The idea is to turn them into traffic builders, just as much as any brand."
That, however, is risky because it rests on a daunting premise.
"Once retailers raise their standards for private label and create new brands, they must compete, and will be judged, like other brands," said Bruce Meyers, executive vice president and director of strategy and business development at BBDO New York, an agency that represents brands like Campbell, Gillette and Pepsi-Cola.
"That means all the things consumers expect from a national brand must be present, whereas with private label, the only thing it has going for it is a very low price," he said. "That's good for national brands, because it means they can fight private label on their own turf."
Mr. Rourke at A.& P. acknowledged that in some instances, America's Choice and Master Choice, a so-called premium private-label line, might not be America's choice.
"There are certain categories where the national brands own the taste," he said, citing ketchup. "To most people's tastes, Heinz is ketchup."
"And when we introduced a Master Choice ice cream," he added, laughing, "we thought we had a great product -- and we did; people loved it in taste tests.
"But there is a strong brand loyalty to Ben & Jerry's and other premium ice-cream brands, and we weren't able to crack that. We've taken the products off the market and are reassessing them."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Hits 6-Week High As OPEC Prepares to Meet

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices climbed to a six-week high yesterday ahead of an OPEC meeting on Friday.
Some traders were also concerned about dwindling American crude stocks, and a number of short-sellers bought back futures contracts to cover their positions. 
 On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for April delivery rose 49 cents, to $15.37 a barrel, the highest settlement price for near-term deliveries since Feb. 4.
Heating oil and gasoline futures also jumped sharply. April heating oil rose 0.62 cent, to 45.09 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline rallied 0.70 cent, to 46.62 cents a gallon.
Crude oil trading was dominated by speculation about what changes, if any, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will make in its production quota when the oil ministers of the 13 member nations gather in Geneva Friday for a quarterly meeting.
Most analysts expect OPEC to make no change in its official output ceiling of 24.5 million barrels a day, because Saudi Arabia and other big producers seem more concerned with maintaining market share than with cutting production to push up prices. Demand for crude remains relatively slack because of economic weakness in Europe and Japan.
But OPEC is unpredictable. "There's still the small possibility of a cutback," said Andrew Lebow, an analyst at E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York. He said the jump in crude prices yesterday reflected the market's attempt to assess the probability that OPEC will reduce production rather than roll over the current quota into the second quarter.
A rollover would not necessarily mean lower prices in the months ahead, said Bob Baker of Prudential Securities Inc. "I think the world's got a fairly tight supply environment out there," he said. "This fairly tight market is giving us strength."
Supplies are tightening in Europe because of maintenance work that has shut down an important offshore drilling platform in the North Sea. A growing economy in the United States has also helped to tighten supplies.
Weekly inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute, an industry trade group, showed that American crude stocks in the mid-continent area were more than 14 million barrels below the level of a year ago, Mr. Lebow said.
He also noted that the biggest move was in the April contract, which expires today. Futures contracts tend to become more volatile as expiration approaches.
On other commodity markets, copper futures sank amid profit taking. Copper for May delivery fell 1.5 cents, to 90.7 cents a pound on the Commodity Exchange. The market reached an 11-month high last week in a rally driven by higher demand linked to the improving economy.

HEADLINE: Uncovered Short Sales Increase on 2 Exchanges

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Apparently emboldened by recent weakness in stock prices, speculators pushed up the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the most recent reporting period, two stock exchanges reported yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange said its total short position increased 3.4 percent during the monthlong period ended March 8, to a record 1.37 billion shares. The increase was the second largest in the last six months, and seemed to reflect rising confidence among bears that the long-awaited, often-predicted market correction was beginning. 
 At the American Stock Exchange, the short position rose 3.7 percent, to a record 108.8 million shares. It was the largest rise in four months.
 
Affected by Interest Rates
 Steadily rising interest rates in the last two months have injected an element of volatility into the stock market that has been lacking in recent years, raising hopes among short-sellers of a big price drop.
After the Federal Reserve Board tightened monetary policy on Feb. 4, "some things started happening in a hurry," said Harry Strunk, an investment consultant based in Palm Beach, Fla. "That got some people interested. It's a choppy market, and these shorts are hoping they see light at the end of the tunnel."
The three largest short positions -- in RJR Nabisco, Walt Disney and Chrysler -- all rose as short-sellers increased their bets.
While there are a number of reasons to sell shares short, including merger arbitrage, the most common impulse is to bet that the price of a stock will decline.
Short-sellers borrow a stock and sell it, hoping to profit if the price declines, enabling them to buy it back for less. The overall level of short sales is often seen as a sign of just how bearish traders are, and is sometimes used as a contrary indicator.
Despite the recent market volatility, the fact that short positions rose again last month came as a surprise to some who follow such activity.
"I would have anticipated that the number would have been stable to down," said Steve Kibbey, a vice president at Centurion Capital in La Jolla, Calif.
"The fact that merger deals are popping up and more mutual funds are taking short positions could be a reason why positions are up," he said. "But I don't find anybody who is making much money except those who are shorting the bond market."

PUB-DATE: March 22, 1994

SECTION: Section D; Page 10; Column 3; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 679 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Winners and losers as Japan expands cellular phones.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
WHILE it has garnered all the headlines, the new trade agreement that improves access for Motorola is not the biggest development in Japan's cellular telephone market. Come April 1, regulatory changes will unleash a new burst of competition, spurring growth for the heretofore sluggish industry and providing new opportunities and new pitfalls for investors.
Consumers will be able to buy portable phones for the first time, instead of having to lease them from the phone company at inflated rates. Consumer electronics manufacturers will flood into the market, driving down the price of handsets. 
 Also starting in April, two new service providers will be allowed to operate in the Tokyo, Nagoya and Osaka areas, bringing the number of competitors in those major cities to four. The two new service providers will offer digital service, which can carry more conversations on a given allotment of frequencies than the older analog technology that is now the mainstream.
One point overlooked in the dispute over the access of Motorola to the Japanese market is how relatively underdeveloped the cellular phone market is.
Japan was the first country to have cellular service and Japanese manufacturers are major worldwide suppliers of portable telephones. But like the cobbler's children who went without shoes, only about 1.5 percent of the population here uses cellular phones, compared with about 5 percent in the United States and Hong Kong and 6 to 8 percent in Scandinavia.
Analysts say a major reason for the slow growth has been lack of competition and high subscription fees. But while the new competition and lower prices expected after April 1 will spur growth, the path ahead for investors will still be tricky.
Most analysts say that it is difficult now to predict a winner among the many companies that will be making and selling cellular phones. Some say that all the companies will be hurt by a price war. And Japanese companies that manufacture in their high-cost country will have trouble competing with Motorola and Nokia, a company from Finland.
One supplier that could be a big loser is the Matsushita Communication Industrial Company, 56 percent owned by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, Japan's largest consumer electronics manufacturer. Matsushita Communication has been the main supplier of portable phones to the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the largest cellular service provider.
"MCI has had a cozy time the last few years reaping monopoly profits from the closed domestic handset market," Jeffrey Camp, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities, wrote in a recent report in which he recommends selling the stock.
Phua Lee Kerk, analyst at Baring Securities, said it was wiser to invest in component suppliers, which will benefit from the increased demand for portable phones no matter which phone manufacturer triumphs.
He recommends Murata Manufacturing, a leading manufacturer of ceramic filters, and Toyo Communication Equipment, a manufacturer of crystal oscillators.
Among service providers, many analysts like the DDI Corporation, which provides cellular service in areas outside the heavily populated Tokyo-Nagoya corridor. It will now be moving into the Tokyo-Nagoya region because it owns a stake in one of the two new companies that will be allowed to provide service there.
Some analysts caution that cellular phone use will take off more slowly than some in the industry anticipate. Even though phones can be purchased, they will still cost more than $800, high by world standards. And the economy is still weak.
Makio Inui of Kleinwort Benson Securities recommends investing in companies that make base stations, antennas and other parts for cellular phone service. That equipment has to be installed before demand for phone service materializes.
One likely winner, he said, is Japan Radio, which provides base stations for N.T.T. Another is Denki Kogyo, which makes antennas. It often installs Motorola base stations, the number of which will increase under the recent trade agreement.

HEADLINE: Fiscal Agency Asks Giuliani to Include Police in Cutbacks

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
The chairman of the State Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday called on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to include police officers, firefighters and teachers in his budget cuts as a way of proving to other municipal unions that the sacrifices he expects of them will be shared by all.
In an interview, Eugene J. Keilin, who recently took over from Felix G. Rohatyn as head of the agency set up to help the city recover from its fiscal crisis of the 1970's, said the Mayor was wrong to declare "sanctuaries" in his effort to improve productivity and eliminate 15,000 city jobs over the next year and a half. 
 Although Mr. Keilin has no formal role in the budget process, his agency controls a $200 million surplus that Mr. Giuliani is seeking to finance a package of severance payments for up to 7,600 employees. As a result, he said, it was his agency's responsibility to help determine how the money was used.
In his preliminary budget, Mayor Giuliani specifically excluded from cutbacks uniformed officers and civilians in the Police Department, firefighters and classroom teachers. He argued that they should be protected against reductions and any real concessions in benefits because to do so would harm the essential services they provide. Instead, the Mayor proposed sharp cuts in the number of sanitation workers, social-welfare providers and corrections personnel. He has also proposed cutting thousands of administrative jobs in the schools and city-owned hospitals.
But Mr. Keilin said: "In the Mayor's plan, there are targets and there are sanctuaries. I think a sense of rough justice requires that there be no sanctuaries."
Mr. Keilin did not specifically contend that the numbef police officers, firefighters and teachers should be significantly cut. But he suggestxd that they should not be permitted to avoid cutbacks entirely and should be asked to go along with benefit concessions and changes in work rules aimed at improving the performance of the city's vast bureaucracy. The police, firefighters and teachers represent more than half of the city's total work force of 216,000.
 
Seeking Union Cooperation
 In pragmatic terms, Mr. Keilin said, the city's fiscal problems can best be overcome only if Mr. Giuliani enlists the cooperation of the unions that are being called upon to accept sacrifices by their members. By exempting half of the city work force from major concessions, he said, the Mayor is making it harder to achieve the leaner and more effective city government he wants. He also said he fears that unions will oppose redeployment of workers from one agency to another unless the budget requires sacrifice from all.
"I've already said that directly to the Mayor," Mr. Keilin said.
Though the Mayor has not responded directly to Mr. Keilin's recommendations, he has in recent weeks vigorously rejected calls for cuts in the Police and Fire Departments, at one point saying it would be "crazy" to retreat from his campaign pledge to improve public safety.
Mr. Keilin's recommendations come amid a growing clamor from others outside the Mayor's office, including some City Council members close to the municipal unions, to spread the budget cuts more evenly.
"I think the Mayor's biggest mistake is his contention that staff reductions automatically mean reductions in services," said Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. "On the contrary, in many cases leaner organizations might actually be able to improve the services provided."
But Mr. Keilin's comments carry much greater weight because the M.A.C. is in a position to impose conditions on use of the $200 million Mr. Giuliani wants for the severance package. Ideally the buyouts would be used as an alternative to layoffs by inducing many to quit voluntarily.
"We think the severance program, as a concept, is an appropriate use of the surplus," Mr. Keilin said. "But there are a lot of details to be filled in, and it is up to the board of M.A.C. to determine the appropriate circumstances for the use of that money."
But Abraham Lackman, the Mayor's budget director, said Mr. Keilin did not understand the extent to which the budget plan already requires all city workers to pay for part of their health insurance. It also seeks productivity gains by calling on the city police, the transit police and the housing police to accept a merger.
"Everyone is being called upon for some sacrifices," Mr. Lackman said. He also said state law forbids the city to achieve budget savings in any way that reduces officers on patrol or squeezes extra work out of the police. "The Mayor has indicated his three priorities are public safety, economic development and education. We are not prepared to do anything that might undermine those priorities."
New York State established the Municipal Assistance Corporation in 1975 to help to market debt for the city after it teetered on the edge of bankruptcy. When the city's financial health improved in the mid-1980's, the M.A.C.'s direct role in its fiscal affairs diminished. But Mr. Rohatyn, its chairman for 18 years, was frequently an outspoken critic of the city's budget and labor practices. By negotiating the terms under which the M.A.C. provided cash from its surplus funds, Mr. Rohatyn was sometimes able to persuade the city's politicians and unions to change their ways.
Mr. Keilin was the agency's executive director during much of the 1970's fiscal crisis and a longtime board member of the state agency.
 
Supporters in Campaign
 Asking the police, firefighters and teachers to join in accepting sacrifices to ease the budget gap would raise delicate political challenges for the Mayor. Police and fire unions supported Mr. Giuliani in the campaign, while the teachers remained neutral. Most of the city's labor movement backed David N. Dinkins.
Through a spokesman, Phil Caruso, head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, said Mr. Keilin's suggestion was "a knee-jerk reaction on the part of a new fiscal watchdog who is totally uneducated and uninformed."
Separately, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that the Mayor's budget plan contained several uncertainties. He issued a report that identified as much as $1.4 billion of the Mayor's proposed $2.3 billion in budget savings that require action "by some organization other than city government, such as the State Legislature or the municipal unions."
The report also stated that the police and other uniformed agencies could rely further on civilians for office work.
