HEADLINE: CABINET EXPRESSES FEARS ABOUT PLAN TO ALTER WELFARE

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
After working for nearly a year, President Clinton's aides presented him today with an ambitious plan to overhaul the welfare system, but the Cabinet has expressed reservations about the way the plan would be financed, arguing that the strategy could hurt the needy.
The mid-level officials drafting the plan have been trying to pay for a $15 billion package of training and work programs by cutting other programs for the disadvantaged. 
 But Cabinet members hesitated at that strategy during a two-hour meeting on Monday, people familiar with the session said. The Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, then agreed to consider possible tax increases to avoid some, though not all, contemplated cuts in food programs and aid to indigent immigrants.
 
Meeting With Clinton
 Cabinet members also discussed strategies for saving money by scaling back the draft welfare proposal. They said they might provide a smaller expansion of child care to poor working families and conduct smaller welfare experiments than originally proposed.
No decisions were made at Monday's meeting, and the Cabinet reconvened today with President Clinton present. While the plan has been on the drafting table for almost a year, this appears to be the first major meeting to confront Mr. Clinton with the painful financing decisions.
An official familiar with today's Cabinet meeting said that it was an informational session that was cut short and that Mr. Clinton had not decided how to pay for the plan.
 
No Savings at First
 The search for money is central to Mr. Clinton's pledge "to end welfare as we know it," a popular message during the 1992 campaign and a possible key to his political future.
Mr. Clinton has promised to give Congress a bill this spring to expand training opportunities for welfare recipients, then require those still unemployed after two years to join a work program.
While putting welfare recipients to work sounds like a savings measure, it is much more expensive, at least in the short run, than simply mailing a check. The cost rises because the Government would subsidize the recipients' wages, as well as providing them with education, training and child care.
The hunt for financing has been a source of anguish for the 32 members of the task force drafting the bill, including one co-chairman, David T. Ellwood, and his deputy, Wendell E. Primus. They are prominent advocates for the needy, who have spent the last decade fighting cuts similar to the ones they are now proposing.
They find themselves in this position because budget laws require any new spending to be offset with cuts or taxes, and until recently they have said that they expected Mr. Clinton and the Cabinet would reject any tax increases. "The financing has been really problematic," said an official involved in the process. "There are no good choices."
 
Surprise at Meeting
 The Cabinet meeting was a surprise, and perhaps a source of secret satisfaction, for task force members who object to the cuts.
The secretaries of some domestic agencies were joined by the President's senior political advisers, including George Stephanopoulos and David R. Gergen. The group seemed to agree, according to people familiar with the meeting, that a strategy of cuts alone appeared unfair and would not find support among Congressional Democrats.
According to people familiar with meeting, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros were among those concerned about the cuts.
Some proposed cuts remain very much on the table, including a plan to cap the emergency assistance provisions of the main Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. The program gives emergency payments to needy families, including those in danger of becoming homeless. Task force members argue that states are abusing the program by billing the Federal Government for services they once provided.
But the Cabinet showed little enthusiasm for a plan to save $800 million a year by changing eligibility rules and removing 250,000 children from the welfare rolls. And it was particularly concerned about a proposal to deny cash payments to needy immigrants who are not citizens.
Some policy experts have argued that immigrants are abusing the welfare program, called Supplemental Security Income, by encouraging relatives to immigrate and seek Government aid. But a plan to cut the benefits seems likely to cause a revolt among House Democrats, particularly members of the Hispanic caucus.
A likelier Administration proposal would be to force the immigrants to wait five years before receiving aid.
 
Republicans May Bolt
 The move toward raising taxes also has risks. Republicans have threatened to bolt from any proposal that raises taxes, even minor ones.
The House Republicans have put forward a welfare bill that would spend $20 billion over five years, but pay for it entirely with cuts, especially in programs for immigrants.
Tax measures that have received some consideration include several that involve gambling. One possible proposal would place a new excise tax on some gambling establishments, although state lotteries and Indian reservations would probably be exempt.
A second proposal seeks to improve tax enforcement, by increasing the withholding rate on certain gambling winnings. Mr. Bentsen is now seeking to flesh out the list of tax options.
 
Considering Some Trims
 The Cabinet considered three ways of scaling back the $15 billion the draft proposals would cost over five years.
One option is to reduce, or sever, a plan to spend $5 billion on child care for the working poor in an effort to keep such families from coming onto welfare rolls. The Cabinet talked about putting the provision forward later in a separate bill.
The group also talked about reducing several welfare experiments, including a test program to increase training for absent fathers, so they could afford greater child support payments.
The group may also scale back an experiment that would spend $550 million over five years, by having the Government make child support payments if absent fathers failed to do so.
Mr. Ellwood has argued passionately for the proposal, saying it has great potential for alleviating poverty among children. One parent, he has said, should not be forced to do the financial work of two.
But the plan's critics, including some inside the Administration, have argued that the cash payments are simply welfare by another name. They have said the Government help could make absent fathers less willing to make payments themselves.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Tumble After Fed Acts Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates plunged sharply yesterday, after the Federal Reserve broke precedent for the second time in two months and announced its intention to raise short-term interest rates.
In a short statement released in the afternoon, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the Federal Open Market Committee -- the central bank's policy-setting arm -- had "decided to increase slightly the degree of pressure on reserve positions." He added, "This action is expected to be associated with a small increase in short-term interest rates." 
 Within minutes of the statement, bond prices rose a half-point on the long end, with rates on shorter-maturity bills dropping sharply. The 30-year bond's yield -- which moves in the opposite direction of its price -- fell as low as 6.83 percent and by late in the day the price was up 110/32 , to 92 18/32 , for a yield of 6.84 percent. The drop of 11 basis points was the largest one-day yield decline in two and a half months. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Rally in Short-Term Bills
 Short-term bills also rallied strongly, with the rate on three- and six-month bills down 11 basis points as well, to 3.50 percent and 3.79 percent, respectively.
The closely followed 10-year note also rallied, dropping its yield to 6.42 percent, from 6.55 percent on Monday.
Traders and dealers said they preferred this type of announcement by the Fed to the central bank's previous policy of not saying anything. Donald Fine, the chief market analyst at Chase Securities, was delighted by the idea of the Fed announcing the slight tightening, and hoped the central bank would continue to use that approach. "It removes all uncertainty about what its intentions are, leaving nothing for speculation," he said. "And you can see by the market's reaction that it is showing its approval."
Assuming that the move would push the Federal funds rate to 3.50 percent, Mr. Fine said: "It will stay at 3.50 percent for a month or two, then you can expect it to hit 3.75 percent and the 4 percent. And we are going to 4 percent by July or August.
"The main reason the Fed wants positive real short-term interest rates is to forestall any speculative inventory build up resulting from higher inflationary expectations." In other words, the Fed is trying to prevent any near-term overheating of the economy because of increasing demand for goods and services to avoid future price increases.
As Fed governors convened yesterday for the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, most economists, 22 out of 30 polled by Reuters, were betting on a tightening of 25 basis points. But some said they would not rule out a 50-basis-point rise given the strength in short-term rates.
But unlike the Feb. 4 rise in short-term interest rates, when prices fell across the yield curve, yesterday's announcement of another credit tightening caused bond prices to rally higher instead.
Gerald A. Guild, senior manager of fixed income at Advest Inc., said the Feb. 4 decline in the bond market was the result of an overreaction by investors not satisfied by the rate rise. The market had expected something more aggressive from the Fed, he said, to show that it was serious about fighting inflation. The selloff has continued for the most part despite soft inflation news, causing many bond traders to suspect that the bond market has been oversold for some time now.
"The market could hold today's gains if people come to conclude that inflation will remain under control," Mr. Guild said.
Analysts at MMS International said the short end of the market rallied strongly since the threat of a half-point rise in rates had already been priced in ahead of time.
Traders said there was some nervousness in the short end ahead of yesterday's $17 billion two-year-note auction. The announcement helped the auction, which produced a high yield of 5.15 percent. But by late in the day the yield on a two-year note in the when-issued market was down to 5 percent.
Today the Treasury will be selling $11 billion of five-year notes. In when-issued trading late yesterday, they were being offered at a price to yield 5.91 percent.
With the market poised for news coming out of the Fed meeting, morning data from the Commerce Department showing the United States merchandise trade gap had widened significantly in January to $9.85 billion had little impact on trading. Economists had forecast a $9 billion deficit in January.

HEADLINE: Christopher Says U.S. Stays Firm on Korea, but Pledges Diplomacy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the United States would defend South Korea against any aggression, but that Washington would pursue diplomatic moves before seeking sanctions against North Korea over its refusal to allow inspections of its nuclear plants.
Mr. Christopher and other officials spent much of the day seeking support in the United Nations for a resolution that will criticize North Korea and point indirectly to economic sanctions. 
 The Administration strained to win China's support because Beijing can veto any Security Council resolution. Chinese officials said they wanted all efforts at negotiation exhausted before economic sanctions were used.
Prime Minister Li Peng warned today in Beijing that increased pressure could aggravate the situation. "If pressure is applied on this issue, that can only complicate the situation on the Korean peninsula, and it will add to the tension there," he said.
It was a day in which all sides talked tough, and South Korea put its forces on defensive alert. But the United States sought to assure the Chinese and North Koreans that it would first seek a diplomatic resolution.
"We've made it clear to North Korea that it must become a responsible member of the international community, or that community will have no choice but to pursue other options," Mr. Christopher told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
The Secretary added: "Our commitment to South Korea's security remains firm. We're prepared to take all necessary steps to insure that the North does not misread our determination to deter agreession."
 
Military Is Ready
 Appearing on the NBC News program "Today," Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for Asian Affairs, said, "I would hope and expect that China would join an overwhelming international consensus" in pushing North Korea to allow full nuclear inspections.
Pentagon officals reported today that there was military activity in North Korea, but that it might be routine military exercises. Dennis Boxx, a Pentagon spokesman, said the Administration was watching the situation "very carefully."
North Korea reacted strongly to developments over the last few days, particularly the Administration's decision to send Patriot antimissile batteries to South Korea. In broadcasts monitored abroad, North Korea radio called the move "a provocative step to lead the situation to extremes by further aggravating tensions on the Korean peninsula."
"The order by Clinton to deploy Patriot missiles in South Korea is a grave threat to us," the broadcast added.
The Pentagon spokesman said that even if North Korea allowed complete nuclear inspections, Washington would send the Patriots. "We have no intention to turn them around," Mr. Boxx said. "The plan right now is these missiles will be put in place."
Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said the United States would protect the 37,000 American soldiers stationed in South Korea and remained committed to fulfilling its treaty obligations there.
South Korea's President, Kim Young San, is to begin a long-planned trip on Thursday to Japan and China, where he will discuss the crisis.
After having been criticized for taking too soft an approach to North Korea, the Clinton Administration won some backing in Congress today.
Gary L. Ackerman, a New York Democrat and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, said: "I'm fully aboard. The Administration is using a steady, even-handed approach to a very difficult situation."

Anger From the North
 TOKYO, Monday, March 23 (Special to The New York Times) -- In its latest oratorical barrage, North Korea called Kim Young Sam, the South's President, a traitor for asking the United States to provide Patriot missiles, and declared that "traitors to the nation must be removed and liquidated within the nation as early as possible."
"Our people and the people's army will severely punish the traitors attempting to stifle fellow countrymen in conspiracy with outside forces," the Korean Central News Agency said today, "and will resolutely defend our socialist motherland and the security of the nation."

HEADLINE: Mysterious Black Hole in Chicago Is Gobbling Up Everybody's Mail

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 22

 BODY:
This city has had a lot of practice coping with hardships, man-made and otherwise, from crooked politicians to wicked winter winds. But there are some things that can push even Chicagoans too far, and the United States Postal Service has done it with mail: mail delivered weeks late, decades late; mail that is burnt to a crisp in a vacant lot and never delivered at all.
In Postal Service surveys, more than one-third of Chicago households have reported problems with their mail, an inexcusably high number, says Marvin Runyon, the Postmaster General. Along Mr. Runyon's national postal route, the city ranks dead last in customer satisfaction. A local alderman even says he will hold hearings next month to assess the mail system's effect on Chicago's economy. 
 The problems here have become so bad and tempers so sharp and short that Mr. Runyon came to Chicago on Monday for a day and a long night of meetings with elected officials, Postal Service employees and residents. He ended with a crowded town meeting that turned into two hours of jeers and complaints and a call to bring back the Pony Express.
Mr. Runyon left promising that a better day was coming. But when, he could not say. He noted only that a team of postal investigators from across the country would begin sorting out the mess sometime this week.
 
City of Horror Stories
 Both Senators from Illinois accompanied Mr. Runyon for part of his trip through what some call the Post Office From Hell. "There are a lot of good, hard-working postal employees here," said the state's junior Senator, Carol Moseley-Braun, a Democrat. "But these horror stories indicate there are not enough."
It was a surreal adventure, including a prominent local atheist who said he was happy with his postal service and an unhappy biker who apparently thought he was God.
"When I passed out brains," the biker told Mr. Runyon, "you thought I said trains and you missed yours."
Then a man asked the Postmaster for a job, saying he was tired of living on Social Security and food stamps. But then he had not received his food stamps from last month, the man said. They were lost in the mail.
Why the system is so troubled in Chicago is unclear. But postal employees and their supporters said many of the buildings are old; the equipment is outdated and the neighborhood post offices are understaffed.
 
Too Many Temporary Workers
 They contend that there are too many temporary employees, who do not stay long enough to learn the job or the names of the people on their routes. When employees speak out about what is wrong on the job, they are often punished, said a woman who has worked for the Post Office here for 17 years.
By every measure, many said, employee morale here and around the country is low. "And they're taking their anger out on us," a teacher at the town meeting told Mr. Runyon.
Post office officials say they know that their image needs quick repair, since unhappy customers today might be gone-elsewhere customers tomorrow. The post office, like utilities and phone companies, is worried about faster moving, less regulated private companies skimming off the more profitable pieces of its business.
Mr. Runyon came to Chicago to save face and the bottom line.
About 500 people turned out for the forum. As Mr. Runyon began to speak, he was quickly awash in catcalls.
"You can count on us to keep you in touch," he said. The hissing from the audience sounded like a nasty wind off Lake Michigan.
One woman drove 100 miles from a small town in Indiana to complain about her mail service. Bertha Gimbel, the clerk for a Chicago suburb, did not have to travel so far but was just as unhappy. She said water bills sent on Feb. 4 did not arrive until March 17, more than two weeks after they were due. One Chicagoan, John Burns, topped that one: He said he had not received any mail since last July.
Earlier in the day, as Mr. Runyon toured a neighborhood post office on the city's North Side, the lobby filled with the displeased, including John Steele and Bo Clausen. Mr. Steele said he had missed his nephew's wedding because the invitation, mailed two months before the ceremony, arrived a week after it was over. The letter had to travel less than 20 miles. "Her family was wondering, 'Where's your uncle?' " Mr. Steele said.
 
Follow That Cab!
 Mr. Clausen said that for two Saturdays in a row no mail came to his home. Then last Saturday he looked out his window and saw the letter carrier walking onto the block, carrying a bag loaded with letters. The next thing he saw was the carrier climbing into a cab and driving off into the sunset without delivering the mail.
They did not get a chance to speak with Mr. Runyon, but Eugene Telser did. Mr. Telser said he wanted to tell him about his letter carrier.
"This system is so lousy, but we have a very good letter carrier who is fighting it," Mr. Telser said. "I asked Mr. Runyon what could be done to reward him."
Mr. Runyon told Mr. Telser to write him a letter about the carrier, and to drop it in the mail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Neither stamps, nor envelopes nor letter carriers seem to be able to get the mail through in Chicago. HEADLINE: Prices Plummet, Life Turns Normal And Sarajevans Rush to Sell Goods

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 22

 BODY:
Panic selling of everything from canned fish to coffee is sweeping Sarajevo's street markets in expectation that scarcities will be eased with Wednesday's scheduled opening of the first overland routes into the city in almost two years.
When prices peaked in late January, 22 months after Sarajevo was placed under siege by Serbian nationalist forces, gasoline was selling for about $60 a gallon, and was rarely available at any price. Ground meat was $27 a pound; coffee, $40. 
 Prices began easing after a cease-fire went into effect around Sarajevo last month. But the price bubble burst over the weekend, pricked by Friday's signing of a federation agreement between Bosnia's Muslim-dominated Government and Croats that opened central Bosnia's road access to the outside world through Croatia, and by the agreement last week between the Government and the Serbs to open Sarajevo's first secure overland access to central Bosnia.
In another signal that Bosnia is inching back to normal, United Nations officials formally opened an airport in the northern Bosnian city of Tuzla today after almost 18 months of pleas by local officials.
 
Everything in the Car
 If Wednesday's road-openings go forward as United Nations officials here plan, Sarajevans will be able to drive to and from Butmir, a southwestern suburb which has an open road to Croatia. Commercial traffic is prohibited, but there is little doubt that motorists will be carrying into the city everything they can jam into their trunks.
Anticipating the surge in supplies, gasoline has dropped to $30 a gallon, coffee to $18 a pound and ground meat to $15 a pound.
"Meat prices are falling because there is already more meat coming in and more will come when the road opens," said Mensur Mrso, a 34-year-old butcher at the Sarajevo's central market. "Prices are falling because of Clinton, because he forced them to sign the federation agreement in Washington."
Hamo Zdralovic, an economics graduate and former Bosnian Government worker, sold packs of York cigarettes for about $2.50 Monday morning and $2 that afternoon. "Prices fall by about half every day as more goods arrive," he said.
 
Market Stalls Full
 "There was a serious scarcity of goods, and the prices were ghastly," he said. "It was a raw struggle for survival. Now, I don't care how much money I lose so long as prices fall and people can live. But I'm lucky I didn't invest much in these cigarettes."
Sarajevo's price collapse has brought small-time "commodity dealers" scrambling to the markets trying to get what they can for the goods they have. Market stalls, empty just a few weeks ago, are now stacked with onions, lettuce, fertilizer for home gardens, new athletic shoes, candy bars and other easy-to-carry items.
 
Still Military Tensions
 Even the price of candles has dropped by about a third, to about $3 for a thick, six-inch candle, because the city now has a constant supply of electricity.
Military tensions have not vanished, however. A United Nations military spokesman here said a standoff continued in the hills northwest of the city, where over the weekend Canadian peacekeepers discovered Serbian weapons inside the "exclusion zone" imposed around Sarajevo by NATO last month.
But the spokesman, Maj. Simon MacDowall, said that the Bosnian Serbs' leader, Radovan Karadzic, had pledged cooperation and that the only dispute was whether the weapons were in fact inside the zone. Major MacDowall said that a United Nations-Serbian team was pinpointing the locations of the weapons today.
 
Gambles Over Diesel Fuel
 But in the city, a 29-year-old Bosnian soldier who gave his name as Almir was more worried about his gambles on the Sarajevo oil and coffee markets, where pessimism about peace had paid off for two years.
"I bought 200 liters of diesel just before the price started falling," he said, adding that the fuel originated with the Ukrainian peacekeepers attached to the United Nations military force here.
In the last week the price of diesel fuel has fallen from about $55 to $10 a gallon, he said.
"I also bought 15 kilos of coffee at $60 each," he said. "Now I can't get more than $25 a kilo for it."
"I'm not going to commit suicide," he said. "I'm just happy to be getting out of this war alive, and I'm sure I'll find some way to manage."
The opening of the Tuzla airport came this morning when a United Nations military cargo jet touched down here carrying United Nations officials and a load of medicine and other supplies. But Kris Janowski, Sarajevo spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said that no start-up date for regular aid flights has been set.
"There are still problems between the Bosnian Serbs and the Bosnian Government, and we have to hold off until they agree," he said.
Refugee-relief officials still say cargo flights into the airport would help their effort to supply some 350,000 aid-dependent people in the Tuzla region, they acknowledge that the recent reopening of overland routes from Croatia and Serbia has virtually erased the airport's potential importance to the campaign.
 
An Appeal From 1992
 "By the time it opens the airport may be superfluous, even for medical evacuations, because there is so little fighting in the Tuzla area," a United Nations official said. "The political momentum is such, however, that we had to go ahead with opening the airport."
Officials of Tuzla's local government have appealed to the United Nations to open the airport since the fall of 1992. But the Serbs, who are within artillery range of the airport, threatened to shell it, arguing that the airport would be used by the Bosnian Government to smuggle arms.
United Nations officials balked, fearing retaliation by the Serbs and insisting that the area was best supplied by ground convoys.
In February, Serbian leaders tentatively agreed to the airport's reopening when Russia pledged to send military observers, but they have not yet arrived.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Croats and Serbs Meet
 ZAGREB, Croatia, March 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- Croatian representatives began meetings here today with breakaway Serbian nationalists who control a third of the country. The meetings, under joint Russian, American and European aegis, were the first between the two sides in two years.
While the goal of the talks is relatively limited -- consolidation of an existing cease-fire -- it represents another step in the rapidly unfolding American and Russian efforts in recent weeks to find a way to end the brutal three-way war in the former Yugoslavia. With the signing of articles of confederation between Croatia and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, the pressure is now on the Serbs, still at odds with both parties.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Turkey May Send Peacekeepers
 UNITED NATIONS, March 22 (Reuters) -- Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali recommended today that Turkey, deeply resented by Serbs because of its Ottoman Empire past, be allowed to send troops to join United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Balkans, his spokesman said.
The President of the Security Council, Jean-Bernard Merimee of France, said he expected the proposal to be accepted.
Turkey has offered 1,000 soldiers that it hopes will go to central Bosnia to monitor the agreement between Croats and Muslims. Both parties have accepted Ankara's offer, but Serbs oppose the idea because of the Ottoman Empire's long occupation of the Balkans until early this century.
Under U.N. rules, neighboring countries or those which have historically been involved in a troubled area are normally barred from providing troops.

HEADLINE: Change Threatens a Legendary Street Bazaar

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 22

 BODY:
On Sunday mornings, a magical, seedy circus of possibilities rises from the broken streets west of the Loop, a ragtag market thick with the smell of grilled onions, the crackle of blues from cheap speakers and hagglers hunting for dried peppers or toilet seats.
For 120 years, the Maxwell Street Market has been the mall of the dispossessed, from the Jewish pushcart peddlers selling fruit at the turn of the century to the black vendors of gospel tapes and toggle bolts, the Hispanic tortilla makers and Korean gym-shoe salesmen who all inherited the market from the Jews. 
 It is a place that draws 20,000 customers even in bad weather and has as much as $20 million in sales a year by some estimates, although no one really knows. It is where Mary Torbert, a retired nurse from the suburbs, comes every Sunday for sweet potatoes and Gloria Torres, a data entry clerk, comes for bananas and tomatillos. Charlie Ford, a tax collector from Mechanicsburg, Ill., drove three hours last Sunday to get a $80 vacuum cleaner for $30.
"This is the greatest market of chance in the world," said Judge Hightower, a blind man who barks the menu of Jim's Original World Famous Hotdog Stand from his chair out front. "You can come down here with nothing and go back with who knows what."
 
Change Is Knocking
 But in the last several decades, as suburban malls flourished, as rival retailers across the city started opening on Sundays and Maxwell Street lost its lock on the Day of Rest, as the original Jewish delicatessen and clothing store owners retired to Florida, as homeless people started selling stolen hubcabs and X-rated videos and as even drugs and prostitution could be found amid the power tools, the market has lost its innocence.
Now Maxwell Street is facing extinction. The city, which owns the land, wants to move the market to make way for softball fields and science laboratories for the University of Illinois at Chicago. The new location would be several blocks east, on the other side of the Dan Ryan Expressway. The city also wants to raise vending fees to $25 a day from $25 a year and limit the number of vendors by prohibiting felons from getting licenses.
"It's the first step toward death," said David Whiteis, a writer and regular at Maxwell Street. "It's like watching a beloved relative who is no longer himself. I would rather see it die and rest in peace than see it yuppified and trendified."
Many city officials and the well-to-do people who live near the university consider the market a faded relic and an eyesore.
All along, it has been said that if you couldn't find what you were looking for at Maxwell Street, you didn't need it. The market has always been the place for bargains.
But now, critics say, some prices are low because vagrants get their merchandise from alleys or trash cans and other vendors steal theirs from the neighborhood. Once, even the altar chairs and candlesticks from Holy Family Roman Catholic Church turned up on Maxwell Street.
"They come and steal off our porches," said Rose Tavolino, a nearby resident. "They take our lawn chairs and mops and brooms and sell them for a buck or two."
There have been times when the market's neighbors have had to buy back their own possessions. "If something is stolen in our neighborhood, whether hubcaps or radios or barbecue grills, chances are you can find it on Maxwell Street the next Sunday," said Joe Pucci, a spokesman for Concerned Citizens of the West Loop.
Mr. Pucci blames the market's customers in part. "If people didn't buy what they know in their hearts is stolen merchandise, the vendors wouldn't be stealing it," he said.
 
City Council Action
 Today, the city drew closer to its goal of moving the market as the City Council's zoning committee approved the university's expansion plans for the 10-block Maxwell Street market area. The plan is scheduled to go before the full Council on Wednesday.
Supporters of the market and vendors who have helped put children and grandchildren through school with their earnings are protesting the move. "It's just like going to the grocery store," said Louis Clinton, who sells wrenches and toggle bolts. "If you're used to going to Aisle B to get your coffee and they move it, you're confused. People don't want to go wandering and looking."
 
Circus of Humanity
 On Sundays after Mass at St. Francis of Assisi Catholic Church, the pockmarked streets south of Roosevelt Road are impassable for all the people picking over old refrigerators and used eyeglasses, drill bits and bottles of Downy fabric softener from 800 or so vendors, their wares set out on blankets or door frames, their rusted fruit stand scales rocking in the breeze.
Children breakdance for spare change. In warm weather, blues bands play under what habitues call the blues tree. Sometimes a homeless man named Tucker will dance for quarters after he has had a pint of wine.
"It's like an amusement park without paying to get in," said Nate Duncan, who has owned a kosher delicatessen at the market for the past 22 years.
The market is so packed it is sometimes difficult to walk. Brooms and rakes and ladders stick out above the crowd as people head home with their awkward but happy finds.
"Some days there are crowds on the level of Calcutta there," said Steven Balkin, an associate professor of economics at Roosevelt University. "This is an indigenous market. Without Maxwell Street, we will have a flood of street people begging and hustling and peddling."
Aside from the crowds, advocates argue that the market should stay where it is because this was the historic point of entry for the city's immigrants. "For more than 100 years this has been the Ellis Island of the Midwest," said Merlyn McFarland, a seller of used clothes.
But since many of the former jewelry stores and delicatessens closed and were boarded up or bought out by the university, entire lots have been razed. The city does not pick up trash like it used to, and the streets are littered with broken beer bottles and discarded tires.
"What's historic there? What's left?" asked Alderman Ted Mazola, in whose ward, the First, the market sits. "Where we're expanding, there is vacant land. There's nothing to save. Right now it's chaos; it's anarchy. It's not a place to bring your kids. This is a seedy part of life we don't want to continue or condone."
 
Making the Argument for Fees
 The death knell for the market, advocates say, will be the increase in vendor fees because the vendors are people hustling on the edges of society. "There's no guarantee you'll make $25," Mr. Hightower, the blind man, said.
The city has said the fees would help pay for better sanitation and police protection and would therefore help the vendors make more money. "There is no such thing as a free ride. said Jim Williams, the Mayor's press secretary. "It takes an investment to do business. Maxwell Street is no different."
But Larry Callahan, a retired printer and market regular, says it is. He was among the angry group of supporters who showed up at the zoning hearing today to ask for reconsideration.
"Maxwell Street belongs to the world," Mr. Callahan said. "It deserves a better death. God willing, we'll save it."

Last Sunday, the offerings for the thousands of browsers included entertainment, fresh produce, fast food and power tools. (Photographs by John Booz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Travelers And Met Life Weigh Deal

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Reaching for greater size and economic power in the rapidly changing managed health care market, Travelers Inc. and Met Life said yesterday that they were exploring "possible alliances among their health care operations."
By joining forces, the two New York-based companies would get closer to the big leagues of managed care, although they would still be well behind the largest national health insurers, Kaiser Permanente, Prudential, Cigna and Aetna. 
 In a brief written statement following a number of reports that the two companies were discussing merging their health care businesses, Met Life, a unit of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Travelers said the talks were "exploratory." They added that "it would be premature to speculate on the outcome, if any."
 
980,000 H.M.O. Members
 If the two combine, the new company would have about 980,000 members in health maintenance organizations and 4 million more in other types of managed care groups, including discount networks for physicians and hospitals.
As the cost of traditional health insurance has soared, millions of people have switched to the cheaper managed care plans, and companies have been scrambling to attract new members. The combined company would have branches around the country, and that geographical reach would make it more attractive to large national employers.
 
Analysts See Benefits
 Analysts said an alliance would benefit both sides, but Michael W. Blumstein at Morgan Stanley in New York said an agreement was "not imminent," although it would fit into Travelers' "strategy of looking at alliances and joint ventures to bolster their competitive position."
Stephen D. Brink, a health care actuary in Milwaukee with Milliman & Robertson, a national health care consulting firm, said that forging a combination was attractive because the alternative, creating a national network of health service providers from scratch, would be "extremely difficult and very expensive."
"Size matters," Kevin Morley, who heads research on corporate debt at CS First Boston in New York, said.
At the end of December, Travelers said it had 678,000 members in H.M.O.'s and 1.2 million in "preferred provider" discount networks. Met Life said it had 300,000 H.M.O. members, 1.7 million preferred provider members, and 1.1 million in other managed care plans that allow members to choose doctors not in the network.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Try a Conciliatory Tack With China

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
In an effort to deal with the looming crisis over its China policy, the White House has begun a campaign to mend rifts within the Administration and to find ways to persuade China to improve its human rights performance through conciliation rather than confrontation, senior Administration officials said today.
In a closed meeting of senior national security and economic advisers at the White House today, the Administration took stock of its strategy in light of Secretary of State Warren Christopher's trip to Beijing, and decided unanimously to continue the current policy that links progress on human rights to renewal of China's low-tariff trade status when it comes up for renewal in June, the officials said. 
 Mr. Christopher tried to reassert control over the policy, presenting an overview of what progress the Chinese had already made and what they still had to do, and insisting that his colleagues in other agencies present a united front in backing the overall policy, senior officials said.
 
'Open Revolt' on Policy
 "This is partly about who is going to be in charge of the China policy," said one senior State Department official. "The Secretary is trying to keep the Commerce and Treasury Departments from trying to make a run over taking over the policy. He wants to make sure State Department keeps a very strong control over the China relationship, that it's not tenable to have the economic agencies in open revolt against the policy."
"Right now, we're in a box. And the question is, what's the Houdini strategy?"
In effect, what the Administration is trying to do is reinterpret the Secretary of State's visit to Beijing not as a confrontational exercise, but a visit in which some progress was made by China toward fulfilling the human rights conditions set down by President Clinton's executive order of June 1993 for renewal of its beneficial trade status.
As a first step toward that strategy, the National Security Council sent a private, three-page memo of "talking points" to all Cabinet secretaries on Monday instructing them on how to publicly present Mr. Christopher's recent visit to Beijing as a success.
Although the Chinese reaction to Mr. Christopher's message "was and continues to be generally negative," there were "positive steps as well," according to a copy of the memo. It added, "contrary to the impression of some reporting, the Chinese took some constructive steps on this front during Secretary Christopher's visit."
 
U.S. Conditions 'Reasonable'
 If officials are asked whether there is dissension within the United States Government over the policy linking trade and human rights, the response should be that the policy has not changed, and that the American conditions for renewing China's preferential trade status are "reasonable, consistent and clear."
Press reporting about that trip, some of which was fueled by confrontational statements made by both Mr. Christopher and his aides, left the impression that China was totally resisting all American attempts to persuade it to improve its human rights performance. And the absence of a ringing endorsement by President Clinton of the policy in general and Mr. Christopher in particular emboldened those in the Administration opposed to the linkage of trade and human rights to strongly -- and anonymously -- criticize it.
Some Administration officials now concede that overheated declarations were made during Mr. Christopher's visit and that the tough talk on both sides resulted in an overwhelmingly negative message that obscured the actual progress made by the Chinese. These officials also admit that perhaps senior Administration officials should not have laid out specific goals they expected the Chinese to meet, because such a move created certain expectations that were not met.

HEADLINE: Dead-End Deal: Why a Merger Collapsed -- A special report.;
A Cultural Clash Defeated Bell Atlantic and T.C.I.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
They went their separate ways on a sleeting, wintry afternoon last month, walking out of the 44th-floor conference room of a midtown Manhattan office tower, after a final two-hour meeting that went nowhere.
It was the end of a sobering journey that began last summer in exhilaration and finished in frustration for Raymond W. Smith and John C. Malone, who tried to forge one of the biggest corporate mergers in history. 
 But the proposed $33 billion combination of the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc., which had once seemed so right, proved a bad match.
"This deal isn't going to make it, so let's shoot it," Mr. Malone recalls telling Mr. Smith.
How could two of the savviest, most powerful men in the communications industry have so misjudged each other's company as a suitable match?
In the weeks since the deal collapsed, both executives, in separate, lengthy interviews, took pains to avoid direct recriminations. Chalk it up to a dream born in the heady days of last summer -- when hype over "convergence," "interactive multimedia" and "paradigm shifts" had an entire industry spinning fevered visions of the future. But over the winter, the dream faded as Mr. Malone, the president and chief executive of T.C.I., and Mr. Smith, the chairman of Bell Atlantic, realized that their business philosophies clashed.
Mr. Malone, who grew up in a rough-and-tumble industry that views growth as a company's principal mission, disdains traditional corporate goals like reporting earnings and paying dividends as distractions that siphon off money that might otherwise be plowed back into building or acquiring new properties. This ethos was at odds with the by-the-ledger-book traditions revered by Bell Atlantic.
"Ray," Mr. Malone said of Mr. Smith, "was always dealing with a financial mind-set within his company that focused on near-term reported earnings instead of creating wealth in the long term -- the old phone company mentality."
But what Mr. Malone saw as prudishness, Mr. Smith viewed as financial prudence. The Bell Atlantic chairman was unwilling to stake too much of his shareholders' money on the uncertain high-tech dreams of Mr. Malone. As the two companies got to know each other, Bell Atlantic also recognized some unsettling differences between their cultures.
"There were difficulties with the T.C.I. system, its reputation for service in some places compared with the way we do things, and the level of animosity in some communities," Mr. Smith said. "Those were seen by our people with a certain horror."
But even though the Bell Atlantic-T.C.I. deal is dead, the forces that fueled it and the issues it raised remain. Private industry, everyone agrees, will have to build what the Clinton Administration has called the information highway -- a marriage of television, communications and computer technology that experts say will someday bring everything from movies to libraries to home screens at the tap of a button.
 
Problems for Others
 And the Bell Atlantic-T.C.I. merger was an ambitious attempt by private enterprise to hasten its arrival. But the story of the deal's collapse, based on interviews with Mr. Smith, Mr. Malone, executives and advisers, shows the kinds of challenges that any business partners will need to overcome if they are to blend hybrid technologies -- and disparate industries -- into a home-entertainment and information revolution.
On Feb. 23, when the deal finally fell apart, the reason given for scuttling the merger was a complex price dispute: how many of its own new shares of stock Bell Atlantic would pay for T.C.I.
The price when a company is being sold, of course, is merely the arithmetic that reflects assumptions about that company's assets, strategy and expectations for the future. Absent common assumptions, there was no deal.
"At the end, there were two strong-willed people with very different views of the value of T.C.I.," said Mr. Smith of Bell Atlantic.
On that issue, at least, the other strong-willed person agreed. "There was a basic difference in philosophy," Mr. Malone of T.C.I. said. "When we had to kill the deal, what the people in our shop felt was mostly relief."
 
Getting Acquainted
2 'Antagonists,' Attracted
 Mr. Smith, 56 years old, and Mr. Malone, 53, seemed headed in the same direction long before they got together last June at T.C.I.'s headquarters in Englewood, Colo.
Early in their careers, although at different periods, both had been engineers at A.T.& T.'s Bell Laboratories. But Mr. Smith had stayed in the telephone industry. Mr. Malone, restless under the bureaucracy of the old Bell System, fled. He eventually wound up heading the largest cable television empire in America.
In the years and then the months leading up to last summer, the phone and cable industries were preparing to invade each other's bailiwicks, as regulations were gradually easing to let phone companies get into the video business and cable companies into phone service. The two industries, though "natural antagonists," in Mr. Smith's phrase, also have complementary strengths to use in building the information highway.
 
Regulatory Diplomats
 The phone companies are seasoned regulatory diplomats; they possess the switching technology needed for two-way interactive networks, and they generate huge quantities of cash.
The cable companies, especially T.C.I., bring national reach, high-capacity cables able to handle voice and video, and programming expertise.
After overtures from Bell Atlantic last summer, and meetings between the two sides, the merger was annnounced at a New York news conference on Oct. 13. The agreement put a tentative price on the T.C.I. cable systems and related programming interests at nearly $23 billion, and called for Bell Atlantic to assume about $10 billion of T.C.I.'s debt.
Yet soon afterward, both sides began to realize how difficult, time-consuming and complicated the merger would actually be.
 
Corporate Tire Kickers
 Bell Atlantic and T.C.I. dispatched inspection teams -- corporate tire kickers -- to each other's empires less than a week after the deal was announced last fall. For each side, the results were revealing.
T.C.I. is the nation's largest cable-systems operator with 10.4 million subscribers nationwide. But only a modest percentage of its franchises are modern, high-channel-capacity systems in major metropolitan centers, passing at least 100,000 homes. In contrast, Time Warner, Cablevision and Cox, for example, each have sizable metropolitan holdings.
The difference reflects T.C.I.'s history as largely a collection of smaller, rural systems. But it also means that the investment costs will be considerable for anyone meaning to upgrade the T.C.I. operations for the high-capacity, 500-channel future. After the deal was scuttled, Mr. Smith said, "T.C.I. is not the premier property in the industry."
On the T.C.I. side, there were gnawing doubts about whether Bell Atlantic, which serves a six-state region from New Jersey to Virginia, including Washington, would really abandon its phone-company traditions and become a growth company.
Although Bell Atlantic is known as the most adventurous of the seven regional Baby Bells created by the antitrust breakup of A.T.&.T in 1984, the scrappy, entrepreneurial types at T.C.I. viewed it as a high-cost, slow-moving bureaucracy.
A joke that made the rounds in the T.C.I. camp spoke volumes about how the cable people viewed the companies' culture gap: What's gray with a blue-and-gold stripe and sleeps six? A Bell Atlantic repair truck.
 
Unionized Workers
 Bell Atlantic's 73,600-member work force is largely unionized, while T.C.I.'s 22,000 employees are mainly nonunion. Bell Atlantic's per-worker benefits costs, according to one T.C.I. adviser, were estimated an nearly four times the level at T.C.I.
But the biggest obstacle to the merger was the companies' disparate financial cultures. Bell Atlantic, in the tradition of telephone utilities, reports hefty earnings -- $1.4 billion last year on revenues of $13 billion -- and it pays generous dividends to its shareholders.
T.C.I., the cable powerhouse, operates by an entirely different financial logic. Although its cash flow -- income before interest payments, depreciation and other charges -- was $1.86 billion last year on revenues of $4.15 billion -- because it borrows heavily to finance aggressive growth and investment, it reports almost no net income, after paying interest on loans, and it pays no dividends. Its shareholders are seeking a stake in a fast-growing pile of assets and betting on the future.
Mr. Malone speaks of reported profits, the traditional yardstick of corporate performance, with disdain. "If you start to show reported earnings," he said, "you've probably stopped growing."
 
Growing Apart
A Financial Gap Too Wide to Span
 Despite the uncertainties -- compounded by a steady decline in both companies' stock prices -- the two executives were cheered after they met on Jan. 27., at the Marriott Hotel near the airport in Portland, Me., not far from Boothbay, where Mr. Malone has a vacation home. Each man had one adviser present.
The two sides, the executives and advisers say, went over thorny issues that had cropped up repeatedly during the merger talks. To allay any Bell Atlantic qualms about his post-merger plans, for example, Mr. Malone was willing to agree not to enter into any venture that might compete with the combined company for at least five years. He said that this proviso "was no big deal."
But pricing, as always, was a big deal. And on this, both sides say, real progress was made in Portland.
 
F.C.C. as Rate Cutter
 Mr. Smith gave Mr. Malone an update on the Federal Communications Commission, which was expected to issue new rules on another round of cable television rate cuts. According to one person at the meeting, Mr. Smith said that Bell Atlantic's people monitoring the agency in Washington had assured him that no drastic cuts were expected -- certainly nothing that would scuttle the merger plan.
And so the two men roughed out what Mr. Malone later called a "robust structure" for the deal -- a set number of Bell Atlantic shares to be paid for T.C.I. Neither side will spell out what that exchange ratio was to have been, citing confidentiality agreements. The two executives left the meeting confident enough to agree that their lawyers could draw up the paperwork for the definitive agreement.
"By the end of January," Mr. Malone recalled, "both Ray and I thought we had a solution."
The details of the "robust structure" had progressed far enough over the next two weeks that, by Feb. 11, Mr. Malone and Mr. Smith agreed to meet again soon to wrap things up.
But the picture had clouded considerably by the time they met on the afternoon of Wednesday, Feb. 23, at the Manhattan offices of Bell Atlantic's legal adviser, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. The day before, the F.C.C. had decided to roll back the rates that American consumers pay on basic cable television service by 7 percent. Moreover, any future price increases would be limited to 2 percentage points less than the rate of inflation.
Thus, it was a wary group of seven who gathered in the 44th-floor conference room: for Bell Atlantic, Mr. Smith and two aides, and for T.C.I., Mr. Malone and three aides.
 
Reduction in Cash Flow
 Mr. Malone, briefing Mr. Smith on the impact of the F.C.C. action, said it would reduce the cash generated from T.C.I.'s cable system subscribers -- $1.86 billion in 1993 -- by roughly $144 million a year.
This was a problem, Mr. Malone acknowledged, but mainly a short-term one. T.C.I., he predicted, would be able to recoup revenues with new pay-per-view services and other offerings not subject to the rate strictures. The F.C.C. action, in his view, should not alter the pricing formula. After all, he argued, this was a merger for long-term gains.
But Mr. Smith saw the F.C.C.'s action as altering the whole equation. The Bell Atlantic model for valuing T.C.I. was to multiply its cash flow by 11.75 times, a formula similar to that applied to most cable-systems purchases. So, by Mr. Smith's reckoning, the T.C.I. price should now be cut by about $1.7 billion. "If T.C.I. was willing to make up much of the $1.7 billion difference," Mr. Smith later said, "we could have still gone ahead."
 
Diluting Earnings
 But if Bell Atlantic went ahead on the terms favored by Mr. Malone, the combined company's reported earnings would be watered down for an additional two to three years -- beyond the three or four years expected when the merger was announced. And Bell Atlantic, Mr. Smith said, would be paying a full 14 times T.C.I.'s cash flow.
Mr. Smith stands by his decision to demand better terms. "The week after we broke off the deal wasn't pleasant," he recalled, "after all the excitement we had stirred up and all the work we had done. But it would have been a horrendous week if I had to justify paying 14 times cash flow to the Bell Atlantic shareholders."
On the T.C.I. side, the unbridgeable price gap is regarded as further evidence of the different corporate cultures. "We were taking a long-term perspective,." Mr. Malone said.
But in the end, Mr. Malone was selling more of the future than Mr. Smith was willing to buy. "It looked like a tremendous deal in October," Mr. Smith recalled, "but it didn't look that way anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Malone of T.C.I., top (Michael Lewis), and Raymond W. Smith of Bell Atlantic could not agree on a deal. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times) (pg. D5)

JUNE 16, 1993: Bell Atlantic's chairman, Raymond W. Smith, calls on T.C.I.'s chief executive, John Malone, at his office in Englewood, Colo. Mr. Smith advances the idea of a "strategic partnership" or even a merger.
 
JULY 12: Mr. Malone and T.C.I.'s founder and chairman, Bob Magness, dine with Mr. Smith andother Bell Atlantic executives at a T.C.I. apartment in Manhattan. They later agree to pursue a merger.
 
OCT. 13: The merger plan is announced. Bell Atlantic agrees to acquire T.C.I.'s cable systems and related interests in programming for nearly $23 billion in stock, and assume about $10 billionof T.C.I.'s debt. Mr. Smith will be chief executive of the combined company, with Mr. Malone overseeing strategy, programming and technology.
 
JAN. 27, 1994: After a series of abortive agreements, Mr. Smith and Mr. Malone meet at ahotel near the Portland, Me., airport. They devise a rough framework for how many shares of Bell Atlantic stock will be paid for each T.C.I. share. Mr. Smith notes that the Federal Communications Commission is about to order cuts in cable rates but reportedlysays no deep cuts are expected.

T.C.I. executives expect the cut to reduce the flow of cash the company generates from its cable system subscribers by roughly $144 million a year. Its 1993 cash flow was $1.86 billion.
 
FEB. 23: In a meeting at a Manhattan law firm, Mr. Malone acknowledges to Mr. Smith that the F.C.C.'s rate-cutting action and its effect on T.C.I.'s cashflow represent a problem, but only a short-term one that does not warrant changing the terms of the merger deal again. But by Mr. Smith's reckoning, the price Bell Atlantic is to pay for T.C.I. should drop by about $1.7 billion. With neither side willing to renegotiate the prenuptial agreement, the wedding is off.

HEADLINE: Export Fall Broadens Trade Gap

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
A record plunge in exports vastly widened the nation's overall trade deficit in January even as the imbalance with Japan narrowed, Government figures showed today.
For the first time, the monthly tabulation counts services, an area that includes such things as tourism in which the United States has traditionally racked up surpluses that have significantly offset deficits in goods. 
 The inclusion of services did little to limit the enlargement of the deficit. Services, a steadier component than goods, according to monthly figures provided for the last two years, produced a $4.7 billion surplus in January, compared with $4.6 billion in December.
For January, combined imports of goods and services exceeded exports by $6.3 billion, up from $4.1 billion in December when computed on the same basis and adjusted for normal seasonal variation.
 
Weather Blamed
 While the enlargement was substantial -- and greater than generally expected -- analysts said that they were not alarmed because the trade figures, which are notoriously erratic, had also been affected by bad weather in various parts of the country, which held down both production and the transportation of goods to export markets.
"These numbers are volatile," Michael P. Niemira, a specialist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, cautioned. "I wouldn't read too much into the size of the decline in exports."
He and others noted that shipments of commercial aircraft alone tumbled by $462 million after a December surge, an almost inevitable sort of correction in a category of high-priced items where deliveries tend to be made in bunches.
Analysts said they could not tell how much of the export drop reflected bad weather, statistical aberration or continued languishing of the economies of American trading partners.
But they were heartened by separate, more recent indicators pointing to continued robust growth in the economy and the fact that exported goods ran nearly 2 percent higher in December and January combined than they had in October and November.
"The worsening may be more statistical than real," said Robert G. Dederick, a former Commerce Department official who is now chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Imports, meanwhile, eased $600 million, the Commerce Department's report showed. Half this reduction was in crude oil, reflecting both lesser volumes and lower prices.
Over all, a deficit in goods totaling $11 billion was partly offset by a surplus in services of $4.7 billion. For services alone, previously published only on a quarterly basis, exports were $15.7 billion and imports were $11 billion.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown observed that $2 billion of the services surplus came from tourism, transportation and related activity; $1.3 billion was in royalties and fees from such intellectual property as trademarks and patents, and $1.7 billion came from finance, engineering, design, legal, accounting and similar work.
Such earnings, he said, "belie any image of the service sector as a low-productivity source of low-wage jobs."
 
Ploy Assertion Denied
 At a briefing, department officials brushed off suggestions that the inclusion of services was a ploy to minimize the size of the monthly reported trade deficit. They said the process had been under way for 18 months and that the change was endorsed by the National Academy of Sciences as well as by service industries and the nation's trade negotiators.
Private economists generally concurred, backing the idea as sound -- though not as revealing as they might have hoped -- even if given some political impetus.
One feature they would like is a breakdown of services by country or other geographic area, which statisticians say is not yet feasible. Nor are services presented in constant dollars to adjust for price changes.
Today's report showed that the nation's goods deficit with Japan narrowed to $4.6 billion in January from $5.3 billion in December, with no adjustment for recurring seasonal factors. This was the smallest deficit since June.
The United States, which ran a $59.3 billion deficit with Japan last year, is waiting to hear what Japan proposes to revive negotiations about American demands for specific goals to gauge pledges of increased access to Japanese markets. Those talks collapsed in February.
 
Other Changes Made
 In addition to adding services, the new presentation shifts the emphasis for import and export values to a balance-of-payments basis. This produces somewhat higher levels than the previously featured set of figures, which relied on Customs Service documentation of physical movements across national boundaries. Goods can change ownership without being moved.
If no accounting change had been made, January would have shown a deficit in merchandise trade of $9.8 billion, up from a $7.4 billion deficit in December that had been the smallest in a year.
While services figure importantly in American trade -- the surplus rising steadily since 1986 -- the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company found little evidence of an American "structural advantage" in this area.
"Trends in overall services trade mirror trends in goods trade," it stated. "There is no noticeable trend toward a greater U.S. concentration of earnings from services."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed In Confusion on Fed Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished narrowly mixed against other major currencies yesterday after whipsawing during the day on conflicting impressions of whether the Federal Reserve was raising interest rates.
Traders said the dollar initially fell after the Fed added reserves to the money market through two-day repurchase agreements. While such an operation is routine, investors mistakenly took it as a sign that the Fed had decided against pushing up short-term interest rates, as the markets had expected. 
 But later, the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, announced that it was slightly raising short-term rates. The Federal funds rate, a rate for overnight loans between banks, rose to 3.5 percent from 3.25 percent.
 
A Way to Increase Return
 Investors then bought the dollar, increasing its value. Higher interest rates usually buoy currencies, since they translate into higher returns on dollar-denominated deposits.
But the interest rate increase was less than traders had expected. "People had pretty much discounted a 25-basis-point hike," said Win Thin, an economist at MCM Currencywatch.
The Fed first pushed up the Federal funds rate to 3.25 percent from 3 percent on Feb. 4.
Traders said the dollar's volatility reflected confusion over which way the currency might next go. The dollar has been weak despite the American economic recovery and Russian political turmoil. The dollar is often seen as a haven in times of ferment.
"None of these factors seems to have given the dollar any support," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber Inc.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 106.05 Japanese yen, up slightly from 105.89 yen on Monday. But it slipped to 1.6885 German marks, down from 1.6895 marks.
The British pound slipped to $1.4875 from $1.4895. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Monday, were: 1.4300 Swiss francs, down from 1.4310; 5.7648 French francs, up from 5.7623; 1,668 Italian lire, down from 1,669, and $1.3669 (Canadian), down from $1.3693.

HEADLINE: Academic Disciplines Increasingly Entwine, Recasting Scholarship

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Human DNA can best be understood if studied as "a work of literature." That, at least, is the contention of Robert Pollack, a professor of biological sciences at Columbia University who has just unveiled the theory in his book "Signs of Life."
Scholars and scientists will recognize Professor Pollack's thesis as an example of one of the hottest trends in current academic life: interdisciplinary studies. At campuses across the country, biology is merging with physics and chemistry, anthropology is borrowing from literary theory and feminist studies, economics is mixing with cognitive psychology and bio spheric studies, and political science is absorbing mathematics, molecular biology and environmental studies. 
 "The boundaries between disciplines are becoming blurred," said Sheldon Hackney, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. "We've reached the point in the study of American history where you can't tell the difference between what the sociologists, the political scientists and the historians are doing."
 
A Basic Transformation
 Of course, interdisciplinary studies are not new. In the 1930's, for example, undergraduates at Yale University could major in an interdisciplinary program called "History, the Arts and Letters." But in the past, scholars would leap academic borders to borrow a skill to solve a specific problem and then retreat. Today, they interact with such intensity that their disciplines themselves frequently become transformed.
In current interdisciplinary studies, explained Colin Lucas, dean of the graduate division of social sciences at the University of Chicago, "you don't just acquire a technique, but new forms appear within your discipline, modifying the discipline itself."
Educational administrators say that young faculty members and students are propelling the trend, which may also transform the university, abolishing outmoded disciplines, creating new ones and developing ways to attack problems from one more than one direction rather than compartmentalizing knowledge.
"We're beginning to recognize that God did not create the universe according to the departmental structure of our research universities," said John A. Armstrong, former director of research at I.B.M. and a visiting lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The sciences have proved an especially fertile field for interdisciplinary studies. "Following the discovery of the structure of DNA, chemistry and physics have gradually become drawn into the field of biology," Professor Pollack said. "Such old disciplines as zoology and botany are fading, replaced by studies like structural biology, which marries physics, chemistry and biology, and cognitive biology, which seeks to understand behavior at the biological level."
In his study of DNA, Professor Pollack said, he is trying to marry the humanities and biology.
 
Opponents Speak Out
 Some professors look upon the trend with dismay. Harvey Mansfield, a professor of political philosophy at Harvard, said interdisciplinary studies "allow professors who don't want to pursue a normal and presumably difficult path to make a success of their unstudied opinions." Professor Mansfield was the only Harvard faculty member to vote against the university's adoption of the women's studies major in 1986.
In the past, interdisciplinary studies were sometimes ridiculed as dilettantism, along the line of "if you can't do anything, try everything." But today what some call "collective engagement" has attracted many of the best brains in academia. For example, one of the most popular new courses at Harvard, "Thinking About Thinking," is jointly taught by the lawyer Alan Dershowitz; the paleontologist Stephen Jay Gould and the philosopher Robert Nozick.
"By juxtaposing our different disciplines," Professor Dershowitz said, "we're forcing students out of their mind-set and making them think about things from a wholly different perspective."
While the trend cannot be measured precisely, Professor Murray Krieger, the founding director of the University of California Humanities Research Institute, said its scope was reflected in the proliferation of advertisements for scholars with multiple specialties, like "19th-century English teacher with additional capacity in feminist theory," and in catalogue offerings like "Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry."
The growth of interest can also be measured by student demand. Over the last decade, registration in interdisciplinary courses at Yale rose 40 percent and interdisciplinary majors 31 percent, said Charles H. Long, the university's deputy provost.
 
Explaining Popularity
 The reason for such growth is simple, said Nannerl O. Keohane, the president of Duke University: teleconferencing and electronic mail have accelerated communication, knowledge is spilling over traditional boundaries and new investigative tools have suggested the possibility of asking new questions.
Sanford Levinson, a professor at the Law School of the University of Texas who has participated in projects relating law to literature and music, said the desire to combine disciplines stemmed from a loss of faith in the traditional disciplines, an event that he said occurred in the 1960's.
"Literary scholars now recognize that there is no such thing as the rock-hard meaning of language," Professor Levinson said, "and legal scholars see that there is no particular way of thinking like a lawyer, and so they both look around for other takes and interesting juxtapositions."
Another explanation for the trend, intellectual restlessness, came from James Winn, director of the Institute for the Humanities at the University of Michigan, an interdisciplinary think tank.
"Many scholars have come to believe that the narrow approaches to a subject have been pretty much played out," Professor Winn said, "and so they have begun to look elsewhere. If the English scholar looks to anthropology, say, he can come up with a striking new set of questions to address."
 
Industry Plays a Role
 Interdisciplinary work in the sciences is frequently stimulated by the patronage of private industry. At Stanford University, more than a dozen industrial affiliates sponsor the Center for the Study of Language and Information, which combines philosophy, computer science, psychology and linguistics in an effort to develop computers that can understand speech.
The sponsors -- many in the computer software business -- donate $50,000 a year, and while they cannot prescribe research, they attend meetings, receive papers and have ready access to the center's work.
But the continued surge of interdisciplinary studies is not without a major obstacle: the departmental structure of American colleges and universities. Departments determine raises, promotions and tenure, and many are notoriously unsympathetic toward faculty members who work outside their disciplines.
Donald McCloskey, a professor of economics and history at the University of Iowa, has written several books arguing that economic writing has much in common with fiction. But because of such academic trespassing, his professional colleagues say, he has not been invited to teach at a top-tier university.
"The system rewards you for becoming boring," Professor Winn of Michigan said. "If a specialist in the Victorian novel writes a book on film, even a brilliant book, his colleagues will say he's 'all over the place' and not doing his job."
 
Success in Teamwork
 Yet interdisciplinary studies continue to gather force. Sometimes the work is done by a varied team of specialists. At Duke, for example, specialists in such diverse disciplines as archeology, art history, nuclear chemistry, linguistics, theoretical mathematics, ethnography and literary criticism joined to study ancient Maya pottery. The variety of techniques and backgrounds they took to the project led to their discovery that the artifacts were not just funerary offerings, as has long been supposed, but contained political messages as well.
"Top-quality research in the future in fields like archeology and history will be strongly interdisciplinary," Dorie Reents-Budet, curator of pre-Columbian art at the Duke Museum who organized the pottery project, said, "simply because no one person can be expert in all the specialties involved."
Groups of scholars, as well as individual ones, are designing interdisciplinary programs and courses. For instance, the newly formed International Center for Humanistic Discourses at the University of California at Irvine will meet next month to find ways to include Far Eastern culture in comparative literature. One of the earliest interdisciplinary majors, comparative literature gained acceptance in the 1950's, but today, because it is usually restricted to European languages, it is considered by some scholars as in drastic need of overhaul.
 
Looking at the Future
 Some scholars expect interdisciplinary studies to continue to grow. Current economic pressures might accelerate the trend, said Stanley Katz, president of the American Council of Learned Societies, by forcing the clustering of departments like anthropology, psychology and sociology. "It could be seen as a more efficient use of human resources," Professor Katz said.
Others prefer to retain the current departmental structure.
"Interdisciplinary work depends on having the disciplines," said Professor Arjun Appadurai, an anthropologist at the University of Chicago who is studying what he calls post national global allegiances. "It's like managing a portfolio of stocks. You don't want to become fossilized, and you don't want to be overtaken by fashions. You have to strike a balance."
Still others believe that the interdisciplinary studies movement is merely a transitional stage toward a radically different university.
Interdisciplinary study is only "a temporary effort to get at a greater interconnectedness," said Ralph Cohen, a professor of English at the University of Virginia and director of the Commonwealth Center for Literary and Cultural Change.
"Ultimately, the whole structure of the university must be changed," he said, "but that's a job for the next century."
