HEADLINE: Struggling With the Fed's Fallout

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
If inflation is under control -- and by most accounts it seems to be -- why did the Federal Reserve raise short-term interest rates yesterday?
One reason may be that the Fed sees inflationary pressures that normal mortals do not. But another reason is that the monetary authorities needed to send a calming message to investors, who had pushed long-term interest rates up to almost 7 percent. 
 One of those investors in Alliance Capital Management, which invests more than $60 billion in bonds for corporations and for individuals who put money in its top-ranked mutual funds. A look at the company and what it has been doing for the last few weeks shows, in microcosm, how such investors are coping with the current uncertainty about interest rates, and how hard it will be for the Fed to calm the bond market. This is because, it turns out, a lot more than inflation influences interest rates.
When their computer terminals flashed the news -- "Greenspan Says Fed Acts to Raise Interest Rates" -- it did not come as a surprise to the portfolio managers at Alliance, who spent a quiet morning sitting around the firm's sleek gray trading desk watching computer screens flickering headlines and prices. Normally, Alliance's managers, who do their own trading, do not worry much about day-to-day Fed activities. But yesterday, they were "looking for a clue, paying more attention than normal, by a lot," Wayne Lyski, who runs Alliance's huge United States bond portfolios, said.
But while Mr. Lyski had his expectations, and his portfolio strategy, confirmed, he is not sure whether the Fed's self-declared "slight" tightening will be enough to calm the market and send the message the Fed intended: that the Fed will do what it must to keep inflation low, the bond markets calm and long-term interest rates down.
"I don't know," he allowed. Like most market participants, he assumed that "slight" translates into an increase of a quarter of a percentage point, or 25 basis points, to 3.5 percent in the Fed's short-term interest rate target. "There is an element of uncertainty introduced by the fact that it was 25 basis points, versus 50 basis points," he said, because the market would now worry that there was another increase coming in a month or so. "It may have been better for the market if the increase had been 50 basis points," he added, "but there has to be economic support for what they do, and that would have been stretching it."
That is because evidence of inflation, the archenemy of the bond market, is still hard to come by. A few indexes do hint at it, Mr. Lyski noted, but many others, from the price of gold to February's Consumer and Producer Price Indexes, are signaling good news. If consumers want to buy something, they can almost certainly find it on sale. In our everyday lives, he said, "We don't have a sense of impending inflation."
And yet, interest rates keep rising. Despite a slight decrease yesterday, intermediate and long-term rates have climbed almost a full percentage point this year, prompting complaints from President Clinton, who said recently that "there's no inflation in the economy."
 
 
More Than Inflation
 But inflation is not all that influences interest rates, even at a firm like Alliance that prides itself on paying close attention to fundamental economic trends. Trading strategies based only on bets on the changing relationship between long- and short-term interest rates -- not on their direction -- prompt buying and selling. Losses in one market -- like those suffered in Europe and Asia in February by big institutional investors, including George Soros -- may prompt investors to sell in the United States bond market to raise money to cover their losses. Academic theories, investor psychology, tax rates and the often arcane science of interpreting what goes on at the Federal Reserve also are in play. And everyone you ask emphasizes a different thing.
In other words, it can be a long way from economic theory to interest rate reality.
At Alliance, the theory begins with Lawrence L. Kreicher, a scholarly, soft-voiced economist and senior vice president. His job is to try to figure out where interest rates will be six months from now; every quarter he prepares an interest-rate forecast, which he and his staff update every week.
Admittedly, he said, "the actual inflation numbers look pretty good, but inflation is a sneaky, insidious kind of variable." By the time inflation is obvious, he said, it is too late for the Fed to control it.
 
 
Too Much Caution Seen
 If anything, he argues, the Fed is moving too slowly, too gradually. "I remain concerned that this Fed will err on the side of caution," he said. Bond investors are not so patient; even if the chance of inflation heating up is only one in five, the market will act, he explained. "The bond market has assumed the role of disciplinarian, and will squelch any tendencies that would produce greater inflation."
But why, if the Fed is acting to stem inflation far down the pike, has the bond market reacted so badly? This is where psychology comes in, said Selig L. Sechzer, the young Alliance economist who spends many mornings on the trading floor explaining the economic data that comes pouring in. Investor sentiment suddenly shifted, he said, from a bull market outlook to a bear market outlook, "where the best you could hope for is some sideways movement." He added, "It's been a while since many bond managers had to operate in a rising interest rate market; there are many young bond managers who have never seen one."
Mr. Lyski has. He recalls vividly that before 1987, "money supply was the big deal." "It was all anybody cared about," he added. "Even if you knew which way the economy was going, it didn't help you." Since then, he said, the economy has been all important, and he clings to economic fundamentals to keep from being swept away in the hysteria that often hits markets.
But he also looks at things that might strike the average person as technical, such as how much money is flowing into mutual funds and the differences between short-term and long-term interest rates. When these interest rates are plotted on a chart, they form what's called a yield curve; the bigger the difference between the shortest and longest rates, the steeper the curve. When the yield curve is very steep, that implies that interest rates will go up, because it indicates that people are worried about holding long-term debt, Mr. Lyski said. "As the yield curve flattens," he added, "it decreases the risk that rates will rise."
 
 
Reacting to the Curve
 Two weeks ago, when the yield curve was very steep, Mr. Lyski decided it was likely to get flatter, that the spread between short-term and long-term rates would narrow. So in the mornings, as he sat at the trading desk, he began selling bonds with intermediate maturities, and buying short-term and long-term debt. His purchases included the bonds that move most sharply as long-term interest rates change -- zero-coupon Treasury bonds -- and corporate notes with rates that float along with short-term indexes.
The strategy -- lots of bonds at the short and long ends and very little in between -- is called a barbell, or, "when it doesn't work, it's called a dumbbell," Mr. Lyski joked. To avoid that nasty fate, he moves gradually, watching the market to see if other mangers are doing the same thing, watching price changes to see if the strategy is paying off. Because the yield curve is getting a bit flatter, he said yesterday, he has continued to implement the barbell approach, and is now about three-quarters completed.
At one end of the trading room, Robert Sinche directs a small army of young men in white shirts who manage Alliance's many international bond funds. His markets have been moving even more sharply than those in the United States. "Everyone is making this out to be an inflation scare, but I'm not sure it's not a little simpler than that," he said. The culprit in the international bond markets was "the weight of the money," he added.
 
 
'Fads and Flows'
 By this he means that investors were pouring so much money into bonds, in America as well as in Europe and emerging markets, that they drove prices up -- and yields down -- to absurd levels. A small shift in interest rates and currencies, and the process reversed, pushing rates up to what an investor might have predicted last year, Mr. Sinche said. "The market moves on fads and flows; you do have to pay attention to it," he said.
And you can take advantage of it. Mr. Sinche said that in the last few weeks, when investors with losses had to sell Italian and Australian bonds -- driving the prices down sharply -- he bought. Once the prices rebounded, he sold. For the longer term, his portfolio is now heavily weighted toward European bonds maturing in three to seven years, he said yesterday. He thinks these bonds, which were hit hard as speculators dumped them, will rally.
In a quiet moment, Paul De Noon, a young Government bond portfolio manager who works with Mr. Lyski, said that in a way it did not matter whether he saw any inflation in the economy or not. What matters is what the Federal Reserve sees, and what the market thinks the Federal Reserve sees. "This is their game, played by their rules, and they brought the ball," he said. "If you disregard policy makers, you may be right in the very long term, but in the very short term you'll suffer a lot of pain."

Wayne Lyski, who runs Alliance's United States bond portfolios, conferred on the trading floor with Lori Cole, an assistant. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Harvey H. Segal; Author, 71

 BODY:
Dr. Harvey H. Segal, an economics professor and author of a book highly critical of American business, died on Monday at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital. Mr. Segal, who lived in Manhattan, was 71.
The cause was kidney and bone cancer, said his wife, Eloise. 
 Dr. Segal's book "Corporate Make-
over: The Reshaping of the American Economy" (1989) cited many tales of managerial waste and abuse. He wrote widely and was a member of the editorial board of The New York Times from 1968 to 1969. From 1971 to 1988 he was a vice president of Citibank.
Dr. Segal graduated from the University of North Carolina and received a doctorate from Columbia University.
Dr. Segal is survived by his wife; his son, Harry, of Ithaca, N.Y., and his daughter, Emma Segal of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Ragnar Naess, Economist, 93, And Counselor

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Ragnar Dekke Naess, an economist and investment counselor to individuals and institutions, died on March 15 at his retirement home in Essex, Conn. He was 93 and had moved there from Manhattan in 1989.
The cause was a heart attack, his family said. 
 For nearly 30 years, Mr. Naess was an owner and a senior partner in the firm of Naess & Thomas, a Manhattan-based investment advisory company. The firm started originally as Naess & Cummings in 1939.
Born in Oslo into a prosperous family, he was educated in Norway until he came to the United States at the age of 19. He graduated in chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1923 and earned an M.B.A. at the Harvard Business School three years later.
He started his career as an assistant economist at the Federal Reserve Bank in New York, a job involving business forecasting and monetary problems. His interest in the stock market led him to develop economic data and charts with which to appraise business outlook, corporate earnings and stock prices.
Moving into the private securities business, he found his career derailed by the economic turmoil of the time. But as a researcher for the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, his bearish forecasts proved to be correct and he was put in charge of the research department of the parent firm, Goldman Sachs & Company.
He was right once more when his measurements indicated that the economy and the market would bottom out in 1932. He turned bearish again early in 1937. Later that year he was named economist and a vice president at Tri-Continental Corporation, a large investment fund, with the princely salary of $35,000.
Two years later he formed his own partnership. The firm was acquired by Schroders Ltd., a London merchant bank, in 1969 and became Schroder Naess & Thomas. He retired as its chairman in 1971 but remained a consultant for several more years. Schroders changed the name to Schroder Capital Management Company in 1983.
He was a sailing enthusiast and skier, competing into his early 80's.
Mr. Naess is survived by his wife of 63 years, Margaret Dixon Naess; two sons, Ragnar D., of Brooklyn and Robert E. of Cavendish, Vt.; a brother, Arne, and a sister, Kristine Naess, both of Oslo, and two grandsons.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
'Crazy Eddie' Sentencing Is Weighed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 22

 BODY:
A Federal judge heard evidence today about what sentence to give Eddie Antar, the founder of the Crazy Eddie electronics chain, for his role in a stock fraud that cost investors millions of dollars.
Mr. Antar's lawyer argued that the sentence and restitution sought by the Government were too severe. He also said that Mr. Antar was willing to plead guilty to criminal charges and settle a civil case brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 The lawyer, John J. Barry, also disclosed that Mr. Antar was willing to return $52 million to the United States, complying with a court order that he had defied since fleeing the country in February 1990.
 
One Brother Also Convicted
 Testimony is to continue on Wednesday, when Judge Nicholas H. Politan said he would sentence Mr. Antar, 46, and his brother, Mitchell, 38, who were convicted eight months ago of defrauding stockholders in their chain.
A third brother, Allen, 44, was acquitted. He attended today's hearing, as did more than a dozen members of the Antar family.
Eddie Antar wore blue prison garb, handcuffs and shackles in court today. He has been jailed since his arrest in Israel in June 1992.
Crazy Eddie became the biggest electronics retailer in the New York area in the 1980's. It was known for loud commercials in which a frenzied announcer boasted of prices that were "INSAAAAAAAANE."
Eddie Antar was convicted of illegally pocketing $75 million by selling his stock when he knew that its price was artificially inflated through bogus inventory and sales figures.
 
Stiff Sentence Sought
 Federal prosecutors are asking Judge Politan for a 25-year sentence for Mr. Antar, four to five times the range of 55 to 71 months calculated by Federal probation officials.
In papers filed with the court, Mr. Barry said that when Mr. Antar offered to plead guilty before the trial he was facing a term of seven and a half years. That proposed deal was scrapped by the Government when Allen Antar refused to plead guilty, he wrote.
The Government will not comment on plea negotiations.
Mr. Barry noted that Mr. Antar waived extradition after his arrest in Israel. "Since Mr. Antar's return to the United States, he has sought continuously to obtain a fair and impartial hearing as to the correct amount of illegal profits he should be required to repatriate," Mr. Barry wrote. "He has been rebuffed at every turn."
A witness called by the Government, William C. Dale, an economist with the S.E.C., said today that investors in Crazy Eddie stock and bonds lost at least $120.3 million while the Antars had control of the company.
That figure rises to $286 million, Mr. Dale said, by including investors who bought stock before it peaked and by factoring in the losses after new management took over.
Mr. Barry said he would call an expert witness on Wednesday to testify that investor losses totaled less than $36 million.
At its peak in June 1986, Crazy Eddie stock traded at about $80 a share, giving the company a worth of $620 million. Two years later, amid disclosures of financial problems, the stock was at $1 a share.
Mr. Antar's offer to pay the $52 million, which stems from a related civil case brought by the S.E.C., must be viewed in light of his conduct over the last four years, the United States Attorney, Michael Chertoff, said.
He suggested that Mr. Antar sign papers to begin the process of returning the money before Judge Politan moves to end the contempt case against him. Mr. Barry said he would have to discuss that proposal with Mr. Antar.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eddie Antar, left, being led into Federal court yesterday in Newark. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Climbs to 4-Year High As Traders Bet on Inflation

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Silver prices surged to their highest levels in more than four years yesterday as some traders bet that the Federal Reserve would fail in its latest effort to keep inflation under control. Other precious metals also gained.
Silver rose 17.3 cents, to $5.596 an ounce, at the Commodity Exchange in New York, the highest price for the active silver futures contract since November 1989. 
 The Fed made its second credit-tightening move in the last two months yesterday, saying it will push up short-term interest rates slightly.
Bernard Savaiko, a Paine Webber analyst, said the precious metals market was "calling the Fed's bluff," expressing its opinion that a small interest rate increase would not be enough to restrain inflation.
Concerns about escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula and about strikes and political unrest in South Africa gave underlying support to precious metals.
Several traders, however, contended that the price gain was technically motivated, with silver attracting new buyers as it moved above certain price points.
"Silver broke through $5.50, then gold hit $388," a dealer said, noting that these prices were buy signals for many traders.
On the Comex, the active April gold contract gained $3.40, to $389.70 an ounce, a two-month high. And April platinum rose $2.90, to $405.90 an ounce, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 Speculation in silver has surged in the last year as a number of countries, especially India, have increased their purchases. But there have been signs that demand has been slowing since silver moved above $5 an ounce in December.
On other commodity markets, speculative buying fueled a rally in coffee prices, which jumped to 15-month highs. Low domestic stocks and fears that coffee producers will crimp supplies lent support. Coffee for May delivery rose 1.15 cents, to 82.90 cents a pound, at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, the April contract on crude oil, which expired at the close of trading, fell 17 cents to end at $15.20 a barrel. May crude declined 7 cents, to $15.16 a barrel; April unleaded gasoline was up 0.25 cent, to 46.87 cents a gallon; April heating oil edged up 0.11 cent, to 45.20 cents a gallon, and April natural gas rose 5.2 cents, to $2.107 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Wheat prices sank to four-month lows at the Chicago Board of Trade, burdened by a lack of export demand and a long-range weather forecast calling for drought-relieving rains in the Great Plains.
May wheat fell 7 cents, to $3.2975 a bushel; May corn declined 3 cents, to $2.8275; May oats dropped 2.5 cents, to $1.3125, and May soybeans lost 2.75 cents, to $6.86 a bushel.
The wheat market was affected by the absence of China and Russia from the American wheat market and also by the United States' recent decision to reject Egypt's bid for subsidized wheat, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
The Riddles Of Race, Circa '68

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
A cacophony of sirens, raised voices and gunshots pervades "The Day the Bronx Died," Michael Henry Brown's cleanly delineated anatomy of racial and class tensions in an integrated neighborhood in the late 1960's; there are vicious shouted epithets and piercing cries for mercy.
But the play's most affecting moment is a quiet one. Three teen-age boys of disparate social backgrounds have just witnessed a murder. And the bold adult postures they have been trying to maintain, in emulation of both baseball heroes and James Bond villains, have slipped off like oversize jackets. Their silence and their hunched, embryonic postures are resonant with fear and a sense of futility. Adolescent fantasies have dissolved in the face of the realization that their world is indeed a dangerous one in which death, as another character puts it, "comes fast and natural." 
 The sharp sense of fears beyond rationalization may account for much of the great emotional pull the work seems to exert on its audiences at the American Jewish Theater. "The Day the Bronx Died," directed with spare economy by Gordon Edelstein, is by no means a particularly well-written play. It is bracingly complex in its sociology, presenting the different layers of antagonism that exist within, as well as between, different races. But as a coming-of-age tale, it gives off the pained sincerity of a young adult novel. Its language can have an inauthentically stilted ring: "Death had established an unwanted intimacy with me," says one character. And there is a nakedly diagrammatic quality to its development.
Still, the play has an inescapable poignancy, which is underscored by the fact that the problems it presents have only escalated since the time in which it is set. Its suggestion that there may be no "safe place" in urban America is guaranteed to strike responsive chords.
Structurally, the work borrows, in very conventional ways, from the old-fashioned memory play. As it begins, Mickey (Leon Addison Brown), a prosperous black man who lives in an affluent Manhattan building where his mother "once toiled as a domestic," is in a hospital, waiting to see if his son is going to live. The 13-year-old boy has been attacked on a subway. Mickey's mind "flashes back" to 1968, the year he was 13 and the year of the Bronx riots that followed the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
"I straddled two worlds," Mickey tells us, as actors representing his past fill the blank stage. The young Mickey (Akili Prince), who lives with his recently widowed mother (Brenda Denmark) in a house in an integrated middle-class section of the Bronx, is torn between allegiances to Billy Kornblum (Neal Huff), a clean-cut Jewish boy, and Alexander (Luis A. Laporte Jr.), a tough, street-smart black kid.
Alexander is gradually drawn into a network of young thugs ruled over by the sadistic Prince (Kelly Neal). And Mickey is presented with diametrically opposed options for self-preservation: Alexander urges him to join Prince's gang; his homily-spouting mother wants him to confine himself to more culturally uplifting pursuits, represented by piano lessons, James Baldwin books and Little League baseball games with his "nice Jewish friends."
These worlds are destined to collide, of course, leaving a path of betrayal, death and disenchantment. Mr. Brown is at his best in exploring the gradations and mythologies of prejudice: the contempt of Mickey's mother for the people in the projects, "where women just stay in bed making babies all day"; Alexander's insistence that Jews don't believe in Christmas because they're too cheap to buy presents, and the revelation that Billy's seemingly humanitarian father (Herbert Rubens) has his own core of bigotry.
The performances are generally lucid and strongly centered, if short on shading. As Daniel, a young piano prodigy believed to be homosexual, Ntare Mwine renders with touching dignity the mannerisms that have made him an outcast. In one of the play's most disturbing scenes, Daniel is brutally raped by Prince and a henchman. "I'm not the enemy," Daniel cries out. Mr. Brown suggests that the point is irrelevant. In the urban battleground he portrays, the line between ally and enemy is harrowingly nebulous.
 
The Day the Bronx Died
 
By Michael Henry Brown; directed by Gordon Edelstein; sets by Andrew Jackness and David Stein; costumes by Candice Donnelly; lighting by Christopher Akerlind; sound by John Gromada; stunt coordinator, Michael Giansanti; managing director, Ellen Rusconi; artistic consultant, Jack Temchin; production stage manager, James D'Asaro. Presented by the American Jewish Theater, Stanley Brechner, artistic director. At 307 West 26th Street, Chelsea.

HEADLINE: Clinton Arts Dinner Whetted Appetites Still Unsatisfied

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER 

 BODY:
On Oct. 7 last year, before an enthusiastic crowd of 600 on the White House lawn, President Clinton presented 12 people with the National Medal for the Arts, commenting on how the work of each recipient had touched his life.
That night the recipients, who included William Styron, Robert Rauschenberg, Arthur Miller, Paul Taylor and Billy Wilder, were honored at a formal dinner and at a concert that was so spirited it brought forth comparisons to the legendary evening in 1961 when President John F. Kennedy and his wife had Pablo Casals perform in the East Room. Coming just after the smooth and rapid confirmation of the actress Jane Alexander as the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, that October day seemed to many people in the arts to be all but the dawn of a second golden age. 
 Now, nearly half a year later, the mood among people in the arts is mixed and strangely cautious, and there is a feeling among many of them that the high expectations for the Clinton Administration in the arts have yet to be realized. Oct. 7 notwithstanding, movie stars and Hollywood executives have been more conspicuous at the White House than practitioners of high culture. Unlike previous Presidencies, Mr. Clinton's has no White House official specifically charged with coordinating arts policy; Melanne Verveer, Hillary Rodham Clinton's deputy chief of staff, has emerged as the prime arts operative, but she has many other duties. The likelihood of the arts getting major attention in a White House preoccupied both with major policy initiatives like the Clinton health plan and with the Whitewater inquiry is small indeed.
At a time when so much political pressure points to budget cutting, the Administration has proposed no new money for the arts endowment despite the fact that, as Ms. Alexander pointed out in a recent interview, inflation combined with minimal increases means that it has lost 46 percent of its purchasing power since 1979. The current budget is $170.2 million, and the White House has requested the same amount for the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1.
By comparison with the many Federal agencies where budget cuts are the rule, this is soft treatment. But it is hardly the kind of encouragement arts advocates had expected from this Administration. The overall budget for the National Endowment for the Arts has not changed noticeably in 12 years, and the total amount the endowment has to support all arts programs remains smaller than the tiny sliver of the Defense Department budget that supports military bands, which is $189.1 million. (Money for bands is down $2 million in the budget the President has proposed for next year, but even with this cut military bands would still get $17 million more than the arts endowment.)
"I know that the President has to talk about saving money, but this record is atrocious," said Harvey Lichtenstein, the president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "Another $25 million or $50 million would be an extraordinary shot in the arm, and it would make Clinton a hero."
The President is anything but a hero to arts organizations as they find money every bit as tight as it was in the last Administration. Some are responding to the squeeze in innovative ways. The Baltimore Museum of Art just offered cabdrivers a free box lunch to encourage them to direct tourists the museum's way, and a Boston performance art group called Mobius promised that anyone contributing at least $10 would get a call from a member of the group to tell the contributor a joke. But the day-to-day life of many arts groups is fraught with black humor about survival.
 
The Record So Far: Mostly Intangibles
 So far, the President's main accomplishment in the arts has not been in tangible areas of policy or money but in intangibles: in creating an aura of support, a sense that after the culturally bleak Reagan and Bush years, the arts are viewed with sympathy by the White House. While the long delay in appointing Ms. Alexander to head the endowment (she was not named until July 1993) caused considerable grumbling about where the arts stood on the totem pole of Clinton appointments, few people quarreled with the choice once it was made. Ms. Alexander brought to the job the independent stature of a well-known figure in the arts, and more than a little of her luster has rubbed off on the endowment, an agency whose standing with the public was badly bruised by the obscenity debates.
Ms. Alexander has been tireless in politicking with Congress, even inviting Senator Jesse Helms, the endowment's most visible critic, to a February meeting of the National Council on the Arts, the endowment's board of overseers. (He accepted but did not make it, saying he was kept away by last-minute legislative pressures.)
"There has been a visible uplift since she came in," said Representative Sidney R. Yates, an Illinois Democrat and the House's senior arts advocate. "We were almost totally on the defensive before, but she has captivated many of the members of Congress. She is a breath of fresh air."
Ms. Alexander's networking goes beyond Capitol Hill; she has traveled the country, meeting with local arts groups, state legislatures, mayors and artists themselves, trying to make the case that the money the endowment offers, however modest, stimulates other sources of support, raises spirits and helps communities. Her role as a kind of upscale Johnny Appleseed of the arts has, for the moment at least, effectively transcended the arguments about obscenity that all but paralyzed the arts agency during most of the Bush years.
Ms. Alexander's ability to relegate those issues to the sidelines is probably her clearest accomplishment. She is an ideal figure to speak for the arts, since she is an artist herself. Yet she is not so huge a star as to have her celebrity overshadow the substance of her arguments. Neither a Barbra Streisand nor a bureaucrat, she has managed to draw more good notices than any endowment head since the agency's first chairwoman, Nancy Hanks.
"If we can maintain an advocacy role, which hasn't happened in 12 years, then people will begin to understand the value of the arts," Ms. Alexander said in a conversation in her sprawling office in the renovated Old Post Office Building on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington. "They will see what the arts can do to revitalize towns, to help children, to help us maintain our competitive edge in business. People say that artists should make money on their own. I say tell that to a choreographer who makes $5,000 or $6,000 a year, whose work has no commercial potential but which enriches lives."
 
Leaving the Arts To Jane Alexander
 Ms. Alexander's message has not gone much beyond the notion that the arts are a good thing. If she were a preacher, she would be of the God-loves-you variety, not the fire-and-brimstone school. Her vision of culture is of a force to lift the spirit, and many people in the arts question whether she or the Administration she serves is prepared to fight tougher battles on behalf of the arts.
"Who really believes that Bill Clinton would rise above politics if Mapplethorpe came to Washington on his watch?" said Leon Wieseltier, the literary editor of The New Republic. "Remember how they built Salman Rushdie up, then cut him down. Clinton is just lucky that he was elected President after Jesse Helms retired as an art critic."
Ms. Alexander's staff, understandably, thinks otherwise. "She doesn't shy away from difficult issues," said Alexander D. Crary, a Capitol Hill veteran who oversaw arts policy for Senator Claiborne Pell for years and is now the arts endowment's chief of staff. "She's got a wonderful, natural ability to be persuasive and she holds to her convictions."
And the White House, for the moment, seems satisfied: so much so that it has more or less left arts policy in the hands of Ms. Alexander and Mr. Crary.
"The White House thinks Jane Alexander is doing just fine," said one Administration official. "She is doing exactly what they want her to. She is out there working her tail off, and there is a real perception of change in the Government's attitude toward the arts. If the right does try to pull something, then all that Jane has been doing is insurance in the bank."
Ms. Alexander's most ambitious program so far is a conference called Art 21 that she is arranging next month in Chicago. Intended to explore issues like the artist and society, arts education and expanding resources for the arts, the conference will feature, among other speakers, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Henry G. Cisneros. Neither President Clinton nor his wife, whose presence endowment officials had been hoping for, will be on the program.
Arts groups have been generally supportive of Ms. Alexander, though they haven't hesitated to gripe about how issues like health care and requirements on lobbying disclosure can affect arts institutions.
"It's like the issue of nonprofit postal rates: they're not specifically targeting the arts, but the arts get caught," said Judith Golub, the executive director of the American Arts Alliance, an umbrella organization for service groups like the American Symphony Orchestra League and Opera America. "We're small businesses and individual artists, and where do we fit into the health care debate? Jane Alexander is a great ambassador for the arts, but we still feel that the White House is not fully sympathetic to these other concerns that we have."
An Administration official, conceding that service organizations have been "the one area where I hear gripes," attributed complaints less to policy differences than to "jealousy that something's happening in the arts and they're not controlling it."
 
The Popular Arts Are Clinton's Area
 How about the President? His decision not to make time in his schedule for the endowment's conference in April, Ms. Alexander's biggest show yet, seems to underscore that he prefers to make supportive comments about the arts but not to get heavily involved himself.
"The Clintons take the right position on the big issues for art," said a New York museum director who insisted that his name not be used. "But their tendency is still to think about culture always in terms of the most popular forms of art. They see it as a populist part of their political life."
It's no secret that the President's favorite cultural activity seems to be showing movies at the White House, and his most frequent cultural guests have been from the worlds of Hollywood and pop music. The Clintons are more believers in high art than they are consumers of it themselves; they do not frequent the Presidential box at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington and have not been seen much at events that might be called high culture.
"I'm unhappy that he has yet to come to the opera," said Martin Feinstein, the Washington Opera director, who recalled that President Jimmy Carter not only went to Kennedy Center events but also requested the texts of plays or opera librettos in advance to prepare.
Yet this Administration has managed, more than any since the Kennedy era, to project an aura of approval for high art, despite the absence of any real initiatives. At the Oct. 7 celebration the President's interests in literature and music were apparent, and his off-the-cuff remarks had an enthusiasm no speechwriter could create. His sense of engagement was intense with the evening's full range of performers, from Leontyne Price and Robert Merrill, who sang spontaneously during dinner in the State Dining Room, to the poet laureate, Rita Dove, who read from her work, to the young classical musicians who performed in the East Room.
The program that night ended with a few remarks from Isaac Stern, who had helped organize the concert portion. He saluted the President, then closed with a gentle warning that "the joyousness that we shared in the dining room, the sense of identification with the power of creativity" not be taken for granted, and that the arts needed tangible support as well as celebration.
"What I was saying that night is that the arts have to be a continuing effort, a fight for the minds and the freedom of our children, and not just a social adornment," Mr. Stern said recently. "I have a feeling that while it is not the No. 1 priority for the White House, they know this and are prepared to back it."
 
On Decency And the Courts
 Arts advocates are dismayed by the Clinton Administration's decision to allow the Justice Department to pursue an appeal of a court decision overturning the so-called decency provision, which requires the National Endowment for the Arts to take standards of decency into account when awarding its grants.
The provision was passed by Congress in 1989 in response to complaints by the far right that the work of certain artists supported by the endowment, like Karen Finley, John Fleck, Holly Hughes and Tim Miller, was obscene. It was deemed unconstitutional and vague in 1992 by Federal District Court in California. The appeal was filed in Pasadena in June 1993 in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
"Why are they doing this when they could have just left it alone?" said Martin Feinstein, the director of the Washington Opera. "Appealing this decision makes no sense whatsoever." He said that letting the lower court decision stand would have sent a signal of clear support for freedom of expression, while appealing it seemed to many people in the arts to be a capitulation to the concerns of the far right.
Privately, Administration officials concede that the appeal, which was made in the early days of Mr. Clinton's presidency, slipped through the Justice Department without being noticed in the White House, and they say they had no intention of sending a message of sympathy to the opponents of the endowment. The vehemence of the original appeal, they say, was muted by a more moderate second brief that more accurately reflects the Administration's views and reaffirms freedom of expression. Nonetheless, the appeal itself was allowed to stand.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Final Thought On Upsets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY

 BODY:
MY first exposure to a so-called upset came in March 1963. The national championship game between Cincinnati and Loyola was blacked out in Chicago so we listened to the game on radio.
Cincinnati was the two-time defending national champion, but the Bearcats were about to be ambushed. Chicagoans already knew that but the rest of the country didn't. 
 The Ramblers won, 60-58, in overtime. The game was shown later on tape, and the scene I will always remember is George Wilson, the Bearcat star, cupping his hands on either side of his head in disbelief as the buzzer sounded.
I saw my first major "upset" in 1966 when Texas Western defeated Kentucky. We had never heard of Texas Western but had heard plenty about Kentucky's legendary coach, the baron, Adolph Rupp. And we had heard all about his all-white team, affectionately known as Rupp's runts, which included Pat Riley, now the Knicks' coach. The national allure translated into favored status for the Wildcats.
All five of Texas Western's starters were black; I'd never seen that before. In one scramble under the basket, a Texas Western player scooped up the ball and dunked in one motion: Kentucky had never seen that before. By the time the game was over, with Texas Western a 72-65 winner, I felt like I'd been misled all along.
Kentucky? This was no upset. Texas Western was faster, quicker, more skilled. But, until the game, Texas Western was also invisible.
Nearly 30 years later, we're still using outdated yardsticks, thanks largely to television, to gauge who should win a basketball game.
After Arkansas defeated Georgetown on Sunday, Nolan Richardson stood by the Razorbacks' bus. Someone asked him about the upset losses suffered by Kentucky, North Carolina and U.C.L.A. These were not upsets, he said.
"People are still thinking of college teams in terms of names and past reputations," he said. "All that has changed. The talent out there is better than ever, and everybody's getting some of it. I've even seen some N.A.I.A. teams that I won't schedule because they're so good."
Comforting words. But they won't help Dean Smith (North Carolina), Rick Pitino (Kentucky), John Calipari (Massachusetts) and Jim Harrick (U.C.L.A.) answer critics who want to know "What happened?"
How could North Carolina, the defending champion with all that talent, lose to Boston College? How could Kentucky lose to Marquette? Massachusetts to Maryland? U.C.L.A. to Tulsa?
The questions are based on perception and name recognition, not on the reality of talent: Boston College was quicker than North Carolina and more experienced; Marquette had a bigger, tougher front line than Kentucky. Maryland was simply better than Massachusetts. Tulsa was a better-shooting team than U.C.L.A. had ever imagined.
We're looking for dynasties in college basketball and they don't exist. The economy may be shrinking, but the pool of talent is more fertile than ever. Nearly every town is producing outstanding players and the players are finding their way to schools as diverse as Liberty University, the College of Charleston, North Carolina A&T and Pennsylvania.
The level of basketball fluency is amazing. Coaches from the Biddy level on up have done an extraordinary job in the last 20 years of priming young players for each higher level of competition.
The end result has been the swarm of so-called upsets in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Coaches are facing the reality that the level of vulnerability for favored teams is higher than ever.
The only team that stands alone is Arkansas, the deepest and most talented team left in the tournament. The Razorbacks can play small or large, fast or moderate, and their defense is hellacious.
Experts are predicting an Arkansas-Michigan final, but there's a distinct possibility that the Fab Four may not make it past Maryland.
After Michigan's narrow victory over Texas last Saturday, Juwan Howard, Michigan's talented center, conceded that he was beginning to feel the pressure of mounting expectations. His Michigan team has played in two national championship games and lost twice.
Howard recalled how two years ago Michigan was a team of upstarts on the rise; now they were being called underachievers.
"It'll be a little disappointing," he said, "if we don't win the national championship for a third time."
Howard paused for a moment, then smiled.
"We don't want to be known as the Buffalo Bills of college basketball," he said.

HEADLINE: In America;
Pretty Words On Haiti

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT; Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

 BODY:
With most people, and especially with politicians, it is more instructive to watch the things they do than listen to what they say. And so it is with President Clinton and the extreme split between his high-toned rhetoric and his Administration's shameful behavior regarding Haiti.
Mr. Clinton has been unwavering in his spoken support for the restoration of democracy in Haiti and the return to power of its ousted President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. In a radio address to the Haitian people in January 1993 Mr. Clinton, then President-elect, said: "Several years ago, I saw personally the beauty of your land. I felt the warmth of your people and ever since then I have wanted you to have freedom and democracy and economic opportunity." 
 As a Presidential candidate, Mr. Clinton repeatedly attacked the Bush Administration's Haitian refugee policy, saying at one point, "I am appalled by the decision of the Bush Administration to pick up fleeing Haitians on the high seas and forcibly return them to Haiti before considering their claim to political asylum."
Mr. Clinton is a master of the correct thing to say in any given situation. But all you need is a glimpse of the net thrown around Haiti by the Coast Guard to capture -- and return -- fleeing refugees to realize that the President's actions can be something else again.
This lesson has been hammered repeatedly into the head of Father Aristide. The treatment he has received from his "friends" in the United States seems very peculiar when you consider that he and the democracy that he represents are the clear victims in this saga, and that the murderous thugs who ousted him in a coup in September 1991 are villains devoid of any redeeming value.
The Clinton Administration has tried to impose on Father Aristide a series of proposed "settlements" that, if carried out, would have meant at best that he would return to Haiti as President in name only, unable to govern effectively, and at worst that he would be placed in imminent danger of being murdered.
The latest of these is a ludicrous plan, dreamed up by the State Department, that would virtually assure the coup leaders amnesty and a strong voice in the formation of a new government, and doesn't even bother to set a target date for Father Aristide's return.
Mr. Aristide has quite sensibly rejected such proposals. For that he has been labeled intransigent and treated increasingly shabbily by the Administration. No matter that he upheld his end of last year's Governors Island accord, and that the coup leaders treated the accord the way a scofflaw treats a parking ticket. Mr. Aristide may have won a free and fair election in Haiti, but to the political sophisticates in the upper echelons of the Government in Washington he is a boor and a nuisance.
The Administration, in conjunction with the United Nations, has also imposed an embargo on Haiti that has substantially increased the suffering of the Haitian people and is so riddled with loopholes it has not come close to bringing the junta to its knees. And a commercial embargo imposed by the United States was carefully crafted to exclude assembly plants, which are used by companies outside Haiti to assemble goods in Haiti (with cheap Haitian labor) for export elsewhere. United States trade with Haiti increased in 1993.
Meanwhile, the atrocities committed by the police and the military against the Haitian population continue. Thousands of civilians have been killed, tens of thousands are in hiding. Human rights organizations report that the Haitian police -- and armed civilians allied with them -- are raping women with impunity as part of their countrywide campaign of terror.
Eventually even the prettiest of words can lose their meaning in the cold light of reality. While President Clinton says nice things about them, the Haitians are being destroyed.
On Sunday I wrote that former Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams had been convicted of perjury in connection with the Iran-contra scandal. That was an error. Mr. Abrams pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor counts of illegally withholding information from Congressional committees, a violation of the contempt of Congress law.

HEADLINE: Why Junk the Old Car if You Can Recycle It?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The problem of secondary hazardous waste, which is produced after the life of a product, has been ignored by the Environmental Protection Agency and Congress. Secondary hazardous waste is responsible for the clutter of our public parks, the oil found in our drinking water and the thousands of tire dumps all over the United States. 
 There is a solution. Congress should enact legislation that requires manufacturers of all products that produce secondary hazardous waste to track, receive and dispose of all such products after their lifetime. This suggestion may at first glance appear to be overburdensome for manufacturers, but in actuality this suggestion promotes economic growth and stability for them.
The best example of the economic effectiveness of secondary hazardous waste legislation comes from Germany. Like the United States, Germany has found retired automobiles an increasingly difficult environmental problem. German roadsides and fields do not have enough space to hold the two million automobiles that are retired annually.
To deal with this problem, the German Parliament is expected to pass mandatory legislation that will require that all automobiles manufactured in Germany are 100 percent recyclable.
This type of legislation might be expected to meet horrified outcries about excess burden from the automotive giants of Germany. But just the opposite is occurring.
The major manufacturers of BMW's, Mercedes-Benzes and Volkswagens have embraced these plans by initiating research and development programs that have devised 70 percent recyclable automobiles. These companies realize that there is considerable loss of money and energy when an automobile is allowed to rot in a field. Instead, an automobile can be recycled and placed into other automobiles, which brings overhead down because less raw material is consumed in manufacturing.
If similar action were to be taken in the United States, manufacturers would have to devise products that were either reusable or simply disposable. The technology is certainly there. If the most complicated secondary hazardous waste, such as paint, can be reused, this type of legislation is feasible.
For example, Seattle has put into effect Seattle Beige, a program that recycles and reuses leftover paint from households to create new paint. The paint retails for about $5 a gallon and will create $1 million to $3 million in revenue for Seattle annually.
Examples such as this prove that creative and technological advances are available. Congress should act quickly to help protect our environment.
 
MEGHAN SCANLON
Ithaca, N.Y., March 14, 1994

HEADLINE: Time to Stretch Hands Across the Pacific

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Both "The Failure of Our Success" (Op-Ed, March 14) by George F. Kennan and Anthony Lewis's column the same day point to the need for the United States to reflect on its failures and successes, and develop foreign policies in response to the emerging political and economic geographies of Asia, Australia and a transformed Europe. Mr. Lewis finds a new sense of selfhood and acceptance of diversity in Australian public life and suggests that a new basis is needed for Australian-American relations. 
 As a teacher in the University of California since 1984, (with a past divided between campuses in New Zealand, Germany and Britain), I think our educational system and general culture are doing a good job in promoting contacts with the new Europe but are failing to wake up to the new Asia-Pacific cultural -- not just economic -- environments.
Europe is easier, because our educational system, as Jefferson imagined it, was borrowed from France, Britain and, later, Germany, and the tourist flow keeps contacts strong. A more urgent challenge -- one that faces the United States more than the expanded European community -- is to create new cultural bridges and learning partnerships with the many Asia-Pacific nations.
Last year I spent two months visiting universities, museums and public art galleries in Australia and New Zealand, under the University of California education abroad program. Both countries are working to improve educational opportunities for indigenous and minority populations. So are we. But they are also expanding the cross-cultural flow of teachers, students, artists, architects, writers and film makers around Asia and the Pacific. They realize that cooperation in foreign and economic policy requires more personal contacts between cultural producers.
Most of the young people I talked to also welcomed the notion of an Australian republic: they see it as a logical expression of a sense of independent identity as a member of an Asia-Pacific, rather than a remote Anglo-European, community.
We too need to increase the cross-cultural flow among schools, universities and museums. We must teach the global present, as well as the national past, to be effective players in the coming century. Pacific cultural studies could provide a forum for exchanges between settler and indigenous groups.
 
M. KAY FLAVELL
 Berkeley, Calif., March 14, 1994

HEADLINE: Inquiry to Cover Loan Accusation Against Clinton

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
After securing a guilty plea from an Arkansas businessman involving the operation of his federally backed lending company, the special prosecutor investigating the Whitewater real estate venture said he would now vigorously pursue the man's accusations that Bill Clinton had pressured him to make a questionable bank loan to Mr. Clinton's partner in the deal.
"This will allow us a full investigation of everything he knows," the special prosecutor, Robert B. Fiske Jr., told Judge Stephen M. Reasoner of Federal District Court in Little Rock, Ark. 
 The guilty plea allows the businessman, David L. Hale, who was also a former municipal court judge in Little Rock, to avoid a trial that was scheduled to begin on Monday. Mr. Hale will then be able to present his accusations about Mr. Clinton to the Whitewater grand jury sitting there.
Mr. Hale has maintained that Mr. Clinton, while Governor in 1986, pressured him to lend money to politically connected friends, including Susan B. McDougal, a partner in the failed Whitewater venture. Mr. Clinton has steadfastly denied any wrongdoing and angrily denied Mr. Hale's accusations.
"At this point, so much depends on Mr. Hale's cooperation," Mr. Fiske said.
The grand jury in Little Rock is just one of two that Mr. Fisk is using to investigate accusations that Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, may have improperly benefited from their association with James B. McDougal, owner of the failed Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan Association. Mr. McDougal, as well as his wife, Susan, was a partner with the Clintons in the Whitewater Development Company.
Mr. Hale, the former owner of Capital Savings Management, pleaded guilty to bank and mail fraud for defrauding the Small Business Administration. He also admitted falsifying information on a February 1986 application to obtain Federal funds to lend to economically disadvantaged businesses. The charges were not related to Whitewater.
An aide to Mr. Fiske said today that the prosecutor believed Mr. Hale had extensive knowledge about the Whitewater deal.
 
More Inquiries
 The guilty plea in Little Rock came as the examination of Whitewater and the failure of the Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan proceeded in these two directions:
*The House of Representatives voted 408 to 15 to have leaders of both parties set an appropriate timetable for hearings on Whitewater.
*The other grand jury sitting in Washington heard from Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, appeared before a grand jury sitting in Washington.
Mr. Altman, who told the Senate Banking Committee on Feb. 24 that he held a procedural meeting with White House officials on Feb. 2 to discuss the actions of the Resolution Trust Corporation on Madison, said in a letter to the committee that he had also had several additional telephone calls and personal conversations about whether he should recuse himself from the case.
 
Letter to the Banking Panel
 In the letter dated March 21, Mr. Altman said he had discussed the possibility of recusal with Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, Harold M. Ickes, the deputy chief of staff, and Bernard W. Nussbaum, the White House counsel who was forced to resign after the first meeting became public.
Mr. Altman would not discuss his grand jury testimony today but said in an interview that the discussions with the White House officials were not significant.
"I've said from the outset that I had one substantive contact and that remains my view," he said. "No one at the White House ever asked me not to recuse myself."
Mr. Altman did not formally recuse himself until Feb. 25, one day after he told the Banking Committee that he had met with the White House representatives.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, rejected Mr. Altman's defense today. "This is the fourth time that Altman has changed his story about contacts with the White House about the Madison-Whitewater affair," Mr. D'Amato said. "In just four weeks, the number of contacts between Altman and the White House has grown four times. How many more letters will it take before we get the whole story?"
 
Warning to Congress
 Both Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, and Representative Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader, warned against allowing the Whitewater inquiry to overwhelm the chamber.
Mr. Altman's latest disclosures about his contacts with White House officials came as he prepared to testify before the grand jury.
Officials said Mr. Altman was trying to reconcile his earlier recollections with accounts provided to the grand jury and to Congress by other subpoenaed officials.
The White House spokesman John Podesta would not discuss the conversations Mr. Altman had with other officials.
"I'm not going to characterize conversations while the grand jury is going on and people are taking testimony," Mr. Podesta said. "It would be inappropriate. We're in a tough spot on that."
But the evidence of repeated contacts with White House officials who had direct, daily contact with the Clintons has again raised the same question of undue influence that brought about Mr. Nussbaum's resignation.
"I generally attend meetings in the White House three or more times a day, and am on the telephone with White House staff even more often," he said in his letter. "It is difficult to recall every brief encounter."
Mr. Altman said that on one occasion, he "literally bumped into Mr. Nussbaum in a White House corridor."
Mr. Altman has been acting head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is investigating the business practices of Madison Guaranty. He is scheduled to step down from that post at the end of the month.
In the House, Democratic opposition to Whitewater hearings fragmented as lawmakers in both parties stopped arguing and voted overwhelmingly to negotiate the time and agenda for a formal inquiry.
 
Hearing Expected in 2 Months
 It appeared that some hearing would be held within about two months, probably by the House Banking Committee and well after Mr. Fiske is expected to have concluded the Washington portion of his investigation.
In a resolution that expresses the lawmakers' sentiments but lacks any legal clout, the House ordered leaders to arrange hearings on all matters involving Madison Guaranty, the Whitewater Development Company and Capital Management Services Inc.
The resolution's language was identical to a Senate resolution approved last week.

HEADLINE: 3 Companies in Landmark Accord On Lawsuits Over Breast Implants

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
In the largest settlement ever negotiated in a class-action lawsuit, officials of three companies gave final approval yesterday to an agreement to pay $3.7 billion over 30 years to women claiming they were injured by silicone breast implants.
In the highly complex settlement, the companies, the Dow Corning Corporation, the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation, will pay women specific amounts for injuries. 
 "We finally did it," said Gary E. Anderson, Dow Corning's executive vice president.
 
Judge's Approval Needed
 The agreement is still subject to approval by the companies' boards of directors and by Judge Sam C. Pointer of Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala. Even if he approves it, the settlement can crumble if too few women sign up. But if it goes through it will clear the courts of many of the 12,000 cases involving more than 25,000 women who had implants and say they were injured.
The manufacturers say there is no scientific evidence that the implants are harmful, and they are agreeing to the settlement to put the expensive litigation behind them. Dow Corning agreed to pay $2.018 billion, Bristol-Myers Squibb $1.154 billion and Baxter Healthcare $555 million.
An estimated one million to two million women had silicone breast implants in the last 25 years. Some women and doctors say the devices caused a variety of diseases, including autoimmune disorders, like lupus, and connective tissue disorders, like scleroderma, a progressive hardening and thickening of the skin and internal organs.
Although the amount of money that the three companies agreed to pay sounds enormous, part of it will be paid by insurance companies and part in future dollars whose value will have been eroded by inflation.
John Churchfield, chief financial officer of Dow Corning, said insurance would pay about $1.2 billion of Dow Corning's $2.018 billion contribution. He said the value of the insurance payment in current dollars is $600 million and the value of the balance to be paid by Dow Corning in current dollars is $640 million.
Geoffrey Miller, a law professor at the University of Chicago who studies large class-action lawsuits, said the agreement was virtually unprecedented because of its size and complexity. "It's going to be a model for future class-action litigation," he said.
Mr. Anderson said the settlement was at least twice as large as the largest previous class-action agreement, which involved workers with asbestos.
The breast-implant agreement provides that set amounts will be paid to women with specific medical conditions, with no requirement that they show that their implants caused the disorders. But the fees can be reduced if too many women sign up. If that happens, the women are allowed to drop out of the class-action agreement.
The companies can also opt out if too few women sign up. "We can't pay both the immense costs of litigation and the settlement," said T. Michael Jackson, a spokesman for Dow Corning, whose ownership is divided equally between the Dow Chemical Company and Corning Inc.
But Ralph Knowles, a co-chairman of the plaintiffs' negotiating committee, said that if the companies backed out the settlement would probably collapse. "If any defendant walks away, we the plaintiff's settlement committee, can say, 'This is so significant that we are cratering the deal,' " Mr. Knowles said.
John McGoldrick, the chief negotiator for Bristol Meyers-Squibb, said that all or nearly all of the company's contribution would be paid by insurance.
 
Two Years of Negotiations
 The agreement culminates two years of negotiations between lawyers for women who had implants and the companies that made them. In that time, Mr. Knowles said, the lawyers gathered more than three million documents and more than 100 videotaped depositions.
Stanley Chesley, the other co-chairman of the plaintiffs' negotiating committee, said, "The plaintiffs are an army of lawyers completely armed with phenomenal documents and depositions and materials necessary to be successful in a courtroom." And, he added, that preparation for lawsuits "was an effective deterrent" to the companies, nudging them toward a settlement.
Mr. Anderson of Dow Corning, disagreed. "I certainly won't deny that they have an army of litigators out there," he said. "But we feel we have developed a strong defense." He said Dow has won 7 of its last 11 cases.
In September, Dow Corning announced that the companies and the lawyers for the women had reached an agreement in principle to settle the class-action lawsuit for $4.75 billion, but it took six months of further negotiation for the parties to come to a final agreement on a document spelling out the payments, terms and conditions of the agreement. In the meantime, some of the smaller companies dropped out or are still negotiating.
Some say that $3.7 billion is not enough.
"It can't possibly be enough," said Alan Morrison, a lawyer with Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group based in Washington. He said that even the original $4.75 billion is not enough because the payouts are so expensive and so many women have been injured.
Sal Liccardo, a lawyer in San Jose, Calif., who represents women with breast implants, said that even if there was enough money in the fund, the amounts that women with severe injuries would receive are inadequate.
One of his clients, he said, is 43 years old and "in constant pain and in constant need of medical care." It will take more than $3 million to care for her for the rest of her life, he added.
Mr. Liccardo also said that women "with good cases" tend to get more by suing than they would get in the settlement. A woman in Texas who had lupus, for example was recently awarded $6 million, he said.
LeRoy Hersh, a member of the plaintiffs' negotiating committee, said that while some women might want to take their chances in a courtroom, others have no choice but to join the class action if they want any compensation. These include women whose implants were made by companies that have gone bankrupt and women who do not know who made their implants.
In addition, Mr. Hersh said, there is a huge advantage to joining the settlement: women do not have to prove that their injuries were caused by the implants.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Ease Rights Goals With Beijing

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, in an effort to resolve the crisis in relations with China, has been quietly signaling Beijing that if it met Washington's minimum human rights demands, the United States would consider ending the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Chinese behavior.
Administration officials said today that there was already a consensus within President Clinton's economic team, which is now spreading to the White House and even parts of the State Department, that the annual rite of threatening China with a withdrawal of its beneficial trade status if it does not meet certain human rights conditions is outmoded and should be replaced. 
 That sentiment, which has been conveyed to China by the Administration, also seems to be taking hold on Capitol Hill, from which the pressure to link human rights and trade originally came.
 
Threat of Trade Sanctions
 The United States has for years used the threat of trade sanctions to promote free immigration and human rights in Communist countries, from the former Soviet Union to China. Any move by the Administration and Congress now away from that approach would be a major policy shift, one that reflects the increasing importance of trade to the American economy.
"I think that today, the Congressional mainstream would still want to maintain some linkage between trade and human rights, but the drift is toward delinkage," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "It is impossible to improve the relationship if you have to go through this fight every year."
He added that there is "a very strong possibility that the Administration will recommend, and the Congress will adopt, the use of other tools" besides trade sanctions to promote American human rights concerns provided that China meets President Clinton's basic human rights demands laid out in an executive order last June.
Administration officials are increasingly arguing that the current policy is outmoded because, as the President has told aides and lawmakers in recent days, the last thing Mr. Clinton wants to do is withdraw China's trade benefits, which would costs thousands of American jobs and billions of dollars in contracts. So in some ways the policy rests on an empty threat.
It is also outmoded, other officials argue, because trade is now such an important instrument for opening up Chinese society, for promoting the rule of law and the freedom of movement there, and for encouraging the Chinese authorities to allow citizens to own everything from their own satellite dishes to foreign newspapers, that revoking it would be self-destructive for both sides.
Finally, American policy toward China is only effective if there is a united front, and that united front has broken down as more Americans do business in China and refuse to see their economic interests imperiled by making them a weapon for pressing human rights concerns.
Administration officials say that in dropping the threat of trade sanctions, they would continue to press China in other ways -- from diplomatic censure to holding up World Bank loans.
 
Conditions for China
 Last May the President signed an order, which many in the Administration now regret, stipulating the precise steps that China must take to win renewal of its trade benefits, which allow it to send its imports to the United States at the lowest available tariff.
The President has told lawmakers and aides that while he would do all that he could to avoid having to withdraw trade benefits from Beijing, he feels politically, morally and legally bound to fulfill the basic terms of that executive order.
One senior official said, "We have told the Chinese, 'Get us over the executive order, and we will consider all kinds of alternatives.' "
The Administration's intent, officials say, is both to offer an inducement for China to cooperate, but at the same time to signal hard-liners in the Chinese leadership that they cannot get by with just doing nothing.
Administration officials said that they believed last May that they had to adopt the executive order because Mr. Clinton, during the campaign, had strongly criticized President Bush for "coddling" China and he did not want to appear to be going back on another campaign promise. They also did it out of a fear that Congressional Democrats might otherwise have forced an even more stringent approach on them through legislation.
The order calls for China to begin putting into effect an agreement made two months ago to end its practice of using prison labor to make products exported to the United States, and to fully comply with American demands to allow a list of Chinese dissidents and their families to leave the country.
 
Visit to Prison
 The Chinese have told the United States they are prepared to deal with most of the immigration cases and have already allowed one visit by a team of American inspectors to a suspected prison labor camp. The Administration feels that China is thus at least getting close to satisfying its demands on these points.
In addition, the President's order calls for "overall significant progress" in China's handling of and accounting for political prisoners, relations with Tibet, and the jamming of foreign radio programs. The Administration has always been prepared to interpret that progress loosely, but officials say that Beijing, while it has been inching in the right direction, has not yet given them even the bare minimum they need to convince Congress on these points.
Therefore, the Administration's China policy between now and June is to redouble efforts to persuade Beijing to take the last few steps. This is going to be done primarily through quiet diplomatic channels, and not high-profile visits -- in light of the confrontation that erupted during Secretary of State Warren Christopher's recent tour.
 
Views of Economic Official
 There has been much wrangling over the Administration's China policy in recent days. At a White House meeting on Monday, members of the Clinton economic team -- particularly Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen -- said they wanted to see more frequent meetings by all the principal policy makers on China to insure that the views of the economic officials of the Administration were being fully taken into account.
The economic aides said they were not troubled by Mr. Christopher pressing the human rights issue, but said that on his recent visit to China he or some of his aides seemed to be doing it in a confrontational manner that was encouraging Beijing to dig in its heels.
Secretary Christopher, backed by the President's National Security Adviser, Anthony Lake, asked that Mr. Clinton issue a public statement reaffirming his commitment to the executive order and the general approach to China being carried out by the Secretary of State.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Administration Takes Fed's Action in Stride

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials refrained from criticizing the Federal Reserve today, even as big commercial banks began raising their prime lending rates slightly late this afternoon to follow the central bank's decision on Tuesday to nudge up short-term interest rates.
Gene Sperling, a senior official on the President's National Economic Council, said tonight of the prime rate increase, "This was a predictable consequence of yesterday's Fed action, and it is not inconsistent with our view that economic growth is strong and inflation is under control." 
 Joan Logue-Kinder, the chief Treasury Department spokeswoman , said: "I don't think you're going to find us in an adversarial position with the Fed over this. You know that when the Fed raises rates that the banks are eventually going to raise rates."
 
Hope for a Closer Connection
 While jogging this morning, before a number of big banks raised their prime rates to 6 1/4 percent from 6 percent, President Clinton expressed satisfaction that the Fed's action on Tuesday had pushed down long-term interest rates by easing concerns about possible inflation. He pointed to the contrast with the Fed's previous increase in overnight rates on Feb. 4, which set off an increase in long-term rates.
"We'll just have to hope that there's a more -- that there's a closer connection between the two actions this time than there was last time," the President said.
Higher short-term interest rates slow the economy and discourage bank lending to commodities speculators, holding down inflation. Expectations of future inflation are the main influence on the movement of long-term interest rates, because investors are reluctant to lend money for long periods of time if they think they will be repaid in devalued dollars.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.84 percent from 6.95 percent on Tuesday, after the Fed acted, although it edged back up today to 6.89 percent.
In general, both short- and long-term interest rates seemed to be a low priority for senior Administration officials today, who had already moved on to other issues like trade relations with China. "We haven't talked about it today," one official said.
Compared with previous Administrations, this Administration has placed an unusual emphasis on long-term interest rates. This emphasis partly reflects economic theory, in that long-term rates strongly influence investment levels. But the emphasis also reflects political self-interest, to the extent that long-term rates may influence the economy's health and the President's re-election prospects in 1996.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and other senior Administration officials were quick to cite a steep decline in long-term rates last summer as evidence that the President's budget package had been welcomed by financial markets. They have been much less outspoken as long-term interest rates have retraced much of that decline this winter.
To some extent, the Administration's silence reflects a sense that little can be done to change the Fed's mind. The Treasury Department's proposal for the consolidation of bank regulatory agencies, taking away much of the Fed's role in bank supervision, has been temporarily stalled as Congressional banking committees focused on President Clinton's links to a failed Arkansas savings and loan in the Whitewater affair.
 
 
'What Are We Doing to Do?'
 Proposals to force the Fed to disclose more information more quickly are also languishing in Congress. And public White House criticisms of the Fed has tended to undermine the financial markets' confidence in the central bank's independence and push up the long-term interest rates that are most important to the Administration.
Administration officials acknowledge their limited influence. "What are we going to do, rescind it?" one official asked today.
Many members of Congress remain unhappy with the Fed's move on Tuesday. "The Federal Reserve is clearly in need of a reality check," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee. "Don't they know that the average rate of inflation is the lowest since the 1960's?"
