HEADLINE: 2 Years, 10 Murders and 1 Question

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 22

 BODY:
In a kinder world, 10 black women would not have been strangled to death over the last two years in this shiny Piedmont boom town. In a simpler world, there would be a clear lesson about race and police neglect in the belated recognition that one man may have been behind it all.
But in the real world, more than a week after an arrest in the worst killing spree in Charlotte's history, nothing is quite so clear. 
 Despite allegations that it was only the race of the victims that allowed their killer to remain at large for so long, most black officials and community leaders here deny those assertions and say that trying to put a simple overlay of race on the killing spree does more harm than good.
Whether that says more about Charlotte or about the lessons of race beyond the civil rights era is hard to say.
 
No 'Outraged Reaction'
 "The easy way to look at this is, it's racial," said Harvey Gantt, a Democrat who became Charlotte's first black Mayor in 1983 and ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate against Jesse Helms in 1990. "But I don't see any evidence that would suggest that. I talk to people, both black and white, and I don't see the outraged reaction."
Charlotte, with one leg in its Piedmont past and the other in its status as one of the nation's most prosperous cities, was turned upside down last week after a 28-year-old fast-food worker, Henry Louis Wallace, was arrested and charged with strangling 10 black women over the last two years. Mr. Wallace, who is black, has been charged with an 11th murder in South Carolina, and other investigations are pending.
Much of the city's reaction to the slayings -- the horror that they happened, the defense of the police -- reflects the split personality of a place that likes to think it has both the small-town virtues of its past and the big-time aspirations of the present.
Charlotte is an intensely image-conscious city that has always prided itself on its reputation for racial amity, and what stung as much as the killings were allegations that only the victims' race kept the police from realizing sooner that a serial killer was at work.
 
'They Deserved More Attention'
 The argument was made most forcefully by Kelly Alexander, executive director of the North Carolina chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Dee Sumpter, whose 20-year-old daughter, Shawna Hawk, was found strangled in a bathtub on Feb. 19, 1993. The police say she was Mr. Wallace's second victim.
"All the victims were African-American women," Mrs. Sumpter said. "When you look at the races of all the individuals, one can only draw the conclusion that race played a part in how the investigation was handled. They may have been black. They may not have been rich. But they deserved more attention than it seems the Charlotte P.D. gave them."
The Acting Police Chief, Jack Boger, who has strenuously defended the Charlotte Police Department, has acknowledged that the killing of whites, particularly affluent whites, gets a lot more attention in the news media and the community as a whole -- here and elsewhere -- than the killings of less affluent blacks.
But he contends that because the crimes occurred over a long period of time in different parts of the city, and because the earliest slayings seemed to have little in common, there was nothing to alert the police to the possibility of a serial killer until four slayings this month suggested a pattern. At that point an arrest was made within three days, he said.
Statistics indicate that crimes against blacks and whites are cleared at comparable rates.
"I have reviewed the work in this case step by step from 22 months until now," said Don Steger, the Assistant City Manager who oversees the police, "and I cannot see any place where I would have to say to the chief of detectives, 'You flubbed it.' "
He added: "You had a killer who was very particular about covering his tracks. As a black man, I can say there is no evidence to support the notion that any kind of bias was seen in this case."
Alphonso Slaughter, whose daughter, Debra Ann, is believed to have been Mr. Wallace's next to last victim, agreed. "Once they were able to connect this guy to the crimes, they had 50 officers knocking on every door," Mr. Slaughter said. "I fault the overall system that makes it hard sometimes to arrest these people, but I don't fault the police."
 
Black Legislators Criticized
 In this regard, he sounds much like Mayor Richard Vinroot, a Republican who is white, and who complained that black legislators in Raleigh defeated a proposal to provide funds intended to allow law-enforcement officers to target people who repeatedly commit violent crimes, saying it sounded like an effort to target black men.
"Maybe if we had those funds we'd have gotten this guy a year ago," Mr. Vinroot said.
The muted reaction to the allegations against the police partly reflects the degree to which Charlotte has had a relatively amicable racial climate, and now has a prosperous economy. With an unemployment rate of less than 4 percent, Charlotte has avoided some of the economic frustrations that lead to racial problems. It also has a boosterish political culture -- some say too boosterish -- that prizes consensus and frowns on conflict.
 
Crime as an Organizing Focus
 But the reaction also reflects the degree to which crime has replaced civil rights as an organizing focus for Charlotte's black residents. There are at least three different anti-crime groups here, and organizers say criminal justice issues can no longer be depicted simply as black versus white.
"What angers me the most is that the black folks who are accusing the police of letting race play a part in this investigation haven't said a word about all the other black murder victims in this city," said the Rev. James Barnett, director of the Stop the Killing Crusade. "The only time you ever hear from some black people is when they're blaming whites for something."
That is not to say that race is not an issue in Charlotte, which is struggling in numerous ways with the cost of growth, ranging from drugs to traffic. Indeed, race and crime have been linked in several recent incidents in which blacks have accused the police of brutality.
"We've got a hell of a lot of problems to solve on the racial side," Mr. Gantt said. "But at least we're able to talk about them here. And I think most people realize they require different tactics than, say, fighting the more simple battle of illegal segregation years ago did."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dee Sumpter, whose daughter, Shawna Hawk, was found slain, believes race was a factor in how the investigation was handled. (Pam Brackett for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Bonds Tumble Amid Investor Concerns

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve yesterday confirmed bond market expectations and officially moved its new short-term interest rate target up a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.50 percent.
The Fed announced its intention to raise its target for Federal funds, the interest charged on overnight loans between banks, on Tuesday after the meeting of its policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee. 
 But after early gains when the Fed formally confirmed the increase in its target, bond prices slid in the afternoon amid investor uncertainty about the economy and the timing of the next interest rate rise by the Fed.
The market fell under further pressure near its close when several banks, led by Chemical and Chase raised their prime lending rates a quarter of a percentage point, to 6 1/4 percent. By the close of the New York cash market the long bond had given up nearly half of the gains achieved the previous day.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 20/32 , to 9130/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.89 percent, up from 6.84 percent Tuesday.
 
Short-Term Securities Rates
 But the rates on short-term securities continued to fall, indicating that the recent selloff may have gone a lot further than it had to. In addition, some investors appeared to be moving out of longer-term securities, whose prices are much more volatile, to the relative calm of shorter-term investments.
The rate for a three-month bill fell 5 basis points, to 3.45 percent, while the six-month rate fell 2 basis points, to 3.77 percent.
Traders said now that the Fed had fulfilled market expectations and raised interest rates again, investors were more apt to buy securities and Treasuries would probably stabilize. The Fed raised its interest rates target for the first time in five years on Feb. 4 but a selloff in the bond market followed, in part because traders were worried that the Fed had not raised short-term interest rates enough.
Fed watchers at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company said there was no doubt that the central bank confirmed the rate increase when it did not add reserves to the banking system. That the Fed has actually announced its intentions in February and again yesterday has set new precedents and also left the market with no uncertainties to fuel speculation.
William Shea, senior vice president at Nikko Securities International Inc.,said, "The market is likely to remain tentative until we reach 4 percent on the Federal funds, which the market believes is what the Fed needs in order to achieve a real level of interest rates."
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading specialist for Chase Securities, thinks that after rallying the day before, investors have begun to wonder how much higher can prices go from these levels. "Have the fundamentals in the market changed?" he asked. "Has anything changed about the economy?"
"Much of the buying after the Fed made its announcement on Tuesday was not a reaction to the Fed tightening as it was to investors covering short positions," Mr. Alexy said. "Many investors are still uncertain about the Fed's next move."
The rise in the prime lending rate will add to the concerns of investors, giving them little reason to buy and limiting the market's upside potential, traders said.
Treasury prices got support early in the day from the report on United States durable goods orders for February, which fell 2.5 percent, or 1 percent excluding the military market. The drop was much larger than the consensus forecast of a dip of six-tenths of 1 percent.
According to economists, there was little in the report that would cause the market to change its view about what the Fed is thinking.
With the last interest rate rise now a day old, traders suspect what the market now needs to know is whether the economy is stronger or weaker than the Fed is betting on.
 
Municipal Bond Market
 In the municipal bond market, analysts said the City of New York saved $90 million when it sold bonds this week. Underwriters repriced part of the city's $1.06 billion general obligation bond issue late Tuesday after the Fed raised interest rates and the market rallied, cutting yields on the issue by as much as five basis points, to 6.30 percent for a bond due in 2023.
The bond offering was the first under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and comes at a time when the city is grappling with a fiscal year 1995 budget deficit of $2.3 billion.
Underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities priced the bonds to yield from 4.45 percent in 1996 to 6.30 percent in 2023.
At yesterday's Treasury auction of $11 billion in five-year notes, the high yield was 5.91 percent, up from 5.61 percent at the Feb. 24 auction and the highest since 6.03 percent on Dec. 23, 1992.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler's Luxury-Sedan Sales Lag

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 23

 BODY:
Dealers' inventories of two luxury models of the Chrysler Corporation's LH sedans are running far above average for the automobile industry, an indication that the cars are not selling as fast as the company had hoped.
The cars have piled up on dealers' lots because Chrysler has not offered lease deals that are as attractive as those of its competitors in the luxury market, said Jack Kirnan, an auto industry analyst with Salomon Brothers. 
 But E. Thomas Pappert, Chrysler's vice president for sales, said today that new, subsidized lease offers on those vehicles should reduce inventories to average levels.
Mr. Kirnan released an otherwise laudatory analysis of Chrysler today that called high inventory of LH sedans "the only potential trouble spot for Chrysler in the near term." In an interview, Mr. Kirnan said that the high inventories did not stem from declining popularity for the sedans, which won critical praise for their unusual styling when they were introduced a year ago.
Rather, he said, "people in that segment of the market are leasing, and the leasing tends to be deeply subsidized."
 
Better Lease Deals Due
 Mr. Kirnan said he expected Chrysler to offer better lease deals not only on the two luxury cars, but also on two other LH sedans, the Chrysler Concorde and Eagle Vision, for which dealer inventories are also above average. He estimated that a subsidized lease program could cost Chrysler up to $100 million in marketing expenses, or about 20 cents a share.
The industry average for dealer inventory was 65 days at the end of January, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. For the two luxury LH cars, the New Yorker and the LHS, inventories average more than 90 days, Mr. Pappert said. Dealer inventories exceeded 70 days for the Concorde and the Vision, Chrysler said.
Mr. Pappert said Chrysler's inventory goal was 65 days. He said that inventory for another LH car, the Dodge Intrepid, was 57 days.
For other Chrysler vehicles, such as the company's hot-selling trucks, dealer inventories are far below average. For example, the inventory of the Jeep Grand Cherokee is 22 days. "I think Jeep is the hottest ticket on the market right now," Mr. Pappert said.
Chrysler in recent years has lagged behind some of its competitors in leasing, in part because a poor debt rating prevented it from offering competitive rates.
Last year Standard & Poor's raised Chrysler's debt rating, increasing the company's flexibility. Still, Chrysler has shown less willingness than some auto makers, most notably the Ford Motor Company, to emphasize leasing.
Mr. Pappert said some companies were gambling on high predictions for the "residual values" of its cars. Monthly lease payments are based on the value the company projects that vehicles will retain when lessors return them at the end of the lease term. By setting that value high, the company can lower the customer's monthly payments, making the deal more attractive.
The danger to the company is that residual values could plummet. "You're playing futures, just as if you were buying hog bellies," Mr. Pappert said.
About 10 percent of Chrysler's retail transactions are leases, while at Ford the proportion of leases is almost 20 percent, according to Mr. Kirnan.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Eddie Antar Signs Over $52 Million

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 23

 BODY:
Faced with an angry Federal judge preparing to sentence him and his brother Mitchell for racketeering and stock fraud, the founder of the Crazy Eddie electronics chain today signed over foreign bank accounts containing $52 million sought by the Government.
Eddie Antar took the stand for the first time since his trial began and signed over the money to a court-appointed trustee. He answered a series of questions from the United States Attorney, occasionally smiling and nodding. 
 Mr. Antar's handcuffs were removed so he could sign the papers, but his leg shackles were not. He shuffled to the witness stand with a deputy United States marshal standing by.
Eddie and Mitchell Antar were convicted in July of pocketing nearly $80 million by selling Crazy Eddie stock, the value of which they artificially increased through inventory inflation and other schemes.
In an attempt to show United States District Judge Nicholas H. Politan that Eddie Antar did not deserve the tough sentence sought by prosecutors, his lawyer, John J. Barry, presented a letter Tuesday in which Mr. Antar agreed to repatriate money he held overseas.
 
'Bait and Switch' Charged
 Judge Politan in 1990 ordered Mr. Antar to return the money, which the Securities and Exchange Commission charged in a separate case that he had obtained through insider trading and transferred to Israel.
Today, the judge erupted when Mr. Barry said Mr. Antar had refused to sign S.E.C. papers specifying the foreign accounts from which the money would be drawn.
"I consider his offer to repatriate the $52 million a bait and switch," the judge said, adding that it reeked of "fraud and deception." He said Mr. Antar remained in contempt of the 1990 order.
"It's all nonsense and garbage," Judge Politan continued. "I have had it. I have the patience of St. Jude. The patience is over with."
Later in the day, Mr. Antar signed the S.E.C. papers, identifying accounts in Israel and Switzerland holding a total of $53 million, slightly more than what the judge ordered repatriated. His lawyers then asked Judge Politan to delay sentencing until the money arrived. The judge then postponed the sentencing of both Eddie and Mitchell Antar until April 15.
The money would go to a court-appointed trustee. It is intended to be turned over to the S.E.C., which obtained a $73 million judgment against Mr. Antar -- grown with interest to $90 million -- for restitution to Crazy Eddie investors.
Eddie Antar, 46, and his brothers Mitchell, 38, and Allen, 44, built Crazy Eddie into the biggest electronics retailer in the New York area in the 1980s. It was known for loud commercials in which a frenzied pitchman boasted of "INSAAAAAAAANE" prices.
Allen Antar was acquitted following the monthlong trial but has attended this week's proceedings, as have more than a dozen members of their extended clan, which have homes in Brooklyn and the New Jersey Shore.
The Government is seeking a 25-year term for Eddie Antar, contending that thousands of investors lost hundreds of millions of dollars because of years of fraud he directed.

HEADLINE: Lehman Bros. Cutting Staff

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Lehman Brothers Inc. plans to cut more than 4 percent of its work force and trim other expenses as it prepares to become a public company, company officials say.
While Lehman is considered among Wall Street's leaders, particularly in the bond market, the company must get its costs down to compete with Goldman, Sachs & Company, Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company, all of which have more capital and higher profits. 
 Lehman's costs were higher than its competitors "by a couple of percentage points," said Gordon Luce, a Brown Brothers Harriman analyst.
Lehman is going public because the American Express Company wants to concentrate on its main businesses, which do not include investment banking. American Express said in January that it would spin off Lehman to its shareholders. Some investors said they might sell their Lehman shares when they got them.
Lehman is expected to provide more information about its operations and finances in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission next week.
As many as a third of the 400 job cuts are expected to come from the 1,200 people who provide support to Lehman's 500 brokers for wealthy individuals, company officials said. The remainder are expected to include senior employees, some with $500,000 salaries. The cuts are already under way.
William Shutzer, a managing director who was one of the firm's senior investment bankers, left the firm early this month to join Furman Selz Inc. The chief equity economist, Robert Barbera, also quit.
In addition to cutting costs, Lehman faces the industrywide challenge of maintaining profits at a time when analysts believe Wall Street is unlikely to repeat last year's record earnings of $8.9 billion before taxes.

HEADLINE: Japan's Economy Grows at Slowest Pace Since '74

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 23

 BODY:
Prospects for Japan's recovery from its worst recession in the postwar era look uncertain after the Government reported on Tuesday that the economy grew last year at its slowest rate in nearly two decades.
With a surge in the value of the yen and a sharp decline in corporate investment, the Japanese economy in 1993 grew only one-tenth of a percent when adjusted for inflation. 
 The almost imperceptible rate of growth in the world's second-largest economy was its worst performance since 1974, when soaring oil prices provoked a global economic upheaval. Although the economy was slightly stronger than many economists had expected in the last three months of 1993, most of them agreed that any rebound was likely to be lackluster.
 
 
'No Signs of an Uptrend Yet'
 "The downward trend is almost over," said Hirohiko Okumura, chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "We are entering the turnaround phase. The problem is that there are no signs of an uptrend yet."
Mr. Okumura forecasts virtually no growth again this year unless the Government acts forcefully to reinvigorate domestic consumption.
Tsutomu Tanaka, Vice Minister of the Economic Planning Agency, which is generally optimistic in its outlook, said, "As for judging if the bottom has been reached, we cannot make that determination yet."
That is bad news for the Japanese as well as for the country's major trading partners, especially the United States. The faltering economy and weak demand are likely to mean fewer imports, while encouraging manufacturers to seek sales overseas. That combination could exacerbate trade tensions by keeping Japan's immense trade surplus at record levels.
Despite the mounting political tensions, the Government appears to be in no great hurry to jolt the economy out of its two-year-old slump with a heavy dose of new public works spending or tax cuts -- as the Clinton Administration has been urging.
 
 
Jump-Starting the Economy
 The Government has announced three such stimulus packages in the last year, with little measurable impact on growth. But the United States has been pushing both publicly and through diplomatic channels for a substantial new effort to add impetus to Japan's economy and the world's.
The Government said in its report on Tuesday that the economy shrank an inflation-adjusted six-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter of last year. Many economists had forecast an even steeper drop, but personal consumption, while weak, was not quite as lethargic as anticipated.
The economy began its long slide two years ago, after a plunge in the stock and property markets ended the spectacular boom of the late 1980's, known here as the bubble economy. The bubble had set off a frenzy of corporate investment and a reckless spree of lending by banks and other financing companies. All these problems surfaced when the speculative bubbles burst.
Commercial banks are now burdened with tens of billions of dollars of bad debts. Manufacturers frequently overexpanded their productive capacity, and so have since reduced new investment drastically. There is a huge glut of office space on the commercial real estate market. Unemployment, though still less than 3 percent, is expected to rise steadily.
 
 
Housing and Public Works
 Among the few bright spots are housing construction, helped by what had been record low interest rates during much of 1993, and Government spending on public works projects.
But the Japanese economy faces several stiff challenges. The recent jump in American interest rates has had a predictable impact on Japan, forcing rates sharply higher for the first time in months.
"The question now is not whether we have a recovery this year, but how strong it will be," said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist here with Salomon Brothers Asia. "These high rates can hurt. They are making businessmen very nervous."
Yoshihisa Kitai, a senior economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank, said on Tuesday: "What you can say is that maybe the Japanese economy has almost reached the bottom. But it is going to be a weak recovery when it comes. That still seems clear, even after being a little surprised by the figures today."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Goes Up vs. the Yen But Loses Against the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mixed yesterday, gaining ground against the Japanese yen but losing against the German mark after the widely expected tightening of American monetary policy.
At its usual intervention time shortly before noon yesterday, the Federal Reserve refrained from adding reserves to the banking system, with Federal funds trading at 3.5 percent, confirming a quarter-point rise in its key overnight lending rate. 
 On Tuesday, the Fed announced that it would increase pressure on bank reserves, but the extent of the credit-tightening move was left unclear until yesterday.
Traders said the rise in short-term interest rates seemed to have been fully discounted and therefore had little influence on the dollar's direction.
"One might have thought that with interest rates moving in the dollar's favor it would have soared, but the market seems to have gotten ahead of itself," said Albert Soria, foreign exchange manager at the Kansallis-Osake-Pankki bank.
 
Dollar Should Benefit
Normally, rising American rates benefit the dollar by increasing the return on dollar-denominated securities. A late flurry of prime rate increases by American banks yesterday also had little impact on the market.
Adding to the dollar's troubles were worries of surging German monetary growth, a development that might slow the pace of European interest rate reductions.
The Bundesbank is expected to trim its official rates soon, but speculation of a sharp rise in the main measure of the German money supply caused the dollar to slip against the mark.
"The market seems to be more dependent on Germany cutting rates than on the States raising them," said Richard Ash, a trader at Commerzbank.
The dollar finished little changed against the yen, as continuing tensions on the Korean peninsula provided the dollar with a base of support.
In late New York trading, the dollar finished at 1.6800 German marks, down from 1.6868 marks on Tuesday. But it rose to 106.33 Japanese yen from 106.05 yen.
Gold prices slipped. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, the active April gold futures contract dropped $2.30, to $387.40 an ounce.
The British pound rose to $1.4980 in late New York trading, from $1.4875 Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4275 Swiss francs, virtually unchanged from 1.4277; $1.3643 (Canadian), off slightly from $1.3675, and 1,663 Italian lire, little changed from 1,668.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Selling a city to the people who live there: The Baltimore of tourists looks homeward and inward.

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky 

 BODY:
AROUND 5 P.M. in most American cities, the traffic generally flows one way. Working-class people head home to the suburbs, where life is presumably safer, parking is abundant and diversions are plentiful.
Which is fine, except for the disconcerting notion that without people,cities decay. Stores and restaurants close. Civic projects die. Empty streets loom dark and dangerous. 
 Thanks to 15 years of urban revitalization, Baltimore has not jeopardized the vast redevelopment that has seeded its downtown landscape with shopping pavilions, museums, a national aquarium, a light rail system, new hotels, scores of restaurants, refurbished housing and a baseball stadium. A $160 million science research and educational center is under construction.
But somewhere along the way, downtown Baltimore lost touch with Baltimoreans. Redevelopment had made the city a tourist destination for others, but not necessarily a magnet for the locals beyond their initial curiosity.
To prevent this trend from getting worse, a civic group of public and private interests called the Downtown Partnership of Baltimore is embarking on a large-scale marketing effort, buoyed by an advertising campaign beginning next month that has enlisted nearly every major media outlet in the city.
In the name of civic pride and spirit, the three television network affiliates, the two independent channels, the largest radio stations, Baltimore's dominant daily newspapers and several weeklies have agreed to provide free time and space to advertise the city for the city to the city.
Jim Dale, the chairman and chief executive of W. B. Doner & Company, the advertising agency coordinating the campaign on a pro bono basis, said the free exposure could be worth $500,000 or more.
By agreement with the electronic outlets, for every spot paid for, the station will donate the same amount of time for another. The Baltimore Sun, the city's principal newspaper, has agreed to provide news listings, two tabloid pullout sections and about $60,000 worth of advertising at a reduced rate.
"They have done so much to rejuvenate the city," said Mark Distler, general sales manager for the NBC affiliate, WMAR-TV. "The idea to promote the city, to get people to come down, was a no-brainer."
The advertising campaign is being built around a program host who will appear in a talk show format at places around town to extol their virtues. The host, Mark Sarien, a 26-year-old men's clothing salesman, won the job this week through an open audition that attracted hundreds of would-be commercial stars.
He has no experience as a television personality, but polish was not so much a requirement as enthusiasm and civic-mindedness. Unabashed boosterism is central to the campaign.
If it all sounds a little hokey, maybe it is. But an advertising campaign selling a city to the people who live there can be an effective tool against the kind of urban rot that undermines municipal efforts at a time that the Federal Government has left states and cities substantially on their own against violence, drug abuse and other civic ills.
Other cities, including Buffalo, Philadelphia and Indianapolis, have initiated similar programs, but have not received the kind of media support Baltimore has generated. New York City has 26 Business Improvement District organizations, with individual budgets and promotional approaches. But none, said Gretchen Dykstra of the Times Square district, with a current campaign of $77,000, has gotten free exposure to help the cause.
"The notion of doing something like this is not particularly new," Richard Bradley, president of the International Downtown Association in Washington, said, referring to Baltimore's efforts. "What is significant is the level at which they have gotten support."
Mr. Bradley said Baltimore had stayed ahead of the curve among cities promoting themselves, largely because it had enough attractions to withstand questions of truth in advertising. Some cities, he said, advertise too much, people investigate and then go home disappointed, seldom to return.
"Several years ago, we were hearing increasing concerns from businesses about the downtown area," said Laurie Schwartz, president of the Downtown Partnership in Baltimore. "Our first step was to focus on safety."
That resulted in the city's hiring of 60 security personnel for the downtown area, paid for through a property tax surcharge, and it led to the second step, developing the promotional campaign with advertising support.
"Addressing those first concerns polished the city," Ms. Schwartz said. "Now it's time to sell the product."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Some relatively obscure business schools shine in a new study.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
LOOKING for a business school that really delivers the bacon? Consider Stanford, Harvard, Wharton or Oklahoma State.
That's right: Oklahoma State. A new study (by a pair of Ivy League economists, no less) offers the first ranking of M.B.A. programs that in the authors' words "does not use subjective responses from various constituent groups." And while the very top of their list looks like the top of everyone else's, a half-dozen relative unknowns end up in the top 20, ahead of some brand-name schools, including Yale, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Columbia, Carnegie-Mellon, New York University and Cornell. 
 According to Joseph Tracy of Columbia and Joel Waldfogel of Yale, survey-based rankings (such as those published in Business Week and U.S. News & World Report) may be biased by the fact that the high-profile schools have their pick of the most talented students, who in turn go on to get the best jobs. What ought to count, they argue in a paper published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, is the "value added" by the degree -- how much more graduates earn than would otherwise be expected from their pre-program qualifications. "This is a very serious matter for students who put their careers and tuition money on the line," Mr. Tracy said.
There are no major surprises in the list of schools that deliver the most lucrative jobs to freshly certified masters of business administration. Even after adjusting graduate salaries for differences in the mix of specialties, Stanford, Harvard and Wharton came out on top in the two economists' list -- not very different from their overall ranking of M.B.A. program quality in the U.S. News survey published last week.
Just what this proves, however, is not clear. The Tracy-Waldvogel team measured the quality of entering classes for each school by an index that includes undergraduate grades, business board scores, work experience and other graduate degrees. The highly rated schools got the best students, suggesting that M.B.A. programs may largely play the role of pre-sorting the smartest and most ambitious for corporate recruiters.
A more significant indicator of program quality, the two economists argue, is average starting salaries measured against an objective benchmark of average student quality -- or, in the language of economics, the "residual" in first-job earnings that cannot be explained by attributes of the students before they pay their tuition.
The top seven schools by this criteria (In order: Stanford, Harvard, Chicago, Virginia, Pennsylvania, Northwestern, Michigan) is a yawn, though some might blink at the prominence of the University of Virginia, which is 13th on this year's U.S. News survey. Thereafter, however, the rankings are sure to shock. Oklahoma State, New Mexico, Wake Forest and Brigham Young occupy slots 8 through 11. And a number of other dark horses round out the top 20: Tennessee (14), Southern Methodist (15) and Oklahoma (18).
What's going on here? One possibility is that the admissions officers at well-ranked schools know something the two economists do not -- in particular, difficult-to-measure qualities of applicants that will make them especially good breadwinners.
That's largely why John Bishop of Cornell is "skeptical of this sort of the model." It is plausible, for example, that a private, high-tuition school like Southern Methodist may admit disproportionate numbers who later get good jobs by virtue of family connections.
Another possibility is that highly ranked, lesser- known business schools specialize in regional job markets, effectively isolating their graduates from competition with M.B.A.'s from equally good programs in other parts of the country. The presence on the list of Brigham Young, a Mormon university, as well as both the University of Oklahoma and Oklahoma State, in the heart of oil and gas country, may support this interpretation.
It also meshes with the Tracy-Waldfogel finding that the most important factor by far in predicting a school's "value added" in terms of starting salaries is the number of alumni who are chief executives of major employers.
Regional business schools may not have the alumni clout of, say, Harvard or Stanford. But a handful of strategically placed graduates may still create networks that yield better-than-average jobs for average M.B.A.'s. The economists note that if Harvard is eliminated from the sample of schools (because such a high proportion of corporate chief executives are Harvard grads), the presence of one extra alumnus at the helm of a Business Week 1000 corporation adds an average of $700 annually to the average salary of a newly minted M.B.A.
Of course, the most straightforward interpretation may still be the most reasonable: Some very solid business schools do not play the publicity game very well and are thus ranked below their real capacities. "We don't pretend to be Harvard," said Greg Mosier, associate dean of the business school at Oklahoma State. "But we think we do a really good job serving our market."

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
After American Dream, Waking Up Cranky

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR 

 BODY:
Headlines tell of job extinction becoming a familiar way of life in this country. Sociologists speak of the spreading pain of unmet expectations. Pundits examine the declining prospects for social mobility.
And prime-time television rushes to make movies about weepy figure skaters and children murdering their parents. O.K., that's unfair. The social and economic unease that drizzles over much of the nation does make itself felt in television entertainment but, more often than not, in the damnedest ways. 
 There's the simple escape route taken in series like ABC's "Byrds of Paradise" or CBS's "Road Home." There's the goofy yet unsettling comic twist of CBS's "Tom," in which the traditional American dream of building a family home ends up literally next to the city garbage dump. And then there are the surprisingly bitter doses of reality that can pop out of blue-collar sitcoms like ABC's "Roseanne" or NBC's "John Larroquette Show." In the topsy-turvy world of prime time, it's the sitcom that tackles the anything-but-funny phenomena of abandoned infants and the impoverished elderly.
A solution to your problems in urban America? Simple, if you're white, middle-class and adventurous. Pack up the family and move someplace else. After his wife is shot in a holdup in New Haven, Sam Byrd (Timothy Busfield), a Yale philosophy professor, moves with his three children to Hawaii where, thanks to his job as headmaster at a private school, they can all live in a beautiful home with two devoted servants. Paradise, indeed. There may be a problem or two with some of the locals who resent outsiders, but nothing to threaten the hula lessons.
In "The Road Home," Alison and Jack Matson (Karen Allen and Terence Knox) have long been spending summer vacations at her family's place on the North Carolina coast. But Dad's shrimp-boat business is in trouble and Mom shows early signs of Alzheimer's disease. There's only one thing to do. Alison and Jack, a schoolteacher, and their four children decide to stay for the rest of the summer, and no doubt longer.
Problems, yes, but life is gloriously simple again. Grandma speaks in samplerese: "To plant for seasons, plant flowers; to plant for eternity, plant children." Civilized discourse is learned at the dinner table. The children stop watching television. People have music in the soul. "The way they walk down the street," Alison observes dreamily, "it's a melody, a rhythm." The fantasy will not be terribly relevant for a teacher friend of mine who works at an inner-city grade school with children who are given little else to do in their cramped apartments but watch television. For them, inheritors of the urban future, the comfortingly safe world of this North Carolina might just as well be on another planet.
"Roseanne," of course, has long been rooted in blue-collar realities, ranging from sudden unemployment to desperate maneuvering for a bank loan. A line practically thrown away suddenly turns out to have a double edge. On Tuesday, while cooing over a possibly limitless future for sister Jackie's out-of-wedlock new baby, Roseanne purred to husband Dan (John Goodman), "Remember when we used to have hopes for our own kids?"
Dan was himself preoccupied with finding $400 to lend to his distraught mother because his dad had skipped an alimony payment. In a scene with Dad (Ned Beatty), Dan bitterly reminded him of his obligations, most of which he had managed to ignore while stumbling through his salesman's life. In an emotional crunch, "Roseanne" hangs tough. A lesbian kiss is a mere distraction.
Shifting of emotional gears is nowhere more dazzling in prime time than on "The John Larroquette Show," broadcast in double episodes on Tuesdays from 9 to 10 P.M. The setting is a St. Louis bus terminal packed with odd regulars and odder transients. John Hemingway (Mr. Larroquette), a recovering alcoholic, has taken a job as night manager in an effort to put his life in order. The show can go from stinging one-liners to suddenly touching moments, as when John ended up dancing tenderly in the empty terminal with his assistant, Mahalia (Liz Torres), who had been stood up for a date.
John constantly snipes with Dexter, the young snack-bar operator played by Daryl (Chill) Mitchell, who detects a racial slur in John's every comment. This week they managed to wind up sharing a cheap motel bed with live chickens while watching "A Streetcar Named Desire" on television. Whatever happened, Dexter wondered, to the 1960's and all those liberal promises for a better, more tolerant world? Replied John, shrugging, "Probably just got high and forgot them."
Back at the bus station, an infant was found in a nearby Dumpster, not for the first time. Police Officer Eggers (Elizabeth Berridge), who tends to equate most people with cockroaches, suddenly decided that she would keep the child "nobody wants anyway." John eventually talked her out of being rash, but not before she warned him that even if the baby's mother were found, "next time she'll throw him off an overpass." This offbeat show can veer suddenly into netherworlds like alcoholism and violence. The upshot, bursting through the wisecracks, is often chilling.
But even the seemingly easy laughs on television these days reflect a kind of uneasy resignation or weariness. In "Tom," the title character (Tom Arnold) wonders why his wife, Dorothy (Alison LaPlaca), wants to go to college: "Just takes you four years longer to get the same dead-end job." Their American dream perched next to the town dump is distressingly fragile. Most viewers will probably go along with Dorothy: "Just promise me that someday we've got to wake up."

LENGTH: 1494 words

HEADLINE: ASSASSINATION IN MEXICO;
LEADERS IN MEXICO BEGIN THEIR SEARCH FOR NEW CANDIDATE

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 24

 BODY:
Shocked by the murder of the man many assumed would be their next President, Mexicans today mourned the violent death of Luis Donaldo Colosio as the governing party began to choose a new candidate who can keep the party's long hold on power and bind the country's wounds.
Though Mexicans were left stunned and grieving by the assassination on Wednesday evening, there were signs that the contest for the future leadership of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, and very likely the country, would begin immediately, and would prove to be divisive and contentious. 
 No one emerged today as a consensus candidate, but it was clear that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari would make the choice personally, as he did in Mr. Colosio's case, after consulting with a coterie of advisers and the leaders of his party, which has 16 million members. What was unclear was how much latitude he would have.
 
Self-Proclaimed Pacifist
 In Tijuana, Government investigators said one assailant had fired both the shots that killed Mr. Colosio, and identified him as Mario Aburto Martinez, 23, a self-proclaimed pacifist who lived and worked in the northern city. No evidence has emerged connecting him with the violent Indian uprising in the south, with drug running or with any other forces for instability in Mexico.
The investigators said Mr. Aburto had confessed to the shooting and said he had bought the gun, a Brasilian-made .38-caliber Taurus, several weeks ago specifically to shoot Mr. Colosio.
The assassination seems to have clouded Mexico's image of itself as a modern, peaceful country that should be considered the equal of established democracies around the world.
"Verbal violence and ideological violence of the kind that has been written and spoken since January are the antecedents of physical violence," said Octavio Paz, the Nobel Prize writer who lives in Mexico City. "That's exactly what we saw with the death of Colosio."
Before his news conference this evening in Washington, President Clinton called President Salinas to offer his condolences and to assure him that the United States believes Mexico's economic and political institutions are "fundamentally strong."
At the news conference, Mr. Clinton said he did "not expect any long-term change" in Mexico. But he directed the Treasury Department "to try to help the Mexicans" if necessary to support the peso if its value begins to plummet in international markets, adding that Washington would make up to $6 billion available in a credit line to help Mexico weather such market jitters.
President Salinas, in selecting a successor to Mr. Colosio, is hemmed in by constitutional constraints that prevent sitting Cabinet members from running for president less than six months after leaving office. The election is scheduled for Aug. 21, less than five months away.
Before the assassination, Mr. Colosio was the front-runner, considered likely to maintain the party's 65-year-old hold on power, to preserve the policies that have led Mexico to invite foreign investment and enter a free-trade pact with the United States and Canada.
 
Stock Market Closed
 Many politicians said Mr. Colosio's successor would also be the front-runner, perhaps getting support because of sympathy and fears of instability. But they said there might also be voter interest in breaking with the past.
In any case, anxiety about investor reaction led President Salinas to close the Mexican stock exchange.
Politicians said Mr. Salinas might try to open up the selection process by proposing legislation to amend the Constitution, enabling a Cabinet member to run. Alternatively, he could have the election postponed for six weeks, which would enable Cabinet members to be considered.
 
Discounting a Rival
 In making his choice, Mr. Salinas needs to find a middle ground between old-line party regulars dismayed by his willingness to push electoral reforms that weaken the party's grip, and reformers angry that he has not pushed hard enough to eliminate fraud.
One obvious replacement, Manuel Camacho Solis, is considered to be too divisive a choice because of his bitter rivalry with Mr. Colosio.
After leaving the funeral home in which Mr. Colosio's body was held today, Mr. Camacho said, "Two days ago, I said I was not looking to be President of the Republic, and after the events that occured in this lamentable act, I repeat what I said: I do not aspire to be President."
Other possibilities include Mr. Colosio's campaign manager, Ernesto Zedillo, and the party president, Fernando Ortiz Arana.
A party official said it could be several days before the selection is made.
Mr. Colosio's body was flown to Mexico City early this morning from Tijuana, where the 44-year-old candidate was assassinated as he left a campaign stop in a poor neighborhood not far from the United States border.
 
Day of Mourning Ordered
 President Salinas, members of the Cabinet and officials of the Mexican military formed a guard of honor around the coffin as Mr. Colosio lay in state at the national headquarters of the party, known as PRI, its Spanish acronym.
Mr. Salinas called for calm, a call repeated by other Government officials, business leaders and the heads of the opposition political parties.
The Government declared a national day of mourning and ordered all banks and all money-exchanges to close for the day. They and the stock exchange are to reopen Friday.
In downtown Mexico City this morning, hundreds of supporters crowded around PRI headquarters waiting for the entourage that carried Mr. Colosio's body to the seat of the organization he once headed. The blocklong complex of buildings was still adorned with Colosio campaign banners, three and four stories high. A long line of 48 portable toilets had been installed, each bearing a black ribbon.
 
Feelings of Disbelief
 Inside the Plutarco Elias Calles Auditorium, the coffin was displayed on a stage that was almost bare except for the Mexican flag. "I never imagined this could happen in Mexico," said a 34-year-old woman as she waited to enter the hall.
Her feelings of disbelief were echoed by many.
The assassination of Mr. Colosio, the most prominent victim in Mexico since 1928, is just the latest in a string of violent incidents this year that have made modern Mexico look increasingly like the chaotic nation that struggled with both democracy and violence in the revolution that began in 1910.
On Jan. 1 armed Indian rebels in the southern state of Chiapas took over four small towns. More than 100 people died, and although the fighting has stopped, there is no peace accord.
 
Chiapas Violence Spread
 The violence in Chiapas briefly spread to Mexico City and other areas. In dozens of small towns, poor farmers and field workers have taken over municipal buildings or illegally seized land, sometimes leading to violence.
Earlier this month, one of Mexico's richest and most important business executives, Alfredo Harp Helu, was abducted as he was leaving his home in the southern part of Mexico City.
The spate of violence was a backdrop for political uncertainty that Mexicans found hard to believe.
Mr. Salinas's appointment of Mr. Camacho, a former Mayor of Mexico City, as peace negotiator in Chiapas -- after he had passed him over in favor of Mr. Colosio as the PRI's presidential candidate -- made Mr. Camacho a more recognizable and attractive political figure than Mr. Colosio.
Mr. Camacho teased Mexico for months with allusions to a possible run for President until finally, on Tuesday, he announced clearly that he would not run. Today, he repeated that declaration.
 
Uncertainty and Violence
 Pressed by demands for democracy across Mexico, and understanding that it would not only have to win in August but win credibly, PRI and Mr. Colosio agreed to successively more liberal electoral reforms. Just this week, in a special session of Congress, legislators turned the Central Electoral Institute, which oversees the presidential election, over to non-Government control.
Such changes, plus the rivalries among candidates and the extraordinary pressures brought by the uprising in Chiapas, blended to form an atmosphere of uncertainty that made Mexicans feel threatened, whatever their party or view of the future.
Around the PRI headquarters, the sidewalks were crowded with bewildered people, some crying into their cellular telephones, others looking as if they had lost their way.
Oscar Barragan Santos took the opportunity to give away campaign posters that had suddenly been tranformed into memorial placards.
"I came here at 7 this morning as a volunteer citizen to do something," said Mr. Barragan Santos, a leathery man with tattooed arms and silver-rimmed teeth. "It's bad, it's all very bad. Nobody knows what's going to happen. This is going to hurt all Mexicans because the rest of the world will think poorly of Mexico."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Allied-Lyons to Acquire Pedro Domecq Group

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:
Despite a generally stagnant global market for liquor, Allied-Lyons Inc., already a giant in the industry, agreed yesterday to pay more than $1.1 billion to acquire the Pedro Domecq Group, whose alcoholic beverages sell particularly well in Spain and Latin America.
The deal would make Allied-Lyons, which also owns Dunkin' Donuts and Baskin-Robbins ice cream, the second-largest alcoholic beverages company, after International Distillers and Vintners, a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. Guinness P.L.C. would fall to No. 3. The deal is subject to the approval of the European Union. 
 "We are extremely committed to the spirits industry and the agreement substantially strengthens our global market position," said Tony Hales, the chief executive of Allied-Lyons, which is based in London.
 
 
Partners Since 1987
 The two companies have been partners since 1987, when Allied-Lyons bought Hiram Walker & Company, which held a stake in Pedro Domecq. That deal left Allied-Lyons owning more than 30 percent of Pedro Domecq.
Allied-Lyons's brands include Ballantine's Scotch, the company's biggest seller; Canadian Club whiskey; Beefeater gin, and Courvoisier Cognac. Pedro Domecq, based in Madrid, makes Presidente, Don Pedro and Fundador brandies, as well as Sauza tequila.
"This is part of the continuing consolidation of the industry into relatively few hands, with the giants controlling distribution as well as production," said Steven Dixon, an analyst with Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder, a brokerage firm in New York.
At the heart of the deal is Domecq's strong position in Mexico and Latin America.
"In developed markets, spirits sales have been stable at best, but in emerging markets, particularly with premium brands, sales have been stronger," Mr. Dixon said. "As the economies grow, the people there who are doing well want to enjoy the same products that they see people in more developed countries consuming."
 
 
Shares of Allied-Lyons Drop
 After the deal was announced in London, shares of Allied-Lyons fell 8 percent, to 561 pence, or about $8.40, on the London Stock Exchange.
To help finance the deal, Allied-Lyons said it intended to raise 651 million, or approximately $975 million -- about 88 percent of the purchase price of 739 million -- by offering shareholders two new common shares at 490 pence each for every 13 shares held.
"This is a very good deal for Allied-Lyons," Les Pugh, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, said. He said he thought the companies' existing involvement helped Allied-Lyons strike a good deal.
Mr. Hales of Allied-Lyons told Reuters: "The logic is about finding a way to grow faster in some of the developing nations. Mexico is a growth market."
Mexico's population of 90 million is expected to grow to more than 105 million by the end of the decade, and about 60 percent of the Mexican population is younger than 30.
 
 
'Expanding Market'
 "As this age group grows to maturity we expect them to constitute an expanding market for leading local and international brands," Mr. Hale said.
Pedro Domecq currently holds 40 percent of the Mexican wine and spirits market, and in the United States sells more than one million cases a year. Its best seller in the United States is Sauza tequila, followed by Presidente and Don Pedro brandies.
The tequila sells to quite a broad market, said Michael Domecq, the president of Domecq Importers, the American subsidiary based in Greenwich, Conn. The brandies, he said, sell principally to the Hispanic market.
Allied-Lyons is not likely to change that approach, because it also produces Courvoisier, the French Cognac.
The sale to Allied-Lyons would settle a dispute among shareholding members of the Domecq family that broke out at Pedro Domecq's annual meeting last June. Several family members complained about low dividends and expressed interest in selling their shares.
Goldman, Sachs & Company was then retained to place a value on the shares, Mr. Domecq said, a process that took months and which led to discussions with Allied-Lyons that began about three months ago.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
Stocks fell on a run of bad news and assorted anxiety, ranging from the assassination of Mexico's leading presidential candidate to concern the Whitewater affair may damage the Clinton Administration, to a drop in European markets. The Dow fell 48.37 points, to 3,821.09. [Page D1.] The killing of the Mexican candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, jolted investors around the world. [D5.] 
 Yields on long-term United States Treasury bonds rose sharply as traders and investors, buffeted on all sides, sold. [D5.]
Gold and silver prices surged on buying linked to the Mexican assassination. [D14.]
The dollar fell sharply against most currencies amid heavy losses in American stock and bond markets. [D14.]
 
Companies
GE Capital, taking its $2.2 billion hostile bid directly to the shareholders of Kemper, notified the S.E.C. that it would seek four seats on Kemper's board. [D1.]
Grumman's board agreed to begin merger discussions with Northrop, which has begun a hostile $2.04 billion bid to acquire the Long Island military contractor. [D1.]
Philip Morris sued the ABC television network for libel, contending that several ABC News programs made false and reckless statements about how Philip Morris makes cigarettes. [A15.]
Allied-Lyons agreed to pay more than $1.1 billion to acquire the Pedro Domecq Group. The deal would make Allied-Lyons the No. 2 alcoholic-beverage maker in the world. [D3.]
An international group of telecommunications companies, including Loral and Qualcomm, plans a $1.8 billion satellite-based telephone network. [D3.]
I.B.M.'s chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., said the company would focus on gaining ground in the corporate market for smaller computers linked in networks. [D3.]
Microsoft and Mobile Telecommunications Technologies said they would develop a nationwide wireless network for sending and receiving data from a variety of electronic devices. [D3.]
In a sign of tension about Viacom's purchase of Blockbuster Entertainment, Blockbuster's chairman said he was not happy with the value his shareholders would receive in Viacom stock. [D4.]
Flagstar, the parent of the Denny's restaurant chain, assumed control of the franchise run by the chain's first black owner. [D4.]
The effort by United Airlines unions to gain majority control of the carrier moved an important step closer to completion. [D5.]
 
The Economy
The notion that small business is the source of new jobs, invoked by everyone from President Clinton to Senator Bob Dole to officials of the Small Business Administration, misses a major dynamic of the marketplace. Big companies have also been hiring, though with considerably less fanfare. And the big businesses that are adding workers are as varied as those cutting back. [D1.]
 
International
Mickey Kantor, the U.S. trade representative, urged Japan to be as forthcoming as possible in a plan it is about to offer to break its deadlock with Washington. Otherwise, he said, the United States would use more punitive sanctions to open Japanese markets. [D2.]
The governor of the Japanese central bank upbraided the nation's battered commercial banks, criticizing their pack mentality, inability to evaluate risks and unwillingness to innovate. [D2.]
 
Today's Columns
In the fuzzy logic of biotechnology investing, Chiron has learned, success can be a dangerous thing. Market Place. [D6.]
Ads for Gianni Versace's latest fashions in The New Yorker again raise the issue of female exploitation. Advertising. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Kantor Warns Japan on Trade Offer

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, urged today that Japan be as forthcoming as possible in a proposal that it is about to make to break the trade deadlock with Washington, because otherwise the United States would resort to more punitive sanctions to open Japanese markets.
"We have been encouraging them to come up with as bold and far-reaching a package as possible," Mr. Kantor said in an interview today. "I met with the Japanese press twice this week to convey that view. It cannot be the same old story. Otherwise, we will have disappointment here and a continuation of our approach of ratcheting up the pressure on Japan." 
 Japan's top Government spokesman, Masayoshi Takemura, who is the chief Cabinet secretary, said today that Tokyo was likely to announce by Tuesday a package of measures to satisfy American demands on opening Japanese markets in autos, auto parts, telecommunications, insurance and medical equipment.
 
 
How Low Can Concessions Go?
 In the last few weeks, a succession of Japanese "special envoys," "secret envoys," "personal envoys," "private envoys" and "self-appointed envoys" from the Foreign Ministry, Finance Ministry, Ministry of Industry and Trade and the Parliament have trooped through Washington, American officials said. The Japanese envoys have been trying to gauge what is the minimum that the Clinton Administration will accept to defuse the current trade crisis.
American officials believe that the Japanese are deeply distressed by the current high value of the yen against the dollar, which makes exports from Japan more expensive, and by the nervousness of the Tokyo stock market. The Japanese, these officials say, seem to be preparing to offer something that will be just enough to elicit a mildly positive response from Washington, which would bring down the value of the yen and ease Japanese stock market concerns, but that will not mean deep concessions.
Senior American economic officials say the Japanese believe that at the end of the day President Clinton does not have the stomach for a further confrontation on trade and that he will reach for an olive branch to get out of the current impasse.
The Japanese, these officials said, have long held the view that in negotiations with the United States, Tokyo can engage in commerce, while Washington will always engage in diplomacy. That is, the Japanese focus on economic interests, while the United States can be counted on to worry about the wider aspects of the relationship, like security ties or cooperation over Korea, and therefore will never press a trade dispute to the breaking point.
Think again, Mr. Kantor said today.
If that is Tokyo's view today, he said, the Japanese had better reconsider before they come forward with their unilateral offer.
 President Clinton, Mr. Kantor said, has made "the firm decision" that he will open Japanese markets, either through negotiations, which up to now have failed, "or on a bilateral basis using our trade laws."
If the Japanese produce something "bold," Mr. Kantor said, the Clinton Administration will be ready to resume negotiations. If they come up with something more illusory than real, the United States will resume its efforts to open Japanese markets by relying on the various trade weapons in its arsenal.
American officials said there were a number of United States-Japan trade agreements -- covering wood products, glass, computers and paper -- in which the Japanese appear to be in violation. In each of these areas, the United States market share in Japan has been going down rather than up. In each case, Japanese noncompliance could be met with punitive tariffs on Japanese exports if Japan did not take steps to remedy the situation, the American officials said.
"We could pick any one and begin to react," a senior American trade official said.
 
 
Motorola Pact Was Renegotiated
 It was such a threat that prompted Japan earlier this month to renegotiate its 1989 market-access agreement with Motorola Inc. to insure that the company would have fair access to the Tokyo-Nagoya market.
"We are trying to be measured," Mr. Kantor said, "but we cannot back down because we cannot put the relationship on a profitable basis for both countries unless they open their markets."
"We understand that it is not going to happen all at once, but we have to begin now. It is not a one-way street anymore."
After eight months of negotiations on a framework trade agreement aimed at opening markets, the United States walked away from the table last month, saying the Japanese were not serious. It was that move, and the threat of American sanctions, which prompted Tokyo to try to come up with its unilateral package.

HEADLINE: Petrolina Journal;
Brazil Waters a Desert. The Desert Is Still Smiling.

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PETROLINA, Brazil

 BODY:
Arcing 1,690 miles through the dusty heart of Brazil's sun-baked northeast, the Sao Francisco River has often been called Brazil's Nile.
For centuries its waters flowed untapped through Brazil's poorest region, a parched landscape of sun-wizened cowboys, emaciated cattle, thorn bush and cactus. 
 But today, images here are radically different.
Vineyard arbors strain under the weight of ripening grapes. At air- conditioned plants, workers pack boxes of mangoes destined for American supermarkets. At the airport gift shop, businessmen waiting for flights to Sao Paulo inspect bottles of locally produced wines.
 
Another Imperial Valley?
 Transforming the Sao Francisco Valley, public and private investment is turning the area into Latin America's fastest growing region for irrigated agriculture. Last year, vineyards and mango plantations made the region around Petrolina Brazil's largest center for growing tropical fruit for export.
"Robert McNamara came here in 1969 and said this could be the next Imperial Valley," said Fernando Bezerra Coelho, Petrolina's mayor. "Well, it's happening now." He was referring to the former president of the World Bank.
From 7,500 acres of irrigated land 15 years ago, the Petrolina region now has 225,000 acres under irrigation. Fed by pumps and hundreds of miles of canals, total irrigated area in the valley is expected to reach half a million acres next year. And that is only one quarter of potentially irrigable land.
The blooming of Brazil's desert has brought prosperity to Petrolina, a city that still displays a cactus on its municipal flag and leather cowboy chaps in its museum.
Overlooking the Sao Francisco's slow-moving, chocolate-colored waters rise new 10-story buildings, the highest for hundreds of miles around. Tripling in size in 25 years, this city of 225,000 is now the largest population center for Brazil's northeastern uplands.
Clashing with the region's stagnant, dust-bowl image, projects under way here will soon give Petrolina cellular telephone service, 90 percent sewer coverage, a convention center and a shopping center. Arriving by jet from Brasilia, visitors can see the glint of swimming pools and parabolic television antennas scattered across residential neighborhoods.
From a backwater that had no paved road to the outside world until 1970, Petrolina has become a magnet for workers from across the northeast.
The farming formula here is simple -- irrigation water, flat and inexpensive land, and 320 days of sun every year. Lying just 10 degrees south of the Equator, the valley has a rarity -- no seasons. And last year Petrolina received four inches of rain.
"We can produce whenever we want, to fill market windows," said Cesar Coutinho, president of Curaca Agricola, which annually exports millions of crates of mangoes to the United States and Europe. "So, we produce mangoes for the American market when the Mexicans can't -- from September through January."
American producers visited here recently to study the possibility of exporting grapes to the United States during off-seasons and of timing sweet onion crops to place Petrolina produce on American Thanksgiving tables.
"You can't get good grapes in the United States from November to December, and in April," said James Huston, president of Le Choix, a Detroit produce company. "I foresee a tremendous boom here for the windows, the times when you can't get good grapes, mangoes or sweet onions in the U.S."
The major obstacle to growth in the Petrolina area is the slow development of fruit strains, such as a seedless grapes, that are adaptable to Petrolina's hothouse growing conditions. Initially, this was the job of Brazil's federal agricultural research service, Embrapa, which opened a station here 20 years ago. But since 1985, Embrapa has cut its research staff in half.
Here, as elsewhere in Brazil, a virtually bankrupt federal Government has shifted in the 1990's from being a catalyst for growth to a constraint. Dealing with Brazil's 42 percent monthly inflation is child's play compared with coping with a decade of neglect.
A slowdown in hydro-electric dam construction has sent electric bills skyrocketing. Telephone lines are congested and faxes are illegible because the state telephone company has failed to invest. Poorly maintained highways force truckers to travel to coastal ports at 35 miles an hour. Lack of investment in the airport runway and in modernizing a local rail line prevents Petrolina growers from moving fruit by air or rail. In Brazil, all these sectors -- telephones, highways, railroads, airports, and electricity generation -- are state monopolies.
"We have to send someone into the office every night to send computer data to Sao Paulo," said Leandro Ferreira Neto, sales director for LaBrunier. "It's the only time we can get a clean telephone line."
Undaunted by these obstacles, Mr. Coutinho predicted that the region's tropical fruit exports will hit $200 million by the year 2000 -- four times the 1993 level. But despite the big growth in Petrolina, Brazil's fresh fruit exports are still small compared with Chile's. In 1993, Brazil exported $150 million worth of fresh fruit. Chile exported $1.5 billion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thanks to irrigation, the area around Petrolina has been turned from a sunbaked wasteland into a major center for production of fresh fruit, and has allowed thousands to harvest paychecks along with grapes. (Renato de Souza/Abril Imagens)
 
Map shows the location of Petrolina, Brazil.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Bolster Forces if U.N. Votes Korea Curbs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The Pentagon plans to strengthen American military forces in South Korea if the United Nations imposes economic sanctions against North Korea, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.
The United States has already decided to send Patriot air-defense missiles to South Korea and to proceed with joint military exercises there because of the North's refusal to allow international monitors to complete inspections of its nuclear sites. 
 But North Korea has responded with threats to attack South Korea if economic sanctions are imposed in retaliation for its stand on the nuclear sites. Today the North Korean Government warned in a radio broadcast that it would view economic sanctions as "a declaration of war against us and will strongly deal with it."
"This will of ours will turn out mightier than the U.S. nuclear weapon," the broadcast said.
 
Concern of U.S. Commanders
 The dominant view within the Clinton Administration is that North Korea is only posturing, to intimidate Washington and its Asian allies from pursuing tough sanctions in the United Nations. But the unpredictable nature of the North Korean Government in Pyongyang and the fact that it has positioned much of its army near the border with South Korea has worried American commanders.
The United States is now working on a proposal for a new Security Council resolution telling North Korea to readmit the International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors and allow them to complete their work.
But Gen. Gary E. Luck, the senior American commander in South Korea, has planned a series of possible steps to bolster American forces in the area in case the North remains firm, the Council adopts sanctions and tensions rise on the Korean peninsula. Pentagon officials are working on similar options.
"If sanctions at any level are authorized, that will cause us to reconsider increasing our defensive measures in Korea because the North Koreans have clearly stated that they clearly believe that sanctions at any level would be provocative," Mr. Perry said.
 
Degrees of Risk
 Mr. Perry said General Luck and South Korean officials were consulting on potential military steps, and he suggested that they would be calibrated to the toughness of the sanctions.
If the sanctions were modest, making the challenge to North Korea small, only a small increase might be needed in the 37,000 American forces in South Korea, Mr. Perry said.
But if the United Nations adopted tough penalties like an oil embargo, American forces would be facing a greater risk of a North Korean attack, and that would increase the need for reinforcements, he suggested.
Mr. Perry's comments come amid a debate over whether the Administration has been firm enough with North Korea and is taking sufficient steps to guard against an attack.
Some former officials, like Brent Scowcroft, who was the national security adviser to President George Bush, have said that Washington should be vigorously and visibly strengthening its military forces in the region by, for example, moving an aircraft carrier into the region or sending more Air Force warplanes there.
Mr. Scowcroft has argued that such moves would maintain the pressure on North Korea to end its nuclear program, better protect the American forces in the area and preserve the option of launching a pre-emptive attack against North Korea's nuclear sites.
But the Clinton Administration has taken a more cautious and deliberate approach, hoping that Pyongyang may yet respond to the possibility of economic sanctions and diplomatic entreaties to allow inspectors to return to North Korea and complete their work.
In testimony to Congress today, Walter B. Slocombe, the principal Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for policy, indicated that the Administration had ruled out a pre-emptive strike.
When Representative Ronald V. Dellums, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, argued that stopping North Korea's nuclear program was not worth risking renewed war on the Korean peninsula, Mr. Slocombe sought to reassure him.
 
Seeking Peaceful Solution
 "The rhetoric about war, about cities burning is not coming from the United States," Mr. Slocombe said. "We see no reason why this problem cannot be resolved in a peaceful way which is in the interests of everybody, even the North Koreans. So if there is military action, it will be as a result of decisions taken by North Korea."
Further reflecting the Administration's caution, the White House is sending Patriot missiles by ship rather than by air to avoid creating a sense of crisis and alarming allies in the region. Mr. Slocombe said the battalion would be operating in Korea by the end of April.
"We're trying to strike a balance here where we make it very clear that we'll do anything that's necessary for the defense of the South Koreans and our own forces and so on, but we still prefer to solve this diplomatically," Mr. Slocombe said.

HEADLINE: THE ASSASSINATION IN MEXICO;
Luis Colosio: A Party Man For 2 Decades

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, who rose through Mexican politics as a protege of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and became Mr. Salinas's choice to succeed him, was assassinated Wednesday in Tijuana. He was 44.
Mr. Colosio was the candidate of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, known by its Spanish acronym, PRI. After coming from a vigil at the party's Mexico City headquarters, where Mr. Colosio's body was taken yesterday, Mr. Salinas said, "Mexico has lost a great man, and I a great friend." 
 In the presidential campaign, Mr. Colosio faced challengers on the left and right, and his campaign has been complicated since January by the peasant revolt in the southern state of Chiapas, which met with widespread sympathy. It was not immediately clear who would be chosen to replace him as the party's standard bearer in the Aug. 21 election.
Mr. Colosio was born on Feb. 10, 1950, in Magdalena del Kino, a small town in the northern state of Sonora, where his father was an accountant.
 
The Demonstrations of 1968
 In 1968 Mr. Colosio, who then wore his curly hair in an Afro, was one of the thousands of students angered by the Government's suppression of demonstrators in Mexico City. He would later dismiss this episode as an affectation of youth, but in PRI's official biography, he is quoted as saying, "I belong to a generation that is marked by great changes and social movements."
He studied economics at the Technological Institute of Higher Studies in Monterrey, where he stood out for his love of Verdi and a taste for American football. He graduated in 1972 and joined PRI the same year.
Mr. Colosio went to the University of Pennsylvania on a government fellowship, earning a master's degree in regional science in 1977.
In 1979 he joined the Secretariat of Budget and Planning, under Mr. Salinas, who provided him with an entree into the party. In 1985, he was elected as a congressman from Sonora, and he was elected as a senator in 1988.
But a more important milestone may have come in 1987, when he became a member of PRI's national executive. The following year, he worked on the campaign that brought Mr. Salinas the presidency, and was then named to lead PRI, promising to clean up the electoral system.
Like Mr. Salinas, Mr. Colosio sought to balance reform with the dominance of PRI, which has held power since 1929.
 
Status Restored
 Mr. Colosio was tarred by accusations that Mr. Salinas had won only through vote fraud. But he restored much of his luster in 1991 by guiding PRI to a sweeping victory in congressional elections.
In 1992, Mr. Salinas named Mr. Colosio the Secretary of Social Development. This put him in charge of the National Solidarity Program, a vast antipoverty program aimed at alleviating the effects of the Government's market-oriented economic changes.
The new post also put Mr. Colosio in charge of environmental programs, and during last year's campaign for the North American Free Trade Agreement he helped reassure United States lawmakers that Mexico would step up enforcement of environmental laws.
Despite his close association with Mr. Salinas, Mr. Colosio had to fight for the candidacy against Manuel Camacho Solis, then Mayor of Mexico City.
In accepting the nomination, he said, "Wide-ranging social reform is Mexico's challenge for the rest of the century." Yet he appeared unsure how to respond when rebels in the south demanded just such reform. Mr. Camacho, named as Government negotiaor with the rebels, quickly stole the spotlight and was talked about as an independent candidate until Tuesday, when he said he would not run.
Mr. Colosio is survived by his wife, Diana Laura Riojas de Colosio, and two children, Luis Donaldo and Mariana.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography
