HEADLINE: Myth: Small Business as Job Engine

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
For years, small business has been portrayed as the source of virtually all new jobs, a notion furthered by the litany of layoffs in recent months by corporate giants like I.B.M., Westinghouse, Johnson & Johnson, General Motors and A.T.& T.
The notion has been invoked again and again, by everyone from President Clinton in his first State of the Union Message to Senator Bob Dole to officials of the Small Business Administration -- and echoed widely by journalists. 
 But to think that America's economic future lies largely with high-tech start-ups and other small businesses, outfits with 50 or 100 workers or fewer, is to miss a main dynamic of the marketplace. Big companies have also been hiring, though with considerably less fanfare. And the big businesses that are adding workers are as varied as those cutting back, from Chrysler and Wal-Mart to Merrill Lynch, Motorola, United Parcel Service and Pepsico. These companies have increased their total employment by anywhere from 3,000 at Merrill Lynch to 182,000 at Wal-Mart from 1992 to 1994.
 
Image, Not 'Reality'
 "People have this image of an economy in which large firms inexorably shrink and small firms valiantly struggle to replenish the stock of jobs," said Steven J. Davis, a labor economist at the University of Chicago. "But this image deviates sharply from the reality."
It is an image that took root about a decade ago, when David Birch, a business consultant and lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, contended that small businesses created 8 out of 10 new jobs. The statistic has been repeated like a mantra ever since, usually to argue for special breaks for small businesses in Washington.
Even Mr. Birch now says he regards his own statistic as neither "interesting" nor "meaningful." But, he complains, "That number won't go away."
One reason, Professor Davis says, is that small businesses hire at twice the rate, relative to their total employment, of midsized and big ones. A recent study of manufacturers by Mr. Davis and two colleagues, for example, found that companies with at least 10 workers created nearly two-thirds of all the new jobs from 1973 to 1988.
But, they also found, small businesses eliminate jobs at a far higher rate. And their job cuts are less visible since large layoffs by large companies make big headlines, while the disappearance of the corner hardware store or the local car dealership is noticed mostly by the neighbors.
In recent years, start-ups and small businesses have also been the first to add workers. They do a disproportionate share of the hiring early in an economic recovery, while big companies are often the last to lay off -- and to hire.
Besides, says James L. Medoff, a labor economist at Harvard University, Americans love small business the way they love small towns and family farmers and are more ready to believe that it plays a uniquely virtuous role. All of the storied companies -- Microsoft, Intel, Wal-Mart -- started small, and everyone looks to small business for that next big success story.
But while small business is getting most of the credit, many big businesses are indeed hiring.
Take Motorola, which has expanded its worldwide payrolls by 18,000 employees in the last two years. Over the last couple of years, it has hired hundreds of factory hands, engineers designers and marketers in Boynton Beach, Fla., to help it keep up with the explosive demand for beepers. It took on so many people that it hit the company limit of 3,000 workers in one plant -- "we like to keep things informal and cozy," a company spokesman said -- and was forced to set up a new operation, which it placed in Fort Worth.
Then there's Wal-Mart. While venerable retailing chains like Sears, Roebuck & Company and Woolworth wiped out some 80,000 jobs last year, Wal-Mart alone -- now the second- largest employer in the United States after General Motors -- created some 85,000 new jobs last year alone.
Other retailing giants like Home Depot have also helped lift total retail employment in the United States by more than 400,000 in 1993. And large chains like Toys "R" Us, Federated Department Stores and Dayton Hudson have all announced expansion plans that would add thousands of jobs -- many, to be sure, part time and without benefits like health insurance or pensions.
 
No Reports on Size
 The Department of Labor does not report how many jobs are created or lost by companies of different sizes. But anecdotal evidence suggests that big companies are also getting bigger and taking on more workers in at least half a dozen other industries, from groceries to securities, restaurants to mortgage banking and temporary help to soft drinks.
"In the service businesses generally, there has been a very definite trend that has favored the large companies," said Mitchell Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc., the nation's largest temporary help company, which also tracks hiring trends.
Economists who have studied job creation and destruction systematically have concluded that size is not an especially good predictor of job-creating prowess. As it turns out, jobs sprout in companies of all sizes: Small companies hire, but so do big and medium-sized ones, and big companies do a lot of laying off, but so do small ones.
"Size isn't the issue," said Frank Levy, an economist at M.I.T. "The issue is which firms are adding jobs."
The lesson, economists say, is that subsidizing small businesses or showering them with tax breaks is not the sure-fire way of stoking job creation that it is cracked up to be.
 
New Study Published
 Three economists -- John Haltiwanger at the University of Maryland, Scott Schuh at the Federal Reserve and Professor Davis at the University of Chicago -- recently completed a study, "Gross Job Flows in U.S. Manufacturing," which will be published by the Census Bureau. It is regarded by many other researchers as the most careful analysis of job creation and destruction to date. The study concluded that job creation was closely related to companies' share of total employment. The team used census data to track individual manufacturers during most of the 1970's and 1980's.
Although small companies are an important source of new jobs, the researchers found, these companies hardly have a monopoly on job creation. And while 80 percent of all private businesses are small, with 50 or fewer employees, three-fourths of all workers in the private sector work for larger companies.
Companies with 500 employees or more created slightly more than half of all the new jobs from 1973 to 1988. Companies with at least 10 workers created nearly two-thirds. But smaller operations, with fewer than 50 on the payroll -- the mom-and-pop and start-up operations that politicians often cite -- accounted for just one in five new jobs.
The team has yet to conduct the same analysis for the much larger universe of service-producing companies, but one study in Maryland -- providing a sample of about 45,000 companies -- also suggests that medium and large companies do a lot of hiring.
"Small businesses are leaner, and therefore an improving economy puts more pressure on the small guy to hire than on the big guys," Mr. Fromstein of Manpower said. "He hires first. But if the upswing continues, big companies will be hiring too."
 
Why It Matters
 Of course, the issue of who creates new jobs is more than academic or sentimental. Most politicians, Republicans and Democrats alike, have invoked the small-business jobs thesis at one time or another in support of preferential treatment for little businesses. Right now, tax breaks for small business cost the Treasury at least $3 billion a year while special loan guarantees eat up approximately an additional $1 billion every year.
In a speech last year to mayors, the President said "small businesses have created virtually all of the new jobs in our country in the last 10 years," a theme he also touched on in his 1993 State of the Union Message when he proposed "the boldest targeted incentives for small business in history."
Mr. Birch's initial statistic, labor economists say, was based on faulty analysis. Tapping into a proprietary data base that tracked employment at individual plants, offices and stores from year to year, Mr. Birch arrived at his number by counting up all the new jobs in each size category at the beginning and end of the decade. Then he divided the change in each size category by the total jobs created in the economy.
It was an approach that seemed to shed light on job growth. But, as other economists have since noted, statistically it has flaws.
"It's very easy to find that large firms seem to contract and small firms seem to grow, but the finding has no particular meaning," said David Card, a labor economist at Princeton University, who edits a journal on statistical methods.
 
Jobs Wiped Out, Too
 Another problem is that Mr. Birch's analysis ignored the distinction between net and gross job creation. In the dynamic American labor market, employers create new jobs at the rate of about 10 percent of total employment a year on average. But, as businesses shrink or disappear, they also wipe out lots of jobs.
"Using a net calculation conveys the image of a few sectors creating all the jobs," Professor Davis said.
During the 1970's and 1980's, he said, manufacturing companies with 50,000 employees or more created jobs at the rate of 6.3 percent a year, substantially lower than the average 9.5 percent for all manufacturing companies, but hardly zero.
Mr. Birch fell into another statistical trap. When big companies lose jobs, they generally simply shrink. But when small ones shed jobs, it is often because they go out of business. Unless the researcher corrects for the fact that small companies disappear from the sample, the results understate job creation by big business and overstate it for small business.
To this catalogue of statistical problems, perhaps the biggest is that the Small Business Administration defines small business as any company with fewer than 500 employees, which includes more than 98 percent of all companies -- and not just the corner hardware stores or local car dealers that most Americans have in mind when politicians push for special tax treatment or exemptions from government regulations.
Ultimately, many economists say, not only is the theory that small businesses create all the jobs misleading, but it does not provide a good rationale for government to come to the aid of small businesses even if it were legitimate.
"Even if it were true on average, there is nothing to say that the particular policy the Government is considering would create more jobs at the margin," Mr. Katz of the Labor Department said. "The real question is whether a particular tax preference or other policy makes sense, not whether some group of companies is the biggest job creator."

HEADLINE: THE ASSASSINATION IN MEXICO;
The Other Victim

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico, March 24

 BODY:
With the killing of Luis Donaldo Colosio, the governing party's presidential candidate, a young assassin ripped at the frayed promise of political stability that has been at the source of the party's 65 years in power.
Almost from the start of his political career, Mr. Colosio had been fashioned by his mentor, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, to represent a new Institutional Revolutionary Party, one that would keep its control over Mexico by modern means. 
 As the party leader for three years until 1992, Mr. Colosio overhauled its powerful machine. As the Government's first Secretary of Social Development until last fall, he personified its effort to contain the social tensions born of its shift from a heavily protected economy to one of free trade, limited state intervention and close partnership with the United States.
And as the party's candidate in elections scheduled for Aug. 21, the 44-year-old Mr. Colosio had struggled to maintain its pledges of better economic times and more democratic politics at a moment when things in Mexico have rarely seemed so uncertain.
 
Lights 'All Gone Out'
 "It was as though there was a light on here, with Nafta, with the election," the novelist Carlos Fuentes said in a telephone interview today, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement. "And now it's as if the lights had all gone out."
Mr. Colosio's slaying in the northern city of Tijuana, on the same border where he grew up in a small, dusty farm town, took place almost as far as it could have in Mexico from the peasant uprising that exploded with the New Year in the southern state of Chiapas.
Yet just as powerfully as the rebellion of the Zapatista National Liberation Army, the assassination suggested the limits of the new Mexico's ascension over the violent and corrupt forces that marked the old one.
What motive might have driven the 23-year-old killer, Mario Aburto Martinez, remained unclear tonight, and there were indications that he might have been deranged.
According to the police, Mr. Martinez described himself as an industrial mechanic who had gone to Tijuana from the politically troubled western state of Michoacan, and as a former funeral parlor employee who wrote books on pacifism.
 
Speculation Ranges Wide
 In casting about for someone to blame, though, Mexicans were quick to wonder about other possible forces behind the violence: the ruthless Tijuana-based drug traffickers who were blamed for the killing of a Catholic Cardinal in the Guadalajara airport last May; the sort of renegade former police agents suspected in the recent kidnapping of a wealthy financier, Alfredo Harp Helu; one of the political adversaries in this most competitive of presidential campaigns.
No matter how wild it gets, there is some twisted reason to the speculation among Mexicans about Mr. Colosio's killer. Where so many interests so deeply vested have been hurt by the Government's efforts to reorient the economy and reconfigure its base of power, there is a sense that almost anything has become possible.
"He represented the continuation of the changes that Mr. Salinas has started," a political analyst in Mexico City, Luis Rubio, said of Mr. Colosio. "And in doing that, he alienated a good chunk of the people who had traditionally held a stake in the system."
Among the handful of fortyish, American-educated technocrats from whom Mr. Salinas chose a candidate last year, Mr. Colosio had emerged as the one most likely to continue his economic and social policies while holding together a governing coalition that is increasingly strained in its embrace of rich and poor, of old party hacks and new, more independent political forces.
What Mr. Colosio was leading, as he knew well from his tenure as the party president, was less an organization of members than a political machine in which the Government brings together and manages a shifting constellation of interests.
 
Fear of Division
 Six years after a governing-party defector, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, pushed it closer than ever to losing the presidency, the coalition wore its fear of division like a thick scar. Yet its central myth -- that all the country's political forces had room beneath its roof, that it alone could keep the country from political turmoil -- had essentially survived.
Under Mr. Salinas's tutelage, Mr. Colosio sought to adapt that myth to changing times.
Even as he pledged and repledged his devotion to clean elections, greater democracy and a reorganization of the country's corrupt judicial system, he made a clear point of bringing in the old guard.
Since the revolt by mostly Mayan Indian peasants in Chiapas, Mr. Colosio had seized the banner of democratic change more forcefully, endorsing many of the political changes demanded by the insurgents. And following the announcement on Tuesday that his chief party rival, Manuel Camacho Solis, would not challenge him for the presidency, Mr. Colosio's campaign -- which never came close to trailing in the polls -- appeared as strong as it has since the year began.
With his sudden, violent death, it seemed likely that at least some Mexicans would turn again to the governing party, out of familiarity if nothing else. But in choosing a new candidate, the party also faces an enormous challenge.
 
Two Possible Candidates
 A law holding that cabinet members and state governors must step down at least six months before running for election would seem to leave only Mr. Camacho and the former Education Minister who was managing Mr. Colosio's campaign, Ernesto Zedillo, as viable choices among Mr. Salinas's top aides. But many governing-party leaders remain deeply angry with Mr. Camacho for his public flirtation with the idea of a breakaway candidacy. Mr. Zedillo, while perhaps a less contentious choice, was also criticized -- for running a weak campaign.
More immediately, the question is how the new candidate will be chosen.
Were the party to act on what Mr. Colosio described as one of his plans and call for the first primary vote, it could face a wrenching new episode. But if Mr. Salinas were to follow tradition and decide alone, he would do so in the face of a clamor for democratic change such as Mexicans have not seen in decades.
"Colosio was supposed to be the candidate who would avoid any rifts, and the rifts came," said Mr. Fuentes, who was among those calling for an open election of the new candidate. "How many more reasons do you want to finally opt for the democratic way in Mexico?"

HEADLINE: THE WHITEWATER INQUIRY: Washington Talk;
Great Lengths to Delay a Senate Vote, With Charity for None

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
In "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," Jimmy Stewart reached for the most inspiring thoughts in American history when he filibustered against corruption by reading from the Declaration of Independence: "Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Happiness -- That to secure these Rights, Governments are instituted among Men, deriving their just Powers from the Consent of the Governed. . . ."
In the real Senate early today, Republicans trying to delay an education bill were not so picky. Apparently desperate for material, they made the clerk read from President Clinton's budget message: "The fiscal year 1995 budget, which I transmit to you with this message, builds on the strong foundation of deficit reduction, economic growth and jobs. . . ." 
 Even that sounded better, though perhaps not to Republican ears, than their first effort at delay, when they directed the clerk to read the entire 231 pages of the House-Senate compromise on that education bill they disliked, beginning: "The committee of conference on the disagreeing votes of the two houses on the amendment of the House to the amendment of the Senate. . . ."
The purpose of that six-hour reading was to delay until after midnight the filing of a motion to cut off debate. Under the rules, that put off the vote on closing debate, scheduled for Friday, until Saturday. And that interfered with senators' plans to rest, meet constituents and raise campaign money.
The motive of Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, in starting the fight was his complaint that the conferees had thrown out an amendment that he had got the Senate to adopt. His amendment would have barred any Federal school aid to any state or locality that prevented "constitutionally protected school prayer in public schools by individuals on a voluntary basis."
Mr. Helms insisted that his amendment had been the clear will of the Senate but that it had been subverted in the House-Senate conference by Senator Edward M. Kennedy. "I am the one Senator Kennedy is trying to roll," Mr. Helms told the Senate. What the conferees inserted instead was a much narrower prohibition; it forbade using any money available under this bill, the so-called Goals 2000 measure, for anti-prayer policies.
The House had come to the negotiation with no language at all on prayer in its bill, although representatives had grandstanded with the House's most historically meaningless kind of vote, a motion to instruct its conferees to take the Helms language. Nobody around the Capitol today could recall when House conferees last paid any attention to instructions.
Mr. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, insisted that everyone had been told in advance that the prayer issue would be the last matter dealt with by the conference, that Mr. Helms had been shown the language that was finally chosen and did not complain -- and that, anyway, the Republicans who were negotiators (Mr. Helms was not) had made no objection.
There is another set of reasons behind the bad tempers and displays of some of the silliest rules any parliamentary body has ever developed.
Democrats are anxious to leave for this recess with some record of accomplishment, and Republicans are trying to thwart them.
In the House, Republicans threatened to tie up the institution with meaningless votes and forced the Democrats to put off their crime legislation until after Easter. In the Senate, the issue isn't settled yet, but politics is at least as much a part of the equation as prayer.
The most immediately affected prayers are not those of Mr. Helms's constituents, but of senators who are Jewish and may not be able to get home for Passover, which begins at sundown Saturday, if the Senate meets that day.
A spokesman for Senator Helms said the Passover question "did not enter his mind."
From time to time today, meetings were held trying to resolve the fuss over school prayer. But if no compromise is found and the filibuster goes on, perhaps life can imitate art and steal directly from Senator Jefferson Smith's lines in the 1939 film.
It would be particularly appropriate, after all, for a dispute that is supposed to be about prayer to use one of his closing lines from the movie filibuster when he quoted from the First Epistle of Paul the Apostle to the Corinthians, "And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity."

HEADLINE: BOSNIA SERBS LIST DEMANDS ON TALKS

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia, March 24

 BODY:
Leaders of the Bosnian Serbs said today that they would not take part in talks on an overall peace settlement in Bosnia until United Nations sanctions against federal Yugoslavia are lifted.
Members of the self-proclaimed parliament of the Bosnian Serbs today also endorsed their leaders' rejection of a new federation of Bosnian Croats and Muslims that emerged from mediation by the United States and Russia. 
 The assembly's decision was no surprise. Momcilo Krajisnik, speaker of the self-proclaimed parliament of the seized territory that the Bosnian Serbs call the Srpska Republic, called the union an unnatural creation that would tear itself apart.
"The Republic of Srpska demands that before any further negotiations the international community meets its obligations towards Serbs regarding the suspension, lifting of sanctions," a statement by the assembly of Bosnian Serbs said.
 
'Formal End to Bosnia'
 Noting that Bosnian Serbs had not been consulted in advance on the agreement between the Bosnian Croats and the Muslim-led Bosnian Government, the statement said the new federation "means a formal and legal end to the former Yugoslav republic of Bosnia-Herzegovina."
It underlined that the Bosnian Serbs' ultimate goal continued to be forming a Greater Serbia by joining the Serbian-controlled territory in Bosnia to other Serbian-held territories in the former Yugoslavia.
The Bosnian Serb assembly's decision came after Bosnian Serb forces hijacked and looted a United Nations aid convoy, forcing its Danish drivers to walk across a front line the Serbs said was mined, carrying a white flag.
A spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Zagreb said the Bosnian Serbs had forced the unarmed Danish drivers from the 10 trucks at gunpoint, and then stole their personal possessions.
 
94 Tons of Aid Hijacked
 The United Nations said the convoy was held up on Wednesday while carrying 94 tons of food and medicine to the Muslim enclave of Maglaj. Nine of the 10 trucks were still missing and drivers said some medicine was dumped in a river.
It was the most audacious yet in a series of provocations the Serbs have directed at United Nations forces since their involvement in Bosnia began, and raised once again the question of the extent of political control over the Bosnian Serb army.
Yugoslavia's Tanyug news agency said the convoy was stopped because the road was mined, and that there was no hijacking. It later quoted Radovan Karadzic, leader of the Bosnian Serbs, as saying the "insane" person responsible had been fired.
United Nations officials discounted claims that the hijacking of the convoy was the work of an individual, saying the assailants were armed and in uniform.
Meanwhile, a United Nations decision to invite Turkey to send soldiers to join the peacekeeping force in Bosnia brought sharp criticism from Bosnian Serbs, Greece and Bulgaria.
The United Nations had been reluctant to accept Turkish troops for Bosnia because of centuries of Ottoman rule in the Balkans. Mr. Karadzic said the United Nations decision was "one among several very dangerous precedents created in the Yugoslav crisis."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Black-Run Denny's Unit Taken Over

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 24

 BODY:
Nearly two years after Donald J. Bohana opened the first black-owned Denny's restaurant here, serving soul food to attract black customers, officials of the restaurant chain have seized control of the establishment.
The Flagstar Companies, Denny's parent, said in a statement that they had acquired the franchise from Mr. Bohana because he was having difficulty meeting his financial obligations as a result of "current economic conditions in Southern California." 
 The parent company, based in Spartanburg, S.C., said Mr. Bohana had agreed that the restaurant, situated in the Watts-Willowbrook area, would be "best operated as a company restaurant in order for it to remain in the community."
The success of the Watts-Willowbrook Denny's, the first full-service restaurant to open in the area since the Watts riots of 1965, is important to the Denny's chain, which is seeking to improve its reputation among blacks.
 
An Image to Live Down
 Last year, dozens of black customers filed lawsuits, charging that Denny's restaurants around the country refused to serve them or made them pay for their meals in advance.
Coleman Sullivan, a spokesman for Denny's, said the company had been operating the Watts restaurant for the last week and was continuing to serve soul-food dishes like oxtails, chitterlings, collard greens and sweet potato pie, which Mr. Bohana introduced. The restaurant also serves Denny's standard fare.
Denny's has said that the popularity of Mr. Bohana's soul-food menu helped spur the chain to use a regionalized-menu concept at its 1,504 restaurants as a way to increase generally sagging sales.
It remains unclear why Mr. Bohana failed to make the restaurant's lease and loan payments. Employees of Flagstar and of Los Angeles County, who are familiar with its balance sheet and who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the restaurant generated enough revenue to cover its bills.
 
Employees From Neighborhood
 Mr. Sullivan said that while new managers had been hired to oversee day-to-day operations at the restaurant, the 45 employees had been retained. Many of them live in the area. Denny's is seeking a new franchisee for the restaurant, preferably someone black, Mr. Sullivan said.
"From a business standpoint, it makes sense for us to be in Watts because the restaurant is in a good location where there's a lot of traffic," he continued. "But we also recognize that this was the first full-service restaurant in the area, and we bear a special responsibility to people in the community to provide them with services they otherwise would not have."
Denny's officials declined to disclose terms of the acquisition of Mr. Bohana's restaurant or to specify the nature of his financial trouble. But county officials said today that he had failed to make payments on a $735,000 county government loan he received because the restaurant was in a redevelopment zone. In addition, they said, Mr. Bohana had not been paying leasing fees at the shopping plaza where the restaurant is situated.
Mr. Bohana declined to comment and referred questions to his lawyer, Jesse Young, who did not return phone calls to his office.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
What do Arkansas lawyers say about the Rose firm? For starters, they're glad it isn't them.

BYLINE: By David Margolick 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Driving home to Minneapolis from Florida the other day, Louise Larson took a detour to inspect the Rose Law Firm, alma mater of Hillary Rodham Clinton and an unhappy epicenter of the Whitewater affair. Arriving at the firm's red brick offices, Mrs. Larson, an older woman who wore her white hair in a tight bun resembling a Q-Tip, walked up to the front door and handed her Instamatic to a newspaper photographer stalking Rose lawyers. Just then a member of the firm poked his head out of a window above.
"What are we now, a tourist attraction?" he said. "We're turning into Graceland!" 
 It was one of the few recent public utterances of any kind by a Rose lawyer.
When the firm was flying high, its members easily met the Little Rock bar's lofty standards for gregariousness and gab. At the time, Mrs. Clinton and three other Rose partners -- Vincent W. Foster Jr., Webster L. Hubbell and William H. Kennedy 3d -- were Washington-bound, and the 28 partners left behind seemed destined for influence and prosperity once inconceivable for an Arkansas law office.
Now Mr. Foster is dead, and Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Kennedy are under attack. Mr. Hubbell, the firm's former managing partner and ethics czar (and, The American Lawyer magazine had recently speculated, a future Supreme Court justice), is both unemployed, having resigned as Associate Attorney General, and accused by his former partners of padding his expense accounts. And the Rose firm itself, which claims to be the oldest law office west of the Mississippi, has had to fight off insinuations that it surreptitiously shredded documents, engaged in conflicts of interest and overbilled clients. Beyond all that, of course, it stands accused of inept public relations.
Consequently the pipeline from the partnership to the press has largely run dry -- except, that is, for leaks about Mr. Hubbell's predicament. The firm's managing partner, Ronald Clark, is also its spokesman, but he is a spokesman who rarely speaks. Other partners talk tersely and with a stiff upper lip: one, Herbert Rule 3d, told a reporter that he and his colleagues were less preoccupied by Whitewater and its fallout than by the progress of the University of Arkansas Razorbacks in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.
But if the Rose brass is not talking, other lawyers around Little Rock surely are -- although only some of them for attribution. ("It's a small town," one explained. "Let me rephrase that: It's a small state.")
Conversations with them find consensus on a number of points.
First, they are relieved that it is not the internal workings and billings of their firms that are under inspection by the press and the Whitewater special prosecutor, Robert B. Fiske Jr. -- a process from which, they feel, few lawyers could possibly emerge entirely pristine.
Second, they are shocked by the willingness of some Rose lawyers to whisper tales about Mr. Hubbell to the press. "Apparently there are a lot of people talking about what's going on, but not for identification," said Alston Jennings Sr., a Little Rock lawyer.
Third, they are puzzled by the firm's decision to go after Mr. Hubbell, a former Mayor of Little Rock who remains popular here and who is, they believe, guilty at worst of sloppy bookkeeping. Asked about motive, they suggest possibilities as venial as shell shock among people unaccustomed to scrutiny, and rudderlessness at an institution whose best and brightest left for Washington; as venal as greed; as petty as bruised feelings; as grand as a plot by powerful Republican clients to bring down Bill Clinton.
Some lawyers think that one faction at Rose, a firm that has traditionally been more a loose confederation of fiefs than a cohesive whole, remains irked at Mr. Hubbell because of his defeat in a case that he assumed for his in-laws on a contingency-fee basis, a loss that reportedly set the firm back $1 million.
"Lawyers are arrogant, and they have more than their pro rata share of arrogance over there," one lawyer said of the Rose firm. "If a lawyer does anything that embarrasses them or costs them money, they take him out of the herd and stone him to death. Margaret Mead had a few things to say about this, and I don't think things have changed in a million years."
Others speculate that the firm, out to polish its sullied image, is offering Mr. Hubbell to the public as a sacrificial lamb. Some point to residual anger at him for his role four years ago in deposing C. Joseph Giroir Jr., then the firm's managing partner and largest rainmaker. Some think a few Machiavellian Rose lawyers are deliberately messing things up, a pre lude to walking away sanctimoniously with a few clients.
These lawyers say they do not doubt that the Rose firm, which dates from Arkansas's days as a territory, will survive. But in what form, with what personnel, at what level of prosperity and with what roster of clients -- all that is another story.
Clients, they note, do not like lawyers who seem unable to keep private matters out of the public eye. "If you have a legal problem, are you going to go to a law firm where you have to run a gantlet of everyone from 'Hard Copy' to Ted Koppel to get through the door?" said one Little Rock lawyer, Jeff Rosenzweig. "Are your secrets going to be safe, or is Bob Fiske going to go over them?"
In a rare interview, Mr. Clark, the Rose firm's current managing partner, would say little about Mr. Hubbell. But he called the firm's new notoriety "somewhat amusing," said morale there was "generally very good" and predicted no financial fallout.
"We've gotten very strong support from our clients," he said. As for the firm's lawyers, he added: "If anyone chooses to leave, that's their business. I have no reason to believe that any lawyers will leave."

HEADLINE: The Law as the Free Market's Rogue: Hostage to the Prisoner's Dilemma

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
KATE: For someone who has nothing nice to say about lawyers, you certainly have enough of them around.
GARFINKLE: You have to. They're like nuclear warheads. They have theirs, so you need yours, but . . . they're only good in their silos.
-- "Other People's Money,"
 by Jerry Sterner 
 Looking for a new reason to blame lawyers for it all? Economists are at your service.
One recent study documented a strong negative link between the proportion of law graduates in a country's work force and its rate of economic growth. Another estimates that litigation between companies reduces their combined stock value, on average, by 1 percent -- real money in a world of multibillion-dollar corporations.
But as many a learned counsel would be happy to point out, there is a seeming contradiction in economists' distaste for lawyers. Modern economics is built on the rock of competition and free choice. If lawyers, who are certainly competitive, can find willing customers for their services, where do economists get off second-guessing the market?
Not to worry, lawyer-bashers. Two seasoned practitioners of the dismal science, Profs. Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton and David Bloom of Columbia, have just come up with an explanation. Competitive markets do sometimes fail to produce efficient outcomes, they note. And they believe that the market for legal services fails in a particularly perverse and fascinating way, known in the jargon of the mathematical theory of games as "the prisoner's dilemma."
Consider a pair of criminal suspects, each held incommunicado. There is no direct evidence of their guilt, and so they can be convicted only if one confesses. Hence, the prosecutor offers each a deal. If only one turns state's evidence, he goes free while the other receives a stiff sentence. If both confess, they both go to jail, although the sentences are less severe.
Were the two prisoners able to coordinate their strategies, neither would confess and neither would go to jail. But since neither can be sure what the other will do, both have incentive to act in a mutually destructive way. A confession, after all, means either freedom or a light sentence. Hanging tough while the accomplice confesses brings the worst possible outcome, what game theorists call "the sucker's payoff."
The prisoner's dilemma is old news to military strategists. It figures in every arms race and may go a long way toward explaining why cold wars become hot ones. But what does it have to do with lawyers?
 
Noncooperation Dominates
 Take Smith and Jones, who disagree about the ownership of $100,000 worth of property. They can settle the dispute very cheaply by splitting the difference or by asking a neutral party to arbitrate. Alternatively, either can hire a lawyer for $10,000 to represent him in a formal proceeding.
Jones believes that by hiring counsel while Smith does not, he can improve his chances of winning by at least enough to make his $10,000 expenditure worthwhile. Likewise for Smith. On the other hand, if both hire lawyers the value of legal representation is neutralized, and the total size of the pie to be split between the two parties is reduced to $80,000.
So one might expect that Smith and Jones would cooperate -- that is, that the incentives offered each of them by the free market would lead them to minimize the collective cost of settling their dispute. What makes the prisoner's dilemma so compelling and so frustrating is that noncooperative behavior dominates cooperative behavior in spite of the certain knowledge that the process will burn $20,000 in legal fees.
 
'Agents of the Devil'
 And it is here that Professors Ashenfelter and Bloom strike their blow against the bar, offering evidence that noncooperation pays -- that the likely payoff in hiring a lawyer does exceed the cost.
In a yet-to-be-published paper entitled "Lawyers as Agents of the Devil," the two economists looked first at public-employee wage disputes from 1981 to 1984 in New Jersey, where arbitrators, rather than splitting the difference, were required to choose one of the disputants' final offers. By the estimates of Professors Ashenfelter and Bloom, expert representation sufficiently increased the probability of winning to make it worthwhile to hire a lawyer.
They also examined the outcomes of 755 union grievance proceedings in Pennsylvania in which arbitrators decided whether employers had the right to discharge workers. Here, they assumed that the loss of a coveted union job cut an average worker's future earning power by 10 percent, and calculated that the improved chances of keeping that job by retaining a lawyer was worth at the very least $5,000 -- far more than the cost of representation. Similar results were found in a study by the Rand Corporation Institute for Civil Justice involving debt-collection, personal-injury and breach-of-contract cases resolved through arbitration in Pittsburgh.
 
But Where Does Justice Lie?
 It is possible, Professors Ashenfelter and Bloom concede, that cases in which both sides are represented by lawyers are most likely to produce equitable results. If that is true, then there is no genuine waste -- no failure of the legal market to produce an efficient result -- assuming that justice has a value exceeding the extra cost of hiring lawyers to pursue it.
But a lawyer's job in the adversarial system is to win, not to produce justice, notes Prof. Gordon Tullock, lawyer by training and economist by sensibility at the University of Arizona. Thus it is also possible that the presence of lawyers reduces the probability that a judge, a jury or an arbitrator will arrive at the just solution.
Indeed, Professor Tullock believes that the continental European legal system, in which the court itself takes the lead in ferreting out and interpreting evidence, is both cheaper and more just than the American system.
 
Gladiators and Peacemakers
 In any event, economists may not have the last word on the games that lawyers and their clients are compelled to play. Douglas Baird, director of the law-and-economics program at the University of Chicago Law School, contends that the "traditional prisoner's dilemma ends badly only because the prisoners aren't able to communicate or to hold the other to an agreement." And, he asserts, those conditions do not typically apply to legal disputes.
Profs. Ronald Gilson of Stanford Law School and Robert Mnookin of Harvard Law School press the point further in an article soon to be published in the Columbia Law Review. They argue that if parties to a dispute believed that they stood to gain collectively from cooperation, and if each was in a position to neutralize the advantage of trickery by the other, would not cooperation become the dominant strategy?
By the same token, they believe that lawyers themselves often have strong incentive to signal a willingness to cooperate. Since many clients prefer to hire lawyers who are disinclined to no-holds-barred warfare (providing the other side does the same), it would pay many lawyers to establish reputations as peacemakers. And indeed they note that the divorce bar is clearly divided between "gladiators" out for blood and "peacemakers" who seek amicable resolution.
But if the free market is inclined to reward lawyers who use low-cost strategies, why has there been an escalation in civil litigation in recent decades? One reason, Professor Mnookin argues, is that as the legal profession has grown, it has become harder for lawyers to establish a clear reputation as peacemakers among other lawyers and potential clients.
Another is that commercial law has become more complex, offering more ways for an advocate to hide his intentions and fail to honor the spirit of an interim agreement. This "noise" in the legal system is often so loud, Professor Mnookin suggests, that it is easy to misinterpret the other side's strategy. And a very noisy case may lead to the classic prisoner's dilemma, in which neither party can risk a cooperative stance lest he be tagged as the sucker.
 
'Cooperative Boutiques'
 While the two economists see lawyers as the problem, Professor Mnookin views them as the potential solution. He wants to make it easier for lawyers to establish and sustain professional reputations as reliable peacemakers -- for example, by letting them more simply withdraw from cases in which clients pressure them to act uncooperatively. And he imagines the establishment of "cooperative boutiques," laws firms that would handle only cases in which all parties signaled their interest in cooperation.
The big question here is whether lawyers as a whole have the will or the way to reduce the demand for their services. And Professor Tullock is plainly skeptical. How, he wonders, could the bar cotton to reforms that would cause "many lawyers to become vacuum cleaner salesmen?"

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Killing and Inflation Fears Spur Gold and Silver Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A precious metal rally accelerated yesterday as gold and silver prices surged on buying linked to the Mexican political assassination, fresh overseas demand and nagging inflation fears.
Indeed, silver prices jumped to their highest levels in more than four years, reflecting in part Mexico's role as a leading producer. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for May delivery, the most active futures contract, jumped 9.3 cents, to $5.745 an ounce. 
 April gold rose $4.50, to $391.90 an ounce on the Comex.
Since March 8, silver has gained about 11 percent. Gold has risen just 4 percent in the same period.
"There was some catching up to be done," said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch & Company.
He said the main factor behind gold's gain was the fatal shooting of Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, who almost surely would have been Mexico's next president. Gold is considered a safe investment in times of global political uncertainty as well as in inflationary times.
Mr. Colosio's death also contributed to a steep drop in the United States stock market yesterday. Analysts said falling stock prices increased investor demand for gold.
The gold rally began overnight in Hong Kong on buying by Middle Eastern syndicates returning to the market after the monthlong Ramadan observance, said George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. "Gold came in like an express train," he said.
Mr. O'Neill said inflation worries remained in the background despite the relatively low inflation that has characterized the American economy for the last year. "Although there's no immediate inflation, I do think the metals are expressing some future inflation fears," he said.
Mr. Milling-Stanley discounted inflation jitters as a factor in gold's advance. He said the metal was moving higher on reawakened demand from the Middle East, the Far East and India that would likely push gold's price above $400 an ounce in the second quarter, if not sooner.
The precious metals rally also extended to platinum. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, platinum for April delivery surged $4, to $408.10 an ounce.
Also at the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil prices rose in quiet trading ahead of today's OPEC meeting in Geneva, where oil ministers will discuss production quotas for the second quarter. May crude oil gained 18 cents, to $15.08 a barrel. April home heating oil rose 0.19 cent, to 45.21 cents a gallon, and April unleaded gasoline rose 0.07 cent, to 46.66 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Districts To Improve Business Proliferate

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
On the south side of West 40th Street at Eighth Avenue, a man in a white uniform and broom was busily sweeping one morning earlier this week. On the north side, a man dressed in cherry red was doing the same.
Each man worked for a different business improvement district, those increasingly ubiquitous organizations dedicated to sanitation, security, sales promotion and other tasks that property owners have decided to pay for themselves. There are now 31 such groups, called B.I.D.'s, in New York City, and as many as 15 others are being formed. 
 "B.I.D.'s have made a stunning difference in midtown," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square district, whose street cleaners wear the cherry red suits. "When districts feel clean, they feel orderly. And when they feel orderly, they feel safer."
 
New Fashion District
 The white-suit cleaners belong to the new Fashion Center Business Improvement District, which celebrated its beginning yesterday with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Donna Karan and apparel industry executives. "People had talked about it for several years," said Carvel Moore, the executive director. "The success of what was happening in Times Square, 34th Street and other B.I.D.'s was the clincher."
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Finance, calls the improvement districts an example of "reinvented government."
"They are a recognition by the city government, however inadvertently, that the city does not do what the people were already paying taxes for," he said. "The B.I.D.'s do this job very well and they also do this job very cheap."
Mr. Dyson wants eventually to rebate 50 percent of the assessments that property owners pay to be part of the districts, a program he estimates would cost $7.5 million and acknowledges the city cannot now afford. His goal is to see Manhattan, at least south of 96th Street, blanketed with improvement districts.
 
Lower Manhattan
 In another step in that direction, business people in lower Manhattan are in the final stage of filing an application to set up an improvement district downtown that would be the city's largest, with more than 100 million square feet of building space. Public hearings have been held this week, and organizers hope to have the organization up and running by year's end.
"This is something that has to happen for downtown to keep up with midtown," said Tom Cusick, the president of the Fifth Avenue Business Improvement District, who is also steering the new district through the application process.
The success of business improvement districts has inspired Douglas Elliman, the large Manhattan real estate company, to begin work on what it calls a residential improvement district. It would extend from 59th to 96th Street and from the East River to Central Park, and fall under the same sort of laws as those governing business improvement districts.
The principal goal would be to augment security, with private guards working closely with officers of the 19th Precinct, though other improvements are also contemplated. "This is reinventing our neighborhoods," said Lucius Riccio, the former Transportation Commissioner, who is a consultant on the project. "We want to create a total environment where people can feel safe."
The functions of the districts are constantly expanding. The Grand Central Partnership has sold $32 million in bonds and the 34th Street district has taken in $25 million to finance such improvements as street lights, curbs, trash cans, signs and newsstands. Mr. Malkin, the largest landlord in both districts, said property owners annually pay 11.5 cents per square foot in the Grand Central district, compared with $8 to $12 a square foot in property taxes.
In addition to the new directions, some midtown districts are expanding. The Fifth Avenue district is getting approval to absorb Madison Avenue from 53d to 61st Street. The Grand Central Partnership is adding three increments totaling 15 blocks. Business people on the Avenue of the Americas, now surrounded by improvement districts, are considering joining one or more districts.
Business improvement districts are authorized by state and local laws passed in the early 1980's. The city's first was the 14th Street-Union Square district, which began in 1984. It was the joint initiative of the heads of the Consolidated Edison Company, the Guardian Life Insurance Company and the New School.
"The streets were filthy and businesses were leaving," said Robert Walsh, executive director of the district.
The process of forming a business improvement district involves a variety of filings and procedures that take 9 to 12 months. The most important requirement is convincing the city that all property owners have at least heard of the initiative. There is no vote. To stop the formation of a district, 51 percent of property owners must make a formal filing of their objection.
The groups vary in their goals, though sanitation and security are high on almost all agendas. The Times Square district, for example, has striven to promote the idea that the area's tawdry image is changing through free shows by Broadway stars and the like. It is studying the effects of pornography on Eighth Avenue.
The Fashion Center district wants to ignite interest by buyers from department stores and other large purchasers. Enticements will range from cheap air tickets and hotel rooms to an on-line video program of available services.
The Grand Central Partnership has spent $2.7 million to illuminate its namesake terminal. It has also cut crime and removed homeless people from the terminal and surrounding streets and got them into homes and jobs.
The new Fashion Center group will work with the Bryant Park group to stage twice-yearly fashion shows in the park. "This will attract attention to this essential industry," said Mr. Malkin, who is also a founder of the fashion improvement district, in which he owns 10 showroom buildings.
Barbara Wolff, the assistant commissioner in the Department of Business Services, the city official who oversees business improvement districts, likes to tell a story to illustrate how the groups work. During a blizzard this winter, she encountered one of the Times Square sanitation workers, clad in cherry red, furiously shoveling snow. She asked why he was working so hard since the snow was still falling.
"Well, this is my job," he said. "I'm making New York City a clean place."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Claims Drop By Jobless

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 5,000 last week, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said a seasonally adjusted 340,000 people filed initial claims at state unemployment offices in the week that ended last Saturday. That was down from a revised 345,000 the previous week, which was earlier reported as 342,000. 
 Economists are expecting similar declines in the weeks ahead as spring weather permits construction crews to put in more hours and factories to step up production levels.
The Labor Department said its four-week moving average of jobless claims fell to a seasonally adjusted 337,250, a decline of 8,750 from the previous week. It was the lowest level since Jan. 8. That number is more closely tracked by economists because it smooths out the fluctuations in the weekly number.
The Labor Department said Ohio had the biggest decrease in the number of initial claims during the week ended March 12, with a decline of 4,010. California followed with a decline of 3,604. No reason was given for the Ohio decline, but the report said there were fewer claims in most industries in California.
Other states reporting large declines were New York, 3,420; Connecticut, 2,204, and Illinois, 2,181. The report cited fewer layoffs in the construction and service industries in most states that showed a decrease.

HEADLINE: All We Need Are More Manufacturing Jobs;
The Overqualified Trap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Two of the job seekers in "Low Pay and Closed Doors Greet Young in Job Market" conclude that to find more challenging jobs "they will have to go to graduate school" (front page, March 10). Unless they choose a field of study in high demand, graduate school is not a simple solution.
Indeed, a graduate degree can lessen the chance of finding a job if one does not have substantial experience beforehand. The experience trap is such that most positions that require a master's degree also require two years of experience. Entry-level positions that would enable one to gain experience require only a bachelor's degree. Thus companies are reluctant to consider applicants with advanced degrees because they are perceived as overqualified.
Times of structural shifts in the economy highlight the deficiency of a market economy in matching employees with employers. From an economic standpoint, unemployment and underemployment reduce the productive potential of the economy. From a human perspective, a spiral of rejection can lead to destruction of self-esteem.
Young people leave college with self-confidence, believing they can help change the world. At the end of the humiliating job search they wonder if they can change a light bulb.
Other than through contacts and unethical insider information, the prime way people look for jobs is through newspaper want ads. Many newspapers have yet to enter the computer age, except for a few like your Fast Track service. It is time consuming for applicants to sift through the want ads and for businesses to go through hundreds of resumes. Computerized searches using new software would greatly increase the efficiency of matching applicants with employers.
Therefore, Congress ought to speed approval of the computerized national jobs bank contained in the Clinton Administration's job retraining plan. Putting jobs on line maximizes both economic efficiency and social justice, which cannot be said of too many things.
 
GREG MURRAY
Alexandria, Va., March 13, 1994
The writer, who received a master's degree in Russian and East European studies, is looking for work.

HEADLINE: Moscow, March '94: Chaos and Hope

BYLINE: By Richard Nixon; Richard Nixon, the former President, returned a week ago from his 10th trip to Moscow in 35 years.

DATELINE: WOODCLIFF LAKE, N.J.

 BODY:
Those who suggest that because of its vast problems Russia should no longer be treated as a world power ignore an unpleasant but undeniable truth: Russia is the only nation in the world that can destroy the United States. Therefore Russia remains our highest foreign policy priority.
The Russia I saw on this trip is a very different nation from the one I visited just one year ago. Optimism about the future is being replaced by pessimism. A strongly pro-American attitude has in many cases become disturbingly anti-American. Boris Yeltsin is still a political heavyweight but he is no longer a superman. When Russia was a dictatorship as part of the Soviet Union, a good relationship with the man at the top was all that was necessary. This is no longer enough. 
 Not all the news is bad. Contrary to some reports in the Western media, the departure of some prominent reformers from the Government does not mean the abandonment of reform. Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin will continue to implement free-market reforms. Though the program would be more gradual, Government leaders say, it would also be more comprehensive and not limited to a tight monetary policy.
But Russia's political scene can only be described as chaotic. President Yeltsin has lost much of the mystique from his historic role in the destruction of Soviet Communism. He may be finding that history is against him. Over the centuries, revolutionary leaders have not been good nation builders. But it would be premature to write Mr. Yeltsin off because of his frequent absences from Moscow and his increasingly erratic conduct. The first freely elected President in Russian history, he is still the country's most popular politician -- the best guarantor of Russian democracy and stability until his term expires in 1996. The U.S. should treat him with respect and work closely with him.
But America should also pay more attention to the new generation of Russian leaders -- many of whom I met -- such as Grigory Yavlinsky, an impressive young economist; Sergei Shakhrai, the analytically minded Minister of Nationalities; and the formidable Economics Minister Aleksandr Sho khin. All in their late 30's or early 40's, they are not yet ready for top leadership, but they are without question presidential material. The 55-year-old Prime Minister is now generally acknowledged to be the front-runner to succeed Mr. Yeltsin.
All the key opposition figures -- and I met with them all, including the Communist leader, Gennadi Zyuganov; the Liberal Democratic Party chairman, Vladimir Zhirinovsky, and former Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi -- stated categorically that there can be no return to the Soviet past. And they all assured me that they would pursue their objectives through constitutional means. Mr. Zyuganov is an impressive Communist Party hard-liner, but when I asked him if the nation could ever return to Communism, he ruefully replied, "No, we cannot cross the same river twice." After 75 years of Godless communism, in Russia today God is alive and Communism is dead.
Although President Yeltsin reacted negatively to my seeing Mr. Rutskoi, on reflection he should realize that Rutskoi supporters will split the Zhirinovsky vote and reduce the threat to Mr. Yeltsin. Mr. Zhirinovsky is a ruthless, shrewd demagogue. But after examining him at length on issues ranging from his views on foreign policy to his attitude toward the U.S. and anti-Semitism, I share the view of President Leonid Kravchuk of Ukraine: he will not be elected President of Russia. He lacks the presence and conviction to lead a great nation. For Hitler, anti- Semitism was a faith; for Mr. Zhirinovsky, it is a tactic, a cynical attempt to exploit popular biases.
When I questioned him about some of his ludicrous statements -- that California would one day be part of Mexico, that Miami would be a black republic, that Paris would be an Arab city -- he referred to opinion polls about his popularity. One of his top associates (who had attended our meeting) said later that Mr. Zhirinovsky had intentionally adopted the extravagant posture of a holy fool. For centuries these "yurodiviyel" were opposition figures whose very inadequacy protected them from brutal repression. Although Russians have always had a soft spot for holy fools, they have never chosen them as their leaders -- as Mr. Zhirinovsky will soon discover when he enters the presidential sweepstakes.
The most disturbing development since the December election has been the sea change in Russian's foreign policy. The rhetoric of Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev has shifted 180 degrees. Before the election, he was too pro-American for his own good. Now he has changed his emphasis on universal human values and commonality of interests with America to a renewed Russian superpower role and the need for Moscow to chart its own course. It is without question a change of the head, not the heart. He has read the election returns and is reacting like any other politician.
Most important, the U.S. should be candid with Russia when our views do not coincide. We are great world powers and our interests will inevitably clash, but the greatest mistake we can make is to try to drown differences in champagne and vodka toasts at "feel-good" summit meetings. The highest art of diplomacy is not to paper over irresoluble differences with gobbledygook, but to find a way to disagree without damaging profoundly important strategic relationships.
In implementing the Partnership for Peace, we cannot allow Russia to determine the future of NATO. The alliance -- the main security bridge across the Atlantic -- is too important to America and to Europe to be sacrificed for the sake of Russian sensitivity. Moscow should be offered guarantees that NATO expansion to include Poland, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia will take place gradually and will not endanger Russian interests. If it does not find those guarantees adequate, we will have to agree to disagree; Russia must not be given a veto over a NATO decision to expand.
Russia has legitimate interests in the region, particularly for the protection of 25 million Russians in the former Soviet republics who suddenly became foreigners in their own land. The claim that Russia is again becoming an imperialist power is exaggerated. Despite their imperial nostalgia, most Russians and their leaders are reluctant to engage in new adventures or even accept economic responsibility for the newly independent states.
The independence of all the former Soviet states is important. The independence of Ukraine is indispensable. A Russian-Ukrainian confrontation would make Bosnia look like a Sunday-school picnic. Moscow should be made to understand that any attempt to destabilize Ukraine -- to say nothing of outright aggression -- would have devastating consequences for the Russian-American relationship. Ukrainian stability is in the strategic interest of the United States. To the extent that Kiev is prepared to proceed with economic reforms, supporting these efforts should be a national security priority for the U.S.
I found no one who had a good word for the U.S. aid program. The issue is not the amount but how it is administered. Rip-offs, shakedowns and outright corruption among recipients, along with incompetence among administrators, have combined to create enormous disillusionment. President Clinton would be well-advised to order an immediate, comprehensive review of aid to Russia and the other former Soviet states before Congress forces him to do so.
The survival and success of political and economic reform are not only in the interest of the Russian people. They are in the interest of peace, since democracies are less likely to wage war against one another. Above all, reform is in the interest of freedom. Its success would provide an example for others to follow; its failure would embolden dictators and would-be dictators throughout the world.
It is a miracle that the new Russian revolution still shows promise. The reformers may fail even with our help. They will certainly fail without it. Mr. Clinton deserves bipartisan support on providing adequate aid to the forces of freedom in Russia. But this support should be hardheaded, without illusions about Russian conduct and without the sacrifice of U.S. interests.

GRAPHIC: Drawing.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 482 words

HEADLINE: Mexico: Shaken, but Strong

 BODY:
For Mexico this has been a year of trial by fire, and it is only March. After the jolt of a January guerrilla uprising, Wednesday's assassination of the front-running presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, has profoundly shaken the confidence of what was long thought to be one of Latin America's most stable political systems. On this side of the border, investors who welcomed Mexico's emergence as an open and modernizing economy are now reassessing their bets.
But panic would be exactly the wrong response in either country. Without prettifying Mexico's still imperfect democracy, Washington should strongly reaffirm its confidence in and commitment to Mexico's underlying stability and its continuing reformist course. And Mexico should continue buttressing its economic reforms with greater democracy, a cause Mr. Colosio identified himself with. 
 The very day Mr. Colosio was murdered at a Tijuana campaign stop, Mexico's Congress was voting for constitutional changes proposed by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in an effort to make the August presidential election the most cleanly run in the country's modern history.
These changes stemmed from President Salinas' enlightened recognition that the Indian rebellion in Chiapas signaled a broader need to rebuild popular faith in a political system too often vulnerable to accusations of fraud and bossism. Mr. Salinas has also responded well to the Chiapas crisis by promoting a negotiated solution with the rebels.
One consolation for this year's troubles is the encouraging resiliency it has called forth from a political establishment once notorious for its complacency. During the last presidential election year, 1988, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, which has been in power since 1929, was so rigid and unresponsive that it became an embarrassment even to its own candidate, Mr. Salinas.
Today, largely thanks to him, the PRI is stronger and more popular, though it is still no paradigm of internal or external democracy. A reasonably open and competitive process for choosing a candidate to succeed Mr. Colosio would be a useful further advance.
Also important at this stage is to undertake a credible inquiry into the Colosio killing and to assure a verifiably free and fair election campaign and vote count. The United Nations and the Organization of American States, both experienced in supervising Latin American elections, should make themselves available to help, if so requested.
Mexico's friends share its horror and outrage at this intrusion of murder into its political life. Assassination is the polar opposite of democracy -- a man with a gun stealing choices that belong to a majority at the ballot box. The best response would be for Government and opposition parties to agree to reinforce democracy by accelerating the political reforms already under way.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Client Is Lenin

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After a meeting with the Prime Minister of Communist China, the Prime Minister of Japan had this to say:
"I told him that it is not proper to force a Western or European-type democracy onto others." 
 According to press reports, the Prime Minister of Japan, Morihiro Hosokawa, also said that the "Western" concept of human rights should not be applied to all nations.
Wrapped up in those statements is the historical falsehood, ethical duplicity, human callousness and political betrayal that the international China lobby now deploys to carry out its latest assignment from Beijing.
The job is to pressure the Clinton Administration to renege on its pledge that unless Beijing shows some respect for the human rights of Chinese and Tibetans the U.S. will end China's low tariff privileges.
What arrogance -- for a Japanese Prime Minister to talk so. Does he think we have forgotten that millions of Asians, Europeans and Americans had to die to defeat Japanese imperialism and allow democracy to be "forced" on Japan -- the system that allowed him to be elected, become Prime Minister and run about kowtowing to the Chinese Communists and insulting our intelligence?
Mr. Hosokawa is Japan's business, but his line is at the heart of the propaganda of the businessmen and politicians who make up the American branch of the China lobby.
In Washington suddenly, people who believe in human rights are being pictured as cultural and political imperialists trying to push around a bunch of dignified old Confucianists.
The truth is that nobody is dreaming of "forcing" Western democracy on Communist China; such a sinful thought. American human rights policy asks simply that Beijing permit some of the decencies to which it is already pledged as a member of the U.N. and signatory to a variety of international conventions.
For example: the right to dissent without being arrested, tortured and imprisoned for years. The right of Tibet to negotiate for at least partial freedom after a half-century of Chinese captivity.
Please, please do these things, the U.S. begs. If not at last we will have to do what Congress has demanded for years -- refuse to cooperate with Chinese despotism by continuing the low tariff rates that oil its economy.
Forget that sociodrivel about Confucianist traditions being at odds with "Western" human rights. The Chinese dissident Fang Lizhi puts it straight in The Los Angeles Times: The Communists fight human rights not because they are Confucianists but because they are Leninists. For all its increasing armed power Beijing, like all dictatorships, knows the greater power of creeping freedom.
Is there one member of the China lobby who respects himself enough to speak the truth? Listen, we are in China to make money in a cheap labor market. If U.S. human rights policy interferes with that by upsetting the Communists, to hell with it.
We get only the pious line about how a strong Chinese economy will bring more human rights -- presumably as under the economies of imperial Japan and Hitler's Germany.
Decision time for President Clinton is May or June. He is being pulled one way and another. A President gets paid to be pulled one way or another -- and remain true to his word.
Rumors float: The fix is in for Beijing, the lobby has won. Government officials of honor say no, the struggle goes on, and I believe them.
Maybe Beijing will make the concessions. Those low tariffs mean a lot to them. The dictatorship will not change much. At least the U.S. will have kept faith with the people in the torture cells.
But the American businesses in the China lobby -- they have lost already. They have shown themselves pantingly eager to use the greatest American asset -- the economic power created by free labor and capitalist strength -- to bolster a Government built on controlled labor and police strength. They certainly will not be respected in China.
At home? Certainly it has happened before -- the arming of foreign dictatorships that prostitutes American idealism, endangers American security and produces a new generation of American cynics. But that does not make it any easier for Americans who believe in political freedom to watch, excuse or forget.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
